fields.headline: Mullin picks his moment
fields.trailText: Burnley kept their faint play-off hopes alive with victory over relegated Tranmere.
fields.body:
Burnley hardly looked like promotion contenders in struggling past the limited challenge of relegated Tranmere here last night but this result kept alive their chances of sneaking into the play-offs.

Stan Ternent's team, who only 12 months ago produced a similar late burst to secure promotion from the Second Division, trailed to Steve Yates's 20th-minute goal before an own-goal from the same player and a second-half strike from John Mullin kept their improbable dream alive.

It will still take an unlikely sequence of events for Burnley to make the play-offs but a six-match unbeaten run has established them as the team most likely to capitalise on any slip-ups by Preston or Birmingham City. "We've given ourselves a chance, albeit a slim one," Ternent said.

"The other teams will be looking over their shoulders because we're on the charge."

But Burnley suffered a blow yesterday when Ternent reluctantly ended his attempt to extend Gareth Taylor's loan spell from Manchester City for a third month. The striker has done much to inspire Burnley's run but the Burnley manager was not prepared to meet City's asking price.

"I still want to sign Gareth on a permanent basis in the summer but unfortunately there was no way we could extend the loan," Ternent said. "I'm dis appointed with City but I couldn't justify giving them an exorbitant fee when we might only have him for three matches."

Burnley had fallen behind when Yates punished some slack defending to put the visitors ahead.

But the game changed when the defender helped in a shot from the former Tranmere forward Ian Moore. Mullin, hitherto anonymous as Taylor's stand-in, settled matters on the hour with a well-struck shot after good work from Glen Little.

After the substitute Andy Payton twice went close, Burnley's nerves began to show in the final stages. Tranmere had Jason Koumas sent off in the 88th minute for a second bookable offence but would have sneaked a point in stoppage time had Nik Michopoulos not pulled off a fine save to deny Scott Taylor.

fields.headline: Fulham ton up with Saha
fields.trailText: Promotion and the First Division title secured, Fulham brought up the century last night to take another step towards their season's final target - the League points record.
fields.body:
Promotion and the First Division title secured, Fulham brought up the century last night to take another step towards their season's final target - the League points record.

Having cakewalked this match thanks to two penalties from the prolific Louis Saha, who has now converted 10 out of 10, Fulham need victories in their last two games, against Wimbledon and at Grimsby, to overhaul Sunderland's tally of 105 two seasons ago.

The news is not so good for Wolves, who still need one point to be mathematically safe from relegation.

While Jean Tigana has topped off the managerial good work started by Micky Adams and Kevin Keegan, the list of under-achievers in the Molineux hot seat is depressingly long. Dave Jones knew how much expectation came with the job when he took over in January but this season now offers only a survival mini-struggle and a chance to assess his playing staff for next term.

A clear-out is likely, with Temuri Ketsbaia, on international duty last night, and Lee Naylor among those thought to be on their way. The scale of his task was evident last night even before the 23rd minute when Fulham, missing several players on international calls, converted dominance into a lead when Saha took his season's total to 31.

Saha deserved the goal because he had begun the move that led to it, dispossessing Ludo Pollet in midfield, then embarking on a run that he ended with a neat pass to Karlheinz Riedle. As the German cut inside, he was brought down by Kevin Muscat.

Fulham were soon in full cry and six minutes after the restart Pollet had to resort to upending Riedle just outside the area. Sean Davis's free-kick was heading for the top corner until Michael Oakes conjured up a fine flying save. Soon Lee Clark burst into the right of the area, only to see his shot cannon off a lucky defender.

Wolves were chasing shadows, forced on to the defensive. A second Fulham goal was inevitable and Saha again obliged after Muscat, under strong pressure, pushed Riedle.

Simon Morgan, long-serving and much loved captain during Fulham's darker days in the lower divisions, earned the night's biggest cheer when he came on as a late substitute, his first appearance after 15 months out with injury. He was, naturally, named Man of the Match. Wonderful.

 Luton were relegated to the Third Division last night after losing 1-0 at home to promotion-chasing Rotherham, whose winner was scored in the 76th minute by Chris Sedgwick. Joe Kinnear, Luton's manager, was dismissed from the dug-out for protesting that Mark Robins, the creator, was offside.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Rovers benefit from flipside of Coyne
fields.trailText: Blackburn put one foot in the Premiership when Matt Jansen's double helped ease them four points clear of Bolton in third.
fields.body:
Poor Danny Coyne. If Grimsby Town stay up this season, as they should, they will owe their goalkeeper a huge debt of gratitude - and, if Blackburn Rovers secure automatic promotion, as they should, they might be tempted to add a word of thanks of their own.

The unfortunate Coyne, comfortably the Mariners' player of the year, gifted Rovers a crucial opening goal in a match in which up to that point they had looked second best.

"For the first half-hour they were the better team," acknowledged the Rovers manager Graeme Souness. "That bit of luck got us on our way."

Thereafter it was relatively plain sailing for Souness's expensively assembled outfit, now four points clear of Bolton Wanderers in third. With only three games to play and a superior goal difference, they should not falter now.

A first-minute shot by Alan Pouton was evidence that Grimsby intended to stretch their visitors. It took a good block by Rovers' goalkeeper Brad Friedel to stop Steve Livingstone putting the home team ahead after 15 minutes and the American was called on again shortly afterwards, scrambling Tony Gallimore's free-kick unconvincingly round a post.

When Paul Groves put a clean header from a corner into his arms Friedel let his defence know what he thought of them but Grimsby, for all their verve and intent, still had not scored and gradually Blackburn were playing their way into the game.

Henning Berg shot high, Craig Hignett low and straight at Coyne but David Dunn was already turning away when his less than powerful curling effort from the edge of the area squirmed through Coyne's arms and into the net.

It was a present Blackburn barely deserved and it changed the match. Minutes later the Grimsby defence was apparently still stunned when Damien Johnson crossed from the right and Eyal Berkovic rose unmarked to head in.

With Grimsby forced to press forward in even greater numbers, Blackburn began to enjoy themselves, passing the ball around on a difficult pitch with an aplomb that bodes well for next season.

Coyne saved well from Berkovic and did even better when Mark Hughes drove in a close-range shot but the writing was on the wall and cruelly underlined on the hour when Matt Jansen outpaced the defence and slipped the ball past Coyne.

That should have been that but almost immediately Rovers dozily allowed Luke Cornwall, a pacy young striker on loan from Fulham, to poke the ball past Friedel from close range. It set up a distinctly awkward final quarter for Rovers, and it took a break from Marcus Bent and a lovely square pass to Jansen to underline the gulf in class.

"It was a harsh scoreline," said Lennie Lawrence. "Poor Danny's won us at least half a dozen points on his own this season and if the first hadn't gone in the second wouldn't have done either."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Referee: S Mathieson.

fields.headline: Record buy set for inaction
fields.standfirst: Van Nistelrooy prepares for a quiet night on the Dutch bench
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy, set to start on the bench for Holland's World Cup qualifier against Cyprus tonight, sings the praises of Sir Alex Ferguson.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy is used to being the centre of attention - and the hubbub buzzed around Britain's most expensive footballer yesterday at Holland's training camp here - but he is likely to spend this evening kicking his heels on the sidelines.

Holland play Cyprus in a World Cup qualifier at Eindhoven's Philips stadium but the £19m 24-year-old is expected to start on the bench. It is 13 months since he last represented the Dutch; he will have to make do with a possible late walk-on appearance, and then only if dominance on paper translates into early goals against the Cypriots. Even so, after his injury-wrecked year that represents progress.

"When you get injured and you know you will be out for up to a year, the time ahead looks so long," he said. "Yet sitting here it feels as if it was yesterday. I was determined this wasn't going to be the end of my career. I saw a lot of examples of people who came back from all sorts of injuries and that gave me confidence. Most players did recover."

It is exactly a year since Van Nistelrooy failed his medical in Cheadle, the legacy of a medial ligament injury sustained in a friendly against Silkeborg that month. Two days later he collapsed in pain at PSV's training ground having ruptured the cruciate ligament in the same (right) knee. "I rushed things and it cost me a year," he says.

"I just wanted to show everybody that I was fit after failing the medical, in particular the Dutch coach Frank Rijkaard. But United wanted to open my knee and that would have put me out of Euro 2000. I really wanted to play in front of the Dutch fans. Maybe I should have gone ahead with the operation; I won't make the same mistake again."

With his knee clamped in a support brace and the memory of his £18.5m transfer fading fast, he was encouraged by words of inspiration from heady sources. "Ronaldo offered me great support, which was fantastic," Van Nistelrooy recalled. The Brazilian, another former PSV player, has spent the best part of two years injured.

"As soon as he heard what happened he was on the phone to me. I also spoke with Marc Overmars. They told me what to expect with this injury and how to handle it. Mr Ferguson reminded me about Roy Keane and Lothar Matthäus, who both had injuries like this. Their determination showed me how it was possible to come back with the knee as strong as before."

Then there was Sir Alex Ferguson. "I rang to tell him about the injury and he was sympathetic. He told me not to worry. Whatever was wrong, it would be fine. He was a big help.

"A few days after it happened he came over to see me personally. It was incredible that someone who had won so much at such a big club should show me so much warmth. The feeling that the whole club gave me - not just Mr Ferguson - swung my decision. I am just delighted to be able to work with him at all, even if it is for just one year."

Van Nistelrooy remains a PSV player for now - he will complete his move to Manchester United on July 1 - and the champions will not be obliged to sign him should he suffer a relapse. But Premiership opponents are already fretting over how to nullify the considerable threat that has brought him 60 goals in two injury-free seasons.

"Everyone will see what a quality player Ruud is," said the Holland and Liverpool goalkeeper Sander Westerveld. "If you were looking for a centre-forward and you made a list of the qualities required and then took everything together, you would come up with Ruud van Nistelrooy. He is the total striker."

Despite all the plaudits, the striker is by no means certain of making an appearance tonight. "He doesn't have the match fitness yet but I picked him in my squad just to stimulate him as a player," said the Dutch coach Louis van Gaal.

Not that Van Nistelrooy needs further incentive. "I feel I am back to my best and nobody should worry about my fitness," he added. "I can be the player I was, if not a better one."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Glaxo defends £1.4bn profits
fields.standfirst:
Critics of Africa Aids policy rebuffed

Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Britain's biggest drugs company, Glaxo SmithKline, was forced on to the defensive yesterday after announcing record first-quarter profits of £1.38bn in the middle of a storm of controversy over access to medicines in developing countries.
fields.body:
Britain's biggest drugs company, Glaxo SmithKline, was forced on to the defensive yesterday after announcing record first-quarter profits of £1.38bn in the middle of a storm of controversy over access to medicines in developing countries.

Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier angrily rejected suggestions that the company should be embarrassed by its booming finances in view of the poor availabililty of its HIV-Aids treatments in Africa.

"As a chief executive, I will never be embarrassed to do well by my shareholders," he said. "People have to come to the realisation that drugs and profits are compatible. You can't get one without the other."

He said there would be no criticism of Glaxo if there were no treatments for HIV-Aids. "The Aids drugs exist because we've discovered them.

"Society wants us to develop new drugs - that's what we're here for. You can't do that without generating returns for shareholders.

"No attempt to discover drugs on a non-profit basis has ever worked.

"Look at Russia - they never discovered any new drugs."

In its first three months as a merged entity, Glaxo SmithKline's profits rose 11% at constant exchange rates, in a performance described by analysts as "solid". Sales of HIV-Aids treatments were up 12% to £298m, of which revenue outside Europe and the US increased 43% to £32m.

A spokesman for Oxfam said: "These figures show quite how profitable the pharmaceuticals industry is, and show how much margin there is for making concessions in developing markets."

Glaxo was the main mover in persuading the industry to drop a court case last week against the South African government that challenged the country's right to distribute cheap copies of HIV-Aids drugs.

"I personally intervened with Kofi Annan to get a solution," said Mr Garnier. "I'm very proud of the way Glaxo SmithKline behaved - we've clearly led the industry in a new direction." Some analysts have suggested that the climbdown could lead to battles for cheap drugs with elderly and low-income groups elsewhere in the world.

But Mr Garnier said: "If this spreads to other countries, it would pretty much kill the industry, because it couldn't recoup its research and development spending."

Glaxo's growth was driven by surging sales of antidepressant Paxil, antibiotic Augmentin and asthma treatments Flixotide and Serevent.

Mr Garnier admitted the firm was keen to licence in more late-stage products for its drugs pipeline. But he played down reports of another merger, this time with American Home Products: "Our priority is to find products and in-licence them."

Controversial flu drug Relenza - which was barred from the NHS two years ago - has proven an international flop. Mr Garnier admitted its performance was "poor" and that it was no longer a priority. Glaxo's shares slipped 25p to £17.85 yesterday.

fields.headline: Stuart David
fields.standfirst:
Borders, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
Stuart David can't be with us. Due to a legal wrangle with a set of fictional characters, he has fled the country and speaks to us only via a videotape sent from some tropical-looking location. It is in fact Tenerife.

Stuart David not being with us is the first of several bits of postmodern tomfoolery in a half-hour send-up of the conventional author event. For that is what this is billed as: David, former Belle and Sebastian bass player, "discussing" his new novel, The Peacock Manifesto. Instead, Peacock Johnson - the novel's protagonist - appears, with his lush wife, Bev, and his business partner, the hairnet-sporting, glue-sniffing Evil Bob.

They tell tales of their Stateside escapades and their vain and hilarious attempts to make a dance record out of Glen Campbell's Rhinestone Cowboy. Just to illustrate the potential of this idea they play the original, while Peacock and Bob form a human beatbox. It sounds dire, mad; shoppers on other levels of the book shop stop what they are doing and stare.

Only one paragraph is read out, and that's Bev checking the description of herself as "loony" and perennially addled by "nuclear cocktails". The idea isn't to sell the book: instead, the characters want it known that Stuart David has stolen their story and, especially, Peacock's words. They are here to start a campaign (stickers are handed round for placing on all copies of the book) to let David know publicly that he has a fight on his hands.

It's a ploy that works well to mirror the atmosphere of the new book - slight, fast and funny. It helps, of course, that the large, young audience, clad in art school chic, adore David, both from his Belle and Sebastian days and his involvement with Looper. They are only too happy to play along with the joke, not mentioning the fact that Peacock, in his chunky gold jewellery, yellow golfing trousers and tight sweater, is in fact David.

When it is time for questions from the crowd, you just know they're not going to ask earnestly what inspires him as a writer, or when he first put pen to paper. A brave boy asks: "Is it true that Stuart David smells of wee?" and the crowd erupts. Peacock Johnson, though, doesn't smile.

Instead, Peacock Johnson - the novel's protagonist - appears, with his lush wife, Bev, and his business partner, the hairnet-sporting, glue-sniffing Evil Bob. They tell tales of their Stateside escapades and their vain and hilarious attempts to make a dance record out of Glen Campbell's Rhinestone Cowboy. Just to illustrate the potential of this idea they play the original, while Peacock and Bob form a human beatbox. It sounds dire, mad; shoppers on other levels of the book shop stop what they are doing and stare. Only one paragraph is read out, and that's Bev checking the description of herself as "loony" and perennially addled by "nuclear cocktails". The idea isn't to sell the book: instead, the characters want it known that Stuart David has stolen their story and, especially, Peacock's words. They are here to start a campaign (stickers are handed round for placing on all copies of the book) to let David know publicly that he has a fight on his hands. It's a ploy that works well to mirror the atmosphere of the new book - slight, fast and funny. It helps, of course, that the large, young audience, clad in art school chic, adore David, both from his Belle and Sebastian days and his involvement with Looper. They are only too happy to play along with the joke, not mentioning the fact that Peacock, in his chunky gold jewellery, yellow golfing trousers and tight sweater, is in fact David. When it is time for questions from the crowd, you just know they're not going to ask earnestly what inspires him as a writer, or when he first put pen to paper. A brave boy asks: "Is it true that Stuart David smells of wee?" and the crowd erupts. Peacock Johnson, though, doesn't smile.

fields.headline: Terror in the Underworld
fields.standfirst:
Underworld
Lyric Hammersmith, London
****
fields.trailText:
Underworld
Lyric Hammersmith, London
****
fields.body:
Have you ever wanted to murder your sister? Or your best friend? Most women have. I have. Female relationships and friendships come under scrutiny in this latest show from Frantic Assembly.

A cross between The Yellow Wallpaper, Goldilocks and every tacky slasher movie you've ever seen, Nicola McCartney's clever script turns up the tension on a sweeping tide of female hysteria. Cool, bitchy Marcia and warm, psychic Sarah arrive to spend the weekend with their psychologist friend Georgina and her apparently disturbed sister Lydia in Georgina's newly inherited isolated farmhouse. Soon the girls are playing with a Ouija board and the lights go out.

This is probably the only theatre show, as opposed to a movie, that I've found myself watching partly through my fingers, which is a tribute to TC Howard's brilliant choreography and the body-in-the-bath staging. The evening is finely judged so that although it sends up the horror film genre, it also generates real terror.

In the end there may be less going on beneath its slick surface than you might imagine, and it's a pity McCartney's script doesn't opt for a more ambiguous ending. But where this scores is in the way it explores internal rather than external threats - the way love and hate are intimately connected and the person you love and rely on can also be dangerous for you.

At its best, this is a psychological exploration of that old horror story where the frightened girl alone in the house locks all the doors, only to discover she has locked herself in with the thing she most fears. For how can you escape your own mind?

Superbly performed by its cast of four, this is a gripping, sassy, accessible piece of theatre. Because they were refused funding Frantic had to beg the money to do this London gig. In the programme Trevor Nunn is acknowledged as one of those who dipped into his pocket to help. A sweet gesture, but it would be sweeter still if this show was at the National, where a run would bring a tide of under-30s into the building and liven up the place no end.

 Until April 28. Box office: 020-8741 2311. Then touring to Wakefield, Birmingham, Edinburgh and around Britain until June 9.

fields.headline: Can Jenny Seagrove handle a Hoover?
fields.standfirst:
The Female Odd Couple
Apollo Shaftesbury, London
**
fields.trailText:
The Female Odd Couple
Apollo Shaftesbury, London
**
fields.body:
One of the few things more tiresome than doing the Hoovering is watching people squabble over a Hoover. Unlike the Walter Matthau/Jack Lemmon film of Neil Simon's Broadway hit, Elijah Moshinsky's lacklustre production is no comedy classic: at several points over the two hours it feels like more of a chore than dusting the skirting boards.

Part of the trouble is that this tale doesn't translate well to women. The character of Felix Unger in the original Odd Couple is, if not unlikely, then at least sufficiently unlike the male stereotype (perfectly represented by his slovenly, sports-loving friend Oscar Madison) for his neurotic behaviour to appear amusingly incongruous. His counterpart in the female version, the prissy, pernickety Florence is merely an irksome caricature. Nor is there anything unfamiliar about her opposite number, Olive: she may wipe the spills from her Budweiser with her sandwich, but ultimately she complains of her biological clock ticking, just as all single 35-year-old women are supposed to do.

There are no surprises either from their assembled friends - a hard-nosed cop, a histrionic, a ditz and a woman with the tongue of a viper, although the conflict between the last two at least provides one of the evening's fiercer gags: "Did you ever think about taking speed so you can keep up with us?"

We're left with the peculiar spectacle of a play purportedly about women and their friendships, probably produced for women to see with their friends, being stolen by the too-brief appearance of two gormless men. As the Spanish brothers Manolo and Jesus, Qarie Marshall and Vincent Carmichael make a winning double act, delivering the pair's contorted proverbs with an array of engagingly silly grins. There is a lightness about their performances that Jenny Seagrove and Paula Wilcox as Olive and Florence desperately need; at the moment, their potentially sparkling lines are being rendered flat and dull.

But then, there is only so much comic value in watching two women tut and scowl as one drops her coat on the floor and the other fussily hangs it up. Good theatre tells us about ourselves, our relationships, our world, but Simon's play is more like Good Housekeeping: it tells us only that it's never too late to learn the neatest way to fold a towel.

 Booking to June 16. Box office: 020-7494 5070.

webTitle: Profits pour into pensions pot for Mayflower directors

fields.headline: Profits pour into pensions pot for Mayflower directors
fields.trailText: A new executive pay row is likely to blow up tomorrow as shareholders question why directors of the Mayflower engineering group have received huge bonuses and pension payments after the company's profits took a dive.
fields.body:
A new executive pay row is likely to blow up tomorrow as shareholders question why directors of the Mayflower engineering group have received huge bonuses and pension payments after the company's profits took a dive.

Mayflower Corporation's profits slid from £55.3m to £50.2m last year. More than three-quarters of the dip is accounted for by a £3.9m injection into the directors' pension pot. In the previous year only £433,000 had been set aside.

The company, which once hit the headlines with an audacious attempt to buy the Rolls-Royce car company and prevent it slipping into foreign hands, also failed to meet its executive bonus targets.

But the remuneration committee, headed by chairman Rupert Hambro, decided to reward the directors with a 45% share handout. He described the payouts as rewards for "excellent results achieved under difficult market conditions."

Mayflower investors have seen the share price fall from 200p to 80p.

Shareholders are also likely to question why former prime minister John Major has been so handsomely rewarded as a non-executive director.

Mr Major was paid £105,000 - some four times the normal fees for a non-executive. In return for this payment, Mr Major has only to turn up to four board meetings a year, unless the company has to call emergency meetings.

One shareholder described the payments as "disproportionately large".

Mayflower's employees have had a bad year. The company paid out £3.1m in redundancy and reorganisation costs as 5% of the staff lost their jobs.

The discretionary bonuses appear to contravene the company's remuneration policy, which states: "The remuneration package should be clearly linked to the group's performance from which shareholders will benefit. In addition it seeks to align the interest of the directors with those of the shareholders ..."

A spokeswoman for Mayflower defended Mr Major's package by detailing his role in devising the company's strategy and his position on the audit committee. She added that he had travelled extensively on behalf of the company, met existing and potential clients, and provided advice on dealing with government departments.

She said the pension award was justified because the contributions to the directors' retirement plans had fallen behind normal levels. The company had asked Bacon & Woodrow to calculate the shortfall.

Chief executive John Simpson was paid a standard contribution to his pension of £155,000 and awarded a "catch-up" contribution of £2.2m.

Joint managing director John Fleming received a regular contribution of £120,000 and a top-up of £774,000.

The discretionary bonuses are paid in shares which can be accessed in two years' time. If the directors hold them for a further 12 months, the company will double the allocation.

One City banker said: "They have got into bad habits over the past seven years, paying themselves a lot of money. In 2000 it all came unstuck. The shareholders have seen their shares go down from 200p to 80p and the directors have hit the jackpot yet again."

webTitle: Morgan Stanley admits it is shedding 1,500

fields.headline: Morgan Stanley admits it is shedding 1,500
fields.trailText: Fears of City job losses increased yesterday after Morgan Stanley admitted it was cutting 1,500 staff worldwide in response to the downturn in the world's financial markets.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York and  Jill Treanor
fields.body:
Fears of City job losses increased yesterday after Morgan Stanley admitted it was cutting 1,500 staff worldwide in response to the downturn in the world's financial markets.

The US investment bank, which employs some 5,000 people in London, told its 62,000 staff that it would shed 4% of its workforce.

By revealing the scale of its job cuts, which are expected to fall most heavily on Wall Street, Morgan Stanley contrasts with rivals which have refused to be specific about the extent to which they have reduced staff.

Neither Merrill Lynch nor Goldman Sachs would give details of their cuts, although the latter is said to have shed 650 jobs from a total workforce of 22,000, including some senior managing directors.

Other Wall Street firms to have announced layoffs recently include Charles Schwab, the online brokerage, Citigroup and Bear Stearns.

Morgan Stanley was understood to be talking yesterday to employees caught up in its largest retreat since it was formed from the merger of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, the retail broker, more than three years ago.

Most of the cuts will come from operations in New York and Silicon Valley although some 200 jobs will go in Europe and some in Asia.

Anxiety about job cuts follows a rapid recruitment drive last year. However, most investment banks are anxious to avoid the problems Merrill Lynch faced three years ago after it sacked 5% of its staff during the Asian economic crisis but later felt its business had been damaged.

Three weeks ago, Morgan Stanley denied reports that it would sack 1,000 retail brokers.

fields.headline: Is it my age?
fields.trailText: April 25: I am a recent graduate, age 31, with a first class degree and middle management experience. So why can I not get on a training scheme?
fields.body:
The problem

I am a recent graduate with a first class psychology degree, and I have applied for several graduate management schemes with various organisations. I am female and aged 31 with several years' middle management experience but, as yet, no interviews.

Is my age a problem or is it more likely something in my application form.

The solution

The typical applicant to a graduate management scheme is probably a 22 year old with little previous experience. Companies that run these schemes like to recruit fresh talent who can be trained in their own style and are unencumbered by outside influences. So, when a competent 31- year-old applies with bags of relevant experience, such companies can get a little nervous. No doubt you will have your own ideas and your own ways of doing things - not really what they want from graduate trainees. In other words, yes, it could well be that your age and experience are holding you back.

But, do not be despondent. There are companies out there who do want a more diverse pool of trainees on their graduate programmes. They will recognise your experience as the asset that it is. Having said that, I would advise you not to rely on graduate training schemes for your first graduate placement. With your background, you could be entering at a much higher level and you are perhaps underselling yourself by going for graduate-entry level.

I would aim for middle management positions and use your application form to really emphasise the relevance of various parts of your degree to your managerial skill development. The benefits of your taking time out to gain a degree might not be immediately obvious, so don't be hesitant about spelling them out.

Of course, it is always a good idea to think about how you can improve your application form. Visit your university career centre, library or bookshop to have a look at the plethora of books that can advise on producing tip-top CVs and application forms.


 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Cosmic Rough Riders
fields.body:
Recent months have seen Cosmic Rough Riders bask in an enviable reputation as rock critics have fallen over themselves to hail the band as the missing link between the Byrds and REM. The public are gradually catching up, and the Cosmics' Enjoy the Melodic Sunshine album is reportedly selling 2,000 copies a week six months after release. The rapt York audience know the words to all the songs and greet the band like heroes.

After pint-sized frontman Daniel Wylie's opening a cappella blast at an old Richard Thompson number, the band launch into Revolution in the Summertime, and their chiming Rickenbacker magnificence floods forth. But, despite their undeniably 1960s-rooted sounds, the Cosmics are not mere retro rockers. Hailing from the rough Castlemilk area of Glasgow, the hazy melodic ecstasy in their songs is tempered by a postmodern cynicism.

Live, the darker moods shadowing the album become even more vivid. Wylie explains that You've Got Me (one of several that could be the best song REM have never written) was penned for a friend who later committed suicide over "drugs and stuff". The lyrics are delivered with a poignancy pop should always aspire to but rarely reaches.

Mostly, though, this is a night of celebration. The five Cosmics don't really look like stars but are so enthusiastic that charisma radiates from them, whether it's lanky guitarist Stephen Fleming contorting his face while delivering yet another sun-soaked vocal harmony, or Wylie's Glaswegian warmth and wit. He introduces the gorgeous Melanie as "our Top 100 single. Unfortunately it only reached number 100."

The bittersweet new single, Baby You're So Free, may do better, but the Cosmics are on to something that cuts deeper than chart positions. By the closing bars of revenge fantasy The Loser, the cheers are so loud it's a wonder Wylie doesn't levitate from the building. "Goodnight," he splutters. "Pop music is not dead!" Indeed. Awesome.

 Cosmic Rough Riders play On Air East, Dundee (01382 228496) tonight, then tour.

fields.headline: Laura Ashley bounces back
fields.standfirst: Furnishings drive £10m recovery two years after near collapse
fields.trailText: Fashion and furnishings group Laura Ashley has bounced back into the black, ringing up full-year profits of more than £10m.
fields.body:
Fashion and furnishings group Laura Ashley has bounced back into the black, ringing up full-year profits of more than £10m.

Two years ago the company was close to collapse after an ill-conceived change of image and an overambitious expansion plan masterminded by US retailer Ann Iverson. The company sold off its US business for $1, was forced to launch a £25m rescue rights issue and its auditors warned there was a "fundamental uncertainty" that the business was a going concern.

But with the aid of Asian conglomerate Malayan United Industries - which underwrote the rights issue and now owns 40% of the company - the company has made a u-turn.

The £10.2m profit recorded in the year to the end of January, compared with the £4.1m loss registered a year earlier, was driven by home furnishings, where like-for-like sales rose nearly 20%. That growth has continued in the first weeks of the new financial year and finance director Jim Bellingham said the company was now planning to open one or two specialist home furnishings shops a month. It already has six, and is targeting well-off provincial towns like Nantwich in Cheshire and Sevenoaks in Kent.

The company now employs a 40-strong design team, doing commercial and domestic interior designs, and supplying everything from paint to lamp shades. At the same time, Laura Ashley's clothes are also showing double-digit growth. "We have been working closely with our customers", said Mr Bellingham. "They don't want us to be trendy, but they do want us to be up to date, and they wanted a more casual feel".

The stores have been updated and the firm is "quietly and cautiously" expanding in Europe. It already operates 63 stores in Europe and plans another six in Germany this year, bringing its total there to 23.

Mr Bellingham has also brought back mail-order - axed by Ms Iverson - and has slowed e-tailing development. The firm is licensing out the name, which now adorns goods from carpets to paint and perfume and is considering licensing the brand to kitchens and garden furniture.

The shares rose 0.75% to 23p.

fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: European telecoms groups yesterday vowed to press ahead with the rollout of third-generation mobile phone networks despite news that the Japanese launch has been delayed. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
European telecoms groups yesterday vowed to press ahead with the rollout of third-generation mobile phone networks despite news that the Japanese launch has been delayed.

This latest setback to the cash-strapped industry came as Ericsson of Sweden and Sony of Japan announced a mobile phone joint venture, to be based in Britain, with the aim of cutting losses and boosting market share.

Launch of the world's first 3G network had been scheduled for the end of May but NTT DoCoMo has delayed the start date until the beginning of October, blaming technical problems.

European operators could have benefited from the experience of a Japanese launch ahead of the rollout of their own next generation services - not least in gaining experience of the extent to which customers would be prepared to move to 3G and which services met the popularity test.

Kurt Hellström, the Ericsson chief executive, shrugged off the Japanese decision.

"It doesn't mean much in terms of sales and orders," he said in Stockholm. "It is an introduction of a new technology and it is good to test it well before it is launched."

Lauri Kivinen, chief executive at Nokia, was equally sanguine. "We don't see any change in the 3G schedule on a global scale."

Investors were more interested in the Ericsson/Sony joint venture, which saw Ericsson shares initially marked up 9%.

Sony Ericsson Mobile Communications, based in London, will develop a range of devices from October to eventually replace the companies' own-brand handsets.

Ericsson, the world's third-largest supplier of mobile phone handsets, is under pressure to bring the business back into profit. It has already announced heavy jobs cuts and is outsourcing manufacturing to a Singaporean firm, Flextronics, while retaining research and development and sales and marketing in-house.

"By combining the complementary strengths of Ericsson and Sony the new company is uniquely positioned to be a world leader in telecommunications as the industry moves rapidly towards mobile internet," Mr Hellström said.

Analysts remain concerned as to whether the combination of Ericsson and Sony will have the critical mass to make money in the face of tough conditions and Nokia's increasing dominance. Ericsson and Sony have about 11% of the global market, compared with Nokia's 32%.

Meanwhile, Deutsche Telekom reported first-quarter losses o 400m euros, compared with a 500m euros profit in the same period last year.

Heavy spending on new mobile licences and networks hit the results but performance should improve as the German mobile phone market moves closer to saturation, cutting customer acquisition costs and boosting revenues.

webTitle: Martin Gorst's top 10  books on science

fields.headline: Martin Gorst's top 10  books on science
fields.trailText: Martin Gorst is a writer and director of science documentaries and the author of Aeons: The Search for the Beginning of Time, a journey through the history of humankind's attempts to give the world a starting point. It is published by Fourth Estate
fields.body:
Martin Gorst is a writer and director of science documentaries and the author of Aeons: The Search for the Beginning of Time, a journey through the history of humankind's attempts to give the world a starting point. It is published by Fourth Estate.
Buy Aeons: The Search at Amazon.co.uk

1. The Faber Book of Science edited by John Carey
This collection contains some of the best science writing since Leonardo da Vinci first picked up a quill. From Newton's discovery that white light is made up of a rainbow of colours, to Armstrong and Aldrin's first moon walk, Carey lets the history of science unfurl in the words of the people who made it happen. I can't recommend this book strongly enough.

2. Possible Worlds by J B S Haldane (Chatto and Windlass 1927)
The British biologist J B S Haldane, who died in 1964, ranks as one of the best science writers we've ever had. A dedicated Marxist who wrote for newspapers and magazines in the 1920's and 30's, he combined clear explanation of scientific ideas with forthright political opinions and vivid personal anecdotes. This is one of the best collections of Haldane's articles but, for a taste of his work, read his essay On Being the Right Size in Carey's The Faber Book of Science.

3. The Man Who Counted by Malba Tahan
In a series of tales straight out of the Arabian Nights, Beremiz Samir, an ingenious Persian mathematician, uses his mathematical skills to solve puzzles, settle quarrels, and overcome his adversaries, thereby winning his way to fame and fortune. A mathematical fantasy, originally aimed at children of 10 years and older (but with a narrative that will captivate any adult), this book deserves to be as widely read as Harry Potter. It must be good: I lent my copy to a friend several years ago and haven't had it back.

4. Zarafa by Michael Allin
Zarafa was the first giraffe ever seen in France. This delightful book tells the story of her capture in Africa, her journey down the Nile and her marathon 550 mile walk from Marseille to Paris. The sight of this extraordinary long-necked animal so astonished the people that by the time she arrived at le Jardin des Plantes, the French centre for research into natural history, in 1827 she was feted as a celebrity. I love this book for its meticulous research and beautiful writing. It's a simple tale, but one to treasure.

5. Darwin by Adrian Desmond and James Moore
I don't think I've read a better biography. This one grips from beginning to end: the dilettante student; the adventure of the Beagle; the stress of his secret theory; the illnesses; the acclaim that greeted The Origin; it's all here, thrillingly written, wrapped in insight and peppered with so many brilliantly observed details that you feel you're walking in Darwin's shoes.

6. The Double Helix by James D Watson
On a recent visit to the Science Museum I found myself marveling at how Crick and Watson's original model of DNA - the famous double helix - was held together, Heath-Robinson style, by a handful of retort stands. Watson's own account of how he and Crick unraveled its structure in Cambridge in the 1950's - between chasing girls and surviving the college food - is one of the classics of science literature.

7. Fermat's Last Theorem by Simon Singh
In the pages of an old text book the French mathematician Pierre de Fermat left a tantalising note: "I have a truly marvelous demonstration of this proposition which this margin is too narrow to contain". His proof, however, was never found, and the proposition - Fermat's last theorem - remained unsolved for 358 years. Simon Singh's compelling account of the quest to solve the riddle is a tale of driven personalities, mathematical enigmas, and, ultimately, sheer determination.

8. On Food and Cooking: The Science and Lore of the Kitchen by Harold McGee
This is more of a reference book to dip into, rather than a book to read in one go, but it's a great volume to have handy in the kitchen to answer those puzzling questions such as why sauces thicken, how toast browns, and why some meat is white and other meat red.

9. Companion to the Cosmos by John Gribbin
This book is surely a must for amateur astronomers, or indeed anyone interested in the universe and what makes it tick. It's essentially an encylopaedia of astronomy, but Gribbin's explanations are beautifully clear, and the range of subjects covered - from aberration to ZZ-Ceti stars - is as comprehensive as most people could wish.

10. Bold Science: Seven Scientists who are Changing Our World by Ted Anton
Entertaining short biographies of some of the major players at the cutting edge of science today: gene-mapper Craig Venter; neuroscientist Susan Greenfield; planet-hunter Geoffrey Marcy; immunobiologist Polly Matzinger; cosmologist Saul Perlmutter; conservation biologist Gretchen Daily; and physicist turned evolutionist Carl Woese.

fields.headline: Grins all round from Tom Tom Club
fields.standfirst:
Tom Tom Club
Electric Ballroom, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Tom Tom Club
Electric Ballroom, London
*****
fields.body:
"God," says Tina Weymouth, by way of the warmest of welcomes, "how we've missed you." She has a point, for the Talking Heads sideline she formed with husband Chris Frantz have not played in Britain for 13 years. Much has happened since: Talking Heads are no more; Frantz and Weymouth's The Heads never gelled; most depressing of all, Tom Tom Club still struggle to rise above insipid on disc.

Live, though, Tom Tom Club can do no wrong. At the front of the stage with bassist Weymouth are cheery, Stakhanovite vocalists Mystic Bowie and Victoria Clamp. Bowie's dreadlocks are saturated by the end of the opening Suboceana; when he performs the encore, 96 Tears by ? and the Mysterians and Al Green's Take Me to the River (which Talking Heads also used to cover) he is topless, and sprays front rows and bandmates alike.

Clamp is tall and pretty but, like Bowie, she is a dervish, sprinting across stage, hitting various percussion instruments, waving to the crowd and never missing a syllable on the complex Wordy Rappinghood, which climaxes in an almighty percussive duel between Bruce Martin and Abdou M'Boup. Behind them Frantz plays in gloves but has the avuncular presence of John Goodman. No wonder everyone on stage, save sullen guitarist Robbie Aceto, smiles all the time.

The newer material - Who Feelin' It, Happiness Can't Buy Money (choreographed somewhere between Cameo and Bucks Fizz) and Lee Perry's Soul Fire - bristles with intricate rhythms and choruses to savour. The older fare - Genius of Love, The Man with the Four-Way Hips - serves to remind that Frantz and Weymouth do not always need David Byrne.

The surprising highlight of a rather surprising evening is their joyful but watertight sprint through Hot Chocolate's You Sexy Thing, a song they were covering long before The Full Monty. Bowie and Clamp chase each other around the stage, Weymouth looks on like a mother hen, Frantz growls "you sexy thing, you" whenever he feels the need and Aceto powers out the riff as if it were When the Levee Breaks. Live music does not get any better than this - really. Faultless.

fields.headline: Czech Philharmonic/ Ashkenazy
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
The Czech Philharmonic's London visit forms part of the Barbican's Bohemian Spring Season, though Czech music itself doesn't feature in their programming. Their first concert with Vladimir Ashkenazy - music director since 1998 - consisted of works by composers whose relationship to Czech culture is tangential: Mozart, who later in life found more acceptance in Prague than he did in Vienna, and Prokofiev, whose works form a response to the Soviet system that subsequently attempted to subsume Czechoslovakia into itself.

Prokofiev's Fifth Symphony, for all its popularity, is a problem piece. It was written in 1944 and the question of political relevance looms large over it. Prokofiev claimed the symphony depicted "the grandeur of the human spirit", and some have deemed it an attempt either to bypass or transcend contemporary events. In many respects, however, this ignores Prokofiev's flickering irony. "The human spirit" possessed anything but "grandeur" at the time. The symphony's tone is far from heroic, and much of its thematic material derives from rejected sections of other Prokofiev scores that depict tragic love stories - the ballet Romeo and Juliet, a soundtrack for a film of Pushkin's The Queen of Spades.

Ashkenazy probes it cautiously in a performance that is strong on ambivalence, if not so hot on sheer clout. The relentless climaxes of the first movement hover between gaudy triumph and totalitarian heaviness. The scherzo is by turns elated and grotesque, its central section lurching from bucolic whimsy to graceless screeching. It is scrupulously played, if sometimes lacking the flamboyance usually associated with the Czech Philharmonic.

Ashkenazy couples it with Mozart's D minor Piano Concerto, one of his darkest, most nerve-ridden scores. Eighteenth-century rationalism is conspicuously absent from the piece, which seethes with febrile tension and a twitchy sensibility. Ashkenazy directs it from the keyboard, locating its emotional core in the extravagant jolts of the second movement and pushing the whole towards high Romanticism.

The opening allegro is curiously reflective when it could be wilder, though there are some wonderfully louring woodwind sonorities. Ashkenazy further stresses the concerto's Romantic links by playing the cadenza that Beethoven wrote for insertion into the first movement. It doesn't quite integrate into the whole - but that is Beethoven's responsibility rather than Ashkenazy's.

fields.headline: Joshua Bell
fields.standfirst:
Wigmore Hall, London/ Radio 3
***
fields.trailText:
Wigmore Hall, London/ Radio 3
***
fields.body:
The Wigmore Hall's Centenary Festival rolls majestically onwards, spawning a series of mini-festivals along the way. This week the focus is on Beethoven - three programmes of chamber music entrusted to "Joshua Bell and Friends". There are trios and the Septet to come, but for the opening concert on Friday the violinist brought just one friend: German pianist Alexander Lonquich, for three of the violin sonatas.

Yet it wasn't the most auspicious start to a series that promised so much high-quality music-making. No performance by Bell is without something to remember - he is far too good and instinctive an artist for that. Here, though, he seemed unsettled and too often technically on edge.

The Op 23 Sonata in A minor, and Op 24, the Spring, in F made an obvious coupling for the first half. Despite their different opus numbers Beethoven conceived them as a pair, but a contrasting pair, whereas Bell and Lonquich seemed much more concerned with emphasising their similarities. That they attacked the sforzandi in the first movement of Op 23 with such zeal and brought out the rhythmic instability in its finale was fair enough, even though the piano tended sometimes to overwhelm the violin. But surely even the second subject of the opening movement of the Spring Sonata doesn't need to be delivered in such a brutal way. The poise with which Bell had floated the opening theme was totally undermined, while the twist into the minor key just before the end was rendered more important than the rest of the finale.

In Beethoven's last violin sonata, Op 96 in G major, all the elements were held in a better balance. There was rather more of the gilded phrasing that one associates with Bell, and more sensitive responses from Lonquich, too. But the technical insecurities continued, and lapses of intonation continued to mar Bell's playing. Perhaps it was just a bad day at the office for the violinist; we know he can play far better than this.

 Further concerts Tuesday and Saturday. Box office: 020-7935 2141.

fields.headline: The Beatles take on the Nazis
fields.standfirst:
Presence
Royal Court, London
***
fields.trailText:
Presence
Royal Court, London
***
fields.body:
The Beatles in Hamburg? It's the stuff of pop legend. It's also the theme of David Harrower's modest but enjoyable 90-minute play, on at the Theatre Upstairs. It deals with the cultural collision between the political innocence of the Merseyside group and the historical experience of their German employers.

Although Harrower never names the band, the play taps into Beatles myth. It is Hamburg in 1960 and we see three of the five-strong group uneasily cohabiting in a dingy basement. Paul is the most arrogant, proclaiming, "We've got nothing to learn from anyone. We are who we are." George, a jobbing electrician, is the naive one who can't quite believe his luck. And Pete is the studious drummer locked into his own private world. But the crisis comes when they learn that the club's owner is an ex-Nazi. Paul's reaction is to go on stage, shout "Sieg Heil" and storm around in jackboots. After playing to rapidly dwindling audiences, the group becomes a Hamburg hit.

Harrower reports the incident without showing it, which muffles its dramatic impact: we're never sure how much it was a two-fingered showbiz prank or the moment the Beatles discovered a complicity with young audiences who wanted to dissociate themselves from history. John Lennon's absence from the play also makes Paul seem, unexpectedly, the spirit of anarchic defiance. And Harrower's decorous group portrait is at odds with the fact that the ur-Beatles spent much of their Hamburg sojourn in a state of smashed frenzy.

But although the play is an odd mix of bio-drama and speculative fiction, it gets across one crucial point: the yawning gap between the playful naivete of touring British pop groups and the painful experience of their European hosts. For the Liverpool lads, Hitler is simply the bogeyman they were brought up to fear. But for Marian, the club's manager and the most sympathetic character, a love of pre-war American swing led to prolonged incarceration. We're also reminded that, for the Beatles and similar groups, Hamburg was a madcap trip: for Elke, the waitress for whom Paul and George compete, it is a place from which urgently to escape.

Without banging across a message, Harrower certainly makes you question the Beatles' youthful charm. And he is well served by James Kerr's production and Rae Smith's design, which highlight the penitential squalor of the group's quarters, and by strong performances from Sarah Woodward as the solemnly businesslike Marian, William Ash as the pugnacious Paul, Michael Legge as the private Pete and Ralf Little as the gawky George. But the Beatles sans Lennon inevitably suggests Hamlet without the prince.

 Until May 12. Box office: 020-7565 5000. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

We're also reminded that, for the Beatles and similar groups, Hamburg was a madcap trip: for Elke, the waitress for whom Paul and George compete, it is a place from which urgently to escape. Without banging across a message, Harrower certainly makes you question the Beatles' youthful charm. And he is well served by James Kerr's production and Rae Smith's design, which highlight the penitential squalor of the group's quarters, and by strong performances from Sarah Woodward as the solemnly businesslike Marian, William Ash as the pugnacious Paul, Michael Legge as the private Pete and Ralf Little as the gawky George. But the Beatles sans Lennon inevitably suggests Hamlet without the prince.  Until May 12. Box office: 020-7565 5000. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: Gillies double fires up St Mirren survival hopes
fields.trailText: Ricky Gillies's second goal, in injury time, secured the valuable points and left bottom club St Mirren just one point behand their rivals with four games to go.
fields.body:
Ricky Gillies's second goal, in injury time, gave St Mirren a lifeline that could keep them in the Premier League.

Earlier Steven Thompson's 54th-minute goal appeared to have all but guaranteed his club's continued existence in the elite. His powerful header of a Jime Hamiton cross was the sort of cruel blow endemic among clubs at the bottom of the heap.

But St Mirren fought back and the bottom club are now just one point behand their rivals with four games to go. They needed more than a point from this exciting occasion and they produced a finale to re-charge the batteries.

Relegation battle it might have been but neither side was choked by nerves; further, there was clear evidence of some of the players having one of their better games of the season. Live television coverage brought out the best, as did two sets of supporters, the huge United support clearly of a mind that if they were to celebrate as if survival was already assured then it would naturally come to pass.

Four points behind their second-bottom opponents and this, the fifth last game of the season, St Mirren had every reason to fret as United feathered their nest in song. But someone had clearly told them to go enjoy themselves.

Two very attacking formations gave succour to the expansive mood both on and off the pitch. United used their height at the front to good effect, St Mirren sprang quick passes from front to back.

Gillies, good for close ball cameos, found a willing foil in the pace of Stephen McPhee, on loan from Coventry City until the end of the season.

When Gary Bowman's deliciously curling corner was headed just wide in the 26th minute, suddenly the absence from the United midfield of the suspended Charlie Miller looked a telling factor.

As United's bright start began to be shaded by St Mirren's esprit de corps, the pre-match expectation that United were simply too skilled and too organised for St Mirren rang hollow. When Craig Easton mis-timed a clear shooting chance from a low, angled cross from the left, given added menace by Jim Hamilton's dummy, St Mirren deserved their break with the interval looming.

webTitle: Sunderland ready to bid for Jeffers

fields.headline: Sunderland ready to bid for Jeffers
fields.trailText: Sunderland are prepared to break their transfer record to sign Everton's England Under-21 striker Francis Jeffers for a fee of around £8m.
fields.body:
Sunderland, having seen European qualification slip away in a post-Christmas goal drought for the second successive season, are prepared to break their transfer record to sign Everton's England Under-21 striker Francis Jeffers.

The Merseyside club are willing to listen to an £8m offer for the 20-year-old, who has a year to run on his contract and has expressed a desire to leave the side he supported as a boy.

Although no contact has been made between the two clubs, the Sunderland manager Peter Reid is considering a formal bid in the knowledge that Arsenal, Manchester United and Tottenham Hotspur have already declared an interest in the striker. Any Sunderland move would dwarf their £4.5m record fee paid to Chelsea for Emerson Thome last September.

Jeffers suffered a broken ankle earlier this season and is currently recovering from a dislocated shoulder sustained in the 3-1 win over Manchester City earlier this month, but has twice rejected a new five-year contract to stay at Goodison. That deal would have doubled his wages to £20,000 a week with his salary eventually rising to £30,000 a week, the most lucrative deal Everton have ever offered one of their players.

Paul Gascoigne, who has made only two appearances for Everton as a substitute since picking up a thigh injury on November 5, made a comeback for the reserves at Sunderland last night and lasted just 22 minutes.

The 33-year-old former England midfielder was taken off after pulling up with a thigh strain on the quarter-hour and is now unlikely to return in time to help Everton in their fight against relegation this season.

Alan Mahon looks set to leave Blackburn in favour of the Scottish champions Celtic after losing patience with negotiations over his future at the promotion-chasing First Division club.

The Republic of Ireland midfielder has been on loan at Ewood Park from the Portuguese club Sporting Lisbon since December, but has been unable to tie up a permanent deal. He has been left out of Blackburn's squad for the game against Grimsby at Blundell Park tonight and is believed to have spent yesterday afternoon in talks with the Celtic manager Martin O'Neill in Glasgow.

The state of the pitch at Cardiff's Millennium stadium is causing such concern ahead of the FA Cup final that the Football Association has asked the Wembley groundsman to assess its condition. Robert McCullagh will meet the Cardiff staff today to see if the pitch needs relaying.

Heavy rain, a retractable roof that is stuck open and a welter of finals has left the pitch cut up and waterlogged in places.

Fulham's Luis Boa Morte has been called up to the Portugal squad for tomorrow's friendly against France. The uncapped striker replaces the injured Nuno Capucho.

Juventus announced yesterday that their Dutch international midfielder Edgar Davids has tested positive for the banned steroid nandrolone. The Turin club said Davids had been tested after a Serie A game against Udinese on March 4.

fields.headline: United sign Van Nistelrooy for £19m
fields.standfirst: Ferguson breaks British record as rebuilding begins, writes Daniel Taylor
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy finally completed a British record £19m transfer to Manchester United last night after turning down a late offer from Real Madrid to agree a move that will be the catalyst for a summer of unprecedented spending at Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy finally completed a British record £19m transfer to Manchester United last night after turning down a late offer from Real Madrid to agree a move that will be the catalyst for a summer of unprecedented spending at Old Trafford.

After passing a stringent medical test Van Nistelrooy has signed a five-year contract, worth around £15m, which will come into force on July 1.

In the meantime the Dutch striker will remain at PSV Eindhoven while Sir Alex Ferguson turns his attention to other summer targets. Kieron Dyer of Newcastle is his priority and the champions are also seeking a long-term challenger for Fabien Barthez. Derby's Estonian international Mart Poom is among those who have been discussed.

United had agreed an £18.5m fee with PSV last April only for the deal to flounder when Van Nistelrooy failed a medical. Only 48 hours later he snapped the cruciate ligaments in his right knee during training at the club's De Herdgang training ground.

However Van Nistelrooy has made a remarkable recovery and, after scoring four times in six games for PSV, he has been recalled to the Dutch squad for tomorrow's World Cup qualifying match against Cyprus in Eindhoven.

"There was interest from Real Madrid but I am more than happy to have finally signed for Manchester United," he said. "In spite of everything that has happened in the past year, my feelings for the club have never diminished. Even when I was convalescing they kept speaking to me and that tells me a lot about the club. It has always been a dream of mine to play for United at Old Trafford so this move has been a very easy choice."

The transfer breaks the previous British record of £18m which Leeds paid West Ham for Rio Ferdinand in November and is the clearest sign yet that Ferguson realises changes are needed if United are to win next season's European Cup in his final year in office.

"Strikers are always going to cost a lot these days but if you can get one who is not only top class but still only 24, it's even better. It means the position is covered, barring accidents, for four or five years down the line," Ferguson said. "I am delighted that we have signed Ruud. It just underlines our determination to improve our squad."

Van Nistelrooy flew into England on Saturday morning for a medical at the same private hospital in Cheadle where a weakness in his knee was detected 12 months earlier. This time there were no problems. "The deal was always going to be on as long as the lad recovered," said Ferguson yesterday.

Van Nistelrooy's arrival is likely to lead to the departure of Dwight Yorke, who has had a poor season, and will also have a bearing on Teddy Sheringham's future at the club. United will parade Van Nistelrooy at Old Trafford on Friday.

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy reaps a rich reward

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy reaps a rich reward
fields.standfirst: United's record buy has earned the red badge of courage this year
fields.trailText: If fate had dealt him a kinder hand, Ruud van Nistelrooy could have been reflecting this week on his first anniversary as the most expensive recruit in Manchester United's history. As it is, his British record £19m transfer yesterday comes at the end of his very own annus horribilis.
fields.body:
If fate had dealt him a kinder hand, Ruud van Nistelrooy could have been reflecting this week on his first anniversary as the most expensive recruit in Manchester United's history. As it is, his British record £19m transfer yesterday comes at the end of his very own annus horribilis.

It is a year ago, almost to the day, that Steve McClaren was driving Van Nistelrooy to Old Trafford for what should have been his first news conference as a United employee. Just a couple of miles from the ground, the Dutch striker took a call on his mobile telephone. "What I was told made me feel sick," he later said.

To learn that the deal had been scuppered by the results of his medical was bad enough. But a couple of days later, as Van Nistelrooy pondered his future in St Anna hospital in Geldrop, near Eindhoven, it was not so much whether he could resurrect the transfer that was weighing on his mind but whether he had any future in football at all.

In those dark hours, waiting to hear whether the operation to repair the cruciate ligaments in his right knee had been a success, he did not know whether he would be able to kick a ball in anger again. "For the deal to fall through, then to suffer such a bad injury doing something as innocuous as jumping for a header in training, it felt as though nothing more could go wrong," he says. "I just lay there thinking to myself: 'What can I possibly have done to deserve this? What have I done wrong?'."

In such an emotional state he could easily have drowned in a vat of self-pity. Instead, he set out to rehabilitate himself with utter determination. PSV appointed a personal trainer and he started making steady headway on the long road to recovery. Every three or four weeks Sir Alex Ferguson would ring to check on his progress and wish him well.

"Ruud's recovery has been nothing short of remarkable," said his agent Rodger Linse. "It is all down to hard work. He has spent hours in the swimming pool building up his strength, then hours on the training ground working on his skills and fitness, improving the condition of his knee. It has not been easy and not everyone could have done it. But Ruud is a special player and a special man."

It is only human nature to be slightly wary, but neither Ferguson nor United in particular are in the habit of making rash gambles and, if there are any lingering doubts that Van Nistelrooy's predatory instincts may have been blunted by so long out of the game, the 24-year-old has done his best to hose them away.

He has scored four times in his six comeback games and Louis van Gaal's decision to include him in the Dutch squad for tomorrow's World Cup qualifier against Cyprus, little more than a month since his return to competitive action, is testament to his powers of recovery. "Van Nistelrooy is back for one reason and one reason alone," said Van Gaal. "Because his form dictates as much."

So, what are United getting for their money? With a reputation as one of the most prolific strikers in European football, Ferguson will have a simple answer: good value.

Van Nistelrooy was the Dutch player of the year in 1999, scoring 30 goals in 34 games in his first season at PSV, and before the cruel events of last April there were at least a dozen clubs, Arsenal and Chelsea included, hoping to entice him away from the Philips stadium.

"Marco van Basten was more of an all-round striker but Van Nistelrooy is more of a decisive finisher," says Rinus Michels, Holland's coach for their European Championship triumph in 1988.

"They are both excellent players but different. Van Basten had better control, perhaps, but Van Nistelrooy is excellent at going towards goal, very speedy and very dangerous."

Tomorrow Van Nistelrooy is expected to win his 11th international cap, probably as a substitute, and then United will finalise details for a press conference at Old Trafford later in the week.

The last time they did that, of course, it ended in farce with the club issuing a hastily written statement to 100 bemused journalists while a pack of press photographers frantically snapped away at the seat Van Nistelrooy was supposed to be filling.

This time there should be no such problems and, for that, everyone associated with United will be intensely grateful.

webTitle: 'Here's £100, make a tubby male's fantasy a living reality'

fields.headline: 'Here's £100, make a tubby male's fantasy a living reality'
fields.trailText: You can pay to have your child act as team mascot but you cannot buy the same excitement for yourself. No wonder Karl Power took matters into his own hands
fields.body:
In Munich last week a rotund Manchester United fan in full kit lined up with his idols for the team photo. Karl Power was soon ushered away by security, though United's subsequent performance was so limp Sir Alex Ferguson must have wished they'd removed a legitimate member of his squad instead.

At Highbury on Saturday a 41-year-old Everton supporter, who looked like he'd had liposuction in reverse, offered to swap places with Alex Nyarko in the Blues' midfield. Whether Stephen Price would have been capable of matching the Ghanaian's athleticism is doubtful, but had Walter Smith taken him up on his offer the certainty is that the visitors' defensive walls would not have taken much organising.

That these two portly interventions occurred within a few days of each other was no coincidence. They were cries for help from the disenfranchised. Nowadays you can pay to have your child act as team mascot for the day but for some reason you cannot buy the same excitement for yourself.

If you were to phone your club and say: "I am a fan with 30 years' service and I have always wanted to lead my team out of the tunnel. Here's £100, make a tubby menopausal male's fantasy a living reality," they'd laugh in your face. What justice is there in that? Who is more in need of fulfilling a lifelong dream, a small child with his or her future still ahead, or those on a downward slope littered with shattered hopes? No wonder Karl Power took matters into his own hands in the Olympic stadium. What choice did he have?

In the past decade football has gone out of its way to alienate the paunchy, middle-aged fan. Modern players are so lean and fit their skin looks like shrink-wrap. With the honourable exceptions of such as Dean Windass and Andy Morrison, there is simply no one for the larger spectator to identify with anymore. Once upon a time men like Bobby Murdoch, Dave Mackay and Frannie Lee, all three of whom looked infinitely more likely to down a six-pack than to own one, bestrode the pitch.

Stars like Mick Quinn looked as if they had stepped straight out of the pub and on to the field. They were heroes because they allowed all of us to dream. If only I had had a bit more skill, you thought, I could have been him. Nowadays, you would have to say, if I had only had a bit more skill, followed a scientifically developed fitness regime and ate nothing but pasta and chicken until I had the fat-to-weight ratio of celery instead of a deep-fried mutton pie, then I could have been him. As a consequence, for many, the theatre of dreams has become a multiplex of self-doubt.

When Fifa banned players from swapping shirts at the end of matches during the 1998 World Cup finals many saw it as a blow to good sportsmanship. It is obvious now, however, that they were acting for the benefit of out-of-shape men.

All too aware of the effect the sight of the finely honed torsos of today's super-fit footballers would have on the confidence of male fans the world over, Sepp Blatter had simply ordered them to cover up.

Alas it seems that football administrators have done a u-turn. Next season it will cease to be a bookable offence for players to remove their shirts when celebrating a goal. More large-scale pitch invasions by large-scale men can surely be expected.

With the honourable exceptions of such as Dean Windass and Andy Morrison, there is simply no one for the larger spectator to identify with anymore. Once upon a time men like Bobby Murdoch, Dave Mackay and Frannie Lee, all three of whom looked infinitely more likely to down a six-pack than to own one, bestrode the pitch. Stars like Mick Quinn looked as if they had stepped straight out of the pub and on to the field. They were heroes because they allowed all of us to dream. If only I had had a bit more skill, you thought, I could have been him. Nowadays, you would have to say, if I had only had a bit more skill, followed a scientifically developed fitness regime and ate nothing but pasta and chicken until I had the fat-to-weight ratio of celery instead of a deep-fried mutton pie, then I could have been him. As a consequence, for many, the theatre of dreams has become a multiplex of self-doubt. When Fifa banned players from swapping shirts at the end of matches during the 1998 World Cup finals many saw it as a blow to good sportsmanship. It is obvious now, however, that they were acting for the benefit of out-of-shape men. All too aware of the effect the sight of the finely honed torsos of today's super-fit footballers would have on the confidence of male fans the world over, Sepp Blatter had simply ordered them to cover up. Alas it seems that football administrators have done a u-turn. Next season it will cease to be a bookable offence for players to remove their shirts when celebrating a goal. More large-scale pitch invasions by large-scale men can surely be expected.  You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: First space tour still up in the air

fields.headline: First space tour still up in the air
fields.trailText: Just five days before blast off, Russia has promised Dennis Tito that his eight-day visit to the International Space Station will go ahead. Nasa, however, has other ideas.
fields.body:
Just five days before blast off, Russia has promised Dennis Tito that his eight-day visit to the International Space Station will go ahead. Nasa, however, has other ideas.

The US space agency, which wants Mr Tito, 60, to sign an agreement promising not to sue if anything goes wrong and to reimburse if he breaks anything, says talks are continuing. Mr Tito has paid £13.9m for the privilege of becoming the first space tourist.

Tito, a multimillionaire California businessman and former NASA employee, was to ride a Russian Soyuz space taxi to the station. Launch was scheduled for Saturday, with arrival at the station set for April 30.

fields.trailText: April 25: Tesco is to target the UK's disabled community with a standalone version of its online shopping service.
fields.body:
Tesco is to target the UK's disabled community by launching a new standalone version of its online shopping service under a separate brand.

Lloyds TSB has partnered with Grey Interactive TV to launch its interactive TV banking service.

Sleeper, the joint interactive TV advertising venture by Blink deepend, is believed to have signed up eight leading UK commercial production companies on an exclusive basis.

Paul Simon, Independent Digital's commercial and marketing director, has left to set up his own digital consultancy.

Tower Records is relaunching its site with a new fulfilment partner E.UK.

Recruitment group Reed has confirmed it has abandoned its tempjobs.com web site and subsumed it into reed.co.uk.
