fields.headline: People power
fields.standfirst: Ken Loach was live online on Tuesday April 24. The questions - of which he sadly had time to answer only a few - ranged from his latest release, Bread and Roses, the state of the British film industry and his personal politics. This is an edited transcript of the talk
fields.trailText: Ken Loach was live online on Tuesday April 24. The questions - of which he sadly had time to answer only a few - ranged from his latest release, Bread and Roses, the state of the British film industry and his personal politics. This is an edited transcript of the talk
fields.body:
KenLoach
Hello, Ken Loach here. Thanks for all your questions - I'll try and come up with some sensible answers.

ASA1
Ken, where did you find Elipidia Carillos? And will we be seeing more of her?

KenLoach
I met Elpidia in LA when we were auditioning a lot of people for Bread & Roses. She's been in several well received films like Salvador and was really brilliant to work with.

FilmFan
What do you think of the current state of the British film industry? What goes through your head every time a film like The Full Monty becomes a huge success?

KenLoach
The current state of the British film industry is much like its past state, and as long as we're a colony of the US as regards cinema, we will remain so. The problem is not shortage of talent, it's shortage of screens. We need to gain control of the screens and the way they're programmed so that a wide variety of films can be shown. Then film-makers here can start to have real relationship with the audience.

SpankTM
Your films have been cursed with spotty British distribution over the years (though things seem to have got better since you hooked up with FilmFour). What do you think could be done to give non-Hollywood movies a fighting chance out there?

KenLoach
The problem is usually not the distribution but the exhibition because you can have a good distributor who works hard, but if the screens are already out of reach you can't do anything. As I said, you need to find a new kind of system of ownership. Screens need to be programmed by people who care about and enjoy a wide variety of films... This is where the Labour government have failed completely - they won't tackle cinema ownership, being basically free marketeers. So however much they wring their hands over the state of the British film industry, nothing will change substantially until they tackle the question of cinema ownership.

KingBoyD
Hi Ken. Land And Freedom seems to suggest that Stalin exploited the Communist Party in Spain in order to provoke division and mistrust among the various assemblies of freedom-fighters. History not being my forte, I'm interested to know what convinced you of this.

KenLoach
Yes, this is a good but complicated question! The politics of Stalinism in relation to the Spanish civil war are I think acknowledged. He was determined to prevent a workers' state arising in Spain because he felt that if he was seen to encourage that, the Soviet Union would itself be threatened from attacks by the West. He therefore undermined the struggles by those Republicans who were establishing collectives on the land and workers' control in the factories. Volunteers like George Orwell who fought with a Marxist group were chased out of Spain. This was at the same time as the Moscow Show Trials were eliminating the old Bolsheviks who had made the revolution. Sorry, this is a big subject and we could go on a long time, but a very important one, because it shows that when the chips were down, the communists - ie Stalinists - and Social Democrats supported a bourgeois republic but would not support a workers' republic.

FayJay
Rather a Blue Peter-ish couple of questions, I'm afraid, but: Who do you think are the most exciting new directors? (For the matter, do you go & see lots of other people's films yourself or not?) Also, do you have a particular favourite amongst your own films, or do you always simply focus on the next project?

Mcgowan2
Dear Ken, which football team? Coventry or Manchester City? I know it's not MFC but I have a sneaky feeling it could be Man Utd. Also, what do you think of the new Saturday Glossy Guardian? Last one. What is going to be the title of The Navigators. I know it was a working title. Anything decided?

KenLoach
I don't go to the cinema very much - preferring football, but there are some good new directors. I enjoyed Lyn Ramsay's Ratcatcher, the films by Gary Oldman and Tim Roth. The brothers behind Rosetta, and I thought The Last Resort was good. And on the subject of football: Neither Coventry nor Manchester City, but Bath city, where I lived for a long time. I also look for the results of Fulham and Nuneatan Borough, but anybody living in the south west, get yourself to Twerton Park before the end of the season!

FilmFan
Who would you say were your biggest influences?

KenLoach My biggest influences - European films of the 50s and 60s, particularly Italian films by Vittorio de Sica and Czech films of the Prague Spring.

barquing
In the British reviews of Bread & Roses, how quickly did it take for the "Oh my God, Ken Loach had made a film in LA" attitude to get on your nerves? And while I'm at it, do you think there should be a balance between a film's form and a film's message and if so how well do you think you achieve this?

KenLoach
It wasn't that attitude that is irritating, but those writers and reviewers who are contemptuous of any time when people take collective action. You see the consequences of the Thatcherite triumph in the reviews more than the films, in the way individualism is lauded at the expense of any group of people getting together. One reviewer attacked it simply because it was about trade unions. Maggie must be rubbing her hands in glee. Second question: Yes, content and form should be indivisible, and if the content can be reduced to a message, it's probably not worth passing on. One problem I have is the label 'political' which means there's a danger that people don't see what is really in the film, they see what they expect to see.

Seona
Are you suggesting we break up the big multiplexes like UGC, Odeon, etc? Because I'm more than happy to do that, evil things that they are.

KenLoach
Yes - what happens in Norway is interesting. Many cinemas there seem to be owned by municipalities and are programmed by people who seem to have a genuine interest in film. My favourite cinema is the Ritzy, Brixton. There are several others that I also like.

ASA1
With reference to "Raining Stones", is there a truly socialist alternative?

KenLoach
Yes there is, but I guess you have to go back and read the books to discover it. One thing's for certain, it's not to be found in the Labour Party.

FilmFan
You're well-known for keeping portions of your scripts secret from your actors until the key moment. Could you elaborate on your reasons behind this - I'm thinking of the loan sharks scene in Raining Stones - and what effect having to re-take has on the a) the actors, and b) the scene. (Also, how often would you typically re-shoot an emotional scene such as that?)

KenLoach
The reason to sometimes keep a script away from the actors is because surprise is the hardest thing to act, so if you film the actual surprise you sometimes reach an authenticity in your response which you wouldn't do otherwise.

zorglub
Is it annoying to be considered controversial simply because you do not propagate right-wing politics or apply a highly stylised form in your films?

KenLoach
This comment is spot on! It's the pro CIA films or cold war films that are always seen as just entertainment whereas a counter view is marked down as political. "Common sense is the sense of the ruling class."

Gazer30
Hi Ken, Do you think that New Labour has gone so far to the right that it is impossible for it to regain its old 'agenda'? How much hope to you have in the Socialist Alliance instead? Does it have enough appeal to become a serious contender to parliamentary politics?

KenLoach
Yes, I think Blair has continued the work of other Labour leaders in transforming the Labour party into a party of business. The last election's slogan was 'Labour means business' without apology. I think the vacuum on the left is waiting to be filled. The most hopeful development in recent years has been the socialist alliances. I think there's an opportunity to develop a real challenge from the left. The Scottish socialist party has made a good start in Scotland. so look out for the alliance!

RichardM
Ken, at the NFT in '98 you said that you wanted to go to the States and use it as a location the same way as Hollywood uses Europe as a location. Was the experience of making Bread and Roses there a satisfying one, and would you go back again? Also are you frustrated that it has taken almost a year since its Cannes premiere for B&R to be released in the UK?

KenLoach
Yes, B&R is a European film on location in LA, with the protagonists being Mexicans and one north American from New York. But I think the whole approach was European, much to the bemusement of the resident film people. As for the time it's taken to be released here: No, we're accustomed to films taking longer here than anywhere else.

susannahfr
Dear Ken, I am currently writing my PHD thesis (University of Lille, France) on your work since the mid-60s (TV,fiction and documentaries) and I am particularly interested in social, political and historical issues. Having seen Days of Hope and Questions of Leadership, my question is : how can you account for the lack of publicity/interest accorded by the media and critics to the issues addressed in this particular strand of your work, whilst most attention focuses on "the latest film" ? How do you think the views expressed in Questions of Leadership and A Question of Leadership have stood the test of time ?

KenLoach
SusannaFR: Yes, people who write about films here seem unable to deal with wider issues, style and technique and show business. The wider questions of society and politics leave them cold. That seems to be the tradition of our cinema, which follows in the wake of the US and is why it's such a pleasure to work with other Europeans, either as co-producers or taking the films to European cinemas. In the case of Land and Freedom, as a typical example, in France we had 120 prints, in Britain we had 17. I guess that about sums it up.

Seymour2
Hi Ken, did you ever consider going into politics when you were younger? Why do you think the younger generation is so generally apathetic these days?

KenLoach
No, my memory's too bad, and you'd have to mix with other politicians - it'd be a terrible waste of your life! ...

...That's all we've got time for - thanks for all the questions. The outlook may not be as black as we sometimes depict it !

Questions Ken didn't have time to answer

danst
Bread & Roses is your first film set entirely in the US. Does this mean that you may start making more films in the US or is the US setting merely there to tell this particular story?

barquing
You've probably been asked this a lot (sorry!) but given that you do a lot of work with non-professional actors, what are your views on the forthcoming SAG and Writer's Guild strikes?

FayJay
Do you have any unfulfilled ambitions (cinematic or otherwise)?

Datta
Did you see "The Limey"? What did you think (in particular, of the way in which the clips from "Poor Cow" were used)? Did you have any say as to whether or not the clips were used? If so, did you ask to see the script or talk to the producers of "The Limey" before you agreed to the inclusion of the clips? Can I please have some clips from "Kes" for the Brian Glover wrestling/bio pic I am developing?

ASA1
Could you settle an argument please. Who's the better actor Brad Pitt or Keenau Reeves? Have you even heard of them?

zorglub
I am teaching English at the local prison (in Norway) this summer and I wonder whether to show 'Raining Stones' or 'My Name is Joe'. Which one would you suggest? Despite the fact that your films are never condescending in any way I am afraid that perhaps my showing them in that particular setting would make them appear so. Do you think there is such thing as a wrong setting to show your films in, or a wrong way to present them?

BeckyLewis
Dear Ken, Is it true that you once made an advert for McDonald's?

mattgale
Hi, I was wondering as to what were your main goals, intentions, or what have you, as to why you decided to direct a film in the USA. I can imagine that it isn't for the reasons of technology, or even the money. Is it for the experience or is there some other motive as to why?

nina793
Your films rarely receive the popular success they deserve. Would you like to have a huge international hit? Do you have a particular audience in mind when you write your films?

sirtaylor
Dear Ken, Doesn't it annoy you a bit that the people you make films about would rather watch "Die Hard" and "Gone in 60 seconds"?

chrislis
I am interested to know how you came to make Kes. Did you read the book and think it would make a good film, did someone ask you to direct it, or did you intend to make a film about the education system or a working class child and look for a suitable script?

eroica
Film making is a crappy and exploitative business in which people are forever ripping off each-other's ideas. How are you able to square your personal convictions with the shoddy politics of making a film? Perhaps you could use "Raining Stones" as a case study?

RussellCrowe
Hi Ken. Have you ever been asked to direct a big budget film? Would you consider making Titantic II or Armageddon II if you could slip in some leftist propaganda? Or do you feel that your principles would be compromised by the accountants and studio executives if you took the big studio dollar?

jodmitchell
Why are British film-makers often unable to source funds domestically? Do we, as a nation, lack self-belief? Or ambition?

KingBoyD
Ken, would you agree that you are one of only a few directors of recent times with as committed an ideology / agenda / social conscience? As an aside, what would you be doing if not directing?

RichardM
I've heard that the screenplay for Land and Freedom had to be cut back due to insufficient funds. Were there any major differences between what you wanted to depict and what ended up on screen? Also are there any other historical events or more ambitious projects than usual that you'd like to tackle if given the chance?

KasperHauser
Ken, In the unlikely event that one of your films was nominated for an Oscar, would you go to the ceremony? - if so, what would your acceptance speech be like if you won? ...also, what did you think of Peter Mullan's 'Orphans'? Along with 'My Name Is Joe' it's one of the few British films I can actually remember liking in recent years...

barquing
.. and what did you make of FilmFour's treatment of Orphans?

criticalmass
Ken, You're directing a party election broadcast for the Socialist Alliance. What will be in it? Also, you must have given money to the Labour party in the past - on their current performance, would you demand a refund?

ka0310
Hi Ken, As an expat of 10 years here in Barcelona, I'd love to know if your recent "Latino" themes have anything to do with the success you have had here compared to the bizzare lack of acclaim that you have garnered in the english speaking world.

zorglub
in the unlikely event that someone offered to finance it, would you consider directing re-makes/spoofs of British mega hits such as Four Weddings, Full Monty etc?

Jamie Sexton
: I'd like to ask you about your early television experiences. More particularly, what did you think about the use of 16mm film in television drama? Did you feel that this technology was personally liberating and did you think it had a positive effect on television drama as a whole? If so, in what way?

ZAPPATA
Hello Mr Loach, with regards to your highlighting of the human rights abuses & needs of refugee or migrant workers in your films, in particular 'Bread & Roses' & 'Ladybird,Ladybird' (last of which I found shockingly powerful & the former I look forward to seeing)how does your experience of the U.S.A's political & social systems compare with that of the U.K,are there similarities? And just one last question, what is your view of the peaceful entry of Subcomandante Marcos & the Zapatistas into Mexico City last month?

nac1
Do you like John Sayles' work? Is he the nearest thing to an American Ken Loach?! Was Matewan an inspiration when you were making Land & Freedom?

Seona
Ken, a completely pointless question but ... do you ever watch Buffy the Vampire Slayer?

EvilWillow
Hi Ken, Have you seen Requiem for a Dream? Stylistically, very different from you. What do you think of the influence of music videos on recent films?

zorglub
Norwegian cinemas are part state-owned. it is not (i think) entirely up to the individual cinema to decide the programme. this ensures that small cinemas in thinly populated areas get the chance to screen European and Asian films as well as the big ones. it is of course also a good idea that 'art' films and hollywood films are not segregated into different cinemas. Norwegian cinemas are doing better and better every year.

Gazer30
Will there be a directors cut of Land and Freedom, considering on another post here it was mentioned that you had to miss out parts due to monetary reasons?!?

Jorge17
How much merit do you think there is in any kind of social democratic politics these days? It seems that whatever happens the system swallows you up within its logic. Do you think that cinema and the arts have now a more vital role to play in terms of promoting some kind of utopian alternative to the corrosive capitalist order?

harrybackhouse
Ken, when you've got a minute, could I ask you to check out www.keepcinemalocal.co.uk with a view towards possibly giving them your support? They can use all the help they can get. Ta. Loved Land and Freedom, by the way.

branch11
do you think your films suffer from an overly romanticised view of the radical potential of the working class?

brankie
Hi I am currently come to the end of my dissertation. I am investigating the strategies need to create cultural and social intervention through documentary film. In which I have used Cathy Come Home as on of my case studies. I would like to ask you what would you consider to be to the essential elements needed to make a film facilitate social and cultural intervention in society. To motivate people to create change, like Cathy Come Home did. Thank you

savageearthheart
I'd like your read your comments about two different issues, if it's not too demanding, really. I'm writing an essay on the indigenous people of Nicaragua, and I'd like to have your opinion on the relations they had with the Sandinistas. The second question is related to 'Land and Freedom' in a way. Do you think that fighting for a better world today has a chance? I believe there are people who do want this, but get lost somewhere among pragmatism, cynicism, fragmentation of efforts and information overload. Do you think there is still hope for making thing better? Thank you

Can I please have some clips from "Kes" for the Brian Glover wrestling/bio pic I am developing? ASA1 Could you settle an argument please. Who's the better actor Brad Pitt or Keenau Reeves? fields.headline: Ride 'em, cowgirl...
fields.standfirst: Sue makes the most of her final week in New Zealand with a jet-boating trip down the Mataura river in Queenstown and a visit to her first rodeo
fields.trailText: Week 21: Wanaka to Wellington Sue makes the most of her final week in New Zealand with a jet-boating trip down the Mataura river in Queenstown and a visit to her first rodeo
fields.body:
This has been a funny old week, mainly in terms of accommodation. After finishing my last report, I set off rather late in the day for Wanaka. Having failed to learn from previous mistakes, I found myself once again negotiating a mountain pass at dusk. Forgetting that it was Easter weekend, and ignorant of the fact that Wanaka had a wine and food festival and a rodeo the next day, I blithely drew up outside my chosen hostel. 'Full' said a sign on the door, so I drove on to the next one, which was also full, so on to the next, and the next, and the next... I began to panic, and drove around to look for motels. There were plenty of them, but every one had a 'no vacancies' sign.

I was just beginning to resign myself to a night in the car when I came across a bed and breakfast. Although it, too, was full, the nice lady made a couple of phone calls and a bed was found about 3km out of town. The price was five times what I'd normally pay, but I agreed and asked her to tell them I would be there as soon as I had eaten. As it happened the arrangement suited my new accommodation plan - the night before, still full of cold, I had suffered the mortifying experience of being shouted at in the middle of the night by a dorm-mate to "stop fucking snoring!". How embarrassing. I'd resolved to pay for a room to myself until normal breathing resumed.

Back in the car I checked my cash situation to find that there wasn't much left after the price of the room - just enough for a sad-looking sandwich from a garage. Garage food seems to conform to the same low standards all over the world. However, the b&b was luxurious with fluffy towels and umpteen pillows, and the following morning I ate an enormous breakfast of pancakes and hot cross buns.

I pre-booked a single room in a hostel in Queenstown for that night and, in bright sunshine, set off to explore Wanaka. I found a lovely two-hour walk up Mount Iron which gave panoramic views of Wanaka Lake and the surrounding countryside. It then occured to me that I had never been to a rodeo, so I paid my $10 and spent a very entertaining few hours watching men being thrown off horses and steers being roped in various ways. I didn't know that New Zealand had so many would-be cowboys, all dressed for the part and watching with deadly seriousness.

I tore myself away from the rodeo in order to be in Queenstown before it got too late.  Queenstown has every sort of foolish, semi-dangerous pastime that the tourist industry can dream up. As I was here and it was now  Easter Sunday I entered into the spirit of the place and looked around for the least dangerous but mildly exciting activity. Jet-boating down the Mataura river seemed to fit the bill, and I bought my ticket. I must admit that my adrenalin was activated more by the fantastic scenery of the river and the mountains than rushing under bridges, narrowly missing the banks and the 360 degree skids in the water, but it was all good fun. 20 minutes late I returned to my car to find I had a parking ticket. Initially angry, I then reflected that if  I was a traffic warden having to work Easter Sunday I would probably slap a ticket on anyone enjoying themselves for too long as well.

Queenstown was as far south as time allowed, now I had to start heading north again to get back to Auckland for my flight on Sunday. I'd booked a room at Killermont Station, a farm on the road to Christchurch, described as "a peaceful place". I drove up a dirt track to a nice-looking farm house from which a lady emerged and beckoned me to follow her, whereupon we drove in convoy down another dirt track until we came to a corrugated shed-like building in the middle of a field. It was perfectly comfortable inside but when I asked if there was anyone else due to arrive the answer was no - and there was no key for the front door, either. "It's perfectly safe out here, dear," she said, as she drove off, leaving me alone in the middle of a field with no key and no phone trying to decide if I should stay or go. The bedroom did have a bolt and there was a sturdy kitchen table to push in front of the front door, so I opted to stay. I turned on the fire and cooked my dried noodles, but declined to use the washing machine complete with mangle, which would have been snapped up by any English antique shop.  The silence was a bit deafening so I put on my "Get by in Latin American Spanish" tape, and listened to the chapter on accommodation - unfortunately there wasn't a section on being marooned on a cattle station. My reward in the morning, after a restless night, was to be surrounded by beautiful mountains, without a human in sight.

I continued on to Christchurch, where the only place with single rooms was an all-female hostel called Frauenreishaus. This was easily the best-equipped hostel I have yet found - free washing machine, cheap internet, lovely warm duvets (good to give the sleeping bag a rest) and every mod con you could think of in the kitchen, including a bread-making machine. The home comforts - plus a compelling desire to stand still for a day - persuaded me to stay a second night. I wandered around Christchurch doing all those things that it's difficult to find time for when you are always on the move - getting films developed, sending off post, faxing my bank to sort out my visa payments and buying a new day-bag. The zip on my trusty bag that never leaves my side, even in bed, had become unreliable. Time for a new one. The only cloud on my horizon was that there were no spaces on the ferry to North Island at all the next day, which meant crossing on Thursday - very tight for reaching Auckland to hand the car back on Saturday. This left me the Wednesday to stop at Kaikoura to go on a whale-watching boat trip. Unfortunately, as we waited, a message was received that the whales were heading out to sea and the trip was cancelled. I suppose  I can't be lucky the whole time.

That evening was one of my few bad ones in terms of feeling lonely and homesick. I'd sat for a while with a group of youngsters discussing their A-level results (mine were so long ago I can hardly remember which subjects I took, never mind the grades), there was no internet available, and I was beginning to panic about how to spend my time in South America.  I think travelling in Australia and New Zealand has made me a bit soft - it's so easy. Also, having a car has meant that I haven't had to lug the monster bag around. I'm sure that once I get to South America I'll be fine. I'll also relax a bit when I have booked my first night's accommodation.

I felt better the next day and had a calm crossing between the Islands before going out for a delicious meal (lamb, of course) with Mike and Clare on Wellington harbour front. No need to worry about my snoring disturbing Jack, their cat, who shares the guest room. I gather that Milly and I must have passed each other at some point in New Zealand; I hope she liked it as much as I did, I'll be very sorry to leave. I'm now beginning to get excited about South America, and the emails are starting to come in with suggestions, which gives me a starting point.

I will be writing from Argentina next week!

fields.headline: New York Post loses chief
fields.trailText: Tuesday 6.15pm: The editor-in-chief of the New York Post, Xana Antunes, has resigned, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The editor-in-chief of the New York Post, Xana Antunes has resigned, fuelling speculation that she could be returned to work at a News International newspaper in the UK.

News Corporation has confirmed that Col Allen, editor-in-chief of the Sydney Daily Telegraph and Sunday Telegraph since 1999, will succeed Ms Antunes.

Ms Antunes is a former Independent and Evening Standard business reporter.

At her time on the Post, she worked under David Yelland in his previous role as editor of the New York paper.

A release from News Corporation said Ms Antunes had left her post "for personal reasons", but it has been reported that she left as a result of direct pressure from Rupert Murdoch.

Insiders said Ms Antunes was tired of her job after three gruelling years and had been talking of moving on to other things, possibly writing a book.

She has also indicated her unhappiness at Lachlan Murdoch's increasingly hands-on role at the paper.

In a recent editorial meeting, Rupert Murdoch publicly criticised changes at the paper, even though the changes had come at Lachlan's prompting.

Friends doubt that Ms Antunes will move back to England immediately, as she likes New York.

But speculation from within News International suggests that Ms Antunes may eventually reappear at the company.

fields.headline: 'Derham not sidelined' says ITV chief
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: ITV has quashed speculation that Katie Derham could be sidelined after naming Mary Nightingale as one of its main election night presenters, writes Jason Deans.

24.04.2001: Nightingale joins ITV election team
10.01.2001: ITV revives double-anchor news format

Special report: election and the media
fields.body:
Steve Anderson, the ITV controller of news and current affairs, has moved swiftly to quash speculation that Katie Derham could be sidelined, after it emerged today that Mary Nightingale would be one of the main studio presenters of the channel's election night show.

Ms Derham is expected to be assigned to cover one of the party leaders or a key constituency.

"Katie will be playing an important role in our election night coverage," said Mr Anderson said.

Ms Derham presents the ITV Weekend News and is also ITV's media and arts correspondent.

"She is likely to be handed a plum roving role, out in the field," said another senior ITV insider.

"It'll be one of the big jobs, covering a major constituency, or with one of the party leaders."

ITV news reporters Bill Neely and Mark Webster are also being lined up for major on-screen roles out in the field on election night.

And ITV's political editor, John Sergeant, is also likely to have a roving brief, tracking down breaking stories around Westminster and the party headquarters.

In the studio, Jonathan Dimbleby is expected to take the main anchor role, with Ms Nightingale as co-presenter.

Related stories

webTitle: MoD claims answer to email viruses

fields.headline: MoD claims answer to email viruses
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: The days of the global email virus may be numbered. Ministry of Defence scientists have developed software that could prevent devastating, worldwide, mail-borne infections such as the infamous love bug. By Stuart Miller.
fields.body:
The days of the global email virus may be numbered. Ministry of Defence scientists have developed software that could prevent devastating, worldwide, mail-borne infections such as the infamous love bug.

Amid mounting concern in government and industry about the threat from virus-laden emails, the defence evaluation and research agency (Dera) says it has produced a simple but effective way of containing malicious viruses before they get the chance to spread to other computers and cause real damage.

The ease with which a well-designed virus can circumnavigate the globe was highlighted last May when millions of people received an email with the heading ILOVEYOU. Within hours the virus in the email - subsequently dubbed the love bug - caused an estimated £2bn of damage as it immobilised computer systems, hitting large companies such as News International, Microsoft and the BBC.

The virus, which was traced to the Philippines, was able to spread so rapidly because its first act on being opened by unsuspecting users was to send itself to every name in the users' email address books.

Since then email-borne virus attacks have increased, although none has created the same chaos. The latest big outbreak was in February when millions of people opened up a virus masquerading as an email picture of the Russian tennis player Anna Kournikova; it replicated itself around the world at twice the rate of the love bug.

These outbreaks have shown up the vulnerability of email systems. Even the best security procedures can fail through computer users opening their unsolicited messages and letting loose the virus.

The Dera software, to be unveiled today in London, is claimed to provide the answer. Based on research to protect highly sensitive government documents and computer systems from attack, the package turns conventional anti-virus thinking on its head: instead of attempting to stop the virus getting in, it prevents it from getting out and damaging other machines.

The principle behind the software, named ::Mail, appears simple - whenever users try to send an email, ::Mail shows a box on the screen telling them what they are sending to whom, and asking them to confirm the command. If the user unwittingly opens an infected email which then tries to replicate itself, the box will appear, warning them that the computer is trying to send emails. Although their own computer will be infected, with a click of the mouse, they will be able to prevent the virus escaping.

The new software is heavily protected from attack, removing the possibility of virus writers producing a code able to override the security.

Simon Wiseman, who led the team which developed the software, said yesterday: "Because most of the work we do is for the MoD we're experienced at preventing confidential information from getting out when it shouldn't. This is an extension of that basic principle. While every other anti-virus company has concentrated on stopping things getting in, we are shutting down the propagation channels so that any damage is contained in the machines of those opening the infected message."

Based on research to protect highly sensitive government documents and computer systems from attack, the package turns conventional anti-virus thinking on its head: instead of attempting to stop the virus getting in, it prevents it from getting out and damaging other machines. The principle behind the software, named ::Mail, appears simple - whenever users try to send an email, ::Mail shows a box on the screen telling them what they are sending to whom, and asking them to confirm the command. If the user unwittingly opens an infected email which then tries to replicate itself, the box will appear, warning them that the computer is trying to send emails. Although their own computer will be infected, with a click of the mouse, they will be able to prevent the virus escaping. The new software is heavily protected from attack, removing the possibility of virus writers producing a code able to override the security. Simon Wiseman, who led the team which developed the software, said yesterday: "Because most of the work we do is for the MoD we're experienced at preventing confidential information from getting out when it shouldn't. This is an extension of that basic principle. While every other anti-virus company has concentrated on stopping things getting in, we are shutting down the propagation channels so that any damage is contained in the machines of those opening the infected message."

fields.headline: Good fellows
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod and Susie Wild talk to two of the contenders in this year's national fellowship awards
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod and Susie Wild talk to two of the contenders in this year's national fellowship awards
fields.body:
Gloria Gordon noticed the young woman on the London bus was reading a textbook from the National Bakery School. "This is where I started 20 years ago," thought Dr Gordon, who was last week shortlisted as one of the best higher education lecturers in the country.

She used to get the bus to the same school (now part of South Bank University) and has gone on to build an academic career and inspire generations of students with her conviction that they can make a difference and change their own lives.

South Bank, which nominated her for one of 20 National Teaching Fellowships, acknowledges that both students and colleagues in the business school where she teaches find her approach challenging.

The judging panel of the National Teaching Fellowship Scheme has now included Dr Gordon among 43 top lecturers in line for £1m prize money. Under the scheme, organised by the Institute of Learning and Teaching, 20 winners will each receive £50,000 to be spent on developing their learning and teaching. The shortlist was chosen from 86 academics put forward by their universities and colleges in England and Northern Ireland.

Gloria Gordon says that as a woman of African Caribbean descent, one way to escape racism was through gaining academic qualifications.

The national diploma in baking technology she gained as a mature student was the first step in a long road. After becoming a part-time and then full-time teacher at the National Bakery School, she embarked on a diploma in management studies, followed by an MBA at South Bank and a PhD at Bath University. Meanwhile, her teaching moved from further to higher education students at what is now South Bank's business school.

The student body at the university is relatively diverse, but there aren't many black women lecturers. She says students are often surprised. Because she believes research and learning should explore the assumptions of those involved as well as the subject - "double loop learning" - she takes up and discusses remarks and attitudes that some might brush aside.

It doesn't make for a comfortable ride for her students. While they are warm in their praise by the end of the course, she encounters resistance at first. "It's not immediately appealing to everyone," she concedes. "You can go into a classroom and shut off and go through the motions - I don't plan my classes for that to be the experience. It can be quite disorientating the unsettling.

"I don't want to be one of the lecturers who deliver material and stare at the wall while I'm delivering it. I am doing something I feel passionately about and something that can make a difference to people's lives."

Students respond to this innovative way of teaching. "I like the realistic and honest view you have of developing and challenging ourselves as individuals . . . I am really keen to use this approach for my dissertation as the aim of studying for me was to stretch and challenge me as an individual, both in terms of my intellect and approach," said one student, quoted in the university's citation for the teaching fellowship.

Others commented on being challenged. "This unit has made me think and question numerous different areas of my life, it has also contributed to my growth as a person and increased my maturity.

"A completely different style of guidance was delivered by the lecturer, forcing oneself to adopt a critical thinking approach, allowing individuals to reason out the con trasting opinions of the group. I found this to be effective."

Her students are not the only ones with praise for Gordon. In recommending her, South Bank stated: "Her work is clearly challenging to her personally, but is also sometimes similarly received by colleagues. This means that individuals are not always immediately receptive to her approach. Nevertheless, there is demonstrable evidence of colleagues actively engaging with Dr Gordon's approach and being inspired by it."

Gordon's specialism is the behaviour of people in organisations and her message is that her students can shape the organisations they go into, that they are not passive entities.

"Somewhere out there are students I have influenced to think differently and act differently, to look at a situation and say 'how can I make it different?'. I believe it is a privilege for me to be in a position where I am influencing people's minds. I want to do that as ethically and as best I can."

Gordon says she wants to see "en thusiasm and expectancy" returned to the centre of the educative process. She wants learners who are personally challenged and want to become lifelong learners.

Coming from a completely different research background in immunology, including HIV, Lesley-Jane Reynolds, of Surrey's School of Biomedical Sciences and Life Sciences, is also passionate about improving her students' teaching and learning.

She makes no secret of her view that current undergraduates are getting a raw deal from large class sizes and the break-up of courses into modules. "The student experience, at a most basic level, is not terribly acceptable," said Dr Reynolds. "With first-year classes having up to 200 students, it is hard to get one-to-one time unless they are brave enough to ask for it."

Given the huge demands on limited resources in universities, she believes it is possible to give students more individual attention. "The fellowship would allow me to develop an integrated learning programme including small group tutorials and the promotion of individual study, a learning to learn approach. Though this would mean fewer contact hours for the students, they would be better quality, allowing any particular problems to be addressed there and then."

Renowned by students and peers for her enthusiasm and attentiveness, students have described her lectures as "inspiring" and "hugely enjoyable", said the university's citation.

Reynolds specialises in macrophages (immune cells that are usually responsible for the initial attack against an invasion launched by a virus, bacterium, or fungus), more specifically in relation to toxic shock and the development of atherosclerosis.

The head of her school has proclaimed it "a testament to her skill that even on the Masters programme where she teaches the same class from 10am until 5pm she still receives high praise".

Ben Knights, head of the English and Cultural Studies department at Teesside University, describes himself as an "intellectual odd-jobs man" and is currently entertaining his level three students with the wonders of masculinity in fiction.

Praised by his university as "an exceptional teacher and professional educator; an innovative and reflective practitioner and an excellent role model for colleagues", Professor Knights is credited with turning round the English department since arriving at Teesside five years ago.

He studied history at Oxford, before gaining a PhD at Cambridge. He then worked in continuing education at the University of Durham until he joined Teesside.

The shortlist for the second year of the teaching fellowship scheme reflected a wide range of talent in different types of institution (23 from old universities, 15 from new and five from higher education colleges) and subjects, said Professor Sally Brown, director of membership services at the Institute of Learning and Teaching. "We were very pleased with the submissions this year, they were of a very high standard."

The winners will be announced in June and have a fairly free hand over how they spend their £50,000 fellowships.

Like the other academics on the shortlist, Gloria Gordon now has to draw up a proposal to spend the money if she was to win one of the 20 fellowships. Her students pressed her recently on whether she wouldn't rather be teaching at Oxford or Cambridge. She told them with conviction that she is happy at South Bank. She grew up in Brixton and loves the diversity of that area of London and the mix of students of all ages who come through the university's doors.

"South Bank has challenged me in many ways and in my own way I have challenged South Bank. At the end of the day, I think it is a very important type of institution in the higher education network.

"If I can be an inspiration to other people there I am happy to do so and support them in their own learning and development."

Who knows what future the young woman studying her bakery textbook on the bus has in front of her?

webTitle: Lecturers say they've waited long enough for a pay increase

fields.headline: Clock ticks on pay
fields.standfirst: Lecturers say they've waited long enough for a decent increase.  Donald MacLeod  reports
fields.trailText: Lecturers say they've waited long enough for a decent increase. Donald MacLeod reports
fields.body:
A flurry of informal talks between union officials and university employers are taking place this week to pave the way for a pay settlement and avoid industrial action by lecturers.

Formal negotiations between the Universities and Colleges Employers Association and unions representing academic and other staff in higher education institutions are not due to resume until May 10 after the unions rejected a 3.3% pay offer on April 6.

After the failure to reach agreement, David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, warned that unless there was progress his members in the old universities would debate a ballot for industrial action at their forthcoming annual conference.

Action such as leafleting at graduation ceremonies - to embarrass university authorities and take the case to parents - is also likely to be discussed when the association meets in Scarborough next month.

"Higher education staff have shown the patience of saints waiting for a serious pay offer from university employers. Unless there is a significant change in the derisory sum currently on offer it is inevitable that there will be a call for stronger action in institutions," Mr Triesman said.

"After many months of exhausting negotiation the employers have one more opportunity in early May to solve this dispute. Increasing demands on higher education and the expansion of university places will not again be funded out of the pocket of lecturers and staff."

Natfhe, which represents lecturers in the new universities and higher education colleges, has already taken action over pay by withholding students' marks.

Tom Wilson, the union's higher education secretary, said they were looking for a decent settlement now that the government was at last putting money into the sector.

Average earnings were rising by 4.4% and lecturers were aware that school teachers had secured a basic rise of 3.7% plus £2,000 for the great majority who qualified for extra performance payments.

"Most teachers will be getting at least 5% and probably a lot more. With an election coming neither the employers not the government want there to be strife and unrest," he said.

The lecturers' case was bolstered by the Bett report which warned of a "swinging sixties time bomb" when the large number of lecturers who entered academic life during the expansion of the 1960s retired. But, unlike schools, there has been no public perception of crisis or threats to send students home.

On the employers' side Declan Leyden, assistant director of the association, said their offer had been rejected, but there was no impasse. Progress had been made on a number of issues. "We would be optimistic that we could reach some sort of settlement," he said.

But he warned that pay depended on what the universities could afford: "They tell us what they can spend."

Bargaining is complicated in the short term by attempts to simplify the negotiating machinery and bring settlement dates for different groups into line. For AUT members the pay year starts in April, for Natfhe mem bers it's September, while the date for many support staff is July. An effort is being made to harmonise them to August 2002.

Every proposal means discussions between the unions on the one hand and the employers' association canvassing individual university vice-chancellors on the other.

Universities are also trying to work out how to implement the government's demands to improve the poor equal opportunities record of the sector and give equal pay. Ministers also want to see appraisal and performance pay introduced as they have been in schools.

A total of £330m over three years is available to fund this and discussions about how universities can qualify for this money form part of the informal talks which took place on Friday and are due to continue this week.

fields.trailText: higher news
fields.body:
The third degree

Was it his eclectic taste in music (Janis Joplin and Mozart) or just that earthy Aussie charm? Whatever the reason, Cambridge University vice-chancellor, Sir Alec Broers (pictured), has emerged as the new pin-up for the middle-class female masses who tune into Radio 4's Desert Island Discs programme. The university has been inundated with fan mail from female admirers since the vice-chancellor appeared on the programme earlier this month. An unnamed company has also sent a free box of chocolates for Sir Alec, following his admission that he is a bit of a chocoholic. How long will it be before the Cadbury sponsored department of food technology is unveiled at Cambridge, one wonders?

Lecturers' unions are looking at the outbreak of solidarity among the schoolteachers with some bemusement. Is this how colleagues are meant to behave? Natfhe and AUT are cooperating on pay talks but the former couldn't resist twisting the knife by suggesting extra money for anyone joining the Institute of Learning and Teaching. That would certainly boost membership (which reached 5,000 this week) just as the AUT is calling loudly for its abolition.

 Do exhibitions come any more obscure? Cambridge Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology offers Bubberhunting on the Sosh - apparently something to do with flint working.

Stories? Gossip? Contact us: donald.macleod@theguardian.com lee.elliotmajor@theguardian.com

News

Research assistance

Reforms to improve the working conditions of researchers in universities - otherwise known as the academic underclass - are to be discussed at a conference for social scientists next month.

New European work directives are set to change the way academic institutions treat the thousands of research assistants on short-term contracts in the UK. From July 2001, these will mean terms and conditions for fixed-term workers should not be less favourable than for permanent workers; successive renewals of fixed-term contracts should be restricted; and employers should inform fixed-term employees of permanent vacancies and provide access to appropriate training.

The Association of Research Centres in the Social Sciences is organising a conference at the Policy Studies Institute in London on May 15 to discuss the moves to improve the careers of young researchers. The Department of Trade and Industry is currently consulting academics on how to implement the new European laws. View the DTI consultation paper at www.dti.gov.uk/er/fixed To register for the conference, contact Dennis Hackett by email at d.hackett@lboro.ac.uk

Research into research

Research into research

Armed with £5m from the government to "develop the UK's management research to a world-class level", the Economic and Social Research Council has written to university business school heads for views on how the money should be allocated to resuscitate one of the UK's underperforming research disciplines. "One major guiding principle for allocating resources will be to develop research capacity," says Dr Gordon Marshall, ESRC's chief executive. Responses are requested by May 15. Email comments to David.Guy@esrc.ac.uk

Universe

Better than McDonald's?

In New Zealand, a study by the Christchurch School of Medicine found that as many as 35% of the nation's sex industry workers were college educated, writes David Cohen.

Sex degrees

Meanwhile, Taiwan is to inaugurate its first sexology programme. Lin Yen-chin, the head of the Shu Te university's new Graduate Institute of Sexology, said she wants to teach people the lustier concepts of sex.

fields.headline: For your eyes only
fields.standfirst: There's a whiff of police state when my private emails can be read   and my phone tapped
fields.trailText: Gillian Evans: There's a whiff of police state when my private emails can be read and my phone tapped
fields.body:
Read any good emails lately? Were they someone else's? Under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000 universities can now "intercept communications" and read emails sent on their systems.

People may now ferret about in other people's private correspondence and tap their phone. If senior members of staff at Cambridge want a good read, all they have to do is decide that it is "necessary to gain access to information" in my absence. Each head of department is allowed to "supplement" this rule, so even that requirement could be dispensed with (I could find myself facing charges of misconduct for submitting this article electronically).

Surely this should not be happening in a great research institution like Cambridge? Our guidelines do not seem to respect the privacy of the scholarly exchange, the overseas student writing in with queries, students writing in trust about their problems. And the same thing is happening in other universities. But if you want access to materials in which you are mentioned, that's another story.

The Lancaster University Data Protection project (www.lancs.ac.uk/dataprotection) guidelines suggest that all information held by the university should be accessible to the data subject unless a specific exemption applies. In the meantime, in higher education institutions which have set themselves against a simple policy of handing everything over, students and staff have to wait until October 24, 2001 to ask for manual records under the Data Protection Act 1998. While we wait, "shred-it" instructions are being circulated and documents are being re-filed so that they can be kept out of reach of the Act. It appears that has already happened with the electronic records.

Students discontented with their exam results will ask to see the marked papers, the comments of the examiners, the minutes of the examiners' meetings and the report of the external examiner.

But my university says that the student is not entitled to see the minutes, since they are not filed with reference to him as data subject. His friends all urge a bullied technician to use the grievance procedure. The head of department calls in the friends to make sure they understand the consequences of being seen to support the technician. He is advised to ask for the records relating to him under the Data Protection Act. The department says it has no records on this technician beyond his basic personnel file and statement of grievance.

Meanwhile, according to our rules, "the university reserves the right to listen to or have access to read any communication made or received by a member of staff using its computers or telephone system without notice", so the senior bully will be able to go fishing for "evidence" against his victim.

Gillian Evans lectures in medieval theology and intellectual history at Cambridge University and is public policy secretary of the Council for Academic Freedom and Academic Standards.

webTitle: Poor Sino-US relations may hit UK student recruitment

fields.headline: Great walls
fields.standfirst: Poor Sino-US relations may hit UK student recruitment, says  Tillie Harris
fields.trailText: Poor Sino-US relations may hit UK student recruitment, says Tillie Harris
fields.body:
Fears that worsening relations between China and the US will have a knock-on effect on British universities have been voiced by academics.

It was expected that up to 10,000 students from China would be recruited by UK universities this year, making it the fastest growing section of the higher education market, according to the British Council. In the year 1999 to 2000, 6,094 Chinese students studied in UK.

But in the wake of the "spy plane" confrontation and the arrest of three Chinese academics there are concerns that this recruitment drive will be affected and damage will be done to academic exchanges painstakingly built up over decades.

In view of the diplomatic sensitivities involved, the British Council declined to comment on the situation. But academics have been less restrained: nearly 400 China scholars around the world have signed a letter of protest about the arrest of the Chinese academics.

Li Shaomin, a Princeton University-educated American citizen teaching business at the City University of Hong Kong, was detained in February; Xu Zerong, an Oxford University-trained historian undertaking research at the Guangdong Provincial Academy of Social Sciences, was detained last August; and Gao Zhan, a permanent US resident and American University scholar, was detained in February and has recently been charged with espionage by the Chinese.

A warning by the US State Department to Chinese-born academics in America about the risks of detention if they visit the People's Republic is the latest move in the confrontation.

To register their concern, 376 scholars, including 25 from the UK, have signed a protest letter to China's president, Jiang Zemin. It states: "Scholarly relations have been in the forefront of the process of improving relations between China and the rest of the world. Tens of thousands of scholars have participated in both directions and have contributed significantly to China's modernisation and the enhancement of understanding between China and other nations.

"It is with dismay that we view the deterioration of the climate for academic exchange and research, as demonstrated by the detention of scholars who have returned to China merely to conduct research and engage in other normal scholarly activities."

One of the signatories, Robin Munro, senior research fellow at the School of Oriental and African Studies, said: "It is certainly true that across the board, in all major countries having academic exchanges with China, this has had a chilling effect."

However, Don Starr, lecturer for the Department for East Asian Studies at Durham university - an institution which has strong links with a Beijing-based university - says he has few concerns on behalf of his department.

"We do send students to China every year, and we welcome many Chinese students here, but we mainly teach language and cultural courses which really aren't threatening to the Chinese authorities."

The State Department warned academics about returning to China if they had published writings critical of Chinese government policies. "In some cases, travel to Taiwan or involvement with Taiwan media organisations has apparently also been regarded as the equivalent of espionage."

Starr says: "You have to remember that a great many American academics are ethnically Chinese, and the Chinese government tend to think of them as still being Chinese.

"This may well be a warning from the president to Hong Kong intellectuals. Until recently they had the kind of freedoms that Western scholars have; now they are being warned to be a lot more sensitive."

webTitle: How the Research Assessment Exercise affects scholarly writing

fields.headline: A write off
fields.standfirst: While today's research style may be "RAEable", it's become so unreadable it risks losing its audience, argues  Les Back
fields.trailText: While today's research style may be "RAEable", it's become so unreadable it risks losing its audience, argues Les Back
fields.body:
The piles of books, papers and reports have been dispatched to the Research Assessment Exercise panels from universities throughout the land, but the effects on the quality of scholarly writing linger on.

The exercise is narrowing the audience for scholarly books and limiting the kinds of writing that academics produce. It's not that academics write too much; it's just that they do it in a highly specific voice.

Single-authored books are prized above all else, particularly if they are with high profile - preferably American - university presses. Next are single-authored pieces in high-status professional journals.

This produces a feverish atmosphere in which we are desperate to have articles in the "right places". It also means that other options and other styles of writing are not considered because they register little on the meter of RAE value.

Many younger academics simply don't have a choice. Their futures are dependent on achieving the requisite number of publications to make them "RAEable", in other words to be put forward as "research active". An article in the Guardian, for example, is viewed as literary decoration and certainly not part of the academic cake.

Scholarly writing has become self-referential and full of convoluted argot. It seems that we are writing too often to impress our peers. This produces a kind of surfeit of metalanguage that passes largely unread from the desktop to the university library. But in order to be published in the right places, work has to conform to conventions that value academic technique over accessible prose.

Even writing academic books for students is viewed as little more than second division output. Originality becomes blurred with a particular form of literary encryption.

Russell Jacoby, author of The Last Intellectuals, suggests this fosters a fetish for difficulty and "the belief that fractured English, name dropping, and abstractions guarantee profundity, professionalisation and subversion". Clarity, on the other hand, is conflated with simplicity.

There are exceptions. In sociology, the wordcraft of Richard Sennett provides the best example of someone who writes with clarity without compromising either the elegance of argument or complexity of analysis. Feminist literary critic Germaine Greer similarly possesses the capacity to develop complex arguments in lucid prose. In the field of cultural studies, Stuart Hall is perhaps the most accomplished written and verbal communicator of the cultural legacy of empire.

Of course, some of the most beastly tracts have been written in perspicuous prose. Equally, there has to be a place for difficult ideas to be expressed in a difficult fashion. There is real beauty in what might be called the poetry of implied meaning. Yet, academic writing is too often laced with exclusive language that operates like an entry ticket, only admitting those who have paid the price.

Sociologist C Wright Mills wrote in the late 50s that "to overcome academic prose you have first to overcome the academic pose". Mills' career - he died in 1962 aged just 45 - was committed to challenging the intellectual status quo and is worth revisiting in the current climate.

He was a prolific writer, but struggled with wordcraft. A collection of his letters, recently edited by his daughters, shows a desperate pursuit of the right language. In a communiqué to his friend William Miller he expresses his dissatisfaction with the early drafts of what was to become his classic book White Collar. "I can't write it right. I can't get what I want to say about America in it. What I want to say is what you say to an intimate friend when you are discouraged about how it all is . . ."

We have stopped trying to make public issues resonate with the kind of private troubles to which Mills refers.

The great Italian writer and chemist Primo Levi wrote: "He who does not know how to communicate, or communicates badly, in a code that belongs only to him or a few others, is unhappy, and spreads unhappiness around him."

And he concludes: "If he communicates badly deliberately, he is wicked or at least discourteous, because he imposes labour, anguish, or boredom on his readers." It is high time to relieve the torture and tedium for students and readers before they stop bothering to turn the page at all.

Les Back is acting head of centre for urban and community research, Goldsmiths College, London.

webTitle: Class of 94 children should have been sent home

fields.headline: Class of 94 children should have been sent home
fields.trailText:
NASUWT head Nigel de Gruchy said that while he sympathised with a headteacher who taught a class of 94 children, the teacher shortage was only made more difficult when heads tried to cover it up.

• Special report: The teacher shortage
fields.body:
The headteacher who admitted teaching a class of 94 schoolchildren for five days should have sent them home instead, the leader of one of Britain's biggest teaching unions said today.

Nigel de Gruchy, leader of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers (NASUWT), said he sympathised with the predicament that Ralph Hedley of Queensway Community Junior School found himself in. But he added that the problem of tackling teacher shortages was only made more difficult when heads tried to cover them up.

Mr Hedley took the decision to cover three classes in the school hall when two of his staff were away on maths training courses and he could not find any supply teachers to replace them.

He said the problem could easily arise again if teachers were off sick. "The difficulty of getting supply teachers now is increasing. Everybody seems to need them and there aren't enough to go round."

The school, in Thetford, Norfolk, has eight staff to teach more than 260 children. Classes of more than 30 are common and parents say a class of more than 40 has been known.

He said the experience of teaching almost 100 children in the school hall was "quite pleasurable", but conceded: "I wouldn't say by any stretch of the imagination that it was teaching the children, it was looking after them."

Mr de Gruchy asked: "I wonder whether [Mr Hedley] did the right thing? Neither the interests of the pupils nor the teachers is served by seeking to hide problems...The brutal fact is that one school sending home a few children for one day achieves more than a hundred deputations and a thousand letters to ministers."

Education secretary David Blunkett responded by announcing that he would write to heads to remind them that teacher training needed to be organised so as to cause minimum disruption to classes. He pointed out that five statutory training days were available each year, and that heads could now give their own staff extra payment to attend evening or weekend training rather than hiring supply teachers.

Shadow education secretary Theresa May said that the incident was indicative of the shortage of teachers in Britain. "I think parents have every right in saying to this government that they didn't think that, four years on, they would be seeing children taught in these size classes and being sent home early," she told the Today programme this morning.

webTitle: On the Web: Elections | Keeping warm

fields.headline: On the Web
fields.trailText: Elections | Keeping warm
fields.byline: Compiled by Amanda Grimwood and Jim Merrett
fields.body:
Electoral Reform

www.electoral-reform.org.uk

Suitable for KS3/4 pupils

The Electoral Reform Society explains the different electoral systems.

Explore Parliament

www.explore.parliament.uk

Suitable for KS2/3 pupils & teachers

The Parliamentary Education Unit's site has a junior section and activities for older pupils. The teachers' lobby has guidance on online resources, as well as curriculum maps. Schools can take part in live debates.

Lewisham Young Citizens

ecs.lewisham.gov.uk/citizens

Suitable for KS2/3 pupils & teachers

An excellent example of good practice in ICT/citizenship. It began as an investigation into what young people know about how the council works and the site describes what they've achieved so far, with lesson plans, questionnaires and activities that could be adapted for any year group.

ePolitix

www.ePolitix.com

Suitable for KS4/5 pupils & teachers

Information about the UK parliament, or assemblies, and politicians.

CitizensConnection

www.yourturn.net

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils

A site aiming to help citizens make real changes in society, with a host of interesting information aimed primarily at secondary students. Excellent interactive resource explains the UK's legislative and representative systems.

10 out of 10

www.number-10.gov.uk/default

Suitable for KS2/3 pupils

The young person's guide to Downing Street and British politics. Pupils can put questions to a minister and decide what they would do if they were prime minister.

Democracy

www.represent.org.uk/index/home.html

Suitable for KS3/4/5 pupils & teachers

Questions on various issues relevant to what democracy means.

A history

www.ukelect.co.uk

Suitable for KS4/5 pupil & teachers

Past election and referendum results from across the UK and Europe. It claims to be able to predict election results based upon current polls and the results of previous elections.

Keeping Warm

Keep warm

www.glps.net/pwrout/keepwarm.htm

Suitable for KS1 teachers & pupils

Offering practical advice on what to do in the event of a power cut, children might like to consider the advice given on this simple and clear site. (I'm not sure how useful this site would be during an actual power cut!)

Thermal insulators

www.primaryresources.co.uk/science/science3.htm

Suitable for KS2 teachers

Includes an explanation of what thermal insulators are and provides a detailed table for recording results. There are opportunities for predicting likely outcomes and drawing up a conclusion.

Residential Energy Efficiency

www.its-canada.com/reed/dex.htm

Suitable for KS2 teachers & pupils

A commercial site with a lot of information on the advantages and disadvantages of different insulating materials. There is an explanation of how insulation works and how heat can be transferred by conduction, convection and radiation. More able pupils could use this site.

Sheffield Hallam

www.shu.ac.uk/schools/sci/sol/invest/logging/physics/heat.htm

Suitable for KS2 teachers

Data logging software is required. An experiment is suggested in which temperature sensors are placed in two beakers of warm water. One beaker is wrapped in insulating material. The software can then produce a graph of the results so that comparisons can be made.

BECTa

curriculum.becta.org.uk/docserver.php?docid=1456

Suitable for KS2 teachers

Offers plenty of suggestions for investigations within the theme, including a consideration of the clothes we wear and the materials they are made from.

Temperature

www.unidata.ucar.edu/staff/blynds/tmp.html

Suitable for KS2/3 teachers

A comparison between fahrenheit and celsius, celsius and centigrade (yes, there is a slight difference), and how to convert between scales.

fields.headline: Book reviews
fields.trailText: Linsey Fraser looks at Saying Goodbye by Ifeoma Onyefulu, and Pure Dead Magic by Debi Gliori
fields.body:
Saying Goodbye
Ifeoma Onyefulu
(Frances Lincoln)
Price £10.99
Age 6-10 yrs

One in a series of books illuminating life in an Igbo community in Nigeria, by a writer and photographer who grew up there. The author's son, Ikenna, shows the elaborate rituals involving the whole community as they remember the extraordinary life of the author's grandmother, Mama Nkwelle. Culturally, this is a fascinating story, simply described with photography that is informal and informative, powerfully evoking the time and care taken to remember a respected family member. But essentially the book is about Ikenna who has lost a great-grandmother, and the importance of shared memories in celebrating her remarkable life.

Pure Dead Magic
Debi Gliori
(Doubleday, £10.99 )
Age 9-14 yrs

This, the first novel from a prolific creator of picture story books, will easily find devotees amongst younger, confident readers, but should also appeal to older pupils seeking something original, challenging, entertaining and, frankly, bizarre. The Strega-Borgia family is not dysfunctional - like most families it has its eccentricities, arguments and resolutions. It's just that they involve hitching lifts on emails; brushes with the Mafia; large, dim beasts in dungeons; and a host of larger-than-life human and animal characters. The result is a warm and hilarious, highly individual literary style which crackles with energy.

This title mainly covers literacy and numeracy but there are also opportunities to cover musical composition, geography, ICT, design and technology and art. fields.headline: On the board
fields.standfirst: The diary of a parent governor
fields.trailText: The diary of a parent governor
fields.body:
Confession: for the first time since taking a place on the governing body I missed a curriculum committee meeting.

I felt a little guilty - even though I was able to give my apologies the day before - but a work crisis intervened so, inevitably, paid work took precedence over the unpaid, voluntary kind.

Our governing body struggles for attendance, but, at least in theory, we can put bums on plastic seats. Currently, there are no vacancies - although that may change if the head starts enforcing the statutory six-month rule.

Failure to attend a single meeting over a six-month period means being automatically struck off, even if you've been more forthcoming and punctual with your apologies than President Bush.

But when you consider the demands on most working parents, not to mention those on single parents, it is hardly surprising that most governing bodies are short of bodies. The Labour group on the Local Government Association has suggested this might be remedied by paying expenses up to £1,000 a year, rather like jury service. It's a good idea, but seems unlikely to happen.

Truth be told, the curriculum committee meetings are not scintillating affairs. They don't have the dangerous glamour of disciplinary committee meetings, nor the heady power of the finance committee. Indeed, they have tended recently to be an opportunity for a good moan and a gossip. I veer between thinking that this is useful feedback and feeling like a fly on the staffroom wall.

The problem is that, even if I've at least done my homework, I still lack special knowledge of education. The usual moan in the committee meeting is about how little fun teaching is now that the curriculum is so prescribed: there's no room for manoeuvre, they say, no time for the creative projects that used to make lessons so rewarding.

Under the yoke of the national curriculum, they have the mentality of a defeated army.

Last weekend, I was chatting to the mother of a friend of Lucy's who is a freelance writer of educational textbooks. She's just finishing one about post-war immigration to Britain for the new citizenship lessons. I tell her about the teachers' complaint.

"But that's completely wrong," she says brightly. "The national curriculum hasn't been compulsory for over a year - not since the literacy and numeracy hours came in. When they became compulsory, the rest of the curriculum stopped being."

I feel foolish. How could I not know this crucial information? But, more important, how could the teachers themselves not know?

"Well, the law keeps changing, and it is difficult to keep track," she explains. "But also the DfEE basically wants schools to follow the national curriculum, so it's not surprising that they don't advertise the fact it's no longer statutory."

I can't wait to tell the committee the good news. But I'm also depressed: this was just a chance discovery. Only as a professional educationist would I have had a chance of finding it out otherwise. So what's the point of the amateur governor?
