fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: We suspect our daughter is being singled out at school by a new head of year. This lady will remain our daughter's head of year until she leaves.  Our daughter is otherwise very happy at school, hard working and attaining good grades.  Our dilemma is whether or not to intervene
fields.trailText: We suspect our daughter is being singled out at school by a new head of year. This lady will remain our daughter's head of year until she leaves. Our daughter is otherwise very happy at school, hard working and attaining good grades. Our dilemma is whether or not to intervene
fields.body:
The head of year is a key figure for the pupil, and it's most important that parents have confidence in them, so the situation needs sorting out.

I would advise any parent in this situation to confide in the head, who is the person best placed to help them. Parents are sometimes wary of doing this for fear of making the situation worse or creating a fresh problem for their child.

On the contrary, however, there is an understanding that to make a success of schooling parents must work in partnership with the school. They should speak to the head either to put their own minds at rest or to change their daughter's perception that she is being singled out.

A good head would be concerned to hear that there might be a problem - or that there is the perception of a problem. A good head would also listen to the parents and give them feedback, rather than just saying "Leave it to me".

The Girls' Day School Trust is the largest grouping of independent schools in the country, and owns and operates 25 girls' day schools with nearly 20,000 pupils. Their aim is to offer a high standard of education for a modest fee. For more information, tel 020 7393 6666.

John Boal, chief executive, the Girls' Day School Trust

Teachers can take exception to a particular child; with me it was my needlework teacher. But children are often unhappy about parents marching in to see teachers. If there is another opportunity for contact, perhaps at a parents' evening, this could be a more gentle way in than demanding an appointment.

If no headway is made and they have to speak to someone more senior, they should make sure they have their facts straight, with actual incidents and examples. They could present what I call a positive- negative-positive sandwich: begin by saying they are very pleased with their daughter's progress, then mention the problem and finally ask "what can we do about it?" rather than demanding "what are you going to do?"

However, fighting your own battles is good preparation for adult life, and letting children sort things out themselves can be a positive thing. It depends on the individual child.

Elaine Douglas, chartered psychologist

Elaine Douglas's website can be found at www.eda-iom.co.uk tel 01624 629264.

It depends on the organisation of the school whether this teacher is a big part of the child's life. As head of year, she's likely to be a subject teacher, take the register and co-ordinate reports - but if she isn't teaching a core subject, like maths or English, the child may not actually see her too much.

The parents should ask their daughter if she wants them to intervene. If not, they could help her review the situation and work out tactics to query what she feels is unfair.

There may even be ways in which their daughter could alter her own -behaviour, as sometimes it's not just from one side that things don't gel. For example, shyness can be misinterpreted as rudeness, or if the child is treated as an adult at home, she may need to adjust her behaviour when in school.

It might also be worth finding out whether her friends also find this teacher difficult to get on with, or whether their daughter is getting things out of proportion.

If they feel it's necessary to intervene, the parents should mention the situation informally and try to get to know the teacher themselves.

If they feel it's too embarrassing or difficult to approach the teacher directly, they should talk to the head, or whoever is in charge of pastoral care.

A big element in all this however, could simply be helping their daughter learn to cope with life's difficulties. Being able to work with someone you don't have a natural rapport with is part of growing up.

Whatever the situation, the child needs to know she has her parents' support to enable her to cope.

Anne Jarvis chair of the Association of London Governments Education Panel

Coming next

My daughter has an August birthday and could start reception at four and four months. However, I feel that's too young, and the school isn't keen on her going part-time. I know reception is mostly play, but it's putting her in an institutional setting so early that concerns me.

Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about his or her school? Each week we ask leading experts to advise on a specific issue. webTitle: How some schools are stocking their classrooms with £75 computers?

fields.headline: PC gone mad
fields.standfirst: Budgets are tight, so how are some schools stocking their classrooms with £75 computers?  Claire Phipps explains
fields.trailText: Budgets are tight, so how are some schools stocking their classrooms with £75 computers? Claire Phipps explains
fields.body:
Aquestion: how does a headteacher square the fact that a school has a budget of £1,000 to spend on computers with the national curriculum requirements of the 120 pupils needing to use them? Answer: pick up a dozen PCs, stash the change in the school kitty and get cracking on that ICT syllabus.

Not as fantastical as it might sound. Thanks to a scheme that matches unwanted PCs with technology-hungry schools, headteachers could find themselves taking delivery of a fleet of computers at just £75 a throw. No begging, borrowing or stealing required.

"Schools have been able to buy equipment bit by bit over time, but now they can take big leaps. It makes an enormous difference," says Jan Tallis, chief executive of Tools for Schools, the organisation - supported by the Guardian - that has taken on the challenge of providing a computer for every classroom desk in the UK. As if that weren't ambitious enough, Tallis, in her third week at the helm of TFS, is preparing tomorrow to launch a new scheme aimed specifically at London schools.

With the active assistance of London First, a consortium of major companies that promotes business in the capital, TFS is setting out to requisition 100,000 PCs from offices over the next three years.

Second-hand monitors cluttering up the school corridors might not be every pupil's dream of an IT-friendly learning environment but there is, insists Tallis, no reason for noses to be turned up at the offer of discarded goods. After all, many schools have relied in the past on the goodwill of local businesses to restock computer rooms, with mixed results.

"Donating locally is fraught with problems," Tallis explains. "There's often no support, no refurbishment and health and safety issues. With TFS that's all looked after." All PCs donated must meet minimum standards - Pentium processors, internet capacity - and are further refurbished by TFS so that, for example, disks are wiped to "Ministry of Defence standards".

So, that's the schools happy. But why - apart from warm feelings of philanthropy - should companies be eager to hand over their equipment? Tallis is adamant that there's a lot in it for them, too. "In the long term, they're creating an IT-literate workforce for the future, by reducing the student-to-PC ratio." And there are more immediate benefits - EU legislation requires that 90% of IT equipment and 70% of monitors must be recycled or reused. "So, in the short term, it has an environmental and economic impact. Monitors are very difficult to recycle but are great for schools. We can take them from the business at no cost to them."

All very well for those London schools for whom a herd of computers is just a jumble sale away. But Tallis is eager to see the initiative spread further. In the past two years, TFS has equipped 500 schools nationally with 10,000 PCs at £95 each. It's the involvement of London First in the capital that has made life easier and caused the prices to fall. "The demand from schools is there," says Tallis. "The supply end is the problem. But if this works as a model, then we're keen to take it nationally. We just need the local chamber of commerce to come and work with us."

Tools for Schools: 020-7689 1990 or www.tfs.org.uk London First: 020-7665 1521.

webTitle: Charity providing answer to problems of after-school care

fields.headline: Gaining ground
fields.standfirst: Schools need cash, parents need childcare and kids need something fun to do after school. Has one group found the answer to all of these problems?  Yvonne Roberts investigates
fields.trailText: Schools need cash, parents need childcare and kids need something fun to do after school. Has one group found the answer to all of these problems? Yvonne Roberts investigates
fields.body:
More and more schools are facing a similar dilemma: how to effect a miracle on their bleak, tarmac wasteland of a playground with next to no resources?

What's required is transformation so that the area will stimulate imaginative play, offer an outdoor "classroom", feed into the national curriculum, raise ecological awareness and allow children to take pride in their school's surroundings.

More often than not, the school and Parent Teachers' Association have little in the kitty, no millionaire benefactors or corporate sponsors in the offing and a dozen other pressing demands on the budget - such as leaking roofs, for instance.

And the creation of a 21st-century play area does not come cheap. A single piece of equipment - like swings, balancing beams or a Wendy house - can cost between £5,000 and £10,000. Even with a high volunteer input, landscaping, murals, floor games, climbing frames, tables and benches can easily push costs way beyond £50,000.

So how to make the dream come true? One solution may be to enlist outside help in establishing an after-school club, to generate extra cash.

A decade ago, Jackie Nunns, now the mother of a 13-year-old, ran a successful night club in London's West End with her husband.

They divorced, she sold her share in the club and, with the financial freedom that brought, decided that she wanted "to do something that involved children and the community and offered more social capital". She had no qualifications except her track record running a business.

In 1994, Nunns saw a part-time job for someone with "entrepreneurial flair" as a community development officer at Eardley Primary in south London. She was hired, Nunns says dryly, because the job had been advertised three times and no one else had applied.

Seven years on, she heads The Trojans Scheme, a multiple award-winning educational charity, which runs after-school clubs at 14 south London schools. It also runs holiday schemes and acts as a community catalyst, providing advice and guidance to four other London boroughs and numerous PTAs on how to create clubs. Crucially, it advises on how to access funding to improve school premises and playgrounds.

"Government aims, such as the creation of a national childcare strategy and the reduction of child poverty, mean that there is a lot of money out there - what is difficult is finding the people who have the time and skills to apply for the funding that's available. Trojans can help because it has learned how to do it," Nunns says.

Three years ago, Trojans opened an after-school club at Granton Primary School in Lambeth, south London. Now, more than 50 of the school's 320 children attend each day, and in September a breakfast club will open, also run by Trojans.

"We were wary at first about allowing outsiders in," explains Richard Courtenay, the school's finance manager. "We'd had our fingers burned with a previous scheme, but our reservations were soon overcome. Trojans knows what it's doing, and does it well - and it opens the gate to extras we wouldn't otherwise have."

The Trojans scheme is straightforward. A school provides rent-free premises and access to some equipment. Trojans keeps the fees at £3.25 a night, £1.50 for those on benefits or free if a parent acts as a volunteer (all volunteers are given training).

An after-school club means the premises are open a further 25% of the day so they have community use. Trojans, which mostly operates in areas where there is social deprivation, can therefore apply for government funding, from the Children's Fund and the Single Regeneration Budget, in addition to non-governmental trusts and grants.

Under the government's New Opportunities Fund for instance, £465 may be given for each after-school place created. A 50-place club will generate over £22,000. The school, Trojans and the children can then decide how best to spend the money.

At Granton, the arrival of Trojans generated £24,000, which was used to buy a mini-bus. More funding means that a playground improvement scheme is about to begin. Trojans also provides access to volunteers from corporate bodies who are able to help with, for example, playground redesign.

Trojans is also attractive because teaching staff do nothing once they have been invited in.

"Teachers can be very territorial," smiles Nunns."It takes about a year for us to calm the horses. We always have sufficient numbers of trained staff and volunteers so that we know who is where - and doing what."

Central to the Trojans philosophy is that children's views count. One child called the clubs Kids' Cities. "They like to see themselves as taking over the school," Nunns explains.

The name Trojans also came from a child: "She said she saw herself as safe in the club, and that outside was a dangerous place."

Clubs are highly structured - a mix of play, education and free time. No one is turned away. The first club at Eardley allocated 11 spaces but 33 children had to be accommodated. Three activities are offered each session, which run until 5.45pm. Among the activities are cookery, IT, drama, junk modelling, chess, martial arts, crafts and talks given by visiting tutors. A third of parents use the clubs as childcare, but its main aim is providing fun, fitness and educational play.

At Henry Cavendish Primary School in Lambeth, school governors heard about Trojans a year ago and asked Liz Antrobus, the head, to consider the scheme.

"I took a bit of convincing," she says. "I was particularly worried about who would keep it going and about security. From the outset, though, Trojans has proved such a bonus. The team who run it are very together, creative and dynamic and that in itself has an impact on everyone in the school."

At Henry Cavendish, Trojans took over a disused furniture and chemicals storeroom and toilets and, helped by offenders on community service orders, adapted them into an office, training centre and storage space. Volunteers on secondment from Nestlé have created murals; more re furbishment in the playground will begin next term.

Eighty per cent of small voluntary groups fold within the first 18 months. One of Trojans' aims is to offer support to improve the chances of sustainability. The organisation itself is not opening any more clubs until January. As it is, 14 clubs and three holiday schemes care for 460 children a day (up to the age of 11). That requires a turnover of £620,000, of which Trojans must raise £260,000.

In addition, in spite of an acute shortage of skilled staff, Trojans manages to attract a high proportion of young men and women from ethnic groups that reflect the community from which the children are drawn.

"I could use a team of three fundraising writers to apply for grants," says Nunns. "As it is, it's just me, and my energies could be better directed elsewhere. A clearer, simpler method of raising funds given for five years or longer instead of for one to three years now, would give us the freedom to do so much more."

Since 1997, after-school clubs have doubled in number and will double again to between 12,000 and 13,000 by 2004. Eventually, according to Anne Longfield of the campaigning group Kids Clubs Network, there will be two clubs to every three schools.

Trojans, for instance, hopes to create clubs for 11- to 15-year-olds and disabled children as well as continuing to wave its "Before" and "After" wand on school facilities.

"Setting up a club isn't difficult," Longfield says. "The problem is that many have small roots in sandy soil so they are very vulnerable. We need a system which doesn't rely on one set of parents or a single wonderful worker. Trojans functions well because it retains staff; it has stability and it knows how to make the system work."

"Our aim is straightforward," says Nunns. "We share our expertise and build partnerships. The rest, we hope, flows on from that."

webTitle: Staff face redundancy as extent of college deficit becomes clear

fields.headline: One million and counting
fields.standfirst: Staff face redundancy as extent of college deficit becomes clear. By  Francis Beckett
fields.trailText: Staff face redundancy as extent of college deficit becomes clear. By Francis Beckett
fields.body:
Waltham Forest College in east London is facing a financial crisis after running up a deficit of more than £1m between March and December last year. Most members of staff expect it to more than double by the end of this year. To cope with the situation, the college is stopping most A-level teaching to concentrate on vocational courses, and shedding up to 70 staff.

The crisis has hit the college at alarming speed. In March 2000 governors were told that the college was set to reach its financial targets. By December the deficit was being quoted at £1.1m. A new principal, Carol Gibson, took over on February 25 and told staff that the deficit was likely to grow. Some estimates put the likely eventual deficit as high as £2.7m.

The former principal, Mike Bourke, left unexpectedly last summer to become chief executive of Protocol Training, the training arm of the company which owns the controversial lecturers' agency, Education Lecturing Services. Mr Bourke, like the heads of many of the colleges which have found themselves in financial difficulties, was very keen on franchised courses and was chairman of FE21, the group of colleges which led the way on franchising.

He was close to David Eade, the principal of scandal-hit Barnsley College, where the Learning and Skills Council is now conducting a forensic audit, and whose tangled web of investments were revealed in the Guardian last month. Mr Bourke once sent senior staff to Barnsley to learn about Mr Eade's franchising methods. One of the training companies in which Mr Eade invested Barnsley College money has recently been acquired by Protocol Training, which is now run by Mr Bourke.

Many Waltham Forest College staff were surprised when he turned up at Protocol Training. They had been told that he had been headhunted by a venture capital company in the City.

Staff say that Mrs Gibson, who is married to Association of Colleges chief executive David Gibson, has approached the task of restructuring and making redundancies with unexpected ruthlessness, though she frequently tells staff meetings: "I'm so sorry it's all happened like this."

Trade unions including the Transport and General Workers' Union and the lecturers' union Natfhe have been told there may be up to 70 redundancies, though human resources director Robin Jones says this figure was given for the purposes of formal notification and he expects the final figure to be "substantially lower than 70".

The deficit includes a six-figure sum of money owed to the Further Education Funding Council - now the Learning and Skills Council - as a result of overestimating the amount of teaching in the college. This sum, says Mr Jones, has now been repaid.

As a result of Mrs Gibson's restructuring, many senior staff are forced to apply for new posts, which may or may not resemble the posts they currently hold. Their applications must be in by May 18. Four college directors have already agreed to take voluntary redundancy.

"This was a personal decision in the light of the circumstances" says Mr Jones. The restructuring, he says, will enable the college to concentrate on its strengths. It has always been stronger on the vocational side than on the A-level side, he says, and the college is "in an area where there are a number of good providers".

Last week Mrs Gibson was on holiday and Mr Bourke was unavailable for comment.

webTitle: A course to help new businesses stay afloat

fields.headline: Hang in there
fields.standfirst: John Crace discovers a course to help new businesses stay afloat
fields.trailText: John Crace discovers a course to help new businesses stay afloat
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever worked for someone else will know the feeling. Your boss is sad, mad or bad; your talents are wasted; your pay is a joke; in fact, all things considered, you could do much, much better yourself. Most people settle for a good moan and then knuckle under once more, but for some the voice telling them to strike out alone becomes irresistible. So they set themselves up in business. Which could be the worst mistake they ever made.

Eighty per cent of all new businesses fail within the first five years, and a further 80% of the remaining 20% will go under in the next five years. So after 10 years, just four out of 100 new businesses will still be up and running. Most people wouldn't put more than a fiver on the chances of a horse romping in at 25-1 but, when it comes to business, a surprising number of people are gambling their houses at those odds. Literally.

"The fatal assumption that causes most young businesses to fail," says Barry Fitzgerald, who has been running his own companies for more than 20 years, "is to imagine that because someone understands the technical work of a business, they automatically understand a business that does that technical work. Frankly, few things are further from the truth." In other words, being a qualified builder does not give you a God-given right to run your own construction company.

So where is a small businessman or woman supposed to turn for the key to success? Until comparatively recently the answer was nowhere. You learnt through a mixture of trial, error, luck and judgment, with error generally turning out to be the runaway winner as MBAs were the preserve of the few.

Which is where the E-Myth Mastery course comes in. The course was developed in the United States over 20 years ago, hence the E stands for Entrepreneur rather than anything netty. It has helped over 18,000 businesses worldwide, but has only taken off in the UK over the past two years.

Barry Fitzgerald was one of the first UK converts: "My businesses were ticking along OK but I wasn't re ally getting what I wanted out of them," he says. "One of the main initial attractions of working at home had been to work the hours I chose, and yet I hardly ever had time to spend with my wife and child."

Fitzgerald became so enthusiastic about what he was learning that he went on train to become a certified E-Myth coach. "The course is very practical," he says, "and everything is applied to the person's particular business with most of the coaching conducted over the phone to make the service as user-friendly as possible." The core of the programme is 21 modules, which typically cover areas such as management, leadership, marketing and finance, and the aim is to create a system that allows the person to run the business, rather than the business the person. "Take McDonald's," Fitzgerald continues. "The business model works perfectly with the restaurants being run by pubescent kids. When you buy a McDonald's franchise you're buying a system rather than a load of burgers."

Michael Taplin runs a kitchen design and installation business in Reading and employs six people. "I'd started off as a kitchen fitter," he says, "but when I started my own business I realised I was caught up in a whole load of admin, such as managing other people and payrolls, that I knew nothing about. I also rather naively assumed people would do the job that they were paid to do and I ended up doing a lot of things myself, which meant that I had less and less time for myself. I've been doing the course for six months and already things are beginning to pan out better."

The full course itself lasts for 18 months, although people are welcome to participate for shorter periods. At £495 per month it's not cheap, but as Fitzgerald points out, "it's less than half the cost of a company's cheapest employee and the long-term benefits are incalculable." He also offers a free introductory coaching session. What have you got to lose?

Barry Fitzgerald can be contacted on 02392 412299 or at barry.f@cwcom.net

webTitle: New moves to train rail workers

fields.headline: Futures on the line
fields.standfirst: In the wake of the Hatfield tragedy, moves are now on track to get rail workers properly trained, reports  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: In the wake of the Hatfield tragedy, moves are now on track to get rail workers properly trained, reports Nick Tester
fields.body:
High speed training for Britain's railworkers and train drivers now appears inevitable following the intervention by a minister and a devastating exposure by a man from the Mirror newspaper.

The debris following the fatal Hatfield crash last autumn had barely been cleared, when lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks voiced concern that "pitifully few" employees in the rail industry were equipped with nationally recognised qualifications.

Staggeringly, out of a national workforce of around 200,000, just 207 national vocational qualifications were awarded to rail employees in the four years to June 2001, he revealed. Just 24 drivers collected similar awards during the same period; the other 14,776 drivers remained empty-handed.

Coinciding with unprecedented anxiety over rail safety, imposed speed restrictions, service cancellations and recriminations, Wicks contacted Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority (SRA), to press for immediate talks to try torectify the lamentable situation.

Rail workers' training "urgently needs to be improved", Wicks demanded, suggesting that competing train operating companies would fail to win future franchise battles if "clear training and skills targets" were absent from their initial, core plans. "Training has become a casualty of privatisation," Wicks said.

Morton does not disagree. The Hertfordshire incident, in which four people died, was, according to the rail authority boss, a "pivotal episode" in the post-privatisation of the country's railways. The railway business had hit rock bottom, with a desperate shortage of skilled people cited as a root cause of its shattered reputation.

"Hatfield revealed problems we did not wish ever to see within our industry and occasioned a period of deep soul-searching," Morton admitted.

These deficiencies were succinctly exposed a couple of weeks later by Mirror journalist David Pilditch, whose disturbing report entitled "A day of lunacy" made grim reading.

"It took me just 10 minutes on my first day on the railways to be made a site manager in charge of briefing 18 men about safety on the line," Pilditch wrote after joining a trackside gang. "No matter that I had only two days' training. No matter that I did not have a clue what to do. No matter that I was colour blind."

He went on: "I had been told stories of how unqualified men were put to work on the track with little or no training after buying their jobs on the black market. Now I was seeing the truth for myself and it was frightening."

Pilditch said he paid £130 for a two-day course in track safety, £40 for a basic medical test and £30 for a pair of steel toe-capped boots.

"The workforce can be supplied by little-heard-of agencies employing anyone they can get hold of. Many of those who apply are moonlighting from other trades. No references were required and the section of my application form showing my 'skills' was left blank."

Perhaps the most devastating revelation was the observation of a rail manager. "People come in off the street and are sent to work with no training. They are out on their own and totally out of their depth. It's dangerous for them and the consequences for passenger safety are horrific.

"But the pressure is to turn men out so the contractors can get the job done on time."

Here is the deep-seated problem. Rail workers may have little or no skills and fewer prospects of obtaining fresh ones, but "work intensification" makes these limited prospects even more remote. Inevitably a reduced workforce, dealing with a higher number of trains and demanding passenger expectations, plus repairing damaged track within a shorter timescale, has resulted in the workers doing longer and more unregulated hours. Subcontractors are often clueless as to what's going on up or down the line.

Morton admits the "perfect fix" is not going to be achieved within months, following 175 years of evolution and seven years of privatisation. "It is in the nature of railways to move forward in carefully planned, slowly implemented steps or chaos will ensue," he says.

He accepts that the fundamental premises of privatisation were faulty, but says, it is time "to go forward, grow up, and cure, replace or repair our shortcomings - not go back to some hazy, but comfortable public sector womb. We need more resources - not only money but people, trained people, skilled people."

One positive outcome of the minister's concern has already emerged, with the publication last week of an 18-point action plan agreed by DfEE officials and representatives of the Strategic Rail Authority.

A pilot scheme has also been put in motion between the Learning and Skills Council and five rail companies - Railtrack, Virgin, GNER, Amey and Central - to develop 300 NVQs. Some 100 signalmen and drivers will be among the first to be tested for their existing skills, with checks made to identify how new skills can be acquired.

"There needs to be a very close relationship between the rail industry and the further education sector," he commented.

He expects rail companies will only win franchising bids if they first spell out their training intentions.

"Although this is a matter for the Strategic Rail Authority, I have asked how each company might set out their human resources as part of their bids, so that training really does become centre-stage."

This was the task envisaged by the Permanent Way Institution - so named to distinguish the permanent rails, sleepers and ballast from temporary track laid to build the railway. webTitle: So you want to learn about...press officers

fields.headline: So you want to learn about...press officers
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.body:
Can I speak to Alastair Campbell, please? Who wants him?

I'm from the press. Well you can **** right off for a start.

Sorry? The Gaffer can't stand Lobby correspondents.

Actually, I'm from Guardian Further. So you're merely scum rather than pond life.

Kind of you to notice the difference. Now that we're on speaking terms perhaps you could help me with the latest in our series of "So you want to learn about..." No problem. Let me guess, you must be up to P.

That's right. Oi, Alastair, the Guardian are doing P for prime minister and want a word.

Umm . . . it's P for press officer, in fact. Is it? Silly me. Still, it's an easy mistake to make. Look, I don't want to be unhelpful, but I'm not sure that Alastair is necessarily the person you want to speak to.

But isn't he the prime minister's? . . . Press secretary. Of course he is, but that doesn't mean he's the sort of person most employers are looking for. A typical press or public relations (PR) officer will have good written, verbal and organisational skills and will be excellent at dealing with a wide range of different people.

I'm beginning to get your drift. Any other important skills? Absolutely. You must be good at motivating yourself and others, keen to take responsibility and capable of working as part of a team. You must also be numerate with good budgeting skills.

Blimey. So there's a chance he'll become chancellor as well. My lips are sealed.

I get it, mum's the word. Tell me more about a press or PR officer's responsibilities. The main function is to promote and maintain good relations between the organisation and the public. This is a two-way process of gathering feedback and concerns from the public and passing them on to management and of promoting the organisation to the public.

Isn't this called spin? Don't be so cynical. It's just that the public often need a bit of help in seeing the fuller picture.

You mean, smoking as an expression of personal freedom rather than a slow form of suicide. Have you finished? OK, I'll continue then. Press and PR work is either done in-house or through an outside consultancy.

Like Sophie Rhys-Jones'? That wasn't quite the example I had in mind.

What sort of businesses use press and PR officers? Almost every medium-sized company will use them at some time. Officers work across all sectors from the arts and media to the consumer, financial and corporate. Work will include evaluating projects, making presentations, understanding how the media works, organising special events, such as trade fairs, and producing films and websites.

It sounds fun. Can anyone do it? Some employers will insist on a degree, but personal skills are often as important as academic qualifications. However, almost everyone will be expected to have at least five GCSEs. Larger companies will also offer their own staff training and may encourage employees to attend courses run by the Communications and Marketing education Foundation Ltd (CAM) or the Institute of Public Relations (IPR).

When can I start? This is the bad news. Entry into this work is extremely competitive with hundreds of times the applicants to available positions. But for those who do get in the prospects are bright. Starting salaries are roughly £15,000 and promotion is made on merit. An experienced PR might earn £25-30,000 while a head of corporate affairs might be making over £100,000. The sky's the limit if you're good.

You mean, you could even become PM? Goodbye.

 CAM Foundation Ltd
Moor Hall, Cookham, Maidenhead, Berkshire, SL6 9QH www.camfoundation.com

The Institute of Public Relations
The Old Trading House, 15 Northburgh Street, London, EC1V OPR www.ipr.org.uk

PRCA
Willow House, Willow Place, London SW1P 1JH
www.prca.org.uk

Scottish PR Consultants Association
62 The Shore, Leith, Edinburgh EH6 6RA

Information can also be found in your Local Library under reference OG

 Learndirect
0900 100900, www.learndirect.co.uk may be able to give futher information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Inspiring prospects
fields.standfirst: Transforming attitudes to learning is crucial to to improving skills, says  John Brennan
fields.trailText: Transforming attitudes to learning is crucial to to improving skills, says John Brennan
fields.body:
It is not surprising that a government white paper on the knowledge economy should focus on improving national competitiveness. Most of the chapter headings - the foundations of economic success, a people first economy, all regions to prosper, a climate for enterprise and growth, global ambition - signal a pre-occupation with familiar themes: the productivity gap compared with our main trading rivals, economic disparities between regions, the importance of investment in research and development, and the creation of a climate that encourages innovation.

Nor is the focus on the revolution in information and communication technologies surprising. A new small business incubator fund to boost the capacity for enterprise, an emphasis on supporting successful business clusters, measures to accelerate the take-up of broadband technology and digital TV, provide just a few examples of the role government is seeking to play in encouraging the creation of new business opportunities.

What is perhaps less expected is the emphasis throughout the white paper on improving individual skills to underpin these developments. The parallel publication of the government's response to the final report of the National Skills Task Force reinforces the message: the range of measures now being developed signals a growing determination to tackle the well- established UK skills gap.

Furthermore, the white paper assigns to the public vocational education and training system, and to colleges in particular, a key role in delivering the desired improvements. With priorities aimed at fostering greater creativity and innovative thinking, at overcoming poor levels of literacy and numeracy, at encouraging greater adult participation in learning,at developing a workforce with advanced ICT skills and knowledge to match international competitors, and at ensuring employers invest in the skills of all their employees, the objectives are clear. The principle vehicle for delivering this ambitious agenda is the Learning and Skills Council, working with a reformed national training organisation (NTO) network and using its powers to plan post-16 learning provision.

Programmes already announced for reducing the number of adults with poor basic skills and enhancing vocational learning are to be complemented by improvements in Modern Apprenticeships, and new programmes to boost the supply of ICT skills in schools and colleges.

An impressive agenda? Certainly - but one which leaves a number of important questions unanswered. For example, while the measures to improve the supply side of the education and training system are welcome, there is little which obviously addresses the demand side. The historic problems of the UK economy stem from a deep-seated unwillingness on the part of employers to engage in training, and on the part of individuals to recognise the enhancement of skills and qualifications as the key to personal and business success. As yet there is little sign of effective measures to address those problems.

Individual Learning Accounts have yet to establish themselves as the "big idea" which will transform attitudes. The National Skills Task Force shied away from a compulsory approach to training, in the face of resistance from employers, and the white paper does not move far from that position. The commitment to give statutory backing to voluntary sectoral agreements to tackle skills problems is, however, a tentative step in that direction.

Fresh thinking will be required if these questions are to be effectively tackled. The Learning and Skills Council - with its statutory duty to promote learning - will have a crucial role to play in this area, but the nature of that role has yet to be defined. Nor is the potential of ICT itself to transform learning and skills development fully acknowledged in the white paper. The considerable commitment already made by government to embedding ICT within the education and training system has, to date, largely focused on infrastructure, with relatively little attention paid to content and delivery.

So overall? Two cheers for recognising the crucial importance of skills development to future UK economic success, and the need to ensure it carries a priority at least equal to that of social exclusion as a driver of the education and training system. But full marks will have to await the completion of the agenda in the next parliament.

John Brennan is director of further education development at the Association of Colleges, but writes here in a personal capacity.

fields.headline: Working it out
fields.standfirst: Excuses, excuses. It's time to hand your coursework in, says  Donald Hiscock
fields.trailText: Excuses, excuses. It's time to hand your coursework in, says Donald Hiscock
fields.body:
It is that time of year again when computers start to do funny things and printers completely cease to function. In other words it's time for students to hand in their coursework. Or rather it's time to hear all the tired old excuses that you heard last year.

One of my students has been waving a floppy disk at me for the last fortnight whenever I mention her coursework. My plea for the final assignment is met with her reply that she just needs to go somewhere and print it off. Of course, the college computers seem to be incompatible with the one she uses at home.

The other day three grannies died, two cats got run over, there was a plague of period pain, someone had to help his dad put the roof back on the shed after a mini-tornado passed through the garden, there were umpteen cases of 24-hour flu and at least one alien abduction.

"I thought I saw you on the checkout when I went to do my shopping last night," I said to a student who claimed he had been bed-ridden with a dose of swamp fever.

"That was my brother. He looks just like me."

"So where's your work?"

And that brings me to another little routine. This is not strictly confined to this time of year, it is an all-purpose perennial. It goes something like this:

"Work?"

"It's in my bag, I'll just get it out."

Whenever a student says anything like the above, be suspicious. It can take a long time to retrieve a folder from a designer duffle bag. And, of course, this is all part of the ruse. When the folder is retrieved there are then a number of possibilities for the student.

Firstly, a prolonged flick through the folder yields the result that the work must be in the other folder. This will be at home. Secondly, the work is there but, oh, the last couple of pages are missing. For some strange reason these might be in a friend's car.

Thirdly, and this has had me fooled on a couple of occasions, you get the work handed in. You put it with the others, of which there are not many, and get on with the class. Later, you find that it is the assignment they handed in last time or work for a completely different course.

You could try this one yourself, the next time your line manager asks you for those retention statistics that you never got round to compiling.

But it was with a distinct feeling of unease that I went into my class on the day of their coursework deadline. There was the predictable rustling in bags, a few vacant stares and sudden exclamations. But everyone produced some work. I checked through the contents. This took a long time. But it was all there.

"Your work seems to be very similar to Rapinder's," I suggested to Roxanne.

"Coincidence," she said.

And there was an awful coincidence yet to come. I searched through my bag, pulled open drawers. I had forgotten the handouts for the day's class. Perhaps my printer had run out of ink, the dog had been sick in my briefcase, my car had been broken into or a block of frozen toilet waste from a passing jumbo jet had come crashing through my office window destroying the computer.

I made my excuses to the class. And they left.

webTitle: Why Junior Chamber is a network for young go-getters

fields.headline: In good company
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley discovers a network for young go-getters
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley discovers a network for young go-getters
fields.body:
Every one knows the networking and business opportunities offered by Chambers of Commerce, Round Table, Rotary and Lions Clubs, but are you aware of a rather more low-profile organisation with a nonetheless impressive array of distinguished international alumni?

British Junior Chamber, as it is somewhat haltingly called, is one of more than 120 national junior chambers worldwide that are affiliated to Junior Chamber International, an international business network consisting of some 400,000 members in 125 countries.

The international association's alumni number President Jack F Kennedy, President Chirac of France and Kofi Annan, UN secretary gen eral. Founded some 81 years ago in St Louis, Missouri, by the local Chamber of Commerce, Junior Chamber, a non-political organisation with no religious affiliations, helps young people develop their skills and confidence professionally and socially in a local, national and international context.

British Junior Chamber has 1,000 members in 52 branches in England, Wales and Northern Ireland - Scotland has its own Junior Chamber.

The idea is to offer "out of hours" personal development, leadership training and networking opportunities to managers and professionals aged between 18 and 40.

Joe Dilger, 33, deputy national president of the British Junior Cham ber and a project manager for the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants, says that the intention is to help individuals fulfil their potential at work and socially. Individuals are encouraged to learn by action-centred doing.

The chamber offers members opportunities to develop their management and leadership skills by managing such projects as the annual lord mayor's parades and shows in Belfast and Manchester, and by practising their public speaking and presentation skills in front of fellow members in a risk-free setting.

Members also get the chance to attend and organise seminars looking at issues such as the balance between work and leisure, or "the paradox of prosperity", and to network with other members worldwide. Many junior chamber branches combine their annual black-tie dinners with fund raising for charity.

Christina Magnowska, regional group chairman of the south-east region of the British Junior Chamber and a relationship manager for Barclays Merchant Services, said she was attracted by the training opportunities and the chance to widen her circle of friends.

"My experience has varied from organising a port-tasting weekend in Oporto to speaking in front of 16 City business people and being interviewed on LBC radio about Junior Chamber."

Colin Parsons, chairman of Taylor Woodrow plc from 1992-1999, recommends involvement in the Junior Chamber as "an excellent training ground" and "a lot of fun".

President Kennedy once said: "At Harvard I did my learning, Junior Chamber gave me learning for life."

Website: www.bjc.org.uk Telephone: 01476-404005.

The idea is to offer "out of hours" personal development, leadership training and networking opportunities to managers and professionals aged between 18 and 40. Joe Dilger, 33, deputy national president of the British Junior Cham ber and a project manager for the Chartered Institute of Management Accountants, says that the intention is to help individuals fulfil their potential at work and socially. Individuals are encouraged to learn by action-centred doing. The chamber offers members opportunities to develop their management and leadership skills by managing such projects as the annual lord mayor's parades and shows in Belfast and Manchester, and by practising their public speaking and presentation skills in front of fellow members in a risk-free setting. Members also get the chance to attend and organise seminars looking at issues such as the balance between work and leisure, or "the paradox of prosperity", and to network with other members worldwide. Many junior chamber branches combine their annual black-tie dinners with fund raising for charity. Christina Magnowska, regional group chairman of the south-east region of the British Junior Chamber and a relationship manager for Barclays Merchant Services, said she was attracted by the training opportunities and the chance to widen her circle of friends. "My experience has varied from organising a port-tasting weekend in Oporto to speaking in front of 16 City business people and being interviewed on LBC radio about Junior Chamber." Colin Parsons, chairman of Taylor Woodrow plc from 1992-1999, recommends involvement in the Junior Chamber as "an excellent training ground" and "a lot of fun". President Kennedy once said: "At Harvard I did my learning, Junior Chamber gave me learning for life." Website: www.bjc.org.uk Telephone: 01476-404005.

fields.headline: Beauty and the beasts
fields.standfirst: When Sam heads  into Zambia to visit one of the most diverse - and scenic - wildlife parks in Africa, even conversations about his companions' baby's bowel movements fail to spoil his mood
fields.trailText: Week 20: Nkharta Bay to South Luangwa National Park When Sam heads into Zambia to visit one of the most diverse - and scenic - wildlife parks in Africa, even conversations about his companions' baby's bowel movements fail to spoil his mood
fields.body:
Our time at Njaya Lodge had been lovely and tranquil but eventually we tore ourselves away and returned to Lilongwe. This involved the usual exciting bus journey. The first leg, Nkharta Bay to Mzuzu, was in a pick-up full of bananas and included an unscheduled stop at a police roadblock. Unfortunately our driver's insurance was out of date and he was hauled away by the police out of sight of the mzungus. I was expecting a severe beating or electrodes on the testicles at the very least, but he soon returned cheerfully tearing up the ticket. A small 'tip' for the police had sorted everything out.

We spent the night at a resthouse in Mzuzu and got up early on Sunday to catch the 7am express bus to Lilongwe. Despite the normal chaos at the bus station but we found a biggish looking bus with 'Lilongwe' written on a board in the windscreen. I stepped up and asked the driver if this was the express. He said yes it was, 450 kwatcha (about four pounds) each please. We paid up and sat down. Ten minutes later I saw a bus which was clearly the real express drive past the entrance. The lady next to us confirmed this and said our bus wouldn't be leaving until it was full.

H and I went over to have a shout at the driver. It was too late by then, of course, but it made us feel better and started a lively discussion amongst the other passengers. They broadly split into two camps: the irate women ("You should not cheat the mzungus!") and the more sanguine men ("Business is business."). The driver kept his head down and looked suitably abashed.

After an hour the bus was full and we set off. Forty five minutes later, inexplicably and to the great delight of our driver, we overtook the express bus labouring up a hill.

I find Africa maddening and wonderful in turn. All you can do is sit back and go with the flow.

The remainder of the journey was uneventful apart from a chicken falling on to my head out of the roof rack.

We only had an afternoon in Lilongwe. This was just as well as we'd exhausted the entertainment options after half an hour and spent the rest of the day in the bar of the old colonial Imperial Hotel.

Our real reason for coming back to the capital was to travel across the border into Zambia's South Luangwa National Park. In terms of accessibility and sheer numbers of game, South Luangwa is one of the best wildlife parks in Africa and offers a wilderness experience that the parks in Malawi can't match. We had booked a tour with Land and Lake Safaris, and were at their office early on Monday morning. Our guides were Godfrey (a Zambian) and Eric (Malawian). Our fellow passengers consisted of three Finnish girls and an expat couple and their 16-month-old baby.

It was a long, hot, dusty drive to the Luangwa valley. It was still the rainy season and once we had crossed the border, the road deteriorated into a pot-holed, track. Even with the two large four-wheel-drive Land Rovers we were rarely able to get over 30km/hour.

But the journey was interesting nonetheless. We swept through small towns with traders frying chips or selling sugar canes and peanuts by the side of the road. We saw small boys struggling on their bicycles with huge bags of maize flour - the staple food here. At one point our vehicle got a puncture. Godfrey and Eric jumped out and changed the wheel with practised ease. Five minutes later we were on the move again. For them this was just another trip along another African road. The expat couple, who were surprisingly unprepared for the journey, helped by complaining the whole way. The baby was fine - it was the parents who did all the whining.

Nearing the Park, the track suddenly turned into a tarmac road. This was the route the Zambian President used when taking his guests to see the wildlife, so of course it was well-maintained.

We were all relieved to reach the camp in late afternoon. The lodge was situated just outside the Park in a serene spot overlooking the Luangwa river. Families of baboons played in the trees and we could see hippos wallowing across the water.

Early the next morning, Godfrey took us into the Park in search of big game. Perched on top of the Land Rover we had an excellent view, and soon came across herds of elephant. They always seemed a bit annoyed at our arrival. Most would turn their backs on us in disgust but occasionally a large, tusked female would trumpet at us in anger. There were tall, languid giraffe who stared at us with utter surprise and would then carry on munching. There were colourful birds and skittish antelope such as impala, and puku.

We did two game drives during the day and saw some amazing wildlife. I was more than happy, but Godfrey didn't seem satisfied. He kept shaking his head and muttering about how quiet it was. He was most disappointed that he hadn't found any lions and joked that he would have to send lots of emails to the relevant authorities that night to see if they could organise something for us tomorrow.

Back at the lodge we had an excellent dinner. It turned out that Godfrey used to be in charge of the anti-poaching strategy in the Park. He would lead teams of armed men into the bush and, camping out at night and tracking the poachers during the day, they would try and ambush them in the act. It was dangerous work and many of his men were injured and even killed.

The expat couple kept wanting to talk about breast-feeding, and how clever their baby was at managing regular bowel movements. The baby baboons could manage regular bowel movements too, but I wasn't expecting them to be intellectuals when they got older.

The next day Godfrey was clearly on a mission to find some lions for us. We covered a lot of ground and did just spot the rear end of a female disappearing into the bush. Unfortunately she refused to come out and give us a proper look.

It was on the final drive of the trip that Godfrey triumphed. We went back to the place where we had seen the female in the morning. And there with the sun setting behind them, lay two very content, well-fed lions. We got quite close but they completely ignored us. As far as these beautiful, powerful creatures were concerned, we were of absolutely no threat. In a hushed silence we watched them pad about.

Godfrey drove us back to the lodge with a happy smile on his face. The emails had clearly paid off.

fields.headline: A life lived in threes
fields.standfirst:
How small can a genome be and still
                                                                                              remain functional? Henry Gee
                                                                                              investigates
fields.trailText: How small can a genome be and still remain functional? Henry Gee investigates
fields.body:
Once upon a time, many hundreds of millions of years ago, a few bacteria - a committee of microbes - got together to form the first eukaryote, the first cell with an organised nucleus. After a while, almost all of the bacteria in this happy union submitted all their genes to this moloch of the nucleus, ceasing to exist as independent entities. The one holdout was the bacterium that became the mitochondrion - then, as now, the energy powerhouse of the cell.

Even today, the mitochondria of eukaryotic cells (yours and mine included) have small, bacterium-like genomes, entirely separate from the much larger genome of the cell nucleus. Some of these simple cells swallowed small, photosyn thetic bacteria, nature's own solar power cells: to invert Swift, capable of distilling sunshine into cucumbers. Like mitochondria, these bacteria retained a vestige of their own genomes even within the larger, symbiotic union.

They became the so-called chloroplasts, and with them, the first cells of green plants appeared. Even then, that was not the end of the story. Some of these simple plant cells - each loaded with a nucleus, a mitochondrion and a chloroplast - were swallowed by larger cells without chloroplasts. The results of this secondary symbiosis can be seen in many apparently simple green algae, whose chloroplasts seem enveloped in an unseemly complexity of membranes: the swallowed plant cell has lost most of its matter, its mitochondrion and even its nucleus, leaving just a chloroplast shrouded in the membranes, the husk of what was once a creature with its own destiny.

Well, almost. There are some single-celled algae, the romantic and mysteriously named cryptomonads, in which the secondary symbiont retains a tiny nucleus in addition to the chloroplast. The cryptomonad cell wears this shrivelled second nucleus, or "nucleomorph" the same way a headhunter would wear the shrunken heads of its enemies slung on its belt. But even after hundreds of millions of years of slavery, the nucleomorph is still not quite dead. Indeed, it may have much to teach us. In today's Nature, Thomas Cavalier-Smith, of the University of Oxford, and colleagues pre sent the complete sequence of the genome of the nucleomorph of a cryptomonad, called Guillardia theta.

Compacted into three, minute chromosomes, the nucleomorph contains 551,264 basepairs of DNA. It is the smallest eukaryote genome sequenced so far. For comparison, the human genome is 6,000 times the size. The genome of the leprosy bacterium Mycobacterium leprae - itself a relic of a much larger genome - is six times the size of the nucleomorph genome. But whereas the human genome is more than 90% junk, the nucleomorph genome is a model of succinct organisation. Its 551 genes are packed together with a density unknown in eukaryotes.

There is virtually no repetitive DNA or wasted gaps between genes - 44 of the genes even overlap, a feature virtually unknown outside the super-concise genomes of viruses. Not that the nucleomorph genome is a powerhouse of activity. The remorseless pressure of millions of years, in which virtually all the activities of the cryptomonad cell have devolved to the much larger principal nucleus, have left the nucleomorph with virtually no genes associated with any kind of metabolic activity. Of all its remaining genes, just 30 seem to be connected with the maintenance of the chloroplast. All the other genes - more than 400 - are concerned with genomic housekeeping, functions such as DNA replication.

These genes seem to be essential to keep the nucleomorph functioning as an independent genomic entity: teleologically, to support the 30 genes that seem necessary to attend to the chloroplast. This peculiar, desperate genome, hanging on to its own independence by its metaphorical fingernails, could have a lot to teach us about genome design. It could be the smallest possible genome that it is possible for a eukaryote to have.

This begs the question of why these nucleomorphs survive at all, when those of most of their relatives perished millions of years ago to leave lone and unattended chloroplasts. It could be that the nucleomorph is maintained because its particular service to the chloroplast in cryptomonads is vital.

Even allowing for what seems a somewhat ad-hoc explanation, one is entitled to ask why - if only for these nucleo morphs - there seems to be an irreducible genomic minimum? The answer, like so many things in biology, lies in comparisons with other creatures. Cryptomonads are not the only organisms whose chloroplasts retain a sliver of a remnant nucleus. Nucleomorphs, derived from an entirely independent symbiotic event from that which created cryptomonads, are also found in a group of single-celled organisms called chlorarachniophytes.

Although only distantly related to cryptomonads, these creatures also contain chloroplasts with attendant nucleomorphs of about the same size as that found in cryptomonads. Furthermore, the genomes of these nucleomorphs are divided into three minuscule chromosomes. Such a case of close, parallel evolution demands some explanation, and it comes from lateral thought.

Rather than asking the question of why the nucleomorph could not get any smaller, Cavalier-Smith and colleagues pose a deceptively simple question - why do the nucleomorphs of cryptomonads and chlorarachniophytes have just three chromosomes? Why not, say, two, or four, or six? The answer could be that to package the genome into one or two chromosomes would create a single stretch of DNA too long to divide reliably in the confined cell-within-cell space available.

On the other hand, dividing the DNA into more than three chromosomes would have led to chromosomes too small to be stable - chromosomes that would have fizzled away to nothing. Three seems to be the magic number that has allowed this weird, condensed, resilient genome to survive for long enough such that it can be wondered at by another eukaryote - this one a multicellular creature, put together by another committee of smaller beings - ourselves.

 Henry Gee is a senior editor of Nature.

fields.headline: You will have lift-off, Russia tells space tourist
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: A US businessman who has paid $20m to be the first space tourist will make his controversial flight to the international space station this weekend after all, the Russian space agency (RSA) promised yesterday.
fields.body:
A US businessman who has paid $20m to be the first space tourist will make his controversial flight to the international space station this weekend after all, the Russian space agency (RSA) promised yesterday.

Dennis Tito, 60, an investment manager from California, "will travel to the space station no matter what", an RSA spokesman, Sergei Gorbunov, said. "We will guarantee Mr Tito's safety during the flight."

NASA, one of the Russians' partners in the space station, had earlier said only that talks were under way on whether Tito would be allowed to make the trip.

This contradicted earlier statements from the Russian agency that NASA and the Canadian, European and Japanese space agencies had already reached an agreement on the journey into space.

Nasa wants Mr Tito to sign an agreement swearing not to sue if anything goes wrong and to reimburse the agency if he breaks anything.

"I don't know what Dennis Tito has signed or not signed," a Nasa spokesman said. "We're continuing to talk with the Russians and other international partners. An agreement is probably the wrong word to use at this point. We are waiting to get an understanding, looking to get some consensus on Dennis Tito's flight.

The US agency has expressed objections to Tito, travelling to the space station over several weeks, saying it was "concerned about (his) level of training" and possible danger to the lives of the professional cosmonauts.

Mr Tito, who was rocket scientist before setting up his investment firm, has paid for the privilege of being taken into orbit aboard a Russian Proton rocket on Saturday. Two days later he is due to enter the station for the 10 day-long mission.

Mr Tito and the two Russian cosmonauts he plans to accompany, team leader Talgat Musabayev and navigator Yury Baturin, arrived at the Baikonur cosmodrome in Kazakhstan where they were undergoing final preparations.

Russian television station ORT showed images of Mr Tito, smiling and apparently fit, as he arrived at the installation with the two Russians.

Tensions over Tito's voyage boiled over in March, when his two Russian Soyuz crew mates walked out of preflight training at Johnson space center in Houston after Mr Tito was barred by NASA from participating. They eventually returned to the training program.

fields.headline: Nycomed delays life science flotation
fields.trailText: Healthcare group Nycomed Amersham's plans to float its $3.5bn life sciences unit in the United States have been put on hold until stockmarket conditions improve.
fields.body:
Healthcare group Nycomed Amersham's plans to float its $3.5bn life sciences unit in the United States have been put on hold until stockmarket conditions improve.

The Nasdaq flotation of APBiotech was due to take place in "the spring" but the chief executive, Sir William Castell, yesrterday admitted that market turbulence now made that unlikely.

"We will only go when markets stabilise and our bankers say the time is right," he said. "Our business is generating profits and cash, so it's not as if we have to go to the market to raise money. We will be prudent with our timing."

Nycomed underlined its long-term commitment to the listing by reporting quarterly figures in line with Nasdaq requirements for the first time. Results for the three months to the end of March were slightly ahead of analysts' expectations and the shares climbed 8.5p to 485.5p.

Group sales rose 16% to £375m but it was sales at APBiotech that interested analysts most. They climbed 21% to £154m, a figure slightly distorted by the inclusion of sales delayed from the end of last year and a favourable comparison with a weak corresponding period last year.

Analysts said the upbeat statement should give investors confidence at a time when rival s were being forced to slow spending.

webTitle: Vatican at war over reformer's legacy

fields.headline: Vatican at war over reformer's legacy
fields.standfirst: Old guard say Vatican II speech was distorted
fields.trailText: A power struggle in the Vatican has burst into the open with the claim that liberals nobbled one of the most influential speeches in papal history.
fields.body:
A power struggle in the Vatican has burst into the open with the claim that liberals nobbled one of the most influential speeches in papal history.

Pope John XXIII's opening address to the second Vatican council in 1962, which reformed the Catholic church, has been misunderstood, it is alleged, because translators purged its conservatism.

The Vatican newspaper, Osservatore Romano, said that progressive forces hijacked the agenda by excising a key passage which defended doctrine and continuity. Its chief theologian, Gino Concetti, said that successive Italian translations of the Latin text had distorted its explosive impact.

Analysts said Sunday's article was an opening shot before next month's extraordinary consistory in Rome, at which cardinals and bishops will debate the direction of the church. Traditionalists are mobilising to rebuff an expected assault from progressives who want more democracy and open thinking.

The victors are likely to be those who succeed in claiming the legacy of Vatican II, which between 1962 and 1965 agreed reforms which still gust through the church.

Its guiding force, John XXIII, electrified the gathering by embracing modernity with a vision of a pastoral church of mercy, charity and optimism.

Fr Concetti said the address, on October 11 1962, had been distorted by the omission of two significant phrases: "the truth contained in our venerable doctrine" and "always conserving the same meaning and the same values".

The next day's Osservatore Romano carried the Latin text and a flawed Italian translation which dropped the two qualifications and paved the way for four decades of misunderstanding, Fr Concetti said.

By seizing on his word aggiornamento - updating - liberals effectively appropriated the authority of John XXIII. "Deviant steps were the result," he said

Critics ridiculed the accusation. There was no cover-up since the Latin text had been freely available to scholars and some translations included the phrases, Alberto Melloni, an expert on the council, told La Repubblica.

The pope wrote the text in Italian and it was translated into Latin for the address. The version translated back into Italian for Osservatore Romano was closer to his original meaning than the Latin, he added.

John XXIII would have had time to correct significant errors, since he lived another eight months, until June 1963.

John Allen, Vatican correspondent for the National Catholic Reporter, said the row was a pre-emptive strike by traditionalists on the eve of the consistory.

"It is a first strike. People are putting down markers, as there is going to be pressure for greater collegiality and decentralisation of power." Collegiality is the Vatican's term for internal democracy.

The church is divided into those who think the council's spirit has gone too far and those who think it has not gone far enough.

The memory of John XXIII served as a proxy battle last year when John Paul II put him on the road to sainthood. Conservatives persuaded the Vatican to simultaneously beatify Pius IX, a 19th century reactionary.

Cardinal Karl Lehmann, head of the German hierarchy, raised the stakes at the weekend by calling for a third Vatican council to discuss collegiality.

The Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, cautiously put himself on the reformers' side when being made a cardinal this year.

Leading the defence of the status quo is Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, head of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, formerly known as the inquisition.

fields.headline: Turn the screw
fields.standfirst:
True market freedom means strictly regulating business so that everyone can thrive

Special report: globalisation
May Day 2001
fields.trailText: What should we be campaigning for? What is the antithesis of totalitarian capitalism? It isn't anarchy and it isn't a command economy. It's market freedom.
fields.body:
You can't help admiring their nerve. Last week, the pharmaceutical companies sought to persuade us that, far from climbing down, they had simply reached an agreement with the South African government. The collapse of their court case was, they assured us, "a success for all parties". If this is success, I can't wait to see what failure looks like.

It's true, however, that their humiliating victory doesn't seem to have done the drugs firms much harm. On Sunday we learnt that GlaxoSmithKline, one of the defeated plaintiffs, might launch a £150bn bid for a rival company. Corporate power shows little sign of retreating.

The people's movements now deployed against it are perhaps the biggest and most widespread popular risings the world has ever seen. Every major trade meeting is blockaded by protesters; every big corporation has attracted its own campaign. But there's one problem we keep encountering: we all know what we're against, but no one can agree what we're for.

Our movements, as a result, have been defined in purely oppositional terms: we are anti-globalisation, anti-corporate, anti-capitalist. But protest (from the Latin testare, to bear witness) means to testify for. Unless we start demanding solutions, our efforts will be wasted.

No one pretends that this is easy. To describe the anti-globalisation network as incoherent is not necessarily to denigrate it: its strength as well as its weakness lies in the extraordinary diversity of ideologies and interests it has mobilised. But the absence of a clearly visible collective agenda has encouraged some people to fill this vacuum with wishful thinking and homeopathic magic.

The belief that the Zapatista revolution, which owes much of its success to regional identity, class loyalty and geographical isolation, can be reproduced among the deracinated people of post-industrial cities is as desperate as the hope that planting cannabis in Parliament Square will persuade global capitalism to come out with its hands in the air. Indeed, it's hard to see, in most circumstances, how stateless self- organisation could help any but the strong.

Imagine, for example, what would happen to an autonomous community of blacks, next door to an autonomous community of rednecks in South Carolina. Or, as a friend of mine suggests, "the moment the anarchist utopia arrives, every Daily Mail reader in the country will pick up a shotgun and shoot the nearest anarchist".

So what should we be campaigning for? What is the antithesis of totalitarian capitalism? I believe that it isn't anarchy and it isn't a command economy. It's market freedom.

As your paper hurtles towards the bin, I should hasten to explain that my conception of market freedom is rather different to that of the neoliberals. A genuine free market is surely one which is free for everyone, rather than one in which the powerful are free to squeeze the economic life out of everyone else. The prerequisite of freedom, in other words, is effective regulation.

This means that in some respects the state will have to become not weaker - as both the anarchists and the neoliberals insist - but stronger. It must be empowered to force both producers and consumers to carry their own costs, rather than dumping them on to other people or the environment. It must be allowed to distinguish between the protection of workers, consumers and the ecosystem and trade protectionism.

Agreements such as those set by the World Trade Organisation, in other words, must be reversed. Rather than setting only maximum standards for the defence of people and the environment, they should set minimum standards, to which multinational companies must subscribe before they are licensed to trade. Opponents of this idea, such as our own development secretary, Clare Short, argue that this would penalise developing countries whose standards are lower than our own. But if we can accept that states should be subject to human rights laws, enforceable anywhere on earth, it's hard to see why corporations should be allowed to maim and poison the people of weaker nations.

If we are to reverse world trade treaties, however, first we must seek to democratise global decision-making. Perhaps we should envisage a world parliament, rather like the European parliament, governing the activities of global agencies.

True market freedom also demands that governments must stop rescuing corporations whenever they get into trouble. It requires that we remove such dispensations as limited liability (which allows corporations to wriggle out of their responsibilities) and ever more generous property rights (which grant them control over such fundamental commodities as knowledge, the genome, plant varieties, land and water). The privatisation of key public services, such as health and education, excludes most of the world's people from any effective form of participation in the market.

Commercial confidentiality, currently used by corporations to defend themselves from public examination of all kinds, should be redefined to protect only the knowledge which would be sought by industrial spies. Otherwise, companies should be subject to freedom of information laws of the kind which permit US citizens to scrutinise the state.

The sheer scale of some corporations has now become an impediment to democracy, dwarfing the power of both citizens and competitors. We should, perhaps, set a global limit, forcing all companies above a certain size to divest parts of their business. A global maximum wage, restricting managers and directors to a certain multiple of the salary of their lowest paid employees, would both restrain the coercive power of the rich and provide an incentive to raise the wages of the poor. And if a single corporate tax rate were set worldwide, companies would no longer be able to force governments to let them off the hook.

Most importantly, when a firm has caused significant public harm, states should be permitted, as once they were, to pronounce sentence of corporate death. The restrictive corporate charter, in other words, needs to be reintroduced. None of these regulations will survive however, unless, like the deregulatory measures being forced through everywhere, they are implemented globally.

In other ways, the grip of the state should be relaxed. As corporations have been deregulated, so citizens have been reregulated, partly in order to prevent them from challenging corporate power. Power needs be devolved not only from international bodies to the state, but also from the state to its citizens. Community planning exercises, for example, better determine how a neighbourhood should develop than delegated authority. A protective state is not incompatible with enhanced autonomy.

Some people will suggest that these proposals are too ambitious, others that they are reformist and tame. But the will for sweeping political and economic change is manifest worldwide, and the state is mandated not by the corporations but by its citizens. Conversely, proposals which first require a complete transformation of human consciousness are simply a refined form of despair. The revolution has begun. Isn't it time we had a programme?

 George Monbiot's column will appear on Tuesdays from now on
