fields.headline: The numbers game
fields.standfirst: Charter88's report gives the government a few black marks. But how realistic are their hopes for change based on popular movement?
fields.trailText: Charter88's report gives the government a few black marks. But how realistic are their hopes for change based on popular movement?
fields.body:
No surprise that Charter88's new pre-election report* should sound grudging. Labour's constitutional reforms are "impressive" in addressing the UK's democratic malaise but there are black marks for Blair's retreat on reform of the Lords and Commons, freer information and a written constitution.

Proportional representation (PR) is the big one. Voting in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland has been transformed but Labour also pledged a referendum on how Westminster MPs are elected. The system, according to Charter88's Pam Giddy, focuses attention on the tiny number (168,000 in 1997) who swing things in marginal seats.

In October 1998 Lord Jenkins reported in favour of a system known as alternative vote plus (AV+). This aims to keep a personal link between MP and constituency while giving minority parties a look in. Under AV+ voters number their preferences in the constituency section and if no candidate wins more than 50%, votes are redistributed until that happens. A second vote gets cast for a regional list of candidates, giving minorities their chance. So, for example, Scottish socialist Tommy Sheridan gets into the Holyrood parliament on Glasgow's regional list when he would have found it hard to win a constituency.

The chart shows how May 1997 would have turned out if the different kinds of PR had been used instead of first past the post. Anoraks say that the alternative vote is not truly proportional. The most radical and complicated form of choice is the single transferable vote, which is used in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. In multi-member constituencies, preference votes are allocated according to a pre-set quota. It is a way of ensuring minority parties are guaranteed a shout.

One of the paradoxes of PR - which Charter88 does not discuss - is that it requires disciplined parties. If they were weak and loose, "top up" would not work. But parties need proper funding and Charter88's prescription for state support risks locking in the existing distribution of party preferences rather than encouraging a different alignment.

Behind all this lies a deeper question, which is what political parties are for in an age when the broad ideological alignments of the last century are dissolving. Parties, like politicians, make an easy punchbag and Charter88 does not hold back. Their selection procedures are unfair and oligarchic. That is true but without them, how is sustainable democratic politics possible? A similar intellectual difficulty has come up in the commission on candidate selection convened by the Electoral Reform Society: imagine what a system comprising 650 different Martin Bells would look like.

Are political parties merely instrumental - the vehicles by which an interest group achieves changes to public policies in its favour? This, after all, was the reason why trade unions created a labour representation committee in 1900. Charter88 publishes a list of the constituencies where the black or minority ethnic vote is significant and so could influence the vote - if such voters thought of themselves and acted as a block. But that is to narrow the idea of representativeness. On this page recently Mark Wickham-Jones of Bristol University showed that the better the Tories do in the next election the smaller the proportion of women MPs. Charter88 notes that only three women have been selected in seats where MPs are standing down this year. (They are all Labour.) Lurking behind these anxieties about race and gender representation is a worryingly mechanical idea of politics. Many would be repelled by the idea that women MPs ought to attend to a specifically female agenda.

Charter88 is a ginger group. It might argue that to make the case for change in a conservative society such as ours you need to exaggerate and ignore the finer points of debate. For Charter88 each and every addition made to the amount of democratic decision-making in the UK is welcome. But this glorification of head count democracy needs to ask about the kind of decision that is properly made by a majority.

People are great activists in theory. When asked by pollsters people say they want to give more power to the Scottish parliament and Welsh assembly. Between a third and a half favour elected regional assemblies in the regions of England. Yes, they say, government power is too centralised (60%). Yes, they say, we should have PR for the Commons (53%). But on present evidence few would avail themselves of new opportunities to vote.

Take regional government inside England. The Blair government is roasted by Charter88 for ignoring it, at least until recently. But advocates of regional elected bodies need to consider their effect on elective democracy at local level in councils. There are real limits to the public's appetite for ballots.

There is also a limit to the public's understanding of and interest in matters constitutional. Charter88 does not resolve a paradox. It would like change to be based on popular movement. But the public do not take to the streets for fairer voting (which is one reason Mr Blair thinks he can get away with it). Labour's constitutional reform has so far largely been top down. Without resolute and single-minded ministers commanding a parliamentary majority the next tranche of needed change (a second chamber for parliament, PR) will not happen.

*Unlocking the policies. The general election handbook on democracy and the constitution

fields.headline: Evolution 'will favour younger mothers'
fields.trailText: Humans in wealthy countries are being genetically altered by evolution to have babies earlier, a group of scientists claims.
fields.body:
Humans in wealthy countries are being genetically altered by evolution to have babies earlier, a group of scientists claims.

The findings fly in the face of the widespread belief that people in rich countries are no longer evolving, protected from the diseases, violence and famine which made life for our prehistoric ancestors a truly Darwinian case of survival of the fittest.

The study was published in yesterday's edition of the journal Evolution. One of the researchers on the Australian-US-British project, Ian Owens of Imperial College, London, said: "Quite a few high profile biologists have suggested evolution has stopped in humans because we are now so cosseted from nature red in tooth and claw. I would have gone along with that suggestion a couple of years ago. I was astounded to find it isn't the case."

The researchers studied variations in the number of children that thousands of Australian female twins had, together with the time they had their first period and first baby and when they went through the menopause.

They concluded that women were under a subtle kind of natural selection, probably involving genes influencing behaviour. Over the next few hundred years, they argue, carriers of genes which prompt women to seek children earlier would multiply at the expense of non-carriers.

The study suggests that 40% of the difference in how many children women have is based on inheritance. "A 40% variation in reproductive success suggests something remarkable is happening," said Dr Owens.

The notion that nature is moving in to undermine women's hard-won freedoms will repel feminists and delight traditionalists.

Dr Owens stressed that he did not believe behaviour was determined by genes, but said they did play a role, even though it would be very difficult to quantify and separate from environmental influences.

"What we are talking about here is behaviour which is maybe 50% genetically determined. These things tell you less about how individuals behave than about how populations may change over hundreds of years."

The evidence, he said, was that humans were still undergoing evolution, but of a different kind from prehistoric man.

Then, evolution was about selection over many generations of inherited traits likely to help humans survive long enough to have children, prolonging the species.

Now, Dr Owens said, the inherited traits selected by evolution in rich countries were not about survival but simply about having children - whether, when and how many.

There are few clues as to what the genes influencing them might be. Over the coming centuries, Dr Owens said, there could be problems if the existing cultural trend in rich countries to have fewer babies, later, continued.

"It means genetic effects are going one way and cultural effects going the other. It means a conflict," he said.

Dr Owens stressed that he did not believe behaviour was determined by genes, but said they did play a role, even though it would be very difficult to quantify and separate from environmental influences. "What we are talking about here is behaviour which is maybe 50% genetically determined. These things tell you less about how individuals behave than about how populations may change over hundreds of years." The evidence, he said, was that humans were still undergoing evolution, but of a different kind from prehistoric man. Then, evolution was about selection over many generations of inherited traits likely to help humans survive long enough to have children, prolonging the species. Now, Dr Owens said, the inherited traits selected by evolution in rich countries were not about survival but simply about having children - whether, when and how many. There are few clues as to what the genes influencing them might be. Over the coming centuries, Dr Owens said, there could be problems if the existing cultural trend in rich countries to have fewer babies, later, continued. "It means genetic effects are going one way and cultural effects going the other. It means a conflict," he said.

webTitle: Michael Longley wins Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry

fields.headline: Medal crowns Belfast poet's renaissance
fields.trailText: The Belfast born poet Michael Longley, who began this year by announcing "at the ripe old age of 61, I feel as though I've just started", scooped the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry yesterday.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Belfast born poet Michael Longley, who began this year by announcing "at the ripe old age of 61, I feel as though I've just started", scooped the Queen's Gold Medal for Poetry yesterday.

The poet, whose work has been overshadowed by the superstar status of his friend Seamus Heaney, is having a dazzling renaissance, after a 12 year silence in the 1980s when he published no poems. Heaney himself called him "a keeper of the artistic estate, a custodian of griefs and wonders".

Or as his publishers, Cape, put it yesterday: "He's really on a roll."

In January he won the £10,000 TS Eliot prize, for his latest collection, The Weather in Japan.

The medal is awarded annually, in recognition of outstanding quality in a living poet, at the nomination of an expert committee currently chaired by the poet laureate, Andrew Motion.

The prize has gone to an eclectic list, including Stevie Smith, WH Auden and John Betjeman, since it was created by George V in 1933 at the suggestion of the then laureate, John Masefield.

The most recent recipients are the Australian poet Les Murray, the last nomination by laureate Ted Hughes - who won the medal himself in 1973 - and the 80-year-old Glaswegian poet Edwin Morgan, the first to be nominated by Andrew Motion.

Longley was born in Belfast in 1939, educated in Dublin, and worked as literature officer at the Arts Council of Northern Ireland until 1991.

Like Heaney, he became a critically and popularly acclaimed poet in the 1960s, both men writing out of their experience of a life in Northern Ireland frequently overshadowed by the Troubles.

Unlike the Nobel prize winning Heaney, Longley's career seemed to have petered out in the 1980s, when he published no new poems.

However, he made a spectacular return in 1991 with Gorse Fires, which was nominated for all the major poetry prizes and won the Whitbread award. Last year's collection, The Weather in Japan, won both the TS Eliot and the Hawthornden prizes.

The Queen's Medal announcement was made yesterday to mark the 437th anniversary of the birth of William Shakespeare.

The day was also marked, however, by a survey which would humble any poet. It was carried out for Lloyds TSB, and revealed that 25% of respondents could not remember the name of any play by Shakespeare, even though two-thirds insisted they had either seen or read one.

Detour

I want my funeral to include this detour

Down the single street of a small market town,

On either side of the procession such names

As Philbin, O'Malley, MacNamara, Keane.

A reverent pause to let a herd of milkers pass

Will bring me face to face with grubby parsnips,

Cauliflowers that glitter after a sunshower,

Then hay rakes, broom handles, gas cylinders.

Reflected in the slow sequence of shop windows

I shall be part of the action when his wife

Draining the potatoes into a steamy sink

Calls to the butcher to get ready for dinner

And the publican descends to change a barrel.

From behind the one locked door for miles around

I shall prolong a detailed conversation

With the man in the concrete telephone kiosk

About where my funeral might be going next.

Michael Longley

webTitle: Academics taking the stand as expert witnesses

fields.headline: Pursuit of truth
fields.standfirst: Taking the stand as an expert witness in a high-profile court case is not a task for the faint-hearted. Academic reputations can be at stake, but for those who relish a fight the personal rewards can be great.  Joe Plomin  reports
fields.trailText: Taking the stand as an expert witness in a high-profile court case is not a task for the faint-hearted. Academic reputations can be at stake, but for those who relish a fight the personal rewards can be great. Joe Plomin reports
fields.body:
As the key expert witness in the libel case brought by David Irving, Cambridge historian Richard J Evans faced six and a half days of hostile cross-examination.

From the witness box, he could see to the back of the court, where Holocaust survivors hung on his every word, occasionally weeping.

In a trial that went far beyond simple slander, Professor Evans felt himself entrusted with proving that the Holocaust took place. On every substantive point, he won.

"It was a serious responsibility. But I showed that historians can use the evidence to make a distinction between falsification and truth. The Holocaust won't be forgotten," he said.

But being an expert witness had its price. Not only did Professor Evans have to endure the cross-examination, much of it by Irving, but the whole case took nearly three years' work.

Academic expert witnesses risk their reputation, time, and the very impartiality of their research. By leaving their ivory tower for the lawyers' den, academics lose not only the security of their own lair, but the conventions and rules of academia.

But it is one of the few times when their specialist knowledge influences directly the most important public debates: disasters, murders, miscarriages of justice or even the nature of history.

Around 10,000 people act as expert witnesses at some time, according to Brian Thompson, the secretary of the Expert Witness Institute. Nearly three-quarters of court cases involve medical practitioners. Most top academics are only called on in high-profile cases.

One of the most experienced expert witnesses around, Professor Peter Vanezis, is a forensic pathologist who has worked with murder trials almost daily since 1974 and with numerous war crimes investigations around the world.

He was the pathologist called by the prosecution during the trial of the "railway killer" John Duffy, who was jailed in 1988 for two murders and 17 rapes or related offences.

The director of Glasgow's department of forensic medicine and science, he argues that court and university are fundamentally different, and that's the way it should be.

"In academia you are looking at truth. In court you are looking at justice. The two are different. In court you will be criticised, but that person might not actually believe what they are saying."

The gentler debates of academia are a world away from what is required from the expert witness. Vanezis sums it up by saying that shrinking violets need not apply.

You have to relish a fight, and woe betide you if you get it wrong. The repercussions of failing to prepare properly for a case can haunt an expert witness.

Years ago, Vanezis went to court with a brief about a woman's murder that he had not read thoroughly. When asked about the wounds, he read out "stabbed incised wounds". The judge knew that stab wounds and incisions were two different things and admonished him, saying "you don't give a fig about this case".

Professor Vanezis scurried out of court too quickly to pick up his remittance.

Even if your evidence is sound and well researched, the nature of what a court needs is different from a learned journal. Judges, juries and investigators have little time for academic complexities.

Dr Charles Woolfson, a reader at Glasgow University and director of the centre for corporate responsibility, was the rail union's main expert witness in Lord Cullen's inquiry into the Paddington train crash of October 1999. He is one of the main proponents of the concept of corporate responsibility, having gained expertise in this area researching the offshore oil industry and the series of disasters within it during the 1980s.

Woolfson believes that the involvement of organised workers can improve a company's safety plans, but cannot point to a vast body of research backing him up.

He knows he is right, but in the publish-and-response world of academia, he could separate what was known from what was believed. In Lord Cullen's enquiry, he had to stand by the belief alone.

Defending the unions in the face of hostile counsel, any admissions of doubt could, potentially, have diluted Lord Cullen's recommendations and Woolfson did not want to be the one to let business off the hook.

An expert witness must balance their beliefs with the need to support their side. For example, Woolfson protested that although he was called to the Ladbroke Grove Inquiry by the unions, he also had his own opinions.

"Although I was supportive and stressed the importance of organised workers, I wasn't their mouthpiece. On the issue of corporate killing, while I believe the management needs to be brought to book, so do workers involved in disasters," he says.

In the best-run cases, these differences of opinions and other doubts are cleared up before a case starts, Vanezis believes. Moreover, if they are serious enough, either the case or the witness should be dropped. The greater danger is that a combative lawyer can lure an academic away from what they actually know and force them to lend "expert witness" status to uncertain views.

"It's not infrequent that expert witnesses get asked questions outside of their specialist knowledge. You have to avoid that. For example, lawyers would try to to ask, 'would you call this attack frenzied?'" says Vanezis.

The idea of traipsing through this legal and moral minefield leaves many academics cold, either with fear or annoyance. And yet thousands more choose to do it.

It is not just naivety, though Evans admits he had no idea how much time the Irving libel trial would take. Nor is it just the kudos of being the expert in a particular field.

There is a more personal reward. Evans was thanked by Holocaust survivors for his work, while Woolfson remembers being congratulated by the families of the Paddington rail crash victims. These are plaudits an academic cannot earn without taking the stand.

But there is a principle at the heart of being an expert witness, according to Woolfson. "As academics, funded by public money to understand a subject, we have a duty to make our knowledge part of the public policy discussion. Even though our credibility is on the line in a way that it never is in academic argument."

Not being one to walk away from a fight, Woolfson found that facing professional debunkers was actually rather fun. Even though they tried to box him into a corner, painting him as an unregenerated nationaliser, Woolfson said that, in the end, it was quite satisfying being able to respond aggressively to hostile counsel. "I did the job that I had to do," he says.

fields.headline: United made £15m move for Dyer
fields.trailText: Manchester United may have broken the British transfer record by signing Ruud van Nistelrooy for £19m, but they are not finished yet. They have set their sights on Newcastle's Kieron Dyer - and have already had a bid of £15m rejected.
fields.body:
Manchester United may have broken the British transfer record by signing Ruud van Nistelrooy for £19m, but they are not finished yet. They have set their sights on Newcastle's Kieron Dyer - and have already had a bid of £15m rejected.

But Guardian Unlimited Football understands that Alex Ferguson will return in the summer with an improved bid of around £20m - a bid, sources close to Newcastle have told us, the club will accept.

However, United's deal for Dyer isn't a formality - they also face competition from Juventus and Leeds.

Newcastle have repeatedly insisted that Dyer is not for sale but their line today fell some distance short of a denial. "It's just speculation," a spokesman said. "We've said our bit and we're not saying anymore. The club does not comment on media speculation."

Manchester United's position was also ambiguous, and director of communications Paddy Harverson would only say: "We have no comment."

Dyer will miss the rest of this season through injury, but his performances earlier in the year earned him rave reviews.

It is thought that United see Dyer as capable of playing on the right of midfield, allowing David Beckham to take his preferred place in the centre of the field.

fields.headline: Chelsea want Poyet to stay
fields.trailText: Chelsea have insisted they want Gustavo Poyet to stay - despite the Uruguay midfielder's claim this morning that he plans to leave at the end of the season.
fields.body:
Chelsea have insisted they want Gustavo Poyet to stay - despite the Uruguay midfielder's claim this morning that he plans to leave at the end of the season.

Poyet, a popular figure at Stamford Bridge in his four years at the club, expressed his annoyance with the club's poor season in the Daily Star this morning.

"It makes me sad to say it but I cannot see a bright future for me at Chelsea," he said. "I want to be given the chance to finish my career at a club where I have a real chance of winning the championship."

"Our performance in the home defeat by Charlton was the final blow," he added. "I am so disappointed with the way the season has gone. We have four games left and are playing for a place in the Uefa Cup. That is not good enough for Chelsea and it is not good enough for me."

And Poyet also appeared to have a pop at manager Claudio Ranieri, claiming: "After we changed the manager at the start of the season, we don't seem to know where we are going."

But managing director Colin Hutchinson, who also faces a battle to persuade Gianfranco Zola to stay at Chelsea next season, claimed the club was keen to keep Poyet.

"Gus has another year left on his contract," he said. "We had a meeting with him in recent weeks when he was a bit frustrated at being in and out of the team.

"We agreed to sit down at the end of the season and review the situation then," he added. "Gus is an emotional guy and we want him to stay. Claudio has already made that clear."

Hutchinson has already made it clear that Chelsea will be further strengthening their squad after an inconsistent season. But he has ruled out any move for Andy Cole or Dwight Yorke if they were to become surplus to requirements following the arrival of Ruud van Nistelrooy.

"Neither Cole nor Yorke is in our plans," Hutchinson insisted. "I can say we have no interest in either player."

fields.headline: Kirch pledges F1 will stay on free-to-air TV
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Kirch has moved to prevent Formula One car manufacturers from launching a breakaway circuit, writes Ashley Davies.
06.04.2001: Teams force Kirch to crumble on pay TV
05.04.2001: Kirch dismisses F1 threat
01.03.2001: EMTV pledges to keep F1 on free-to-air TV
fields.body:
Formula One motor racing will remain on free-to-air television, the rights owners said today.

German TV group Kirch and its partner EMTV made the pledge in a bid to prevent Formula One car manufacturers from launching a breakaway circuit.

The commitment was made after Kirch's part-owned holding company, SLEC, paid £219m to the International Automobile Federation for a 100-year extension to its commercial rights to Formula One.

The contract was originally to run until 2010.

However, the move will not guarantee an end to the car makers' unrest.

They want more say in the way the sport is run and are understood to want a stake in SLEC.

SLEC is 75% owned by Kirch and EMTV, with Bernie Ecclestone controlling the remaining 25 per cent.

In addition, the car manufacturers are only bound to the existing Formula One deal until 2007 by the Concord Agreement.

The car makers were worried a transfer to pay TV would limit the sport's audience and therefore shrink sponsorship revenue.

Today's placatory move by Kirch was made at an extraordinary meeting in Paris.

After the meeting, the International Automobile Federation said: "SLEC and Kirch Group have confirmed the championship will continue to be shown on free-to-air television."

fields.headline: Columbine parents sue entertainment companies
fields.trailText: The families of several victims in the worst school shooting in US history have filed a lawsuit against companies that create violent video games and sex-oriented web sites, claiming their products influenced the teenage gunmen who killed 13 people at Columbine high school.
fields.body:
The families of several victims in the worst school shooting in US history have filed a lawsuit against companies that create violent video games and sex-oriented web sites, claiming their products influenced the teenage gunmen who killed 13 people at Columbine high school.

The suit seeks $5bn in punitive damages from 25 entertainment companies. It was filed on behalf of the family of slain teacher Dave Sanders and other Columbine victims in federal court.

Companies named in the lawsuit include Nintendo of America, Sega of America, Sony Computer Entertainment and Time Warner Inc, which is now AOL Time Warner, and ID Software Inc and GT Interactive Software Corp, creators and publishers of the game Doom.

During the investigation into the April 20, 1999 shooting, police found videotape that shows one of the killers with a sawn-off shotgun on his lap. He called the gun "Arlene" after a character in the Doom video game.

Doom is a target shooting game. Other violent video games mentioned in the lawsuit include Quake and Redneck Rampage. The lawsuit also claims Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold looked at sexually violent material on at least two internet sites.

"Absent the combination of extremely violent video games and these boys' incredibly deep involvement, use of and addiction to these games and the boys' basic personalities, these murders and this massacre would not have occurred," said the lawsuit filed Thursday, a day before the two-year anniversary of the shootings.

Sega declined comment, issuing a statement that it had not seen the lawsuit. Nintendo said it does not comment on pending litigation.

A nearly identical lawsuit filed after Michael Carneal killed three Heath high school students in Paducah, Kentucky in 1997 was dismissed last April. A federal judge there said video games are not subject to product liability laws.

Companies named in the lawsuit include Nintendo of America, Sega of America, Sony Computer Entertainment and Time Warner Inc, which is now AOL Time Warner, and ID Software Inc and GT Interactive Software Corp, creators and publishers of the game Doom. During the investigation into the April 20, 1999 shooting, police found videotape that shows one of the killers with a sawn-off shotgun on his lap. He called the gun "Arlene" after a character in the Doom video game. Doom is a target shooting game. Other violent video games mentioned in the lawsuit include Quake and Redneck Rampage. The lawsuit also claims Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold looked at sexually violent material on at least two internet sites. "Absent the combination of extremely violent video games and these boys' incredibly deep involvement, use of and addiction to these games and the boys' basic personalities, these murders and this massacre would not have occurred," said the lawsuit filed Thursday, a day before the two-year anniversary of the shootings. Sega declined comment, issuing a statement that it had not seen the lawsuit. Nintendo said it does not comment on pending litigation. A nearly identical lawsuit filed after Michael Carneal killed three Heath high school students in Paducah, Kentucky in 1997 was dismissed last April. A federal judge there said video games are not subject to product liability laws. fields.headline: Lastminute launches in South Africa
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Lastminute.com has partnered its way into South Africa, expanding its international operations to nine. By Amy Vickers.
22.03.2001: Lastminute moves
12.02.2001: Thumbs up for Lastminute despite losses
fields.body:
Lastminute.com has partnered its way into South Africa, expanding its number of international operations to nine.

The internet retailer, whose share price has stabilised around the 45p mark, has launched Lastminute.co.za in partnership with Tourvest, the South African Tourism Investment Corporation.

Tourvest holds a majority stake of 74.9% in the venture, and Lastminute.com the rest.

"The launch of a South African version of our website is a further step in extending the online lastminute market place globally," said Lastminute.com CEO Brent Hoberman.

The move will also benefit other Lastminute.com customers in France, Germany, Sweden, Australia, Spain, Italy, the Netherlands and the UK, who will now have access to a range of South African related products and services.

But global expansion is not necessarily going to plan.

Only recently, Laurent Therezien, head of Southern Europe for Lastminute.com, parted company with Mr Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox amid rumours of discord over its purchase of French travel firm Degriftour.

Additionally, over the last seven months, at least half of Lastminute.fr's original staff have left, citing cultures clashes.

Lastminute.com has also been rocked by rumours that its Italian and Spanish subsidiaries are struggling, and have until the end of June to find a strategic investor or buyer.

In Sweden, Lastminute.com has laid off employees and, according to reports, only six remain from an original 15.

webTitle: More 'human foot and mouth' cases investigated

fields.headline: More 'human foot and mouth' cases investigated
fields.standfirst:
 Two more suspect human cases

 'Carcass explodes and fluid goes in his mouth'

 Dioxin concern mounts

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Two more suspected cases of human foot and mouth disease are being investigated, the public health laboratory service said today, bringing the total potential cases to three.
fields.body:
Two more suspected cases of human foot and mouth disease are being investigated, the public health laboratory service said today, bringing the total potential cases to three.

The new suspect cases were revealed this afternoon and are not from Cumbria where it emerged yesterday that a slaughterman working on the cull was having tests for foot and mouth.

The service would not disclose exactly where or who was affected but had earlier stressed how rare it was for humans to contract the disease and revealed that several people had been tested but all had been negative.

The only human in the UK to contract the disease previously was during an earlier outbreak in 1966.

This morning, a government spokesman described the events leading up to the possible infection of the slaughterman, as health risks to humans came under the spotlight.

A spokesman for the prime minister, Tony Blair, said: "My understanding is that he was moving the decomposing carcass of a cow when that carcass exploded, and the fluid went into his mouth."

Results are expected by tomorrow evening, but the government stressed that there was no health risk to the general population from the disease, which has flu-like symptoms and causes blisters on the hands and mouth in humans. It is thought not to be serious and poses no long-term threats.

The Downing Street spokesman stressed that he was only giving details "to illustrate how unusual are the circumstances regarding this individual possibly contracting foot and mouth".

He said that the Food Standards Agency had said there were no implications for the human food chain. "There is no question of any of the meat going into the food chain. Even were it to do so, there is no risk to human health," he said.

Meanwhile, another area for health concern is the mounting anxiety over cancer-causing dioxins which are being released from the carcass-burning pyres.

There have been protests at the giant pyre for 7,000 animals which was ignited on Sunday night at Arscott Farm, near Holsworthy, Devon.

Health fears were fuelled after Department of Environment officials confirmed on Sunday that fires lit during the first six weeks of the foot and mouth crisis had released some 63g of cancer-causing dioxins into the atmosphere - some 18% of the UK's average annual emissions.

Concern about dioxins is increasing pressure on the Environment Agency to reconsider on-farm burials in an attempt to deal with the growing foot and mouth carcass mountain.

There are currently more than 170,000 carcasses awaiting disposal in Devon from animals culled in the battle against the disease, and last week, the National Farmers Union in south west England accused the agency of being too inflexible about on-farm burials.

The average number of daily cases is now 16 compared with 43 just over two weeks ago. The total last night was 1,448 cases in Britain and four in Northern Ireland.

The government is also expected to announce today the lifting of foot and mouth restrictions on farms in west Wiltshire and part of Essex, near Brentwood.

fields.headline: Government boosts digital signal
fields.trailText: 5pm: The government is hoping to boost take-up of digital terrestrial TV by doubling the power of the signal, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The government is hoping to boost take-up of digital terrestrial TV by doubling the power of the signal from eight transmitters around the country.

Media secretary Chris Smith and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers have written to broadcasters seeking their commitment to the plan, which has been drawn up by the TV industry regulator, the Independent Television Commission.

Doubling the power at the eight transmitters, including Crystal Palace in south London, would improve the quality of the digital signal in areas where the service is already available.

It would also allow more people in those areas to receive digital TV.

"I do not want to see the progress of digital television hampered by a problem of poor coverage if it can be addressed," said Mr Smith.

"I want to see digital television continue to forge ahead and good coverage and reception are a vital part of this."

Mr Byers added: "Digital television combined with a phone line can give everyone access to the internet from their living room.

"This plan to boost the reception of digital terrestrial television is a key step in avoiding a digital divide."

The government wants to implement the plan to boost the digital TV signal around the country within the next six months.

Other transmitters lined up for a digital TV signal power boost include Sutton Coldfield in the midlands, Mendip in the west of England and Oxford.

The remaining four are Emley Moor and Bilsdale, in west and north Yorkshire respectively, Winter Hill in Lancashire and Black Hill, east of Glasgow.

webTitle: Tories are using the race pledge to attack Hague

fields.headline: Tories are using the race pledge to attack Hague
fields.standfirst: As the Commission for Racial Equality's parliamentary officer, Richard Jarman was integral in getting all the main parties to sign up to the race pledge. He says William Hague was proud to sign the pledge, but now his party is using it as a stick to beat him with
fields.trailText: As the Commission for Racial Equality's parliamentary officer, Richard Jarman was integral in getting all the main parties to sign up to the race pledge. He says William Hague was proud to sign the pledge, but now his party is using it as a stick to beat him with.
fields.body:
I represent one of the most ethnically diverse council wards in the UK, Ferndale ward in Lambeth, which straddles the area from central Brixton westwards to Clapham. A large number of my constituents come from the African, African-Caribbean and Asian communities and - in recent years - refugees and asylum seekers, particularly from eastern Europe, have settled here.

So I'm well placed to take a view on the row over the Campaign for Racial Equality's election pledge. In my constituency, racism is a real issue.

Black people living in my ward are more likely to be the victims of burglary, assault, vehicle theft and robbery than my white constituents, yet 4 or 5 times more likely to stopped and searched by the police.

It was against this background that I played a part, as the CRE's parliamentary officer, in persuading William Hague to sign the pledge. His enthusiasm - at the time - stands diametrically opposed to his party's subsequent hostility.

The pledge grew out of the Leadership Challenge, a CRE initiative designed to encourage leaders to make a personal commitment to promote race equality within their organisation.

William Hague, accompanied by his wife Ffion, signed the Leadership Challenge publicly at a ceremony at the Conservative party conference in October 2000.

He even referred proudly to his signing to during a Q&A session on the conference floor the following day.

By persuading Mr Hague to sign, the CRE managed to get a foot in the door in winning the confidence of the party to put in process a plan to seriously promote racial equality at every level of its structure.

Yet had it not been for the intervention of the party chairman, Michael Ancram and the cultural unit (a body set up by Hague to promote racial diversity within the party), Hague would probably never have signed the Leadership Challenge.

He was suspicious - he didn't want the CRE to use his signing as a stick to beat him with at a later date. We assured him this wouldn't happen.

It was this gaining of confidence that lead the Tory leader to sign the CRE's pledge, alongside Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy and the leaders of the main nationalist parties on March 14 2001.

It was agreed at the time that the parties would make their leaders commitment known to their members. Michael Ancram's letter to party members - now controversial - was simply honouring that obligation.

It would have been more appropriate now if the Labour party and the Liberal Democrats followed Ancram's example rather than criticise him for carrying out what was agreed.

No matter what Tories say now, it was agreed that individual MPs would be approached to sign up. And this is Hague's problem. It is the Tories, not the CRE, who are using the pledge as a baton with which to beat him.

Last year the Stephen Lawrence inquiry challenged parties to look seriously at how their practices, policies and procedures result in unequal outcomes for ethnic minorities.

Unfortunately, none of have selected significantly more ethnic minority candidates to stand in winnable seats in the forthcoming election.

And in Ferndale, racial inequalities continue irrespective of the national Punch and Judy. I, and my constituents, wish politicians would use the pledge as an opportunity to attack racial inequality - not each other.

Those who use race to kick political opponents in the teeth for easy press coverage are not that different from those who use language intended to stir up racism. It's just a nicer way of being nasty, that's the only difference. Both, in the end, are exploiting ethnic minorities.

 Richard Jarman is a Labour councillor for the London borough of Lambeth.

webTitle: BNP chief to stand in volatile constituency

fields.headline: BNP chief to stand in volatile constituency
fields.trailText: The head of the British National party is to stand in the general election at Oldham, Greater Manchester, the scene of rising tensions between Asian and white communities.
fields.body:
The head of the British National party is to stand in the general election at Oldham, Greater Manchester, the scene of rising tensions between Asian and white communities.

Nick Griffin, chairman of the BNP, used St George's day to announce that he would challenge the environment minister, Michael Meacher, in Oldham West and Royton where police have warned that race-related violence is sharply increasing.

Mr Griffin claimed that the row between the Conservatives and Labour over the commission for racial equality's compact was helping the BNP by making race a legitimate political issue. He also claimed that he would benefit from Robin Cook's "chicken tikka masala speech" - when the foreign secretary stated that Britons were not a single Anglo Saxon race - and the Tories' decision to concentrate their fire on the asylum issue.

"It legitimises the idea that we cannot afford to have asylum seekers here in the first place," Mr Griffin said.

The BNP's decision to stand in Oldham West - one of about 30 seats which the party will contest in the general election - will not pose any threat to Mr Meacher, who won a 16,201 majority in 1997. However, the presence of the BNP may be highly divisive in a town where race relations appear to be deteriorating seriously.

The announcement by Mr Griffin followed a racist attack on a 76-year-old man in Oldham, which was at the centre of controversy last week over alleged no-go areas.

Walter Chamberlain was attacked on Saturday, allegedly by three Asian youths who told him: "Get out of our area." He was dragged to the ground, kicked in the face and battered with a coffee flask he had been carrying, which broke his cheekbones.

Chief Superintendent Eric Hewitt, of Greater Manchester police, said: "Some arrests have already been made and our inquiries are continuing. There is no question of any parts of town becoming no-go areas." Police are treating the incident as racially motivated.

Mr Chamberlain underwent surgery on his face yesterday at North Manchester general hospital. His family have appealed for witnesses to the attack to come forward.

"We're so upset, because now he might be too frightened to go out. We just want to find the people who did this," said Anita Baker, Mr Chamberlain's daughter. "Hopefully someone will have a conscience." Her partner, Malcolm Pawley, said: "He's in shock at the moment. We all are."

webTitle: Tory 'paid asylum seeker for odd jobs'

fields.headline: Tory 'paid asylum seeker for odd jobs'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: William Hague faced renewed pressure over race last night amid allegations that a Tory candidate in the general election employed a Romanian asylum seeker who did not have a work permit.
fields.body:
William Hague faced renewed pressure over race last night amid allegations that a Tory candidate in the general election employed a Romanian asylum seeker who did not have a work permit.

Paul James, Tory candidate in Gloucester, who regularly attacks the government over asylum, paid Walter Flicka £5 an hour to tidy up his garden and paint a fence at his home last May.

Mr Flicka, 35, who fled to Britain in February last year, did not have a work permit because asylum seekers have to wait six months before they are allowed to work.

Mr Flicka, who now works legally as a hospital catering assistant, decided to speak out yesterday after Mr James said that asylum seekers were placing a burden on Gloucester and should be locked up while their applications were processed. During a visit to the constituency last week by the shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe, Mr James said that Gloucester was struggling to meet the costs of housing asylum seekers.

Mr Flicka said: "I was very upset when Mr James said that it was expensive to pay for housing asylum seekers. I pay my tax, my national insurance and my rent. I was also angry when he said that we should be locked up - the Tories want to place us in a concentration camp. They are trying to stoke up hate against us because they are racists."

He said he told Mr James that he did not have a work permit during the six days that he worked for him last year.

This was denied by Mr James, who said last night: "I was not aware that Mr Flicka was an asylum seeker. I was not aware that he did not have a work permit. If I had asked questions about him because he sounded a bit foreign, then my opponents would have accused me of being racist."

This was denied by Mr James, who said last night: "I was not aware that Mr Flicka was an asylum seeker. I was not aware that he did not have a work permit. webTitle: The CRE: in search of harmony

fields.headline: Tightrope walk in search of harmony
fields.standfirst:
The Tories feel betrayed but anti-racism campaigners have no regrets about naming MPs who refused to sign an election pledge

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The commission for racial equality hit back yesterday at criticism of its attempts to get every MP to sign up to a pledge to oppose racism in the upcoming general election campaign.
fields.body:
The commission for racial equality hit back yesterday at criticism of its attempts to get every MP to sign up to a pledge to oppose racism in the upcoming general election campaign. The CRE denied Tory claims that it had deliberately set a trap for the party, and alleged the party had damaged its own standing.

Robin Banerji, spokesman for the CRE, gave a detailed chronology of how the pledge came about and dealings between the statutory body and party leaders.

But senior Tory sources yesterday stuck by their position that they were not told that individual MPs would be asked to sign up until after the party leaders put their names to the compact at a public ceremony on March 14.

Party sources said they had "never expected this to turn into a naming and shaming exercise" and felt let down by the CRE.

William Hague and the CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, met to discuss the race compact on February 13. Mr Banerji was at the meeting and says Mr Hague and his aides were told that MPs would be invited to add their signatures after the party leaders at a signing ceremony. That ceremony, on March 14, was in dining room A at the House of Commons and the CRE says 100 MPs did sign.

Mr Banerji said the CRE had written to all MPs on March 9 inviting them to attend. After the ceremony MPs were contacted to see if they would sign the compact.

By last week three Tory MPs had contacted the CRE to say they would not. Newspapers ran stories naming them and, said, Mr Banerji: "It was better to make the information public about who had or hadn't signed to stop speculation or hunting by the media. If asked, why would we keep that secret?"

Hindsight

The CRE is adamant it had no intention of embarrassing anyone, and yesterday the body, charged with policing the 1976 Race Relations Act, was left wondering how it had ended up in the eye of a storm.

The pledge on race had surfaced at the 1997 general election, when it was signed by Tony Blair, the then Tory chairman, Brian Mawhinney, and the then Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown.

The aim was to ensure that racism did not enter the heated political debate during the campaign. But the CRE decided that individual MPs should be asked to sign for this year's election. "That would send out the strongest possible signal to the public that all politicians of all persuasions stood shoulder to shoulder on this issue," Mr Banerji said. "It's not an agreement with the CRE, it's an agreement between the parties. All we did is walk from office to office saying are you happy with this."

Hugh Harris was deputy chairman of the CRE during the 1997 election. He said that with hindsight it was a mistake to ask individual MPs to sign the compact. "It probably has backfired, it's allowed the people who want to throw mud at the CRE to do so.

"I don't know what the logic was that led the CRE asking them this time. Because of all the flak coming out, it's unhelpful, but a lot of the flak is unjustified."

Some on the left believe that the CRE should be merged within a human rights commission covering race, gender and disability. Some ministers believe that under its current powers too often the only way for the CRE to tackle racism is through confrontation such as legal actions and formal inquiries.

The CRE has a tightrope to walk. Some Asian and black people accuse it of doing too little, while rightwing Tories believe it should be abolished. Within the organisation there has been a belief that its powers need to be beefed up for it to be more effective.

The former chairman Sir Herman Ouseley said running the CRE and navigating it through competing concerns was a nightmare. "You manage with a lot of difficulty, you feel like topping yourself most of the time, you get no thanks from anyone, you have to live with your conscience."

He believes the latest row will cause no lasting damage to the CRE.

But one expert believes the real loser could be the Conservative party and its efforts to improve its appeal to Asian and black voters. Shamit Saggar, a psephologist who studied the ethnic minority vote in the 1997 election, said the row would "harm the Conservative party's chances of making inroads into the ethnic minority vote".

If the last election is any guide, there are very few votes for the Tories to win this time from Asian and black voters. In 1997, the Conservatives won just one in 10 of the ethnic minority vote, with Labour getting 85%.

Dr Saggar, a reader in politics at Queen Mary and Westfield College, said: "The view at the top of the Tory party has been we'll engage in the rhetoric of racial equality but not the deed. The row is bad news for those in the party who believe in social inclusion and tolerance."

Despite increasing prosperity among Asian and black communities, Dr Saggar says the Tory party's stand on race puts ethnic minority voters off, especially middle class ones the party wishes to court. "The Tories have defaulted on winning the ethnic minority vote. The default is the long term ghost of [Enoch] Powell in the party. The grassroots is made up of little Powellites, despite what the leadership try to do."

Away from Westminster, the CRE compact was designed to ensure that racial tension in areas such as Tower Hamlets, in east London, does not increase because of politicians' rhetoric during the election campaign.

Control

Asians and black people in Tower Hamlets have suffered from racist attacks for years. Mohammed Shazad, 33, supports the CRE but thought the election pledge was worthless.

He said: "It's just a piece of paper. If deep down you're racist and you sign, it doesn't change you. The CRE shouldn't have bothered." But he felt it was "appalling" that MPs had not signed. "If you look at William Hague, he hasn't got control over his party - how is he going to control a government?"

Alan Grant, 49, unemployed, said: "MPs are the figureheads of the country and they should lead by example. They should have signed. It's better to have the CRE than not. They've opened up people's eyes and brought things to the forefront."

Others opposed the CRE pledge. Mrs Stoker, 60, from Wapping, east London, said: "I don't think the CRE should be a statutory body. I don't think MPs should have to commit themselves in this way.

"Anyone who is going to adopt a racist attitude would do so anyway. They're trying to make an election issue out of it."

fields.headline: The CRE compact
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Text of the Commission for Racial Equality election compact
fields.body:
Text of the Commission for Racial Equality election compact

Principles for good practice and conduct

This compact applies to all those involved in national, local or European election campaigns, whether they are prospective MPs, MSPs, AMs, MEPs, councillors, candidates, party members, campaigners or supporters.

I, the undersigned, undertake to:

1 Represent the interests of all my constituents, regardless of race, sex, colour, religion or any other discriminating factor, and promote good race relations

2 Reject all forms of racial violence, racial harassment and unlawful racial discrimination

3 Not publish, or seek to have published by others, or in any way endorse any material, including pamphlets, leaflets and posters, likely to generate hostility or division between people of different racial, national or religious groups, or which might reasonably be expected to do so

4 Ensure that in any dealings with the public, including door-to-door and telephone canvassing, no words or actions are used which may:

 encourage, instruct or put pressure on others to discriminate; or

 stir up racial or religious hatred or lead to prejudice on grounds of race, nationality or religion

5 Make sure everyone involved in my (my party's) campaign for election pledges to abide by these principles, and call on all those involved in promoting or reporting political debate, especially the media, to do the same.

In endorsing this declaration, I accept responsibility to ensure that every alleged breach is properly investigated by my party, and that appropriate action is taken against any candidate, party member or person acting on behalf of the party or a candidate, who knowingly fails to comply with these principles. This could include their removal from any formal role on behalf of my election campaign or that of the political party I represent, and a public disavowal by that party.

fields.headline: The usual suspects
fields.standfirst:
An Asian GP attacks the Commission for Racial Equality for stirring up racial tension. A surprising view? Not if you read the Daily Mail. Joseph Harker on the right's favourite 'race experts'

Special report: race issues in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: An Asian GP attacks the Commission for Racial Equality for stirring up racial tension. A surprising view? Not if you read the Daily Mail. Joseph Harker on the right's favourite 'race experts'.
fields.body:
Any Tories feeling uneasy about their party's recent turmoil would have been heartened by the front page of yesterday's Daily Mail. After an onslaught against his party sparked by an MP's racist comments, William Hague must have been regretting his handling of the Commission for Racial Equality declaration in which the main party leaders pledged that their party candidates would not stir up racial prejudice.

But in a typical agenda-changing front-page splash, the Mail led with "Racial Watchdog 'Fuelling Hatred': former commissioner launches attack". Dr Raj Chandran, it revealed, "who was ousted after Labour came to power, claims the CRE has been 'packed with Labour activists and sympathisers' intent on portraying the Conservative party as 'riddled with racists' ". The body has "fostered prejudice and self-pity ... stirring up resentment among Britain's Black and Asian minorities".

For seasoned Mail-watchers, Chandran's outburst will come as no surprise, for even before his departure he was an outspoken critic of the commission, regularly accusing it of damaging race relations and being an insidious, self-serving part of the so-called "race relations industry".

So why would an Asian GP be so keen to do down a body whose task is to eradicate racism and improve the quality of life for all Britain's ethnic minorities? Perhaps because Chandran is not just any Asian GP, but a member of the tiny, select group of Daily Mail "race experts" who pop up whenever such issues arise and proffer an opinion that would have most black and Asian readers choking on their cornflakes.

For any readers who haven't realised he's not white, Chandran frequently spells out his ethnic credentials. "As a Tamil immigrant who came to England to escape racist persecution and discrimination, I have become increasingly disillusioned by the hectoring policies of the CRE," he lamented in one recent commentary.

In the last 18 months, Chandran has dispensed his surprising views on everything from political correctness in policing to the problems created by foreign doctors in the NHS. On policing in the wake of the Macpherson report, he had this to say: "Already the demoralised police in London are terrified to use their legitimate powers to stop and search suspected wrongdoers in case they are accused of racism. No wonder crime in the capital has risen sharply in the past year." [Time to rein in the race crusaders, Feb 7 2000]

On asylum, his views were similarly robust: "Take the phrase 'bogus asylum seeker'. To my mind it is not racist in any form. I am a Tamil from Sri Lanka ... I know what it means to be an asylum seeker. There are organised asylum racketeers who are 'flooding' our country with bogus asylum seekers and we must find ways of dealing with it." [Sickening, this attempt to silence free speech, April 10 2000]

Those foreign doctors in the NHS? "As a Tamil doctor who trained in Colombo, I arrived in this country seeking postgraduate medical education 30 years ago. With this background, I find myself in some agreement with the controversial - some have said racist - comments of Dr Liam Fox, the opposition health spokesman, that foreign doctors working in this country should be able to communicate properly in English." [How dare they dismiss concerns about foreign doctors as 'racist', August 29 2000]

Of course the views of Britain's ethnic minorities are diverse, but how many Asian people in this country agree with him? Nadeem Khan, editor of the weekly newspaper Asian Xpress, says: "He's not representative of Asians at all. The CRE does a lot of good work and many people have taken an active role in its work since the appointment of Gurbux Singh as chairman last year."

The Mail has its pet black voices too. A recent favourite is Lola Ayonrinde, a Conservative councillor for the London borough of Wandsworth. Following the murder of Damilola Taylor last November, she told Radio 4's Today programme that Britain's African community was the victim of a campaign of racial violence by Caribbeans.

Most black Britons were shocked by this claim, which bore no relation to their experience. But her appearance created enough waves for her to be signed up by the Mail. Shortly afterwards, under the headline "Black on black, the race war we can't ignore", she wrote: "As a Nigerian immigrant who was for many years a social worker on the estate on which Damilola lived and died, I know that black-on-black violence is destructively commonplace, and that much of it is racially motivated. More specifically, some people of Caribbean descent are bitterly resentful of those like me - and Damilola - who come from Africa ... This black-on-black violence is much more deeply entrenched than other forms of racial violence."

In another piece, she hit out at "the foolish people who have ... found it politically incorrect to recognise the harsh reality that some black people are disproportionately responsible for the robberies and other street crimes which make life in the inner city so unpleasant, and potentially dangerous for us all". [Yes, I welcome the truth about black crime, January 19 2001]

A few months later she wrote under the heartwarming headline "As an immigrant, I know I am living in the world's most tolerant country". Her first sentence said it all: "As an economic migrant myself, a person who came to this country from Nigeria, lawfully and honestly, to improve my prospects ..." [April 4 2001]

So how credible are the Mail's black voices? Not very, according to Michael Eboda, editor of the weekly black paper New Nation. "These people have no respect within the communities they pretend to represent. They tend to be out-of-touch publicity-seekers who represent only themselves. Whenever they make the news, 100% of the letters we receive are against them."

In attacking the CRE, it seems, the Mail is being perceived as attacking the very notion of equality for all. And in using black and Asian people to mouth the sentiments of the white backlash, many minorities are left wondering exactly what gains have been made which seem so threatening to the white population.

Even seasoned journalist Trevor Phillips fell victim to the Mail bug when, last year, he wrote an article slating Mike Tyson during his visit to Britain. Phillips' words were strong enough, but the accompanying headline was calculated to cause even greater offence: "We blacks should all beware of this dangerous brute."

Eboda says: "Most people used to say the Sun was racist, but now they see the Mail as worse." If so, there has been a sea change in the last four years. In February 1997, the Mail became a major force for racial justice with its front-page headline "Murderers" above the pictures of the five suspects in the killing of Stephen Lawrence. This move effectively brought middle England on the side of the campaign for a full inquiry into the investigation. As Khan says: "They did a very brave thing and some of us thought they were changing, but recently their whole perspective seems to be anti-Asian and anti-black."

Following the Macpherson report, many media institutions recognised their own institutional discrimination and sought to increase their representation of black and Asian writers. The Mail's own recruitment drive, though, will leave some people wishing it hadn't bothered.

webTitle: Straw hits out at 'weak' Hague as tit for tat goes on

fields.headline: Straw hits out at 'weak' Hague as tit for tat goes on
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday launched a strong attack on William Hague's handling of the race pledge as the political row rumbled on, descending into what one minister called a "tit for tat" war of words.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday launched a strong attack on William Hague's handling of the race pledge as the political row rumbled on, descending into what one minister called a "tit for tat" war of words.

The Conservative leader was unable to contain factions in his party who refused to sign the compact, Mr Straw told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"The problem with William Hague is not that I think for a second he is a racist but he is very, very weak and he is unable to contain this."

As the culture secretary, Chris Smith, admitted the issue had turned into a "tit for tat" argument, Tony Blair's spokesman acknowledged the Conservatives had every right to challenge the government over asylum.

Meanwhile the Lib Dems attacked a campaign leaflet published by David Shaw, Tory prospective parliamentary candidate in the Lib Dem-held marginal of Kingston and Surbiton. The leaflet, which prominently states that asylum seekers are costing each UK household £34 annually, includes a quiz to win the prize of a "bottle of English wine" featuring the question "What is the percentage of asylum applications that are unjustified?"

Kingston and Surbiton Lib Dem MP Ed Davey said: "Voters will see this scaremongering for what it is, both distasteful and irresponsible."

The former home secretary Michael Howard yesterday denied using inflammatory language in an advert revealed in yesterday's Guardian highlighting the Tories' record on asylum seekers.

The advert, in the local paper in the MP's Folkstone and Hythe constituency, asked: "What matters most to you? Bogus asylum seekers? Conservatives reduced the number before. We will do so again."

Mr Howard insisted: "I do not see what in this advertisement could possibly be regarded as objectionable."

Mr Blair's official spokesman said asylum issues had to be separated from arguments about racism - a response to Tory accusations that the government is running away from a debate on asylum.

"Our complaint about the opposition is not that they have raised the issue of asylum It is a perfectly fair, legitimate thing to do. Our complaint is that they have opposed the measures we have put in place to deal with that."

Mr Straw will today make a speech to the Foreign Press Association defending the government's asylum policy.

The government is now likely to stick to policy issues and steer clear of mudslinging over alleged racism within the Conservative party, since its accusations have led campaigners to question its own record on race matters.

A speech by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, praising Britain's multicultural identity and its love of chicken tikka masala was widely seen as patronising.

The Conservative leader was unable to contain factions in his party who refused to sign the compact, Mr Straw told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. "The problem with William Hague is not that I think for a second he is a racist but he is very, very weak and he is unable to contain this." As the culture secretary, Chris Smith, admitted the issue had turned into a "tit for tat" argument, Tony Blair's spokesman acknowledged the Conservatives had every right to challenge the government over asylum. Meanwhile the Lib Dems attacked a campaign leaflet published by David Shaw, Tory prospective parliamentary candidate in the Lib Dem-held marginal of Kingston and Surbiton. The leaflet, which prominently states that asylum seekers are costing each UK household £34 annually, includes a quiz to win the prize of a "bottle of English wine" featuring the question "What is the percentage of asylum applications that are unjustified?" Kingston and Surbiton Lib Dem MP Ed Davey said: "Voters will see this scaremongering for what it is, both distasteful and irresponsible." The former home secretary Michael Howard yesterday denied using inflammatory language in an advert revealed in yesterday's Guardian highlighting the Tories' record on asylum seekers. The advert, in the local paper in the MP's Folkstone and Hythe constituency, asked: "What matters most to you? Bogus asylum seekers? Conservatives reduced the number before. We will do so again." Mr Howard insisted: "I do not see what in this advertisement could possibly be regarded as objectionable." Mr Blair's official spokesman said asylum issues had to be separated from arguments about racism - a response to Tory accusations that the government is running away from a debate on asylum. "Our complaint about the opposition is not that they have raised the issue of asylum It is a perfectly fair, legitimate thing to do. Our complaint is that they have opposed the measures we have put in place to deal with that." Mr Straw will today make a speech to the Foreign Press Association defending the government's asylum policy. The government is now likely to stick to policy issues and steer clear of mudslinging over alleged racism within the Conservative party, since its accusations have led campaigners to question its own record on race matters. A speech by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, praising Britain's multicultural identity and its love of chicken tikka masala was widely seen as patronising.

webTitle: Leader: The CRE should be active at elections

fields.headline: Singh's song
fields.standfirst:
The CRE should be active at elections

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: There is "no place in our democratic process for those who seek to incite or encourage racial hatred, prejudice and discrimination". Not only is that an unexceptionable sentiment, it is also a straight inference from a growing body of statute law on human rights, public order and racial equality.
fields.body:
There is "no place in our democratic process for those who seek to incite or encourage racial hatred, prejudice and discrimination". Not only is that an unexceptionable sentiment, it is also a straight inference from a growing body of statute law on human rights, public order and racial equality. For the commission for racial equality to restate that glorious platitude in the run-up to a general election is right and proper; things have gone awry only in making the declaration of principle a litmus test of individual candidates' attitudes. The attempt during the past few days by rightwingers in the Conservative party and the Rothermere and Black newspapers to diminish the commission is unsurprising. They have never liked this body, even in its original and weaker incarnation as Harold Wilson's dual bodies for race relations. Any excuse will do to have a go.

Like the equal opportunities commission, the CRE's job is to see the law applied to individuals while attending to the needs and aspirations of groups. That involves reminding employers, landlords and everyone else of the prohibition on discrimination and, in the last resort, supporting court cases. In addition, the CRE shares the Home Office's general overseeing of public attitudes and this is trickier territory. Also, a series of counter-intuitive advertisements has sought to break down stereotypes - they excited controversy. But sometimes headlines are where race has to be. Meanwhile, quietly and not without effect, the CRE campaigns to eliminate racism in sport, in prison, the army and the media. There is debate to be had about the future implementation of human rights legislation - and so the future of the separate executive bodies for women, race and disability - but Gurbux Singh and the commissioners deserve the fullest support in monitoring and, where necessary, reproving political conduct at election time.

fields.headline: McCarthyism goes anti-racist
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Nobody ever did anything very foolish except from some strong principle, Melbourne said, and he could have added that nothing corrupts liberalism like good intentions.
fields.body:
Nobody ever did anything very foolish except from some strong principle, Melbourne said, and he could have added that nothing corrupts liberalism like good intentions. The row over the commission for racial equality's "compact", by which parliamentary candidates have been told to subscribe to "principles for good practice and conduct", illustrates this truth yet again.

We all know that there is racism in our society and we can all agree that anti-racism is a fine ideal. But the CRE's pledge is profoundly objectionable in authentic liberal terms. That is not less true because Ann Widdecombe and Nicholas Soames say so. The document is patronising, insulting and bullying at best; its implications almost totalitarian. Subscribers are invited "to reject all forms of racial violence, racial harassment and unlawful racial discrimination". And when did you stop beating your wife? The wording itself makes a presumption of guilt.

This is not the first time liberalism has been compromised in the name of anti-racism. The Race Relations Acts themselves were inspired by high ideals, and they were an attack on free speech which introduced a new form of censorship, as honest libertarians like John Mortimer and the late Nicholas Walter pointed out.

What happened in the struggle against white supremacy in South Africa was worse yet. Here was a good cause if ever there was one. And, all unnoticed, anti-apartheid campaigners adopted methods identical to those of McCarthyism: boycotts, blacklists and loyalty oaths. Sportsmen and entertainers who worked in South Africa were placed on blacklists designed to deprive them of work, but could purge their offence by making formal condemnations of apartheid. A generation earlier, American academics accused of fellow-travelling had been allowed to keep their jobs by signing anti-communist loyalty oaths.

Perhaps the most displeasing single feature of the anti-apartheid campaign was the boycott of South African universities and scholars. This was defended on the illogical as well as ignoble ground that although academic freedom was an absolute good, the fight against apartheid was even more important.

That was what anti-communists once said about their own cause. Once it is allowed that a South African academic could be ostracised for political reasons, how can we protest at, for example, the recent withdrawal, also for political reasons, of an invitation to Edward Said by a Freudian conference in Vienna?

Another case of good intentions leading to illiberal bullying was the Macpherson report. Leave aside the intellectually absurd definition of a racist incident as one which is perceived as such by any of those involved. The concept of "institutional racism" has totalitarian overtones: you are all guilty.

The idea of institutional racism smacks of the witch-hunt. A woman would be thrown in a pond. If she was innocent, she drowned. If she floated, she was guilty of witchcraft and could be burned to death. Accused of institutional racism, you can plead guilty (in the tones of a defendant in the Moscow trials), or not guilty - and are held to have demonstrated your greater guilt merely by having done so.

The row over the CRE compact has seen a good deal of humbug. Certainly there is racism on the fringes of the Tory party, and perhaps a guilty conscience among some Tories which made them walk into an obvious political trap. But a Pharisaical display of anti-racist scruples by the Labour party is as unappealing as anything on the Tory side. This is a government which has Jack Straw as home secretary, and is led by Tony Blair, who privately asked an adviser (we learned from a leaked document) to find ways he could be seen to take a tough stance against asylum seekers.

To say that liberals have betrayed their principles on this issue is not entirely true. Plenty of people on the left instinctively dislike the CRE pledge. That includes some Labour MPs, although in the cowed state of the parliamentary party their reservations are muffled. Straw said yesterday that Hague's weak leadership is shown by his inability to tell his MPs what to do. One might think the contrast with New Labour democratic centralism is one of the few things to be said for the Tories.

Outside the reach of party punishment squads, Mark Seddon, the editor of Tribune, has spoken up for left libertarianism by condemning the CRE and the government. Why stop at anti-racist pledges, he wondered. What about "compacts" of support for the free market, or oaths of undying loyalty to the party leadership?

It hasn't quite come to that, but those who have been gloating over this episode may live to see the glee wiped off their faces.
