webTitle: Hugo Young: The Race Relations Act

fields.headline: Ministerial double-talk simply masks a racist law
fields.standfirst:
The Race Relations (Amendment) Act offends against natural justice

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Race Relations (Amendment) Act offends against natural justice.
fields.body:
Behind the rival hands of race cards that party politicians hold are the facts on the ground. This column is about one of them. As the main parties proclaim their concerns about race, facts are drowning under a Niagara of piety. Yet this particular fact is so startling that it deserves wide study. In an honest society, it would tell you that race, far from being excluded from the election, would be near the forefront of discussion. But since only the Liberal Democrats care about it, and have an honourable record in dealing with it, the conspiracy of self-congratulatory silence is likely to succeed.

The fact in question is the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000. Though William Hague is a slimy cardplayer, Jack Straw, I think, is worse. He, after all, is the minister. He saw the act through. Yesterday, purring sanctimoniously about Labour's superiority in all matters racial, he said this act "puts on the statute book some of the best anti-discrimination legislation anywhere in the world". But that is not why it should be famous. Its uniqueness is quite the opposite. It puts on the statute book the bluntest piece of state-sponsored ethnic discrimination in the 35 years since British parliaments started legislating in the field.

The act's ostensible purpose was benign. Responding to the Stephen Lawrence tragedy, it extended anti-discrimination law to public authorities, notably the police, previously outside its reach. There were hiccups along the legislative way. Ministers had to be goaded into outlawing indirect, as well as direct, discrimination. What they couldn't be shifted from, however, was a decision to exempt all immigration, nationality and asylum decision-makers from the new law. These are now explicitly permitted to override what were for many years accepted principles: first, that immigration officers must observe the law against racial bias, and second that ethnic groups must at all times be treated as individuals not as a collective.

How did this happen? Partly through the reptilian disingenuousness of the Home Office. Mr Straw depicted the specific change as itself benign. Without it, he said, "ministers would, for example, be unable to authorise special compassionate exercises when necessary for particular ethnic or national groups". The exemption would have only good purposes. Straw cited the mercy Britain had recently shown to Kosovo Albanians en masse. Discrimination for positive purposes had to be exempted from a new anti-discrimination law.

Seldom in the annals of ministerial double-talk was such apparent virtue so swiftly renounced. We know this from the first ministerial instruction to immigration officers that was issued under the act, under cover of near-darkness, which has been operative since early April. This legal document, seen by almost no one, makes clear how the act should be operated not to let needy cases in but to keep national groups, irrespective of individual circumstances, out. Here comes the heightening of authorised official prejudice against national groups. The instruction says these must be examined more rigorously, detained more freely, and refused entry more swiftly if "there is statistical evidence showing a pattern or trend of breach of the immigration laws by persons of that nationality".

Even supposing the statistics were reliable, this grotesquely offends against natural justice, not to mention the Human Rights Act and several international obligations. "Statistical evidence" in the immigration field is hard to verify, and in any case a baseless way of predicting the truth about an individual case.

What case is there for punishing a newly arrived Serb merely because previous Serbs have been refused? A society that had kept its legal head would be unhappy answering that question. Yet the sweeping exemption grants officials, through ministers, the power to deport, exclude, refuse leave to enter, withhold exceptional leave to remain, and grant or not grant asylum, not only by reference to the collective record of earlier Nigerians or Chinese or Russians, as nationalities, but on the still more offensive basis of ethnic or national origins.

During the act's passage last year, ministers showed themselves aware of the sensitivities this might arouse. When an issue arose about the meaning of "ethnic", Straw was quick to say it was unlawful for immigration staff to discriminate on grounds of race or colour. But this was as circular as it was duplicitous, as he surely knew. It was wordplay in the interest of squaring a supposedly progressive conscience with an indisputably aggressive attitude to asylum seekers. How can an immigration officer take ethnic origins into account, as the new law instructs, without this being simultaneously racial? Answer: any problem the officer may have can now be handled by the power the new act confers on ministers to determine when a racial/ethnic decision is "justified" or "necessary".

Searching for a reasoned justification, ministers fell back on racketeering. The main scenario they offered against which these blanket powers were necessary was where criminal gangs organised economic migration from China. People who looked Chinese might on these grounds have to be singled out for attention. Revealingly, Straw's deputy, Mike O'Brien, when challenged with a parallel hypothesis of white economic migrants from eastern Europe, perhaps orchestrated by Russian gangs, shrank from making a similar ethnic generalisation. "White people are not one homogeneous ethnic group, incapable of being distinguished one from another," he said, as if non-white people were somehow other.

The truth is that this part of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act is ethnically discriminatory, in a way which such ministerial language only confirms. It is not aimed at scams alone. It's meant to withhold justice from groups of people - unspecified in the law, but in categories open-ended to the whim of ministers - based on their ethnic or national origins, and without a fair chance to answer back. Anyone who doubts this has only to read the final clause in the ministerial directive. It says: "If the information [needed to pursue an application to enter] is not available in a language which the person understands, it is not necessary to provide the information in a language which he does understand."

So the net closes on the British reputation for the rule of decent law. Asylum and immigration pose complex problems in the modern age, but they do not need to be addressed by this kind of perversion of the system. Maybe only an optimist would expect it to feature in the election campaign. Even the Lib Dems may hesitate to talk up their record. But behind the smarmy talk about what politicians should say, there's the issue of what they do. What Jack Straw, famous for his anti-racism, has done is write into statute a law of national and ethnic and racial discrimination.

webTitle: Race attack victim, 76, 'told to get out'

fields.headline: Race attack victim, 76, 'told to get out'
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A 76-year-old man has become the latest victim of a racist attack in a town which was at the centre of controversy last week over alleged no-go areas.
fields.body:
A 76-year-old man has become the latest victim of a racist attack in a town which was at the centre of controversy last week over alleged no-go areas.

Walter Chamberlain was attacked in Oldham, Greater Manchester, on Saturday by three Asian youths, who told him: "Get out of our area."

He was dragged to the ground, kicked in the face and battered with a coffee flask he had been carrying, breaking his cheekbones.

Chief Superintendent Eric Hewitt, of Greater Manchester police, said: "Some arrests have already been made and our inquiries are continuing. There is no question of any parts of town becoming no-go areas." Police are treating the incident as racially motivated.

Mr Chamberlain underwent surgery on his face yesterday at North Manchester general hospital.

His family have appealed for witnesses to the attack to come forward.

"We're so upset, because now he might be too frightened to go out. We just want to find the people who did this," said Mr Chamberlain's daughter Anita Baker. "Hopefully someone will have a conscience."

Her partner, Malcolm Pawley, said: "He's in shock at the moment. We all are. I just can't believe what they've done to him. He's a lovely fellow. He wouldn't harm a flea."

An off-duty policeman was also attacked in the town by a group of youths as he walked through a park at the weekend.

fields.headline: 3G phone launch postponed
fields.trailText: The world will have to wait at least four months longer for third generation mobile phone services after Japanese telecoms firm NTT DoCoMo pulled the plug on next month's planned 3G phone launch.
fields.body:
The world will have to wait at least four months longer for third generation mobile phone services after Japanese telecoms firm NTT DoCoMo pulled the plug on next month's planned 3G phone launch.

The company had promised a Tokyo-wide launch of its i-mode internet enabled mobile phone service for May, but today a spokesman said the 3G service has been changed from a commercial offering to an "introductory" test run starting May 30. The full service is now scheduled for a September launch.

The company denied that technological problems were behind the decision, saying that NTT DoCoMo wants extra time to collect user feedback and compile data on how the system worked before rolling out a commercial service.

When it appears, the 3G i-mode service is expected to tempt users with a service that is 40 times faster and includes video and wider internet capabilities. NTT DoCoMo has said that users will be charged for data and voice transmission, but not for the 3G handsets.

The delay will probably not threaten NTT DoCoMo's hopes to be first to market with 3G services.

European companies such as BT, Orange and Vodafone have spent billions of pounds and gone deeply into debt on the promise of delivering 3G services. An auction of 3G licences pulled in £22.5bn for the UK government alone, with countries from Italy to France to Spain following suit with auctions of their own.

This week British government ministers formally ruled out any change in the terms and conditions of the licences, quashing rumours that ministers were considering refunding part of the licence fees.

The companies are still negotiating over the ability to share network resources, rather than incurring the cost of building separate networks. The UK government believes the establishment of four distinct 2G networks improved quality through competition.

When it appears, the 3G i-mode service is expected to tempt users with a service that is 40 times faster and includes video and wider internet capabilities. NTT DoCoMo has said that users will be charged for data and voice transmission, but not for the 3G handsets. The delay will probably not threaten NTT DoCoMo's hopes to be first to market with 3G services. European companies such as BT, Orange and Vodafone have spent billions of pounds and gone deeply into debt on the promise of delivering 3G services. An auction of 3G licences pulled in £22.5bn for the UK government alone, with countries from Italy to France to Spain following suit with auctions of their own. This week British government ministers formally ruled out any change in the terms and conditions of the licences, quashing rumours that ministers were considering refunding part of the licence fees. The companies are still negotiating over the ability to share network resources, rather than incurring the cost of building separate networks. The UK government believes the establishment of four distinct 2G networks improved quality through competition. fields.headline: Net closes in on campuses
fields.standfirst: The e-university is a daring step in the trend towards a more flexible education, says  Joe Plomin
fields.trailText: The e-university is a daring step in the trend towards a more flexible education, says Joe Plomin
fields.body:
In the tradition of "the king is dead, long live the king", distance education as a distinct entity is disappearing, and that is all to the good. Technological change and university reforms are narrowing the difference between distance- and campus-based higher education, a trend that the government hopes a new project - the e-university - will support.

When it is launched next year, the e-university will be a warehouse of courses from both British and overseas universities which institutions and individuals can access over the net. Created by £62bn of government funding with complementary private money, the project aims to make learning on the web a reality, according to its project manager, Alice Frost.

"This is about having a focus on e-learning," she says. "There has been a marked trend towards using the internet, and there is an increasing number of people who want to learn on it. Plus, the vision is to take advantage of the best from around the world."

The new project is a daring step in distance education, but one that reflects the trend towards flexible learning on campus. The question is whether it will work.

Both the Open College, which sought to provide distance learning through television, and the Commonwealth of Learning, which provides course materials from different universities, have had difficulty making an impact on individual learning or teaching. The founding course director of the Open College, Richard Freeman, is not convinced the e-university has learned from their experience.

Freeman, who was director of the national extension college between 1976 and 1986 and is author of Managing Open Systems, said: "There is the 'not invented here' syndrome. If teachers do not have complete control over materials, they shy off and even prefer to prepare less good courses. Plus, people's problem is not about accessing information, it is having the confidence to do a course.

"Much of this is hugely centralised thinking, not about what students actually want. The most interesting things are being done in individual institutions that are responding to student demand. Those things are about more flexible learning."

The move towards flexible learning has been driven by the growth of the internet. When the Open University was set up in the 1960s, no individual university could spare the start-up funds required to prepare distance learning materials. Now every university can, in theory, teach anyone anywhere.

Allowing students to fulfil their course requirements in different ways has obvious benefits, particularly now there is increased competition for places. A student in Hong Kong can study on the same course as a campus-based student or one who lives 20 miles away and who only attends lectures intermittently.

For the entrepreneurial universities, that has been a boon. For the more conservative, the change has only meant increased competition, sometimes even from other continents. The e-university could assuage that fear by helping everyone into long-distance provision.

But as traditional, campus-based courses have become more flexible, the division between them and distance education has been breaking down. The edges have blurred, according to Professor Robin Mason, director of the MA programme in open and distance education at the Open University.

"It's inevitable, but, I don't see it as negative; we can learn from them, and they can sure as hell learn a lot from us,"she said. "I've always argued that universities teaching in classes the whole year is the wrong way to go."

While the OU uses the internet on many of its courses, its vision of the impact of technology is markedly different from that of the e-university. The policy of the OU is to use technology where there is a tangible benefit to students in doing so. The fear is that too great a reliance on the web could create an underclass that can afford neither computers nor their maintenance.

"We note any change in our students' behaviour and then make changes, but are worried some could be excluded by cost. Also, we are not pushing for course content on the web because we know that students will just print it out and get inferior information," said Prof Mason.

Higher education will discover in a year whether the e-university can provide a quality of material that proves that estimation wrong. Meanwhile, Frost is confident they can.

It's not only in the UK that the gap between higher and distance sectors is narrowing. In Australia a new phrase, "flexible education", has taken over. But it is the American phrase "distributive justice", meaning an increased distribution of skills between workers and of courses between campuses, that is catching on at the OU.

Either way, the point is mainly semantic and about keeping staff sweet, according to Freeman. Universities avoid talking about distance education because some lecturers see it as a means of employing fewer teachers and cutting costs. It is much more difficult to object to being flexible.

fields.headline: Publicity for 'top' hospitals backfires
fields.trailText: The latest attempt to publicise NHS performance has backfired after the promoters of a "40 top hospitals" list refused to name the poor-performing hospitals who failed to make the grade.
fields.body:
The latest attempt to publicise NHS performance has backfired after the promoters of a "40 top hospitals" list refused to name the poor-performing hospitals who failed to make the grade.

NHS performance analysts CHKS admitted that their list was compiled entirely from its own client roster of 115 acute trusts - less than half of the total number of acute trusts in the UK.

It emerged that 40 of its clients were not involved in the project, and that CHKS had no intention of naming the 35 trusts clients who failed to reach the list - and which pay the company £5,000 a year for its services.

"I think they should have produced the whole list - it's all very well saying these are the best hospitals but the public has a right to know the worst ones," said Mike Stone, director of the Patients Association.

Graham Harries, chief executive of CHKS International, said the list was not meant to be a league table but a "celebration" of excellence: "We see them [the trusts] as members of a new club that all hospitals will wish to join."

The "40 top hospitals" club is open only to CHKS clients. But Mr Harries admitted: "There are probably and possibly better hospitals operating in the UK but we do not have any data on that."

The hospitals' performance was calculated by using data for 13 indicators, including death rates, waiting times for treatment, length of stay in hospital and re-admission rate after discharge from hospital.

CHKS provides a "benchmarking" service to its trust clients which involves analysing performance and comparing it with that of similar hospitals to enable the client identify areas where services can be improved.

The "40 top hospitals" club members will be awarded a "specially designed sculpture" to mark their achievement at an award ceremony hosted and paid for by CHKS this evening.

A similar - if more comprehensive - performance analysis produced by the publishing firm Doctor Foster in January caused controversy after revealing which hospitals had the highest death rates.

webTitle: Creativity is the name of the game

fields.headline: Creativity is the name of the game
fields.trailText: 4.45pm:Creativity must be promoted more by the industry, says the new president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. Claire Cozens reports on Bruce Haines first speech.
fields.body:
The new president of the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising has called on the advertising industry to do more to promote creativity in advertising.

In his inaugural speech today Bruce Haines, chairman of Leagas Delaney, said he would make promoting advertising's "creative star quality" the mission of his two-year presidency.

"We have become so concerned to promote the industry as the producers of advertising which is absolutely proven in almost scientific terms that we have lost sight of the simple fact that it really isn't like that for most of us for most of the time," he said.

"We all run our agencies in different ways. But whatever our differences, the common factor is that the combination of specialist skills within an agency environment is still the best delivery system of effective advertising. This environment is something that clients - and any of their advisors - simply cannot match."

Mr Haines, who today took over the presidency from Rupert Howell, said he was keen to see more creative directors becoming involved with the IPA.

He said he would work with Andy Cheetham and Robert Campbell, the only creative directors who serve on the IPA's council, to identify ways in which creative people can increase their involvement with the organisation.

fields.headline: Q&A: '40 top' hospitals
fields.trailText: Q&A: '40 top' hospitals
fields.body:
What's this fuss about the "top 40" hospitals?

It's "40 top" hospitals, actually - an important distinction. A company has released a list of 40 top hospitals which it says deserve accolades for excellence, or at least for reaching "a high level of performance in a range indicators that measures clinical activity from mortality rates to waiting times".

Great, so who's number one then?

There's no number one. It's not a league table, nor are the 40 in any order. They are simply "all achievers of high quality care" whose performance "demonstrates to us and their local residents that their hospitals are well-managed and focused on the needs of their patients".

But they are the best 40 hospitals in the UK?

Er, no. The list draws from acute hospitals alone (meaning, roughly, those which perform inpatient surgical operations), so it doesn't include community hospitals, or mental health hospitals. Although there are 250 acute hospitals in the UK, the list of 40 is drawn from just 75 hospitals that agreed to be surveyed by CHKS, the health performance analysts.

So not exactly a representative sample?

No. All 75 hospitals are clients of CHKS. The firm has 115 NHS acute hospital clients, but 40 of these appear not to have wanted to be part of the survey. So it's really a "top-40-of-75-random-clients-of ours" kind of survey. "There are probably and possibly better hospitals operating in the UK, but we don't have any data on that," says Graham Harries, chief executive of CHKS, helpfully.

Do they name the 35 hospitals that don't achieve high quality care?

What, and lose 35 embarrassed and disgruntled clients? "Our focus is entirely on trying to get the successes across and not the negatives," says Mr Harris. As well he might.

So what's the point of it?

According to CHKS: "We see them as members of a new club that all hospitals will wish to join For the first time we have a group of hospitals, across the UK, which has passed a series of rigorous tests that they themselves volunteered for [it's] a celebration of the success of many NHS hospitals."

In other words At the risk of appearing cynical, it's a very useful marketing tool for CHKS to recruit more NHS hospitals, at £5,000 a pop. And a nice-sounding, if somewhat nebulous achievement for the "top 40" NHS trusts to boast about on their letterheads.

But isn't it a useful guide for patients of good hospitals?

Cynics would say that patients of Portsmouth hospitals NHS trust might more readily recall that last November it was threatened with a "hit squad" by the Department of Heath after surgeons called for all emergency operations to be stopped, saying that "patients' lives are being put at risk".

So what lesson can we draw from all this?

Never trust a PR man bearing hospital statistics.

fields.headline: Army, Arsenal, and Automobile Association
fields.trailText: TWO CRIMES AND PUNISHMENT
fields.body:
TWO CRIMES AND PUNISHMENT

Are Chesterfield really as bent as the wonky spire on the city's Parish Church? "No way!" mewled the liberal, sandal-eating members of the Football League's disciplinary panel. Two weeks ago they found the club guilty of just two of the 90 charges levelled against them and sent them home with a £20,000 fine, a nine-point penalty, and a packet of chocolate digestives. "Yes way!" screamed the Football League's board of directors however. Today they threw out the same nine-point deduction recommended by their disciplinary panel - because they considered the punishment softer than an army-sized pack of Andrex.

"As a result of the findings of guilt by the panel, the board considers that the recommendation to deduct nine points does not sufficiently reflect the damage brought to the integrity of the competition," thundered Football League chief executive David Burns in his best borstal-boss voice. "Accordingly we have asked the panel to reconvene to consider the matter afresh." That view was endorsed by sports minister Kate Hoey, who demanded the sort of vengeance that usually earns you a place in George W Bush's cabinet. "The penalty, which would have still allowed the club to benefit from breaking the rules at the expense of the other clubs who have abided by the rules, is just not right," she shrieked, before chanting "burn them, burn them" over and over again.

Not surprisingly, Chesterfield - who are now facing a larger points deduction which could rob them of promotion to the Second Division - have been left bemused by the news. Chief executive John Green admitted to feeling "extremely disappointed", while ex-chairman Darren Brown, who resigned after the charges were brought, kept insisting: "We felt nine points was perhaps too harsh because we had done nothing wrong." But the man who summed up the club's torment best was assistant manager Ian Banks. "We all thought it was done and dusted. We thought that was it - and it just keeps going on," he wailed. "It's another kick in the goolies - and it's not as though we haven't had enough of them this season." Indeed, indeed. And unfortunately it's the Spireites long-suffering fans who are feeling the pain more than most.

VAN DAMN

He may have only just arrived in the country, but already the Fiver doesn't like the look of Ruud van Nistelrooy's face*. There's something about that nose, especially in conjunction with the floppy haircut, that's just too damn Mr Noseybonk**. But if the Imperial Lord Ferg has decided the man is worth £19m of Money Mart's money, then who are we to criticise? Arsenal Wenger on the other hand

"I was surprised at the fee United have paid," the Arsene manager told the Evening Standard today. "But it just shows that the new transfer rules have no influence." Which must make anyone who spent £13m on Sylvain Wiltord breathe a sigh of relief. "Is it too much for a club to pay? It depends on how old the player is and most of it is down to what he does on the pitch." Two words: Igor Stepanovs.

But then here's another two words: Dwight Yorke. The £12.6m United wastrel is the one widely tipped to make way for van Nistelrooy, but apparently he is no longer a target for Claudio Also-Ranieri's happy Chelsea. It seems United are not too worried about recouping any money just yet, however, as the Newcastle Evening Chronicle suggests they have just had a £15m bid for Kieron Dyer turned down. Like a boomerang made out of gold they'll be back though and, according to sources at St James Park, it could be that £20m is enough to buy United a new right-winger. Transfer gossip, innit brill?!

* That's cos he looks like Greg van Rusedski
** Listen, if the BBC can devote entire evenings to childish nostalgia, then we can give it one line.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I have very strong principles about which substances I consume. I have only one body which is the home of my spirit therefore I cherish my body. Because of the importance of this principle it is not always easy for our medical staff to work with me. Sometimes I don't even accept the simplest medical treatment. It is a matter of deep conviction that would lead me to reject a simple glass of wine at dinner or any sort of chocolate bars" - Edgar Davids, whose positive test for Nandrolone must have been a complete mistake.

END OF THE ROAD

They're forever building things at Chelsea's of Chelsea. If they're not throwing up a lovely conference hall, they're opening a charming cod-Irish restaurant like Arkles. But is that enough for the swish London boutique? No way! And now that the C's of C Village is officially no longer a money pit, it's time to ask the construction men to get down to some serious work. But what's the first thing they're going to build? Why, it's a great big dual carriageway, of course, which will allow the club's biggest stars to get the hell out of west London as quickly as possible.

Vvrrooom! There goes Marcel Desailly, who is well narked off with doing sod all at the Chelse and fancies being put out to pasture at Marseille. "I had the feeling that I could have been used by [former Marseille manager] Rolland Courbis in 1999," he explained as he tested out the tarmac. "Nothing happened, though. But now, what do they do in Marseille for me? Nothing. But the day they do make some effort, you will hear from me on that subject." Which was interesting, as only a few hours later he was turning right while indicating left, and telling his personal website: "I don't have any doubts about my future, I'm with Chelsea."

Neeeeooowww! Not far behind M Desailly is Gustavo Poyet. "I cannot see a bright future for me at Chelsea," he bellowed today as he slammed his foot to the floor. "I want to be given the chance to finish my career at a club where I have a real chance of winning the championship. We have four games left and are playing for a place in [Euro Vase]. That is not good enough for Chelsea and it is not good enough for me." So what the Uruguayan will make of Colin Hutchison's attempts to catch him on a trendy C of C's Village scooter is up for debate. "Gus is an emotional guy and we want him to stay", panted Hutch. "Claudio has already made that clear." Which must, in some way, be a first.

THE RUMOUR MILL

AC Milan are preparing a £20m bid for Mark Viduka. "Everyone at the club knows how much Viduka is wanted," said a spokesman. "There is no desire to sign Beckham or Owen. We want to beat Roma and Internazionale to sign Viduka."

Arsenal are ready to make a £12m move for Roma's Hideotoshi Nakata.

Bayern Munich are prepared to bid around £12m for Hertha Berlin star Sebastian Deisler.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The pitch at the Millennium Stadium is to be completely relaid ahead of the FA Cup final on May 12. Work is expected to begin on Saturday, with the whole process set to take three or four days.

Thierry Henry has said that Arsenal's season will be a failure even if they win the FA Cup final next month. "Whatever the outcome, we have failed this season", said Henry on the eve of France's friendly against Portugal. "When you finish 15 points behind the champions you have to say you didn't live up to expectations. And we can say we have failed this season even if we win the FA Cup."

Fabien Barthez has claimed the current Manchester United side is the best he has ever played with. "They are true professionals. It was the first thing which impressed me when I went there," Barthez said. "They just treat you like a grown-up. It's not like in France where coaches and staff always treat you like a kid." fields.bodyText: TWO CRIMES AND PUNISHMENT Are Chesterfield really as bent as the wonky spire on the city's Parish Church? "No way!" mewled the liberal, sandal-eating members of the Football League's disciplinary panel. Two weeks ago they found the club guilty of just two of the 90 charges levelled against them and sent them home with a £20,000 fine, a nine-point penalty, and a packet of chocolate digestives. "Yes way!" screamed the Football League's board of directors however. Today they threw out the same nine-point deduction recommended by their disciplinary panel - because they considered the punishment softer than an army-sized pack of Andrex. "As a result of the findings of guilt by the panel, the board considers that the recommendation to deduct nine points does not sufficiently reflect the damage brought to the integrity of the competition," thundered Football League chief executive David Burns in his best borstal-boss voice. "Accordingly we have asked the panel to reconvene to consider the matter afresh." That view was endorsed by sports minister Kate Hoey, who demanded the sort of vengeance that usually earns you a place in George W Bush's cabinet. "The penalty, which would have still allowed the club to benefit from breaking the rules at the expense of the other clubs who have abided by the rules, is just not right," she shrieked, before chanting "burn them, burn them" over and over again. Not surprisingly, Chesterfield - who are now facing a larger points deduction which could rob them of promotion to the Second Division - have been left bemused by the news. Chief executive John Green admitted to feeling "extremely disappointed", while ex-chairman Darren Brown, who resigned after the charges were brought, kept insisting: "We felt nine points was perhaps too harsh because we had done nothing wrong." But the man who summed up the club's torment best was assistant manager Ian Banks. "We all thought it was done and dusted. We thought that was it - and it just keeps going on," he wailed. "It's another kick in the goolies - and it's not as though we haven't had enough of them this season." Indeed, indeed. And unfortunately it's the Spireites long-suffering fans who are feeling the pain more than most. VAN DAMN He may have only just arrived in the country, but already the Fiver doesn't like the look of Ruud van Nistelrooy's face*. There's something about that nose, especially in conjunction with the floppy haircut, that's just too damn Mr Noseybonk**. But if the Imperial Lord Ferg has decided the man is worth £19m of Money Mart's money, then who are we to criticise? Arsenal Wenger on the other hand "I was surprised at the fee United have paid," the Arsene manager told the Evening Standard today. "But it just shows that the new transfer rules have no influence." Which must make anyone who spent £13m on Sylvain Wiltord breathe a sigh of relief. "Is it too much for a club to pay? It depends on how old the player is and most of it is down to what he does on the pitch." Two words: Igor Stepanovs. But then here's another two words: Dwight Yorke. The £12.6m United wastrel is the one widely tipped to make way for van Nistelrooy, but apparently he is no longer a target for Claudio Also-Ranieri's happy Chelsea. It seems United are not too worried about recouping any money just yet, however, as the Newcastle Evening Chronicle suggests they have just had a £15m bid for Kieron Dyer turned down. Like a boomerang made out of gold they'll be back though and, according to sources at St James Park, it could be that £20m is enough to buy United a new right-winger. Transfer gossip, innit brill?! * That's cos he looks like Greg van Rusedski ** Listen, if the BBC can devote entire evenings to childish nostalgia, then we can give it one line. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I have very strong principles about which substances I consume. I have only one body which is the home of my spirit therefore I cherish my body. Because of the importance of this principle it is not always easy for our medical staff to work with me. Sometimes I don't even accept the simplest medical treatment. It is a matter of deep conviction that would lead me to reject a simple glass of wine at dinner or any sort of chocolate bars" - Edgar Davids, whose positive test for Nandrolone must have been a complete mistake. END OF THE ROAD They're forever building things at Chelsea's of Chelsea. If they're not throwing up a lovely conference hall, they're opening a charming cod-Irish restaurant like Arkles. But is that enough for the swish London boutique? No way! And now that the C's of C Village is officially no longer a money pit, it's time to ask the construction men to get down to some serious work. But what's the first thing they're going to build? Why, it's a great big dual carriageway, of course, which will allow the club's biggest stars to get the hell out of west London as quickly as possible. Vvrrooom! fields.headline: Robinson's 'racism' cranks up BBC complaints
fields.trailText:
4pm: Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh prompted a vast increase in complaints to the BBC about racism, writes Jessica Hodgson.
10.03.2001: Welsh say Robinson is the weakest link
fields.body:
Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh on the programme Room 101 prompted a vast increase in complaints to the BBC about racism this quarter.

The BBC's quarterly complaints bulletin, which details complaints received by the corporation and the responses made, notes that the BBC received 108 complaints about alleged racism, "almost all of them about Anne Robinson's remarks on the Welsh in Room 101."

In his report, the director general, Greg Dyke, blames press coverage for distorting the coverage of the incident.

"Together with the large number of calls to the BBC switchboard, a reaction of this scale would normally be a pretty strong indication that the programme had stepped over the line," he says.

"But this wasn't a normal case, because of the amount of newspaper coverage it generated."

He said it was "difficult to tell how many of the complaints were a spontaneous reaction to the programme, and how many were coloured by the descriptions of it in the press."

He added that when the programme complaints unit looked at the programme, they noted that they felt the press coverage "hadn't caught the flavour of it".

Mr Dyke added that in spite of the large number of complaints, the BBC felt that the programme fell "within the long tradition of banter between the component nations of the UK and didn't cross the line into the kind of hurtful stereotyping or suggestions of inferiority which would have opened it to charges of racism."

The BBC and the Broadcasting Standards Commission came under a hail of criticism after Ms Robinson appeared on the programme Room 101.

On the programme, in which guests are asked to consign certain objects and people to Room 101, Ms Robinson chose the Welsh, on the grounds that they are "irritating and annoying".

The Broadcasting Standards Commission cleared her of racism, but ruled that her remarks came "close to the boundary of acceptability".

The BBC is likely to face accusations of a whitewash.

Related story

This weekly email selects the best graduate jobs from Guardian Unlimited Jobs. It includes links to useful articles from Rise, the Guardian's graduate section, and previews the next week's issue. It also includes a tip of the week aimed at helping graduates find a great first job.

This week's Graduate Jobs Email
In a week when a B&Q salesman was sacked after failing a psychometric personality test, here is this week's super-switched on email from The Guardian. If only Carl Filer has read our tips on how to pass such tests published last month he would still be selling hammer drills.

As usual we take a look at the best graduate jobs offered by Guardian Unlimited Jobs - the website devoted to finding you the best vacancies.

We review last Saturday's Rise, The Guardian's graduate section, and there's a past article that we think is worth a second read in Rise Gold. NEXT WEEK'S RISE sees the launch of the Volvo/Guardian Environmental Scholarship which will send the two winning graduates off to the Biosphere centre in Arizona for 12 weeks. We also offer some tips on how to get through your finals, and there's even an article about brothels!

If you were too busy finishing off the last of your Easter egg stash to get to the newsagent, this is what you missed in LAST WEEK'S RISE (Saturday 21 April).

David Williams looked at the growing phenomenon of "employer branding" and asked is there something in it, or is it just the latest piece of corporate nonsense. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,475976,00.html

Hilary Freeman offered her personal guide on How to... be a diplomat and avoid foot-in-mouth outbreaks. It's all about building a network of contacts, using top intelligence and concealing emotions, apparently. http://jobs.theguardian.com/rise/feature/0,5190,475973,00.html

In the light of the B&Q episode, this week's RISE GOLD goes back just a few weeks to Irene Krechowiecka's guide on how to pass such tests. More employers are using them to weed out job applicants - make sure you don't fall at the first hurdle. http://www.theguardian.com/Archive/Article/0,4273,4166431,00.html

THIS WEEK'S HOTTEST JOBS.
For engineers looking to follow the Jam's advice and go underground: Infraco, the London Underground's engineering division, is offering "a daily dose of undiluted engineering excitement" no less. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114320,00.html

The Commission for Health Improvement, an independent statutory body - part of the overall NHS - is looking for Graduate Trainee Information Analysts to help review every healthcare trust in the country. Up to £20K. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114319,00.html

If you are researcher with a love of all things trains - lets face it, we've all been there at some point - The Railway Forum is looking for a self-starter "who can ferret out the key facts and present them convincingly". It's paying £23K. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114745,00.html

This week's top marketing job is being offered by the Imperial War Museum in Duxford. You'll be handling its day-to-day marketing activities; print and design projects, and media enquiries. "An interest in aviation history would be an advantage" - of course it would. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114559,00.html

If you are ready to abandon traditional boundaries of set, lighting and costume, then we have the post grad course for you. The Laban Centre in London is currently offering places on its MA Scenography (dance to you and me). Get ready to "draw inspiration from non-verbal stimuli provided by the body in space, revealed by light."Wow. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114779,00.html

If you've always wanted to work behind the scenes at the BBC, this could be your chance. It is currently looking for grads to train up to become the next generation of broadcast engineers and technicians. You've got to enjoy problem solving. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114765,00.html

And if you want to work on the other side of the microphone, BBC Wales is looking for people who graduated either last year or will this. One year training course starting in the autumn - and Anne Robinson will be pleased - you don't have to be able to speak Welsh. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114758,00.html

And finally, if all you want is to get some cheap flights, the Flight Centre is inviting applications from bright, ambitious graduates to be trained as International Travel Consultants. The money's only OK at best but you can book up every weekend away for the next 12 months. http://jobs.theguardian.com/Browse/Fulltextjob/0,1755,100114467,00.html

fields.headline: Davids: I never took nandrolone
fields.trailText: Edgar Davids has denied taking drugs and says he was "totally perplexed" to have failed a dope test.
fields.body:
Edgar Davids has denied taking drugs and says he was "totally perplexed" to have failed a dope test.

Juventus were told yesterday by the Italian Olympic Committee (CONI) that the Dutch midfielder had produced a 'non-negative' sample following a Serie A match against Udinese on March 4.

But in a prepared statement this afternoon Davids said: "I have never taken any illegal substances in my life."

"I never took nandrolone. I'm always against any type of doping and I have always been loyal to sport," he added. "I have never even thought of the possibility of using any kind of doping."

"After the match against Udinese on March 4 I had to report for a doping test which was a routine test to which all Serie A players are regularly subject," he went on. "In the past I have been tested many times and several times already this season. Obviously I expected that as all the times before everything was fine and that the test would be negative.

"Therefore I was totally perplexed and surprised when I read and heard the news of recent days that allegedly something was wrong with my test."

The Dutch international, who must now wait for the result of a second test before Italian soccer authorities can decide whether to act, said he was very careful about what he ate and drank.

"I have very strong principles about which substances I consume. I have only one body which is the home of my spirit therefore I cherish my body.

"Because of the importance of this principle it is not always easy for our medical staff to work with me," he added. "Sometimes I don't even accept the simplest medical treatment, such as for example the anti-flu vaccine.

"It is a matter of deep conviction that for this reason would lead me to reject a simple glass of wine at dinner or any sort of chocolate bars."

Davids's case is the latest in a series of positive tests in Italian football and comes just days after a second test of a sample given by Lazio defender Fernando Couto showed levels of nandrolone.

fields.headline: A deal too far: down under
fields.standfirst: Heavy handed Australian move
fields.trailText: It was always a possibility that Shell's bid to buy Australia's Woodside Petroleum would be blocked by politicians, but the decision is still a surprise, and comes laden with implications for Shell and Australia.
fields.body:
It was always a possibility that Shell's bid to buy Australia's Woodside Petroleum would be blocked by politicians, but the decision is still a surprise, and comes laden with implications for Shell and Australia.

The decision was was made on the grounds of Australia's national interest - with the treasurer, Peter Costello, ruling against the deal despite the foreign investment review board's failing to be convinced the takeover would threaten any national interest.

Given Shell's 100 years of hitherto happy involvement in that country it is surely questionable to suggest the oil company might neglect the prized North West Shelf LNG project in favour of Asian schemes, as detractors have claimed.

In fact Shell made clear it would cut costs by developing its Gorgon gas project alongside the NWS. That makes sense for Shell and for Australia.

The Aussies' concerns are purely nationalistic - four of its top companies have been involved in recent mergers with overseas companies and in the cases of BHP/Billiton and GKN/Brambles the local management is being displaced by foreigners.

But let us Brits not get on our high horse about political interference. Remember the way the British government got all hot and bothered about Kuwait taking a stake in BP at its 1987 flotation?

Kuwait was forced to hand over all but 10% to safeguard the British national interest despite the fact that the Middle East kingdom had bought during a slump, when no one else was interested.

BP was encouraged to buy back the rest of the Kuwaiti holding in a move it could not afford, which led to five years of underperformance.

So Shell has been dealt a bad hand in Australia, but might it not have seen this coming? Was it not a little heavy handed in going for its first hostile takeover in a country where nationalism would clearly raise its head.

It certainly puts pressure on Shell to pull off its second hostile bid - for Barratt Resources in the US. This is a tiny deal by Shell standards, but incoming boss Phil Watts - widely seen as the driver of the more hostile corporate strategy - will not want another embarrassing reversal. Yet it is far from in the bag, with the price not particularly generous and US national feeling also running high - especially since BP swept up Amoco and Arco there.

Some see Shell's predatory antics as an oil major awash with cash moving back to the bad old days of capital indiscipline long after BP and Exxon have hoovered up the best assets around when the oil price was much lower.

This is too harsh. Shell used the past two years to put its own house in order and is now keen to pick up choice gas businesses.

Nevertheless if Shell fails to win Barratt, expect to see the wilder investment banks suggesting the "super majors" be broken up so that proposed acquisitions will not frighten the politicians. Pity any naive financier who puts that idea to the pugnacious Mr Watts.

Trading places

Matthew Taylor, the Liberal Democrat treasury spokesman, summed it up rather nicely. Britain's trade deficit, he said, is the unnoticed disaster of the Labour government, and was a cause for concern even before foot and mouth did its bit to harm exports of food and imports of tourists.

To be sure, part of the problem is the result of events beyond these shores, more specifically in the United States, where belt-tightening by consumers and cutbacks in investment inevitably means fewer orders for British firms. However, the 35% increase in exports to the US from 1998 to 2000 helped to mask the underlying problems caused by an overvaluation of the pound.

An illustration of the deep-seated malaise is provided by trade in cars, where the effect of the plant closures of the past year are all too apparent. Exports of cars were down 6% in the latest quarter, while imports were up 27%.

With consumer demand underpinned by lower base rates, the US weak, foot and mouth yet to show up fully in the figures, and the pound still stubbornly strong, the outlook is bleak.

This may not be a silent disaster much longer.

Up in the air

The state-owned Italian airline, Alitalia, must wonder just who is at the corporate controls.

Yesterday the transport ministry said a merger with Air France would take off within days. But a few hours later the Italian treasury, which holds the state's controlling stake and is said to favour KLM as a partner, said negotiations were in a holding pattern with several potential partners circling.

The proximity of the general election might have been expected to concentrate minds or at least prompt a show of unity. Apparently not.

fields.headline: The Economic and Social Research Council
fields.trailText:
Funding body
Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)
fields.body:
Funding body
Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC)

People to know
The Research Grants Board manages the Research Grants Scheme and ESRC Fellowships.
Chairman: Professor Hazel Genn, University College, London
Vice Chair: Professor John Eldridge, University of Glasgow
Secretary: Mr Chris Caswill, ESRC

Aims
The ESRC's mission is to fund high quality social science research and training which meets the needs of the users and beneficiaries of research and enhances the UK's competitiveness, quality of life and the effectiveness of its public services and policy.

The ESRC's policy for postgraduate training and its portfolio of related activities are designed to help ensure the production of highly skilled social science researchers and professionals for employment in academia, business and the public sector. The budget is targeted to postgraduate training of the highest quality.

Background
The ESRC is the UK's largest independent funding agency for research and postgraduate training into social and economic issues. It was established by the Royal Charter in 1965.

Budget
£46m per year is invested by the ESRC in social science research.

Top ten beneficiaries
Expenditure by Institution 1999-2000
The following shows the major recipients of ESRC funding in 1999-2000:
Overall Expenditure on Research and Training 1999-2000 (£)
London School of Economics 4434
Essex 3924
London Institute of Education 3192
Oxford and Colleges 2939
Warwick 2854
Cambridge and Colleges 2731
Manchester 2718
London University College 2492
Bristol 1962
Sussex 1960
For more information click here.

Future issues and priorities
A new research programme, Science and Society, will get underway this year. The ESRC expect to appoint a Programme Director shortly. The programme aims to develop and refine UK research relevant to the understanding of science, technology and social change, and to enrich the quality of public and policy debate about new scientific and technological developments. The proposed budget is £4.5m over five years. This is expected to buy around 25 projects and fellowships, to be coordinated by a part-time Director.

Enquiries: Dr Stephen Struthers, Sociology, History, Anthropology and Resources Research Support Team.
Tel: 01793 413048
Fax: 01793 413010
E-mail: stephen.struthers@esrc.ac.uk

The Research Priorities Board is currently reviewing funding for the Evolution of Knowledge Programme, in competition with other programme proposals and the outcomes of the 2000/01 Research Centres, Groups and Priority Networks competition. This will mean that no interim funding will be available until such a review has taken place.
For enquiries contact: Angelika Hamilton
Tel : 01793 411922
E-mail: angelika.hamilton@esrc.ac.uk

Subject coverage
Area Studies
Economics
Economic and Social History
Education
Human Geography
Linguistics
Management and Business Studies
Multidisciplinary
Planning
Politics and International Relations
Psychology
Social Anthroplogy
Social Policy
Socio-Legal Studies
Sociology
Statistics
Research Methods and Computing Allied to the Social Sciences
Science, Technology and Innovation.

ESRC subjects overlap with those of the Arts and Humanities Research Board in some areas.

Grants
Postgraduate awards
Standard Research Studentships
Advanced Course Competition Studentships
Deadline: Departments must submit applications by no later than 1 May 2001.

Collaborative (CASE) Research Studentships
Success rate: 540 available.
Deadline: Departments must submit nominations by no later than 1 July 2001.

Advanced Course Studentships
Success rate: 563 available.
Deadline: Departments must submit nominations by no later than 1 June 2001.

Value of maintenance grants
London £8,500 Outside London £6,800

ESRC also pays:
 Disabled students' allowance
 Mature students' incentive

Research centres and groups
Purpose: to provide long-term research in a particular area of social science.
Funding: Centres are normally funded for 10 years (in exceptional cases, this may be extended to 15 years) and research groups for five years.
Deadline: New centres and groups are selected through a competition, normally held annually, and are managed by the Research Priorities Board.

Research Grants Scheme
Purpose: A Research Grant is an award made to an eligible institution to enable an individual or research team to undertake anything from a small project through to a large scale survey. There is also considerable flexibility when it comes to subject area.
Funding: Funding decisions are based on four key criteria: scientific quality, timeliness, track record of applicants, and value for money. Applications are considered for awards from £2,000 to £750,000 in total, with up to a maximum of £300,000 in annual expenditure. Research grants can be awarded for a period of up to five years and can be for basic, applied or strategic research.
Deadline: Applications invited under all areas of the ESRC remit. Applications can be submitted at any time.

ESRC/Ministry of Defence (MOD) Joint Scheme
Purpose: To stimulate collaboration between research establishments and academic institutes.
Funding: 50% of your funding from the MOD.

Research Fellowship Scheme
Purpose: The Fellowships will be available for research in the full range of social and economic sciences, and will be considered by the Research Grants Board alongside Research Grants.
Funding: There is no ringfenced sum for fellowships, therefore it is difficult to give guidance on the likely number of awards. Fellowships will be in competition with applications made under the existing Research Grants scheme.
Success rate: In the first year of the scheme's operation, 11 fellowships were funded and there is the possibility of these numbers increasing this year.
Deadline: Available to social scientists at all stages of a post-doctoral level career. Applications can be submitted at any time.

LINK Eating, Food and Health
Purpose: To provide the basis for a better understanding of factors leading to a healthier UK diet. The programme extends over a five year period from 1 June 1998 at a cost of approximately £5m, with £2.5m public sector sponsorship matched by an equal industrial investment.
Deadline: Open to applications until May 2003. Outline applications will be received on an open date basis for consideration. The Programme Manager, Dr Richard Shepherd, is available from 1 June 1998 to discuss potential applications.
Contact: Dr Richard Shepherd
Department of Psychology
University of Surrey
Guildford, Surrey
GU 5XH
Tel: 01483 259449
Fax: 01483 259553

Meg Wilson
BBSRC
Polaris House
North Star Avenue
Swindon SN2 1UH
Tel: 01793 413350
Fax: 01793 413201
Email: meg.wilson@bbsrc.ac.uk

Catherine Flynn
ESRC
Polaris House
North Star Avenue
Swindon SN2 1UJ
Tel: 01793 412064
Fax: 01793 413010
Email: catherine.flynn@esrc.ac.uk

LINK Sustainable Livestock Production Programme
Purpose: To initiate collaborative, pre-competitive research and technological development projects so that UK livestock production can maintain its economic competitiveness - with due regard for animal health and welfare, and environmental concerns. The ESRC has also agreed to consider, on a project by project basis, applications addressing the social science aspects of sustainable livestock production.
Funding: Industry must provide at least 50% of the project seeking , either in cash or in kind. Research or industrial organisations seeking appropriate partners for potential bids under the programme may contact the Programme Coordinator (see below) for advice.
Deadline: The programme is currently open to applications.

For further information contact:
The Programme Coordinator, Dr Jennifer Gunning
MAFF
Seventh Floor
1A Page Street
London SW1P 4PQ
Tel 020 7904 6289
Fax 020 7904 6758
E-mail: j.gunning@csg.maff.gsi.gov.uk

LINK Management of Information Programme
Purpose: This programme is aimed at the detection and countering of fraud, and the security and privacy of data and the individual.
Contact: For further details visit www.dti-mg.org.uk or contact the Programme Coordinator, Stan Price, on 0161 953 4026
E-mail: stan@ppsl.u-net.com

Joint Research Equipment Initiative (JREI)
Purpose: To contribute to the research infrastructure and to enable high quality research to be undertaken, particularly in areas of basic and strategic priority, for science and technology.
Funding: The essential requirements are that bids must be for research equipment; must have external sponsorship and must request a minimum of £12,500 from the JREI. Applications seeking less than 50% of the total cost of the bid from the JREI are particularly encouraged.
Deadline: This will now be run as an annual event by the Research Councils, the Higher Education Funding Councils for England, Scotland and Wales, and the Department of Education for Northern Ireland (DENI).

The initiative will run as two competitions:

Competition A - to fund bids for scientific and engineering research equipment requesting up to £150,000 from the JREI. This competition is to be funded and run through five of the Research Councils: BBSRC, EPSRC, MRC, NERC and PPARC. Applications should be made to the most appropriate of these Research Councils.

Competition B - to fund bids for research equipment requesting over £150,000 from the JREI. This competition is to be funded by the Higher Education funding bodies. Applications should be sent to the most appropriate of the six Research Councils.

Both competitions are open only to researchers in a UK higher education institution, funded by either a Higher Education Funding Council or DENI. The closing date for receipt of applications is 31 May. For a full list of the rules, click here.

The timetable for future years will remain the same.

ESRC 2000 Research Seminars
Purpose: Seminar Groups are multi-institutional groups of academic researchers and non-academics who meet regularly (usually at least three times a year) to exchange information and ideas with the aim of advancing research within their fields.
Funding: Successful proposals will be funded for up to two years. Applications should not exceed £12,000.
Deadline: Applicants will be notified of funding decisions by 28 February and awards may begin on 1 May or later. Applicants should return the form plus six copies to:
The Registrar
The Economic and Social Research Council
Polaris House
North Star Avenue
Swindon
Wiltshire SN2 1UJ
by Monday, 27th November 2001.

Contact: Lisa Hill, Science Manager
Direct Dial: 01793 413067
Email: Lisa.Hill@esrc.ac.uk

Fifth Framework Programme
The Framework Programme is the European Unionês programme for the financial support of Research, Technological Development and Demonstration (RTD). It runs in four-year phases.
Purpose: In the programme's current phase, Framework Programme 5 (FP5), more stress is laid on the socio-economic objectives of technology development and the commission wants more participation by social scientists in the collaborative projects.
Deadline: FP5 runs between 1999 and 2002.

Opportunities to submit projects for funding commenced in early 1999 will continue throughout the years of the programme. Information about call dates can be found on the CORDIS (Community Research and Development Service) website.
Contact: Stephen Struthers
E-mail: stephen.struthers@esrc.ac.uk
Tel: (01793) 413 048
Angelika Hamilton
E-mail: angelika.hamilton@esrc.ac.uk
Tel: (01793) 411 922

Devolution and Constitutional Change - Phase 2 (LINK)
Note: The deadline for proposals has now passed.
Purpose: This £4.7m programme of research, which is running from 2000 to 2005, examines a wide range of areas relating to devolution, constitutional change and consequential effects. The programme of research has three themes - nationalism and national identity, governance and constitutional matters, and economic and social policy.
Success rate: The first round of the programme committed funds of £3.1m and funded an initial group of 18 projects. The second call for proposals will lead to research to a value of around £1.6m being funded and it is likely that about 15 projects will be funded in this phase.

Millennium Cohort (LINK)
Note: The closing date for proposals for the initiative has passed.

Teaching and Learning Research Programme
Purpose: The core objectives of the Programme are to enhance the achievement of learners at all ages and stages in education, training and life-long learning; develop effective and efficient teaching and training practices and promote and extend multi-disciplinary and multi-sector research in teaching and learning.
Funding: Following a recent announcement of additional funding by the HEFCE (see below) it now has a budget in excess of £23m.
Deadline: Following consultations, the main phase of commissioning is expected to start in late 2001 and will be completed in early 2003. Research projects will then be expected to start from mid-2003 and run for up to five years (up to the revised end-date for the Programme in 2008).

Teaching and Learning Research Capability-Building Network
Purpose: Over the next three years the network aims to foster collaboration between the programmeês researchers and the wider teaching and learning research community, to support their professional development and facilitate the sharing of skills and experience. The Network will begin work in spring 2001. Its activities will be focused around three core elements: a review of the research resources available and the identification of opportunities for adding value and collaboration; support for research capacity building activities and training within the programme; dissemination and training targeted at the wider research community.
Funding: Details can be found on the Programme website or by contacting Dr Gorard at the School of Social Sciences, University of Cardiff. E-mail: Gorard@Cardiff.ac.uk

Polaris House
North Star Avenue
Swindon
SN2 1UJ
Tel: 01793 413043
Fax: 01793 413056
Website: www.esrc.ac.uk

webTitle: US finds it just ain't sport

fields.headline: US finds it just ain't sport
fields.standfirst: Americans like football and wrestling, but Julian Borger says combining them, with added sex and violence, is a turn-off
fields.trailText: Americans like football and wrestling, but Julian Borger says combining them, with added sex and violence, is a turn-off
fields.body:
"How low can you go?" is the seminal question posed each week by television networks around the world. Now, at last, from the United States comes a possible answer.

After burrowing to previously unimagined depths, the US network NBC appears finally to have underestimated its audience. Its attempt to launch a new American football league called XFL - in which the X implied extreme in everything from violence to cheerleaders' cleavages - has hit the rocks of viewer indifference.

After a hugely successful start, fans have been turning off by the million. But by last month, the matches broadcast by NBC received the lowest viewer ratings in modern prime-time history. It is now all but certain the NBC will axe its experiment before next season.

XFL's dismal failure is evidence that a distinction still exists between sport and entertainment, even if the border-line is patchy.

It was comprehensively breached in the case of wrestling, leading the advertisers and network executives to believe that the formula underlying the World Wrestling Federation (WWF) could be applied to other sports to enhance their humdrum ratings.

Some of the normal football rules designed to safeguard the players would be relaxed, while the pantomime violence, testosterone-infused script and scantily-clad women would bring in the all-important, high-spending, young men.

It was intended to be a genetically-engineered hybrid between the WWF and the orthodox National Football League (NFL) - which was thought to be too slow and stodgy. But instead, the XFL turned out to be a mutant which scared off almost everyone.

At the launch in early February, it looked as if everything was going to plan. The advance publicity had generated huge interest, in part by lingering over cheerleaders who were clad only in towels in a steam-filled changing room.

One of them provided her suggestive assessment of the Las Vegas quarterback. "He knows how to score," she purred.

In a nod to the perpetual state of anger exhibited by WWF contestants and commentators, the teams were given names like Rage, while the players assumed names like Death Blow.

Sixteen million people watched the first game on February 3. But somewhere in the awkward crack between football and hype, things began to go wrong. The teams were hurriedly brought together and had very little training, so the quality of play was shoddy.

Second, commentators had been brought in from the NFL, but were made to "get with the programme" and salivate over the dancing women.

One seasoned professional, Matt Vasgersian, could not bring himself to do it. According to the Wall Street Journal, he was supposed to produce some sort of exclamation when the "cleavage cam" zoomed in on the dancing women. He was even given handy suggestions like: "Now that's a cheerleader."

But Vasgersian could not bring himself to do it and lapsed into silence, with his producer yelling into his earpiece, ordering him to say something. In the end, the commentator laughed nervously and came out with: "I feel uncomfortable ... Man alive ... All righty then ... Those suits are something else."

He was demoted the following week, to be replaced by a WWF commentator alongside the tough-talking, ex-wrestling Minnesota governor, Jesse Ventura.

More recently, fans have been offered fly-on-the-wall views from inside the cheerleaders' changing rooms.

But it turned out that a lack of enthusiasm was not the problem. People had tuned in at first in the hope of watching some exciting football, but all they saw was mediocre sport against a background of overblown hype.

And that, thankfully for the future of sports - and possibly of civilisation too - that was not enough.

fields.headline: Norfolk
fields.standfirst: Disney's plan to shoot a sci-fi film in Norfolk has one minor flaw - the script calls for mountains. Read our online guide to the famously flat county
fields.trailText: Disney's plan to shoot a sci-fi film in Norfolk has one minor flaw - the script calls for mountains. Read our online guide to the famously flat county.
fields.body:
1. The county of Norfolk, famous for its mustard, its gorgeous broads (gedditt??!!) and its failed chat show hosts. But today sees the unveiling of a new tourist attraction, the Norfolk mountains.

2. Some of you may be surprised to hear of this development, Norfolk traditionally being as flat as a turkey steak (on the subject of turkeys, try typing www.bernard-matthews.com into your browser).

3. But this hasn't stopped everybody's favourite entertainment conglomerate Disney, who have decided to set a new sci-fi film in the fabled peaks of Norfolk.

4. Christian Bale is set to star alongside Matthew McConaughey in the upcoming Reign of Fire as a fireman fighting off, er, dragons in post-apocalyptic Swaffham (or thereabouts).

5. To get over their massif problem, the bods at Disney have relocated filming to the altogether more undulating Wicklow mountains in Ireland.

6. This, of course, is not the first time Disney have played fast and loose with the detail. They were somewhat creative with the story of Pocahontas which didn't go down well with native Americans.

7. This time though, they have enraged a more powerful minority group - the Norfolk tourist board.

8. Actually, they haven't, as a spokesman for Norfolk county council has confessed: "If fans of the film want to come to Norfolk to look for the mountains they are most welcome." And why not visit the mustard shop while you're there?

9. Because let's face it, you're unlikely to be able to wander freely around the fields.

10. Other famous films to have involved Christian Bale include Empire of the Sun and American Psycho. Other famous films involving Norfolk include, erm, Swallows and Amazons.

fields.headline: Brown remains optimistic on economy
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, today delivered a speech of cautious optimism about the state of the European economy, when he addressed the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, today delivered a speech of cautious optimism about the state of the European economy, when he addressed the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development in London.

His speech came as the European and American financial communities are at loggerheads over the state of the economy in Europe, with one report predicting solid growth while the Americans suggest that Europe can expect no better than the weak growth that the US has seen.

Mr Brown warned that Britain could not be insulated from the effects of the global economic slowdown. But he emphasised that the underlying strength of Britain's economy meant that it should be well-placed to weather the current turmoil and carry on delivering "stability and sustained growth".

He said: "At a time of slowing world economic growth, this is a moment not for retreating from global economic cooperation or losing faith in its efficacy and turning inwards, not to retreat into protectionism, but a time for enhanced global cooperation. It is time to recognise that while in recent years America has been the engine of growth in the world economy, Europe must also show a leadership role."

With the US economy flagging, Mr Brown has been under pressure to stave off recession here. The growth targets that he outlined in the budget in March - between 2.25% and 2.75% - have been contradicted by forecasters from Ernst and Young, which used the Treasury's own economic model and predicted that growth this year will fall to 2%.

Last week, the US treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, said he could not understand Europe's apparent confidence in light of the US downturn. Arriving in London for the EBRD meeting, the European commissioner for monetary affairs, Pedro Solbes, retorted that Europeans are in a better position to judge the state of the European economy than Americans.

Delegates at the EBRD meeting will be cheered today by a leaked report from the International Monetary Fund which says Britain is set to shrug off the global slowdown and emerge as one of Europe's fastest-growing nations.

The IMF report - due to be published on Thursday - said that only Spain's economy was expected to grow faster than the UK economy.

The figures from a draft of the IMF biannual World Economic Outlook predict that the British economy will slow to 2.6% growth this year compared to 3% in 2000. But it says that, in 2002, output will pick up to rise by 2.8%.

The leaked report emerged after it was announced yesterday that the government netted a record cash surplus of £37bn during the last financial year.

Fears of a US-style slowdown have put pressure on the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to cut interest rates again in order to offer the economy some protection from the international slowdown.

The Ernst and Young report forecast that interest rates, which currently stand at 5.5%, would have to be cut to just 3.5% to maintain even a reduced rate of growth.

fields.headline: C4 crowns Royal Blunder with 2m
fields.trailText: Channel 4 attracted nearly 2m viewers last night for a quick turn-around documentary about Sophie and Edward Wessex.
fields.body:
Channel 4 attracted nearly 2m viewers last night for a quick turn-around documentary about Sophie and Edward Wessex.

A Right Royal Blunder: the Sophie and Edward Story, commissioned from ITN in the wake of the recent Sophietapes furore, was broadcast between 10.30pm and 11.05pm last night on Channel 4.

The documentary drew 1.8m viewers and a 12% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

Channel 4 also attracted a good audience for another royal-related show, the Real Edward VII.

The documentary about the man who replaced his mother, Queen Victoria, as monarch on her death in 1901 went out between 9pm and 10.30pm.

It had 2.9m viewers and a 13% audience share.

ITV won the battle of the 9pm dramas last night, with new Michelle Collins two-parter Perfect proving more popular than its BBC1 opposition, Clocking Off.

Perfect, which stars Collins as a serial bigamist, debuted between 9pm and 10.30pm.

The first instalment had 7.4m viewers and a 33% audience share.

Clocking Off, which this week featured the story of a woman who takes on responsibility for her daughter's abandoned children, had just 6.1m and a 26% share in the same slot on BBC1.

Later in the evening ITV comedy drama Bob Martin made a wobbly return for its second series between 10.50pm and 11.20pm.

Bob Martin, which stars Michael Barrymore as a self-obsessed game show host, had just 2.5m viewers and a 21% audience share.

It lost out to BBC1 opposition Judy Garland - Hollywood Greats, which was on between 10.35pm and 11.20pm.

The biographical documentary drew 3.7m and a 28% share.

Channel 4 began repeating award-winning drama Traffik, the inspiration for Steven Soderbergh's Oscar-winning film, between 11.05pm and 1.10am last night.

Traffik had 0.5m viewers and a 9% share of the available audience.

fields.headline: Reuters anticipates slower growth rate
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: Reuters has warned the economic slowdown will dampen its short-term growth, reports Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Reuters has warned the economic slowdown will dampen its short-term growth.

Peter Job, the chief executive, made the announcement as the media giant reported healthy revenues in its first quarter trading statement today.

Revenue for the first quarter of 2001 rose 17% year on year to £970m.

Subscription-based products grew by 7% to pull in £458m.

"Revenue growth from Reuters's core financial business in the first quarter continued the strong trend of the second half of last year," said Mr Job.

"We anticipate growth will continue in the current quarter at a slightly lower rate. Our business model remains robust based on repeat revenues, which show no sign of eroding.

"The financial customer base is well diversified across many different institutions in over 50,000 locations worldwide," he added.

fields.headline: Mosquito flies into art world
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Three graduates have launched Mosquito, a magazine which hopes to create a forum for young artistic talent. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
A new magazine launched for young artists and creative people hopes to create a forum for young artistic talent.

Mosquito, launched by three graduates from Nottingham with Prince's Trust funding, has attracted over 500 contributions from artists and creative writers through a flyer campaign targeting cities including London, Manchester, Sheffield and Nottingham.

The magazine's co-founder, Guy Cookson, said the magazine wanted to be more "inclusive and accessible" than traditional art magazines, and would feature "everything from graffiti to fine art".

He said the magazine's primary focus was to allow young, creative people to get their ideas seen and recognised, and the magazine was soliciting contributions from across the world.

"There are so many people out there who want to get their creative ideas across" he said.

The magazine will launch with an initial print run of 15,000, priced £2.75 and will be stocked in Waterstones, Blackwells, independent newsagents, book and record shops.
