fields.headline: Blair unveils young offenders scheme
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has today unveiled plans to force young offenders to clean up graffiti and repair damage under a "community payback" scheme.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has today unveiled plans to force young offenders to clean up graffiti and repair damage under a "community payback" scheme.

The move is meant to make youths aware of the effects of anti-social behaviour on their neighbourhoods, as well as giving communities a sense that justice has been done. The scheme builds on reparation orders, introduced in England and Wales last June, under which young offenders undertake work to repair the damage to their victims and the local community.

The government is keen that the courts and multi-agency youth offending teams, which work with young offenders and will run the scheme, make greater use of the orders, especially the community payback element.

"Young offenders take something out of society through their offending. This scheme will allow them to put something back," Mr Blair said.

The prime minister set out his approach to youth offending, which also includes incentives to encourage good behaviour, in a speech to community leaders in Croydon, south London. Youths on high crime estates who stay out of trouble and are prepared to help their community could be rewarded with clothes and music vouchers.

Mr Blair said he wanted to build on 70 youth inclusion programmes already run by the youth justice board, which provide supervised leisure activities and personal development programmes for young people most at risk of offending.

A privately sponsored pilot scheme is being set up by the board in London, offering rewards to youngsters - such as vouchers for clothes, music, travel or computer equipment - if they take part in community renewal work.

The youth justice board is to issue guidance "strengthening and broadening" the orders, according to a spokesman. The new community payback scheme should ensure that, even where a victim does not ask for direct reparation, offenders can be ordered to work for the community removing graffiti, repairing vandalism and clearing up litter.

Crime reduction charity Nacro welcomed the prime minister's commitment to the principle of reparation.

"The traditional notion that young offenders can be 'punished out of crime' by a stretch in prison has always been a dubious one," said a spokesman. "If prison worked for young offenders, why do more than three-quarters of them commit more offences on release?

"Our own experience running such schemes shows that giving a young offender the chance to pay back for their offences brings home to them in a much more immediate way the impact of their actions than a spell in prison ever will."

And local communities would probably appreciate seeing young offenders trying to make up for their crimes in beneficial ways, he said.

A spokeswoman for the NSPCC children's charity said it was favour of using community interventions for dealing with minor offences such as graffiti and vandalism.

"We also support the principles of restorative justice which involve healing for both victim and offender to help make good the harm that's been done," she said.

fields.headline: Billiton blocks pay vote to spare blushes
fields.trailText: Mining group Billiton is refusing to let shareholders vote on a £6.5m options and cash package to be paid to chairman Brian Gilbertson on completion of its merger with BHP of Australia because it wants to spare the blushes of a South African shareholder.
fields.body:
Mining group Billiton is refusing to let shareholders vote on a £6.5m options and cash package to be paid to chairman Brian Gilbertson on completion of its merger with BHP of Australia because it wants to spare the blushes of a South African shareholder.

Several British investors had wanted the opportunity to vote on Billiton's controversial remuneration policy. But they were told such a vote could prove embarrassing for the Industrial Development Corporation of South Africa, which has an 8% stake.

As a firm focusing on development projects in some of the poorest parts of Africa, the IDC is thought to want to avoid any controversy over pay deals. Billiton, which announced its merger with BHP last month, is understood to have heeded shareholder concerns, however, by altering some terms of the original plan.

Mr Gilbertson, who is expected to run the combined company in two years' time, is agreeing to hold shares - worth £4.4m - maturing under a long-term incentive planfor three years, two years longer than the other directors.

One shareholder said: "This is an important case because it's raising issues about the discretion of remuneration committees." Billiton refused to comment, as did the IDC. The former is holding an extraordinary meeting on May 15 to endorse the BHP merger.

As a firm focusing on development projects in some of the poorest parts of Africa, the IDC is thought to want to avoid any controversy over pay deals. Billiton, which announced its merger with BHP last month, is understood to have heeded shareholder concerns, however, by altering some terms of the original plan. Mr Gilbertson, who is expected to run the combined company in two years' time, is agreeing to hold shares - worth £4.4m - maturing under a long-term incentive planfor three years, two years longer than the other directors. One shareholder said: "This is an important case because it's raising issues about the discretion of remuneration committees." Billiton refused to comment, as did the IDC. The former is holding an extraordinary meeting on May 15 to endorse the BHP merger.

webTitle: Blair outlines plans to improve cities

fields.headline: Blair outlines plans to improve cities
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today promised to reward young people who stay out of trouble on high crime estates as part of a package of measures giving local authorities and business more power to revitalise run-down towns and cities.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today promised to reward young people who stay out of trouble on high crime estates as part of a package of measures giving local authorities and business more power to revitalise run-down towns and cities.

The prime minister said he wanted to introduce new incentives to encourage responsible behaviour among young people with rewards such as music vouchers.

At the same time, he said that those youngsters who do get into trouble will be forced to clean up their graffiti and repair damage caused by vandalism as part of a new "community payback" scheme.

Mr Blair set out his carrot-and-stick approach to youth offending in a speech to community leaders in Croydon, south London, in which he stressed his determination to improve the "liveability" of Britain's cities towns and villages.

His package of reforms also includes plans to give private sector firms a bigger role in regenerating their local area, through so-called "business improvement districts" (Bids).

The plans, revealed exclusively by SocietyGuardian.co.uk yesterday, will see businesses voting on whether or not to pay for a package of improvements to their local area, such as more graffiti cleaning or extra police officers.

If they vote in favour, businesses will then work in partnership with local authorities to deliver the changes, paying through a supplementary business rate levied by councils.

Many of the details of the Bid schemes will be left to local politicians and businesses, including the level of the extra rate to be raised, and which businesses in what areas will pay.

Local government leaders, however, appeared unimpressed by Mr Blair's plans for Bids, arguing that a much more extensive reform of local government financing was needed.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, said: "We are calling on the government to deliver a finance system to local authorities that is fair, accountable and makes a real connection between cash raised - and spent - locally."

As part of the government's drive to clean up streets and parks which had become "dirty ugly and dangerous", the prime minister announced a doubling of "spot fines" for dog fouling and dropping litter.

Councils will also be able to earmark the revenues from specific fines and penalties, for example litter, dog fouling and parking fines, for additional spending on local environmental and quality of life improvements.

The prime minister also promised £50m for a street warden programme to crack down on neighbourhood nuisances such as litter and graffiti.

And there was £30m over three years to fund new "home zones", which aim to ensure that the needs of families in residential areas are taken into account as much as those of motorists.

"Britain needs to feel proud of its public spaces, not ashamed," said Mr Blair. "We need to make it safer for children to walk or cycle to school in safety. We need local parks which are well looked after and easily reached with a pushchair. We need streets to be free of litter dog mess and mindless vandalism."

But shadow environment secretary Archie Norman said the prime minister's launch illustrated "the bankruptcy" of the government's policy towards the inner cities.

He told reporters that for four years the government had neglected these areas, and spent less on the inner cities than his party had in office.

fields.headline: Chesterfield face larger points deduction
fields.trailText: Chesterfield face a new enquiry after the Football League's board of directors sensationally decided not to ratify the nine-point deduction recommended by their disciplinary panel - because they considered it too lenient.
fields.body:
Chesterfield face a new enquiry after the Football League's board of directors sensationally decided not to ratify the nine-point deduction recommended by their disciplinary panel - because they considered it too lenient.

The decision means that Chesterfield face a larger points deduction which could rob them of promotion to the Second Division.

The panel had originally suggested the Spireites be docked the points, and fined £20,000, after being found guilty of two of the 90 charges brought against them following allegations of financial irregularities.

But Football League chief executive David Burns said the punishment recommended by the panel didn't go far enough.

"As a result of the findings of guilt by the panel, the board considers that the recommendation to deduct nine points does not sufficiently reflect the damage brought to the integrity of the competition," he said.

"Accordingly we have asked the panel to reconvene to consider the matter afresh."

Sports minister Kate Hoey, who has been involved in measures to combat corruption in soccer, welcomed the Football League's decision.

She said: "I very much agree with the board's view that the punishment did not sufficiently reflect the damage brought to the integrity of the competition.

"The penalty, which would have still allowed the club to benefit from breaking the rules at the expense of the other clubs who have abided by the rules, is just not right."

Officials at Chesterfield, who would have dropped to third place had the nine-point deduction been rubber-stamped, were upset to hear that the League considered the punishment too lenient.

Chief executive John Green said: "I'm extremely disappointed but we need to consider what our next move is in the next 24 hours."

The club's assistant manager Ian Banks added: "We all thought it was done and dusted. We thought that was it - and it just keeps going on. It's one thing after another.

"It's another kick in the goolies - and it's not as though we haven't had enough of them this season."

Ex-chairman Darren Brown, who resigned along with vice-chairman Paul Grafton after the charges were brought, said: "As far as I'm concerned, the panel made a decision - be it good, bad or indifferent - and at least everybody at the club thought they could still get promoted.

"The decision was made to take the medicine and get on with it and get promoted, but now it's been thrown up in the air and it's in turmoil again.

"We maintained right through the hearing that the club had done nothing wrong. We were disappointed with the nine points.

"They're [the Football League] obviously insinuating that it's not a harsh enough punishment. We felt nine points was perhaps too harsh because we had done nothing wrong."

fields.headline: Pret a Manger seeks top marketeer
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: The sandwich chain is on the hunt for its first dedicated marketing chief, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
Pret a Manger is looking for its first dedicated marketing chief, four months after selling a 33% stake to McDonald's.

Marketing is handled by Morag McKay, the company's executive director, but her role has been widened to allow her to focus on international expansion.

The head of UK marketing will be charged with building awareness of the Pret a Manger brand beyond London as the chain opens 20 more outlets outside the capital.

It already has 30 branches outside London.

Although the McDonald's deal netted the chain £26m, a Pret a Manger source said the company had always intended to hire a dedicated marketing chief.

Ms McKay is expected to continue handling marketing until the new marketing head comes on board.

fields.headline: Dangerous liaison for email users
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: The latest drama to be unleashed on email users is a tale of jealousy and intrigue called the Evil Sex, writes Ashley Davies.
fields.body:
The latest web-based drama to be unleashed on email users is a modern adaptation of the 18th century novel, Les Liaisons Dangereuses.

The drama, called the Evil Sex, is being billed as a tale of "scheming, bitching, control-freakery, jealousy and sexual intrigue".

Users receive an email every day for 16 days telling them where to find the latest video message from characters in the drama.

The plot centres on a man who seeks revenge on his dumped friend's former boyfriend.

"You get a lot of people saying online dramas have to be non-linear but we want to keep it simple so people at home can use it," said Mark Capell, co-creator of the project and a former development producer of New Media for United Productions.

Related story

webTitle: Isle of Man cancels TT races

fields.headline: Isle of Man cancels TT races
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The Isle of Man TT motorcycle races today become the latest sporting victim of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The Isle of Man TT motorcycle races today become the latest sporting victim of the foot and mouth crisis.

The decision was taken in the Tynwald, the island's parliament, after fears that the expected 40,000 spectators would increase the risk of bringing the disease to the so far infection-free island.

The races, which were scheduled to take place from May 26 to June 8, have never been cancelled during peacetime since they began in 1907.

The move by the council of ministers follows professional advice that the influx of motorcycle fans, who watch the racing from farmland around the 37-mile course, would "significantly" increase the chances of the disease spreading.

The Isle of Man's chief minister, Donald Gelling, said: "I and my colleagues in the council of ministers are sorry to announce a decision that will be disappointing to our tourist industry and the many loyal TT visitors.

"Our priority now must be to help this important sector at this difficult time and to ask the fans to look forward to a special TT festival in 2002."

He added: "The Isle of Man remains free from foot and mouth, and Manx tourism is still very much open for business. It is the unique nature of the TT - the concentration of numbers involved and their proximity to livestock areas - that has raised special concerns in this case.

"The decision to cancel was extremely difficult and not one that was taken lightly.

"We hope people will understand that the alternative was to take an extra risk, against advice, of introducing a terrible disease which could devastate the Manx countryside and cause long-term damage to tourism as well as agriculture."

fields.headline: Canberra halts Shell takeover
fields.standfirst: $3.2bn Woodside bid 'against national interest'
fields.trailText: Royal Dutch/Shell's new strategy of hostile takeovers was thrown off course yesterday when the Australian government blocked its proposed £3.2bn deal to take control of Woodside Petroleum.
fields.body:
Royal Dutch/Shell's new strategy of hostile takeovers was thrown off course yesterday when the Australian government blocked its proposed £3.2bn deal to take control of Woodside Petroleum.

The Anglo-Dutch group is now under more intense pressure to pull off a sensitive bid on the other side of the globe - a contested £1.2bn deal for Barrett Resources in the US.

Peter Costello, the Australian treasurer, ruled against the Woodside deal on the grounds that it jeopardised the national interest. The decision, widely interpreted as political, knocked Woodside shares - which fell 10.5% to A$12.49 - and the Australian currency. Shell shares ended the day up 8p at 574.5p.

Mr Costello said: "Australia welcomes foreign investment - there's no change of policy there - but we also have to have an eye to the national interest for maximum exploitation of our resources."

He said Woodside's control of the North West Shelf gas project, potentially Australia's biggest export earner, was very important. His supporters claimed that Shell might prioritise other gas schemes in Asia. Opponents saw Mr Costello making a blatant populist move on behalf of the ruling conservative coalition in the run-up to federal elections.

Shell officials in London said the decision was a "deep disappointment" but the company made clear privately that its more aggressive policies would not be sidetracked on the basis of one setback.

In a statement, Peter Duncan, chairman of Shell Australia, said the company saw the move as a significant lost opportunity for Australia to enhance its position in the fiercely competitive liquefied natural gas market. "It is disturbing that the intensive campaign to position the merger as [being] against the national interest has succeeded in depriving Woodwide shareholders of the benefits of the merger proposal," he said.

Shell said it would take time to digest the impact of the decision but few analysts expect the energy group either to sell off its 34% holding in Woodside or to come up with a re vised bid. London analysts said chasing Woodside had been costly to Shell in terms of management time and effort but believed that the group had not come out of the long-running attempt too badly.

"It was a perfectly sensible strategy which was sat on for political reasons," said one analyst, who asked not to be named. Another added: "It's not good news, but this deal was never a company maker and is not a company wrecker, either. Shell will want to succeed in America [with Barrett], though."

Analysts and fund managers in Australia were shocked by the decision, saying it would send a negative signal to overseas markets about buying Australian assets and suggest that the local markets were subject to political pressure. The national currency dropped 1.5 US cents to below US$0.51 on fears that Australia was closing its doors to foreign investment.

Monica Fan, senior economist at JP Morgan, said: "The danger now is that the Australian dollar will be dogged by perceptions that the government is anti foreign investment."

fields.headline: Hart joins Excite@Home as CEO
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: The appointment coincides with the release of disappointing quarterly results, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Struggling high-speed internet access provider Excite@Home has ended its seven-month search for a leader by hiring telecoms industry veteran Patti Hart as CEO.

The announcement coincides with the release of disappointing quarterly results and the news that Excite@Home may sell its media operations and trigger a further round of redundancies.

In January the company laid off 250 workers - about 8% of its staff.

Although the results were in line with analysts' expectations, the company said its media assets were a huge drain.

They cancel out much of the strong growth achieved by the high-speed internet access business.

Excite@Home needs £57m to survive this year. This money could be raised by either selling off the portal or parts of its network to the majority shareholder, AT&T.

Excite@Home posted losses of £594m in the first quarter and has lowered its outlook for the second quarter.

Its revenue rose 3% year on year to $142.8m.

The company's new boss, Ms Hart, 44, was most recently the head of Telocity, a digital telecoms company owned by Hughes Electronics.

She recently appeared in Fortune's list of the 50 most powerful women who influence corporate America.

Ms Hart replaces George Bell, who resigned as CEO in September and yesterday stepped down as chairman and board member.

Mr Bell's decision to leave Excite - after promising he would stay on as chairman - mirrors that of Yahoo!'s Tim Koogle, who last week announced he was leaving the company.

Excite@Home was created in 1999 from the merger of internet portal Excite and broadband cable provider @Home.

The company was touted initially as a potential threat to AOL and it planned an ambitious expansion into Europe.

While the broadband business has been successful - it has signed up 3.2m subscribers - the internet portal has suffered at the hands of the diminishing internet advertising market.

In the UK, Excite.co.uk competes with Lycos.co.uk and Yahoo.co.uk but does not appear in any lists of top 10 website.

The portal's last reported traffic figures in November were 76m.

fields.headline: Ericsson rings up Sony alliance
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Ericsson has linked up with Sony to revitalise their loss-making mobile phone operations. By Amy Vickers.

20.04.2001: Ericsson to cut 10,000 more jobs

20.04.2001: Ericsson and Sony discuss mobile alliance
fields.body:
The Swedish mobile phone giant, Ericsson, has jumped into bed with the Japanese consumer electronics giant, Sony, to revitalise their loss-making mobile phone operations.

The joint venture, called Sony Ericsson, was confirmed this morning following months of speculation.

The alliance is expected to leapfrog Ericsson, which last week laid off 10,000 staff, into a more competitive position against the leading mobile phone manufacturer, Nokia, and second placed Motorola.

"We will create an entirely new brand for the products that will come out of the joint venture," Ericsson's chief executive, Kurt Hellstrom, told a news conference this morning.

"We will start operations in October and we expect to launch the first products during the first half of 2002."

Analysts believe the alliance with Sony will allow Ericsson to revive its fortunes and give it a foothold in the lucrative Japanese market.

Sony, in turn, will be able to boost its weak presence in Europe and the US, and tap into wireless expertise and a ready-made distribution network.

The partnership, which will work on a number of products for 3G networks and other mobile internet and audio applications, will focus on product research, design and development.

Rival mobile manufacturer Motorola is also feeling the pinch. This morning it was reported that more than 3,000 mobile phone workers at a Motorola plant on the outskirts of Edinburgh were about to be laid off, as the company closed the site.

fields.headline: Ex-Ministry pair go it alone
fields.trailText: 2pm: Ministry magazine's former managing director Mike Dash is working on plans to launch a new publishing company, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The former managing director of Ministry magazine, Mike Dash, and its new launch director, Fiona Jerome, are working on plans to launch a new publishing company.

They were made redundant earlier this year by the club superbrand, after its plans to expand its media empire were shelved.

Mr Dash confirmed he was in discussions about a new company, but would not be drawn on what form it would take or what type of magazines it would launch.

He was recruited by Ministry last year in a bid to spearhead its expansion into other platforms, including a book publishing arm and an Australian-based men's magazine.

Ms Jerome, the colourful former editor of John Brown Publishing's lads' magazine, Bizarre, was also recruited to spearhead new magazine launches but was made redundant when Ministry was forced to retrench.

Ministry of Sound, set up by James Palumbo in the early 1990s, has become one of the most successful dance music brands.

In the mid-1990s it launched Ministry magazine, which has grown to rival Mixmag and Muzik.

But the publishing arm has been hit by problems this year amid reports that it has overspent on its internet division.

The magazine has made several redundancies over the past weeks.

webTitle: Sky not bidding for World Cup

fields.headline: Price of World Cup is outrageous
fields.trailText: 10.30pm: Sky TV has declared it will not be bidding to broadcast the next two football World Cups because the price set by rights owner Kirch is "outrageous", writes Ashley Davies
fields.body:
BSkyB is refusing to bid to broadcast the next two football World Cups because the price set by rights owner Kirch is "outrageous".

Kirch is believed to want £170m from UK broadcasters to show the 2002 and 2006 tournaments. BBC and ITV paid only £4m each for the 1998 competition.

"We're not going to be used just because they have overvalued the European rights for the event without doing their homework," said Vic Wakeling, the managing director of Sky Sports.

"BBC and ITV have winced at the price and I don't blame them... We wouldn't pay that sort of money if we were allowed to," he told the Financial Times today.

But Kirch's massive demands will only be put into practice if the European Court agrees to annul the European Commission agreement on a UK list of protected sports events such as Wimbledon, the Grand National and the World Cup.

A spokesman for the department of culture, media and sport said it was confident the list would stand up to legal scrutiny.

Kirch bought the World Cup rights from Fifa for £570m.

fields.headline: May Day protest propaganda
fields.trailText: More than 100 stories have appeared in the national press in the past month alone on the subject of the forthcoming May Day protest - yet virtually every single one breaks the cardinal rule of journalism: to get both sides of the story.
fields.body:
More than 100 stories have appeared in the national press in the past month alone on the subject of the forthcoming May Day protest - yet virtually every single one breaks the cardinal rule of journalism: to get both sides of the story.

Today's briefing from the London mayor, Ken Livingstone, and the chief commissioner of the Metropolitan police, Sir John Stevens, pledging zero tolerance to those intent on committing criminal damage, is the latest in a long line of police briefings which many journalists have reported without seeming to make an effort to contact those behind the protests to get a balanced view.

As a recent letter to the Guardian claimed, these special branch briefings serve two purposes: to discredit the anti-capitalist movement, and to acclimatise public opinion for a violent police crackdown.

Paradoxically, it is the demonstrators' ability to outwit both police and journalists through disinformation on the internet and emailing campaigns that is the ace up their sleeve, but also creates a void into which any amount of speculative reporting can be filed.

The London Evening Standard has led the charge with headlines such as:

 May Day Rioters Train at US Camps
 Anarchists Plot to Halt London on May Day
 May Day "Zero Tolerance"
 Capital Chaos Looms In May: Police step up security over riot and terrorist fears
 Anarchists to Loot Oxford Street Stores on May Day
 Wanted: the 24 May Day Anarchists Scotland Yard is Hunting.

In fact, the only concrete details about the plans for May 1 are two mass bicycle rides leaving from Marylebone and Liverpool Street stations at 7.30am, to disrupt motor vehicles driving through the capital in rush hour, and a mass convergence of demonstrators at Oxford Circus at 4pm.

Indeed, the critical mass bike ride is only an offshoot of the monthly event, where cyclists ride around the capitals of all major European and many US cities to highlight the dominance of the motor car.

These events are advertised on the web, but the gap in the schedule has allowed journalists the freedom to speculate that the advertised May Day Monopoly "Sale of the Century" will encompass separate attacks on the Square Mile, vandalisation of chainstores such as McDonald's, Starbucks, Gap and Niketown, destruction of the Royal Opera House and even the occupation of a major London landmark.

The Observer has also reported that armed guards will be on patrol to disarm demonstrators carrying samurai swords, and the Independent reported that armed police raided a derelict factory in Herne Hill, south London, thought to be occupied by "the Wombles" - that is, the White Overall Movement Building Liberation Through Effective Struggle. The factory was empty.

Those with slightly longer memories would do well to look at the press coverage through March and April of last year, where scores of stories detailed how "guerrilla gardeners" would bring pitchforks and spades into central London, under the guise of digging up Parliament Square, in order to attack police.

In fact, the planting of sods of grass on the tarmac around Whitehall was the most peaceful aspect of last year's demonstration and no gardening implements were used against riot police.

But why left the facts get in the way of a good story?

There is no denying last year's protests were marred by violence, but graffiti on statues and the smashing of McDonald's' windows were, as even the usually conservative Financial Times reported at the time, little more than the usual Friday night events of many provincial English towns.

fields.headline: Work goes on for Labour advertising
fields.trailText:
1.45pm: Labour has rushed to fill the poster sites it booked for a May 3 election with a new campaign. By Claire Cozens.
03.04.2001: Parties rush to cancel costly posters for hold-up"
Useful link: labour.org.uk
fields.body:
Labour has rushed to fill the poster sites it booked in anticipation of a May 3 election with a new campaign dubbed "The work goes on".

The campaign, created by Labour's advertising agency TBWA/London, launched this week on poster sites around the country that Labour has been unable to offload.

The three main political parties began their campaigns back in January, expecting a May election.

Had that gone ahead as planned, this week would have been crucial in the pre-election advertising battle.

They now face the challenge of keeping the momentum going without overloading voters with too many different messages.

"Labour has delivered a lot to the British people, but we know there is still much to do, so the work goes on," says the Labour party's website.

fields.headline: Spending on the regions
fields.standfirst: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland could stand to lose billions as the government looks to reassess the way it spends. But how did these devolved governments end up with more cash per head then in England? Simon Parker explains
fields.trailText: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland could stand to lose billions as the government threatens to review the way it spends. How did these devolved regions end up with more cash per head then in England anyway? Simon Parker explains.
fields.body:
So the Scots get more money than the English?
That's right. And so do the Welsh and the Northern Irish. In fact, while public spending on services like education in England averages nearly £4,300 a head, Northern Ireland gets nearly £6,000, Scotland around £5,300 and Wales more than £5,000.

Why has the government allowed this to happen?
It's all down to the Barnett formula, named after the former chief secretary to the Treasury who introduced it in the late 70s. The formula is actually supposed to reduce the differences between spending in the UK, but it has not done a good job. Faced with the threat of nationalism, successive ministers bypassed Barnett, and so differences in spending remain large. Some academics suggest Gordon Brown is the first chancellor to properly apply Barnett, and research shows that Scottish budget increases are currently being "squeezed" by around £350m a year relative to those in England.

If the differences are already being reduced, why the calls for change?
Opponents argue that the need for extra spending in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland has declined since the formula was introduced, but that the three assemblies still receive unfairly high funding. Some of the English regions, meanwhile, are in need of a helping hand. The calls for a change have been led by the usual suspects - northern backbench MPs, regional lobby groups and north-east council leaders - who believe they will get a better deal from a review of Barnett. All three groups think the process of redistributing funds between the regions and nations needs to be sped up.

Who would be the winners and losers if the government changed the formula?
The simple answer is that the three devolved administrations would probably lose out, and the English regions would probably gain. Even relatively wealthy areas like East Anglia might see a funding boost. But things may not prove to be quite that straightforward. The government will probably try to change the Barnett formula on the basis of need, and the countries on the Celtic fringe do have real problems that might justify higher spending than England. Scotland, for example, has a geographically diffuse and ageing population, which suffers from famously poor health. These kinds of factors push up the costs of delivering public services to the same standards of those in England.

Why is the government thinking of reviewing funding now?
Partly because some ministers, led by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, are pushing hard for the creation of devolved English regional parliaments. A green paper on the issue is expected shortly after the election, and insiders are predicting that the first English regional governments could be in place within two years. This massive constitutional change provides ministers with a prime opportunity to re-examine the way money is distributed around the UK.

fields.headline: 'Whassup?' goes intergalactic
fields.standfirst: Click here to watch the advert
fields.trailText:
10.30am: The latest Budweiser commercial features a group of aliens shouting the famous catchphrase, writes Claire Cozens.
Click here to watch the advert
08.03.2001: 'Whassup?' man wins top advertising prize
fields.body:
The "Whassup?" phenomenon spawned by Budweiser's adverts has reached outer space.

A new campaign to be screened in the UK next month shows a group of aliens shouting the famous catchphrase to one another.

The commercial, which is already showing in the US, shows a cute dog being beamed up into a flying saucer.

Once inside the spaceship, he greets the awaiting extraterrestrials and pulls off his dog costume to reveal an alien head beneath.

When the aliens ask what he has learned on earth, their friend replies by shouting: "Whassup?".

The final shot shows a scientist listening to sounds from outer space, suddenly deafened by the sound of aliens shouting: "Whassup!".

"Oh man! We are not alone," he exclaims.

The "Whassup!" campaign made its UK debut last September with an advert that showed a gang of friends greeting each other's phone calls by shouting: "Whassup?" then replying: "Watching the game, having a Bud."

The campaign is one of the most successful of the last 12 months and picked up the top prize at last year's Cannes advertising festival.

It has even spawned a host of spoof versions on the internet.

These include a northern version that has a group of Lancashire lads shouting: "Ey up!" and a Star Wars version featuring Chewbacca and Han Solo.

Related story

fields.headline: Interactive TV firm sees way ahead
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: The future of Two Way TV looks more certain after it secured £12m in new funding, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The future of the interactive TV games company, Two Way TV, looks more certain after it secured a £12m fresh round of funding.

The company said it was a huge relief to bank the money after an uncertain few months in which it had to slash costs by laying off 25% of its workforce.

Two Way TV, which is 48% backed by NTL, now says it has enough money to carry it through to break-even point at the end of next year, but will look for additional capital to support growth in other territories in a year's time.

It also means Two Way TV can revive plans to roll out its games and interactive programming to satellite TV.

At present, Two Way TV services are only available on Telewest and NTL's interactive TV areas, but it is about to launch a separate interactive TV channel on ONdigital.

It has been held back from launching its flagship enhanced TV products because of cable's delayed roll-out of enhanced TV technology.

The investment has come from Swedish fund SMI Media Invest, which will become a significant minority shareholder in Two Way TV, with two of its directors joining the main board.

This adds to a £4.86m loan from set-top box software company Liberate Technologies at the end of last year that will now be converted into equity.

webTitle: US-Taiwan arms deal takes middle ground

fields.headline: US-Taiwan arms deal takes middle ground
fields.standfirst:
While China may baulk at the US provision of weapons to Taiwan, the deal represents a compromise, writes Mark Tran

Special report: Taiwan

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: While China may baulk at the US provision of weapons to Taiwan, the deal is a compromise, writes Mark Tran.
fields.body:
China will grumble and may even recall its ambassador for consultations when the Bush administration today announces the biggest arms sales to Taiwan in almost a decade.

Not since the previous Bush administration has the US sold so much weaponry to Taiwan. Although Mr Bush has yet to make a formal announcement, US officials briefing in Washington say the sale is to include four Kidd-class destroyers, a dozen anti-submarine planes and as many as eight diesel-powered submarines.

The package could amount to $4bn, the largest chunk of change since Taiwan bought 150 F-16 fighters from the US in 1982.

China will feel particularly aggrieved by the sale of so many submarines, as they could take a serious toll of any armada crossing the Taiwan strait should open conflict ever break out.

In its initial reaction, China has expressed its "serious concern" about the sale, but it got its way on the hardware that really raised hackles. President Bush has decided against the sale of destroyers equipped with ultra-sophisticated Aegis radar system that is supposed to be able to track 100 aircraft and missiles at a time.

China objects to any military equipment that goes to Taiwan, but would have been apopletic about the Aegis as it would mark another step towards a regional missile defence system, something it vehemently opposes.

The Aegis system featured on Taiwan's wish list, although some Taiwanese defence officials considered overly sophisticated and pricey. China said the Aegis sale would have been provocative yet it is Chinese behaviour that stokes Taiwanese anxieties.

China brands Taiwan a renegade province, conducts intimidatory military manoeuvres and builds missiles at the rate of 50 a year, in addition to the 300 it already has. The number may seem puny compared to American numbers, but they look daunting enough to Taiwan, although it has to be said that relations between the two have not all been tough talk.

In January, the two countries authorised boats to travel between the mainland and Taiwan's two islands, Quemoy and Matsu, in a little-noticed sign of rapprochement between Beijing and Taipei.

Under the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, the US agreed to provide Taiwan with "such defence articles and defence services as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defence capability".

But that runs smack into a 1982 US-China agreement calling on Washington to gradually reduce the quality and quantity of arms sold to the island. With such contradictory pieces of legislation, the White House has plenty of legal leeway, less so diplomatically.

The US may feel closer ideologically to the democrats in Taiwan than the autocrats in Beijing, but huge commercial interests invariably trump political empathy.

As long as China's vast market beckons, the US will refrain from actions that antagonise Beijing too much. The sale of Aegis-equipped warships would have been a defence system too far, especially coming so soon after the row over the collision between an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter.

Taiwan's reaction to the proposed sale indicates that it too recognises the political limits of the latest transaction. The defence ministry said any arms sales from Washington were welcome as they helped preserve stability in Asia.

While it will not get everything it asked for, Taiwan considers the scale of this package as signalling a new level of support from the US. Under the circumstances, the deal should suit all three parties.

China objects to any military equipment that goes to Taiwan, but would have been apopletic about the Aegis as it would mark another step towards a regional missile defence system, something it vehemently opposes. The Aegis system featured on Taiwan's wish list, although some Taiwanese defence officials considered overly sophisticated and pricey. China said the Aegis sale would have been provocative yet it is Chinese behaviour that stokes Taiwanese anxieties. China brands Taiwan a renegade province, conducts intimidatory military manoeuvres and builds missiles at the rate of 50 a year, in addition to the 300 it already has. The number may seem puny compared to American numbers, but they look daunting enough to Taiwan, although it has to be said that relations between the two have not all been tough talk. In January, the two countries authorised boats to travel between the mainland and Taiwan's two islands, Quemoy and Matsu, in a little-noticed sign of rapprochement between Beijing and Taipei. Under the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, the US agreed to provide Taiwan with "such defence articles and defence services as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defence capability". But that runs smack into a 1982 US-China agreement calling on Washington to gradually reduce the quality and quantity of arms sold to the island. With such contradictory pieces of legislation, the White House has plenty of legal leeway, less so diplomatically. The US may feel closer ideologically to the democrats in Taiwan than the autocrats in Beijing, but huge commercial interests invariably trump political empathy. As long as China's vast market beckons, the US will refrain from actions that antagonise Beijing too much. The sale of Aegis-equipped warships would have been a defence system too far, especially coming so soon after the row over the collision between an American spy plane and a Chinese fighter. Taiwan's reaction to the proposed sale indicates that it too recognises the political limits of the latest transaction. The defence ministry said any arms sales from Washington were welcome as they helped preserve stability in Asia. While it will not get everything it asked for, Taiwan considers the scale of this package as signalling a new level of support from the US. Under the circumstances, the deal should suit all three parties. fields.headline: Metro set for further expansion
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Associated Newspapers's free newspaper could be launched in Liverpool, Bristol and Cardiff, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Associated Newspapers's free urban newspaper Metro could be set for a further wave of expansion, with Liverpool, Bristol and Cardiff earmarked as potential launch cities.

Metro's managing director, Mike Anderson, said the three cities "all looked good from a marketing analysis perspective".

Although he said there were no firm plans, Mr Anderson hinted these were the next three cities lined up as launch targets.

"It would be distinctly possible to launch in these cities," he said. "We don't consider Metro a done deal by any means."

Presenting statistical research on Metro readers, Mr Anderson said it had allowed Associated to "filter out whether Metro should manifest itself as another business".

He said Metro delivered 809,000 copies a day throughout the UK, with 375,000 handed out in London.

He said the newspapers made a profit on some days on a nationwide basis, delivering close to £40m of advertising revenue this year.

Metro in London - the first city to launch the paper - makes a clear profit, although other cities have yet to catch up.

He said the paper had been successful at targeting the "lost children" - people who don't read newspapers.

"Metro has no political spin or bias," he said. "It says nothing about you except for its brand."

He said the Metro reader was typical of the kind of "apathetic" voter that Tony Blair wanted to reach.

Metro's readership, he said, "cannot be accessed any other way", giving the company a degree of future-proofing against a downturn in advertising revenue.

webTitle: Blair announces crackdown on yob culture

fields.headline: Blair announces crackdown on yob culture
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, has announced a new crackdown on yob culture in the run up to a possible June general election, with culprits forced to clean up after themselves in their local communities.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, has announced a new crackdown on yob culture in the run up to a possible June general election, with culprits forced to clean up after themselves in their local communities.

In a speech today Mr Blair singled out "liveability" as a key factor undermining pride in Britain's cities, and promised to make young vandals repair the damage they cause.

And he held out the "carrot" of music and clothes vouchers for reformed young offenders who take party in community renewal work.

However, the "community payback" scheme, which comes backed with government money and a partnership with the private sector, was immediately attacked both by local authorities and the Conservative party, who dubbed it another of the prime minister's "eye catching" initiatives - a reference to the infamous leaked memo from the PM last summer.

Speaking to community leaders in Croydon, south London, the PM said: "Young offenders take something out of society through their offending. This scheme will allow them to put something back.

"These issues affect the whole country. Streets that are dirty and threatening deter people from going out. They signal that the community has lost interest. As a result, anti-social behaviour and more serious criminality may take root."

Mr Blair said that he wanted to build on the youth inclusion programmes already run by the youth justice board on 70 high crime estates, which provide supervised leisure activities and personal development programmes for youngsters most at risk of offending.

A privately sponsored pilot scheme is being set up by the board in London, offering rewards to youngsters - such as vouchers for clothes, music, travel or computer equipment - if they take part in community renewal work.

At the same time the new community payback scheme will expand the system of reparation orders in England and Wales, so that when the victim does not ask for direct reparation, offenders can be ordered to work for the community removing graffiti, repairing vandalism and clearing up litter.

Other measures announced by Mr Blair in his speech included:
 A tripling of funding, to £50m, for the neighbourhood wardens programme, building on existing pilot projects designed to clamp down on nuisance behaviour
 A new £30m challenge fund to create more "Home zones" - areas where priority is given to walking and cycling over traffic
 Reducing the time it takes local authorities to remove abandoned cars. Pilot schemes will be set up in London to study the scope for local authorities to wheelclamp abandoned vehicles and remove them within 24 hours
 Giving local authorities the revenues from specific fines and penalties, for example litter, dog fouling, and parking fines, for additional spending on local environmental and quality of life improvements.

Shadow secretary of state for the environment, Archie Norman, condemned the initiative as an election gimmick, saying: "Tony Blair has had four years to address the plight of inner cities.

"In almost all of these areas council tax has gone up by nearly a third but the quality of life in inner cities has declined. Now in the run up to the election he produces a torrent of superficial initiatives."

Local government leaders also appeared unimpressed by Mr Blair's plans, arguing that a much more extensive reform of local government financing was needed.

Sir Jeremy Beecham, chairman of the Local Government Association, said: "We are calling on the government to deliver a finance system to local authorities that is fair, accountable, and makes a real connection between cash raised - and spent - locally."

webTitle: Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe

fields.headline: Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe
fields.trailText: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are poised to lose their privileged status as the big spenders of the UK. Ministers are preparing for a post-election battle with the three devolved administrations by unstitching the complex Whitehall formula which guarantees them much higher levels of public spending than the English regions.
fields.body:
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are poised to lose their privileged status as the big spenders of the UK. Ministers are preparing for a post-election battle with the three devolved administrations by unstitching the complex Whitehall formula which guarantees them much higher levels of public spending than the English regions.

The move comes amid mounting criticism from regional lobby groups, backbench MPs and senior English ministers that the current method of distributing resources discriminates against the poorest parts of England, where unemployment is high and manufacturing is steadily declining.

New Treasury figures show that attempts to narrow the public-spending gap between England and the remainder of the UK under New Labour have failed: Public spending in Scotland remains 23% above the English average, while Northern Ireland and Wales are 39% and 18% above, respectively.

Senior ministers are alarmed because, for the first time, the figures make direct and unflattering comparisons with the English regions.

Yorkshire and Humber, which roughly reflects Scotland's 5m population, would need an additional £5.2bn annually to match the spending levels north of the border. The north-east would need more than £1bn and the south-east more than £12bn due to its larger population.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has signalled that a review of local government finance, promised soon after the election, will include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK.

Warning of "blood on the carpet" because the exercise will produce losers as well as gainers, he says the government should "bite the bullet" before the summer and finally address an issue which has been dodged for years amid fears of a tartan backlash.

"This will have to be done quickly because it's not the sort of row you want in the [next] election period," he told The Guardian. "We need to get a timetable for it to be settled as quickly as we can."

While careful to stress that direct comparisons between the nations and regions of the UK can be invidious, Mr Prescott insisted that the complex funding formula is certainly not "written in stone".

He said New Labour only in tended for the so-called Barnett formula to apply for the current parliament.

"No government can guarantee beyond that," he said.

The formula was devised by Lord (Joel) Barnett while Treasury chief secretary during the mid-70s. At the time, Scotland was poorer than many parts of Britain, although its level of wealth is now considerably higher than many English regions.

Lord Barnett now says it has outlived its usefulness and discriminates against England.

Mr Prescott predicted "one hell of a debate" as the government moved to examine spending throughout the town halls, regions and nations of the UK.

With a string of ministers pressing Downing Street to answer the English question by moving to create elected re gional assemblies where there is demand, the deputy prime minister said it was time to consider new financial structures.

He wants the prime minister, Tony Blair, to include plans for regional referendums to test the mood for elected assemblies in the first Queen's Speech of the next parliament.

Stressing that English regionalism should form the centrepiece of constitutional reform in Labour's second term, he said: "I don't think it will be at all credible not to have referendums in the next parliament."

He said that the government had no plans to abolish county councils to make way for regional assemblies. They would be purely strategic bodies overseeing planning, transport and housing, while supervising eight regional development agencies, business-led quangoes.

"The argument before has been that Whitehall always delivers best and knows best, but regions are now looking to London and saying 'maybe we can do things a bit better'," he said. "I think the regions would make for better government and make decisions more likely to work instead of blaming central government for getting it wrong all the time... they could challenge central government where necessary."

webTitle: 3,000 jobs to go in Motorola closure

fields.headline: 3,000 jobs to go in Motorola closure
fields.standfirst:
Bathgate facility to close despite intervention from prime minister

Talk about it
fields.trailText: Communications giant Motorola today confirmed plans to close the Bathgate plant in Scotland where more than 3,000 workers make mobile phones.
fields.body:
Communications giant Motorola today confirmed plans to close the Bathgate plant in Scotland where more than 3,000 workers make mobile phones.

A Motorola statement said: "This proposal potentially affects all of the 3,100 employees at the site, although no final decision has yet been made.

The decision is a huge blow to the region's economy and would present the Government with a problem close to the expected general election. Prime minister Tony Blair personally intervened by pleading for jobs to be safeguarded when Motorola announced earlier this month that cutbacks were being considered.

But the company said the background to the 'proposal' was a global decline in the demand for mobile phones already highlighted by the company when it announced on March 13 cutbacks of up to 7,000 jobs worldwide in the personal communications sector. "Today's proposal forms part of that action," said the statement.

The company said it had come to the decision only after long and complex deliberations, and weighing up "a huge number" of considerations.

It acknowledged the decision would cause concern for the Bathgate workforce. The statement continued: "As you would expect Motorola is committed to providing a full range of support services to its employees throughout the coming weeks as it continues to discuss the proposal with the elected employee consultation forum."

Union leaders reacted with fury to the news and demanded that Motorola hand back £20 million worth of Government grants it has received over the past two years.

Danny Carrigan, Scottish regional secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said: "This is a real kick in the teeth for the workers. The whole Bathgate community depends on that plant and the area will now be destroyed. Motorola should now hand back over £20 million worth of grants the company has been given over the past two years. They are sacking the workers so we want the money back."

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said Motorola was taking advantage of the fact that it was "easier and cheaper" to sack workers in the UK than elsewhere in Europe.

"Motorola told workers that they did not need a trade union as their jobs were secure - the workforce can now see that the company cannot be trusted to keep its word."

Thousands of jobs are under threat in the UK electronics industry mainly because of problems facing American firms. The latest effect was revealed last night when US manufacturer 3M said 500 jobs would be cut in the UK over the next year as part of a global cutback.

The AEEU is holding a special summit in London on Friday to discuss the job losses in the industry.

fields.headline: Nightingale named in ITV's election night team
fields.trailText:
1pm: Mary Nightingale has cemented her position as one of ITN's top presenters after she was selected to front ITV's election coverage, writes Jason Deans
16.11.2000: Nightingale makes it to Grade A ITN roster
Special report: general election and the media
fields.body:
The former Wish You Were Here presenter, Mary Nightingale, has cemented her position as one of ITN's top presenters after she was selected to front ITV's general election coverage.

In a major promotion for the 37-year-old TV anchor, Ms Nightingale will join Jonathan Dimbleby to present the network's election night programme.

The deal will be seen as a rebuff for Katie Derham, the newscaster Ms Nightingale now seems to be usurping at the top ITN roster.

Ms Nightingale, who only returned to news presenting for ITV in January after a stint on holiday show Wish You Were Here, will also be working alongside the ITN political editor, John Sergeant, and her ITV Evening News co-presenter, Dermot Murnaghan.

Details of ITV's general election coverage plans are included in the broadcaster's first ever statement of programme policy.

webTitle: Brown sticks to the safe path

fields.headline: Brown sticks to the safe path
fields.standfirst: Guardian deputy financial editor Mark Milner analyses the chancellor's messages on the state of the economy
fields.trailText: Guardian deputy financial editor Mark Milner analyses the chancellor's messages on the state of the economy.
fields.body:
Yesterday, Gordon Brown, the chancellor, told the Times that Britain would weather the combined impact of the US slowdown and foot and mouth at home.

This morning, he warned the annual meeting of the European bank for Reconstruction and Development of "more challenging global economic conditions".

So is the chancellor sending out mixed, even contradictory, messages? Not a bit of it. Remember, an election is in the offing. Mr Brown is neither about to trash the UKÕs economic prospects, nor announce that his spending plans will have to be trimmed in the face of hard times to come.

He has little need to do either. The UK will see a slowdown in the economy this year. Growth is likely to be relatively modest - probably at little over 2%. But that is hardly the slough of despond.

The US will have an impact. Indeed it is already doing so. But the European Union is a far more important market for British firms than the US, which accounts for just under 20% of British exports, compared with just over 50% which go to the rest of the EU.

If anything, Mr BrownÕs comments yesterday might have been seen as giving a nudge to the European Central Bank which has, so far, resisted calls for lower eurozone interest rates as part of the battle against global slowdown.

The chancellorÕs comments, taken together, would suggest a man who is cautioning that life is likely to get a little tougher - as workers at a number of mobile phone plants round Britain are beginning to find out.

But he is also making it clear that any difficulties are down to external factors (ie donÕt blame me) and that his longstanding policies of prudence and stability mean the UK is well placed to cope.

Mr Brown may also be gently jogging the prime ministerial elbow; a reminder to Mr Blair that, from an economic perspective, it would be better to have the general election sooner rather than later.

LabourÕs economic record will be a central plank of the partyÕs campaign as it seeks a second term. Mr Brown Ð and Mr Blair for that matter Ð will not be keen to risk any shadows being cast on their claims for economic competence. The outlook may not get much worse over the coming months but it will not get better. The only danger is in delay.

webTitle: Technology sector hit by massive job losses

fields.headline: Technology sector hit by massive job losses
fields.standfirst:
The technology sector has been devastated by a wave of redundancies in recent months.

Talk about it
fields.trailText:
3M

Last night US manufacturer 3M said 500 jobs would be cut in the UK over the next year as part of a global cutback.
fields.body:
3M

Last night US manufacturer 3M said 500 jobs would be cut in the UK over the next year as part of a global cutback.

Ericsson

Last week Ericsson, which has about 2,000 staff in the UK, announced plans to axe 12,000 jobs worldwide. The Swedish company blamed the job losses on a need to cut costs by £1.4 billion a year after being hit by the slowdown in the telecoms market. Ericsson is closing its plants at Carlton, Notts, and Scunthorpe.

The cuts were an attempt for better "economies of scale, higher capital efficiency and better volume flexibility," a company spokesman said.

Marconi

1,500 British jobs at telecoms group Marconi are to go in the next year as the company shakes up its global management and reorganises the business.

The job losses represent around 6% of Marconi's total workforce of 55,000 - around 20,000 of which are employed in the UK, where it has large sites in cities including Coventry and Liverpool.

Compaq

Computer giant Compaq, one of the main overseas companies operating in Scotland's Silicon Glen computer belt, said that 700 jobs were to go at its plant in Erskine, Renfrewshire.

The US-based company plans to outsource the manufacture of consumer and desktop personal computer products currently made at Erskine but will continue to manufacture made-to-order personal computers and servers there.

Other big losses

In an effort to head off a sharp shortfall in revenues in the hi-tech sector triggered by lower demand in the US, Asia and parts of Europe, three of the world's biggest companies also announced job cuts this month. The move by network equipment firm Cisco Systems, Dutch electronics group Philips and photography giant Eastman Kodak, has left thousands of British-based workers fearing they will lose their livelihoods.

Full details of job cuts have not been released but 8,500 jobs from Cisco Systems's 40,000-strong global staff base are to go. The group, which hopes to save £697 million a year through the cuts, employs about 2,000 people at Uxbridge, Manchester and Strathclyde.

Philips, which has a worldwide workforce of 200,000, said the 7,000 job cuts would be made over the next couple of months in its consumer electronics and component businesses.

It employs 6,300 people at manufacturing sites in Durham, Washington, Stockport, Blackburn, Burnley, Southport and at Hamilton in Scotland.

Eastman Kodak, hit by a sharp slowdown in film sales, is cutting 3,000 to 3,500 jobs to cut costs and improve the effectiveness of its operations.

webTitle: Nesta: I'm afraid to drink water in current drugs climate

fields.headline: Nesta: I'm afraid to drink water in current drugs climate
fields.trailText: Lazio captain Alessandro Nesta has claimed he is "afraid to drink a glass of water" after watching Edgar Davids become the latest Serie A footballer to test positive for Nandrolone.
fields.body:
Lazio captain Alessandro Nesta has claimed he is "afraid to drink a glass of water" after watching Edgar Davids become the latest Serie A footballer to test positive for Nandrolone.

And Nesta's fears have been echoed by Juventus striker Alessandro Del Piero, who says the confusion over the banned substance is threatening players' careers.

Last night, the Italian Olympic Committee (CONI) revealed that Davids failed a preliminary doping test after the Udinese-Juventus match on March 4. He is the eighth player to test positive in Italy since random testing was introduced, while a further 67 cases are under still being investigated by the Turin public prosecutor's office following claims by former Roma coach Zdenek Zeman in 1998 that Juventus gave banned steroids to their players.

During the past few days, Fernando Couto has tested positive a second time for the steroids Norandrosterone and Noretiocolanolone, while Bari keeper Jean Francois Gillet failed a second test for Nandrolone.

The spate of positive results has left Nesta and Del Piero afraid they could be next.

"At this time the players are victims," said Nesta. "We don't now what to do. We afraid, and everybody is talking to each other about what we can do."

"In the past I've taken some blood supplements, but now I'm afraid to drink a glass of water," he added. "Even the scientists aren't sure in this situation. Drugs are drugs, but nobody is certain about Nandrolone."

His fears were supported by Del Piero, who said: "We are nether experts nor doctors. We are asking around, trying to find out more.

"There are rumours that 25 players who were pushing the limit on their last test, and now it seems that any name can be linked to Nandrolone," he added.

And Del Piero also revealed that the doping affair has left players fearing for their futures. "Nesta is afraid to drink water," he said. "It's true. I'm afraid to eat. We players are not so stupid to risk a career for Nandrolone. The players' association will have to organise something."

But former Parma coach Nevio Scala has insisted that there is a widespread use of drugs within Italian football.

"It's a nonsense to say that nobody is guilty," he said. "At the crucial time of the season, when results are decisive and players are tired, there are people in Italian football and around the clubs who are prepared to act incorrectly and to administer forbidden substances."

"I don't know who is doing this, but it's clearly a very bad thing."

fields.headline: Channel 5 sets out programming stall
fields.trailText:
8.30am programme promises: Channel 5 has promised to deliver 'modern, contemporary and straight-forward' programming, writes Jessica Hodgson.
23.04.2001: Channel 4 in sitcom pledge
fields.body:
The highlights of Channel 5's next year of programming will include a three-part documentary about serial killers Fred and Rosemary West, a south London based version of La Boheme and an extended version of the discussion show, the Wright Stuff.

Channel 5 today set out its programming stall, promising to continue to deliver "modern, contemporary and straight-forward" programming.

Returning popular entertainment series such as Night Fever and Fort Boyard, the nightly movie and unusual sports coverage will remain at the heart of the channel's programming formula.

And nudity keeps its central place in the schedule with Rankin's Male Nudes the flagship offering in Channel 5's arts output.

But the programme bosses are also planning some more unusual offerings, such as Boheme, a version of the opera set in contemporary London.

During the general election campaign, Channel 5 will integrate 5 News with the Wright Stuff, presented by Matthew Wright.

Channel 5 has joined other broadcasters today in setting out its programming vision and plans for the first time.

The system replaces the Independent Television Commission's annual performance reviews.

Under these, the regulator measured broadcasters' performance and adherence to the programming codes.

From now on, the broadcasters will present their programming stategy and the new regulator, Ofcom, will measure their performance against their stated aims.

webTitle: Koizumi to be next Japanese PM

fields.headline: Koizumi to be next Japanese PM
fields.standfirst: Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: Maverick reformer Junichiro Koizumi today defeated one of Japan's former prime ministers to win the ruling party presidency, guaranteeing his election as the next prime minister.
fields.body:
Maverick reformer Junichiro Koizumi today defeated one of Japan's former prime ministers to win the ruling party presidency, guaranteeing his election as the next prime minister.

Mr Koizumi's victory over Ryutaro Hashimoto followed an overwhelming show of support by rank-and-file members of the Liberal Democratic party (LDP) in the primaries.

The election upset reflected growing public disgust with the political establishment and the sour economy, and the LDP's desperate attempt to revamp its stick-in-the-mud image ahead of upper house parliamentary elections this summer.

"This election was held against an unprecedented headwind," Mr Koizumi said in accepting the post. "I promised to change the party and to change Japan, and fortunately, many party members supported my call."

The vote comes as a blow for Mr Hashimoto - premier from 1996 to 1998 - who had been expected to win based on his power bloc in the party. But he was rejected overwhelmingly in the local primaries, where party members were sensitive to his reputation for mismanaging the economy during his term in office.

Initial reaction on the stock market was optimistic. The market was sharply lower early in the day, shedding 200 points, but rallied strongly after the election to finish 27 points - or 0.2% - up.

But Mr Koizumi, certain to be formally named prime minister later this week by the LDP-dominated parliament, takes office as Japan is wallowing in a decade-long economic slowdown.

Unemployment is high, a hoped-for recovery has fizzled and the financial system is riddled with bad debts.

Japan's political system is also in trouble. Mr Koizumi will take over from prime minister Yoshiro Mori, whose dismal year in office has been defined by a string of scandals, political gaffes and support ratings in the single digits.

Mr Koizumi, a former health minister known for his shaggy hairstyle, his passion for karaoke love songs and fiery rhetoric, is pushing economic and structural reforms, including the privatisation of Japan's massive postal system, which offers saving accounts and even insurance policies to clients.

However, many analysts believe he will have a hard time carrying out the promises of reform that were the focus of his campaign, as his desire for change has little support among the party leadership

"The chances are not low that if he makes compromises with the various party powerbrokers, then there will be little change," Takashi Inoguchi, a politics expert at Tokyo University, said. "But if his performance in parliament is good, then he can achieve a good deal, because he has ideas."

fields.headline: ITV makes peaktime pledge
fields.trailText:
11.45 programme promises: ITV is aiming to fill at least 85% of its peaktime schedule with original UK output, writes Jason Deans.
Useful link: ITV policy statement


C5 sets out programming stall
23.04.2001: C4 in sitcom pledge
23.04.2001: Promises, promises, promises
fields.body:
ITV has ordered a sitcom pilot about a West Indian family, a drama about a "significant miscarriage of justice" and a documentary about child poverty as part of its commitment to original UK programming over the next 18 months.

In its first statement of programme policy, ITV is aiming to fill at least 85% of its peaktime (6pm-10.30pm) 2001 schedule with original UK output.

The leading commercial channel is also expecting to exceed its current 65% minimum level of original production across all hours this year and to maintain similar levels of original output next year.

And at least half of ITV's network commissions are expected to come from outside London.

The statement, published as part of the move towards "lighter touch" broadcasting regulation, describes home-grown production as "a central plank of ITV's public service offer".

"ITV will maintain its current high proportion of original productions for as long as revenue supports the very high level of investment required," the document states.

Unveiling ITV's first programming statement, David Liddiment, the director of programmes, said: "As niche and pay TV channels proliferate, I believe ITV's public service role as a mass audience, free-to-air channel will become more rather than less important."

More than a third of ITV's £750m 2001 programming budget will be invested in new drama.

"There will be a degree of innovation in form and content, with at least one project in 2001 and 2002 that breaks the mould in mass-appeal drama in some way," ITV promises.

Two "risk taking" pieces are a project written by John Sullivan and starring David Jason as the Dickens character Mr Micawber, and Bob and Rose, a project by Russell T Davies about a gay man's love affair with a woman.

Big new "event" drama scheduled for the next two years includes an adaptation of the Kingsley Amis novel, Lucky Jim; Beating Jesus, written by Gimme Gimme Gimme creator Jonathan Harvey and starring Sarah Lancashire; and Anybody's Nightmare, a dramatisation of a "significant miscarriage of justice" starring Patricia Routledge.

In comedy, a pilot has been commissioned from writer Paul McKenzie featuring a West Indian family.

ITV has pledged to run an average of 90 minutes of documentary programming each week over the next year.

The main single documentary slot will appear after ITV News at Ten at 10.20pm.

New factual programmes will include Poor Kerry, a documentary about child poverty; three shows about Hitler's closest working and personal relationships and the British Empire in Colour.

fields.headline: Firms defy doom-mongers to increase marketing spend
fields.standfirst:
Tables
Forthcoming budgets compared with previous year
Total marketing expenditure: new budget setting
Total marketing expenditure: revisions to current budget
Media advertising expenditure: new budget setting
Media advertising expenditure: revisions to current budget
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Most companies are raising their marketing spend rather than cutting back, writes Claire Cozens.
Tables: forthcoming budgets compared with previous year
Total marketing expenditure: new budget setting
Total marketing expenditure: revisions to current budget
Media advertising expenditure: new budget setting
Media advertising expenditure: revisions to current budget
fields.body:
The UK advertising industry is in more robust health than the doom-mongers would have us believe, with the majority of companies raising their marketing spend rather than cutting back.

Twice as many companies raised their marketing budgets as cut them in the first three months of the year, according to research published today by the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising.

Just over 40% of companies surveyed for the IPA's quarterly Bellwether Report said they had raised their budgets for 2001 compared with the previous year. This was twice the number that reported a decline.

"It is perhaps surprising that twice as many clients are increasing their spend on advertising and marketing despite the general turndown in growth," said Bruce Haines, the new president of the IPA.

"Everyone expected these figures to prove the UK was set for a downturn, yet the picture is much more one of 'steady as she goes"."

According to the IPA, companies that slashed their marketing spend during the recession of the early 90s suffered as a result.

Many businesses now recognise an economic downturn can actually be a good time to build a brand because advertising is relatively cheap.

Nevertheless, companies are being more cautious than they were this time last year.

In the first quarter of 2000, 61% of companies increased their marketing budgets and just 15% reported a cut.

And the research shows companies are opting for cheaper alternatives to advertising such as direct marketing.

The report also indicates the internet advertising market is holding up, in spite of the dot.com crash.

Advertisers allocated 1.8% of their total budget to internet advertising, the same proportion as in the final quarter of 2000.

The Bellwether Report is a quarterly survey of marketing expenditure produced for the IPA by NTC Research.

It is based on a questionnaire of nearly 300 UK companies that have agreed to provide regular quarterly information on trends in their advertising and marketing activities.
