webTitle: Putin is out to get me, says media tycoon

fields.headline: Putin is out to get me, says media tycoon
fields.standfirst:
Gusinsky gains his freedom but loses his empire

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: After the state seizure of his Media Most empire, the only independent news organisation in Russia, Vladimir Gusinsky says Vladimir Putin is building a totalitarian state.
fields.body:
Vladimir Gusinsky is eagerly clutching one of his three mobile phones, hanging on to every word spoken by his Spanish lawyer.

"You have the decision in your hand? I can go? Can I get on the plane now? Make sure, please."

A Spanish sun sparkles on the swimming-pool beyond the plate glass windows of his luxurious villa, El Crucero, in the exclusive Sotogrande resort. Water gurgles from a marble dolphin. Servants and bodyguards slide discreetly through the shadows.

But Vladimir Gusinsky, the once-mighty Russian media magnate brought low by President Putin's government, is blind to the luxuries surrounding him. He is savouring freedom. The call means that, for the first time in four months, he can go where he wants.

The Spanish judges who refused to extradite him to Russia on fraud charges confirmed yesterday that the three-day appeal period had expired. No longer must he make the humiliating daily trip to report to the local Civil Guard police post. He is finally allowed out of Cadiz province.

But it is a hollow victory. The great oligarch, the most powerful man in the Russian media, has lost virtually everything he owned in Moscow.

Over the past 10 days control of his Media Most empire has been wrested away. Now he watches helplessly as his television channel, newspaper and magazine - the most professional news outlets in Russia - are dismantled by the state-controlled Gazprom company.

Russia's only independent national news organisation is dead. The news reports that told Russians difficult, sometimes horrible, truths about the Chechen wars, the Kursk submarine disaster, or those dying of cold in the eastern provinces, will simply dry up.

Mr Gusinsky, 48, a fast-talking former theatre manager, is a betrayed man who now realises he is reaping the bitter rewards for past behaviour.

He is convinced that Russia has spawned a new monster, and a threat to global stability, in President Putin. That monster, he says, will pursue him wherever he goes. "I am absolutely sure Mr Putin and his government will use anything they can to destroy me and my partners," he says.

The time he has spent trapped inside this gilded cage, and in the harsher surroundings of the Soto del Real jail, has allowed him to work out where it all went wrong.

"I made one big mistake ... when we started to support Yeltsin against the communists in 1996," he admits. "The liberal media worked for several months like the propaganda machine against communism. I am responsible. Now I am paying for it."

Mr Gusinsky rescued Mr Yeltsin in 1996, swinging the weight of Media Most and its NTV station behind him. His executives took over the ailing Yeltsin campaign and led him to victory.

It was a key moment in recent Russian history - when the oligarchs became the new kingmakers in Moscow. It was an operation repeated four years later when his fellow oligarch and sometime enemy Boris Berezovsky pushed Vladimir Putin into power.

Now the dog has turned. President Putin does not want millionaire businessmen publicly attacking his stories. Mr Berezovsky is already in self-imposed exile. Mr Gusinsky realises that he has played, even helped invent, the bizarre game of Russian democracy -and now he has lost.

Gazprom used its loans to Mr Gusinsky - given partly in recognition of his role in electing Mr Yeltsin - as the weapon. Mr Gusinsky says he could have paid off the $250m (£180m), but Gazprom would not let him. In any case, Mr Gusinsky's business has run up $800m in losses and Gazprom wanted his companies rather than his money. Last week it got them.

These are dangerous days in Moscow, Mr Gusinsky says. Mr Putin may be popular, but he is using that popularity to build a new totalitarian state. "Any totalitarian regime must produce fear in the country. He must demonstrate to any potential opponent what will happen to him. Business cannot fight him."

Western countries, meanwhile, look on nervously. Some, Germany and the US fof example, are happy to criticise the attack on Media Most and join the clamour for a free press as an essential ingredient in Russia's new democracy. Others, including Britain and France, are not.

Mr Gusinsky says we will all pay the price if western leaders appease President Putin. He likens the situation apocalyptically to the 1930s and the world's treatment of Hitler. Mr Putin's hands, he says, are already red with the blood of murdered Chechens.

"If a Russian president uses his power to destroy human rights and social balance in order to make that power absolute, then that is very serious," he says.

The west must decide whether to sit by and make friends with Mr Putin or stand up for human rights and freedom of expression.

"Any European leader, including Mr Blair, has a difficult choice," he admits.

"I am a Jew. We know what genocide is. That is why I care about Chechnya," explains Mr Gusinsky, who also has Israeli nationality and founded the Russian Jewish Congress.

In the medium term his future lies in Israel. He already owns one newspaper there and he claims to have made "several million dollars" in Israel last year.He said the loss of Media Most by no means meant he was bankrupt.

He now urgently needs to unload what is left of his holding in Media Most. CNN's founder, Ted Turner, an earlier mooted buyer, appears to have dropped out.

Mr Putin's popularity comes in part from his promise to do away with the oligarchs, a group of 20-odd billionaire businessmen who got rich stripping assets from privatised companies they bought for nothing.

But why target Mr Gusinsky? If the oligarchs were bad, and he denies having been one, he was the best of the bunch. He started Media Most from scratch eight years ago, investing and building a com pany in what, to western eyes, was a recognisable way. He took loans and planned to make a profit in the future.

In 1998, before Russia's economic crisis spoiled his plans, Media Most was about to float on the Nasdaq for $1.2bn. His media outlets were the most independent and professional in Russia.

Mr Gusinsky says his problems come precisely from that. He invested in media, not steel, oil or coal. Other oligarchs are doing very nicely under president Mr Putin. "Most are being left alone."

It took remarkably little time to engineer Mr Gusinsky's downfall. The pressure had been building up since armed police raided Media Most offices a year ago. In the end it took Gazprom three days to apply the coup de grace.

First it ousted NTV's journalists, who fled en masse to the TV6 channel owned by Mr Berezovsky. Then the daily paper Sevodnya was closed down and the director of the weekly magazine Itogi sacked.

Now, Mr Gusinsky alleges, it is the turn of the popular Ekho Moskvy radio station. The days of it's editor, Alexei Venediktovo, are numbered.

So what now for Mr Gusinsky? He is certainly not going to Russia. "That would be a one-way ticket," he jokes.

The next stage of this saga may well be played out in London. One of his many homes is there. He wants to leave soon.

Russian prosecutors say the Interpol arrest warrant is still valid outside Spain. What if the Metropolitan Police were obliged to arrest him?

"I am not afraid," he says. But he admits he has lawyers in Britain and the US working out whether he might be jailed, or even extradited. "We have asked the British authorities for their views."

He does not want to go back to jail. Last year he spent three nights in Moscow's notorious Butyrka prison. He thought that by coming to Spain he would avoid repeating that experience. Then judges sent him to Soto del Real prison to await the extradition decision.

"Prison is prison. Everybody, rich or poor, is shocked when they get there. But it is worse when you do not understand why you are there. In Russia I was there because I was a government opponent. But in Spain I did not understand why."

Exile has allowed him to rediscover friendship with Mr Berezovsky, who has since fallen out with Mr Putin "We have difficult relationship. We are friends, enemies, friends, enemies," he admits.

In the long-term he would like to found a new Russian media empire. Yesterday he was enjoying the prospect of boarding his Gulfstream jet and flying to Madrid. Afterwards he will go on holiday to Israel.

As a last thought I ask him whether he fears for his life. He gives me a quizzical look, one eyebrow lifted over his rimless glasses. "Can I not answer that question?"

How the kingmaker fell from grace

Empire at its peak

 Most Bank, a commercial bank set up in 1989. Gusinsky claims to have introduced credit cards in Russia.

 Most Group (1992) involves dozens of trade, property, insurance and investment businesses. Gusinsky made a fortune through property deals in early 1990s.

 Privately trained 1,100-strong security force; a fleet of bullet-proof cars. Several properties abroad.

 Media Most holding (Valued at £700m before 1998 rouble collapse). Group built a stable of media outlets with Gusinsky having the controlling stake, including:

NTV: Russia's sole national, independent TV channel, with respected news and current affairs, but also dramas, entertainment.

NTV-plus: satellite network bringing world TV to Russia.

TNT: a regional network, focusing on entertainment.

Ekho Moskvy: talk-radio station with serious news.

Sem Dnei: publishers of Sevodnya, a leading liberal broadsheet, and Itogi, weekly current affairs magazine produced with Newsweek.

Empire today

 Gave up presidency of Most Bank and renounced role at Most Group to focus on media group. Bank sold. Now in process of forced closure.

 1998 financial crisis, the waning advertising market, and the loss-making NTV-plus project, put Media Most in a critical state. Russia's state gas monopoly, Gazprom, offered new loans in return for large stakes.

 Gazprom's attempts to call in debts led to seizure of NTV's offices on April 14. Gusinky and aides have been removed from the station's board and replaced by Gazprom-appointed executives.

 Gusinsky loses control of Sem Dnei publishing house. On April 16, Sevodnya closed. On April 17, Itogi's editor dismissed.

 Still controls TNT and Ekho Moskvy, although TNT executives complain of harassment by tax police.

webTitle: US blocks sale of hi-tech warships to Taiwan

fields.headline: US blocks sale of hi-tech warships to Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan
fields.trailText: US President George Bush will today unveil the largest ever sale of arms to Taiwan in US history but will stop short of selling four state-of-the-art destroyers that have become the latest flashpoint in the diplomatic struggle between Washington and Beijing.
fields.body:
US President George Bush will today unveil the largest ever sale of arms to Taiwan in US history but will stop short of selling four state-of-the-art destroyers that have become the latest flashpoint in the diplomatic struggle between Washington and Beijing.

Mr Bush has decided against selling Arleigh Burke-class destroyers equipped with the Aegis combat radar system that Taiwan had requested, but has agreed to sell four Kidd-class destroyers, which have a much less powerful radar system, officials said last night. China has mounted a fierce diplomatic campaign against the sale of Aegis-equipped destroyers.

The decision is due to be announced in Washington today, when the US defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld holds a meeting with Taiwanese officials that has assumed a much higher profile in the wake of the stand-off earlier this month between the US and China over the detained spy plane and its 24-member crew.

The arms sale to Taiwan is a huge upgrading of the island's defences, in spite of the decision to "defer" sale of the Aegis ships. In addition to the four Kidd-class destroyers, Mr Bush has approved the sale of eight diesel submarines and up to a dozen P-3 anti-submarine aircraft, officials said.

Taken together, this constitutes a quantum leap in Taiwan's ability to combat any Chinese naval or submarine threat in the Taiwan Straits.

The response from Beijing is likely to be an angry one. Officials in Washington yesterday made clear that they expect China to make its displeasure very clear, possibly to the extent of recalling its ambassador in Washington for consultations, a move which is one step short of a full recall.

US officials will also be closely monitoring the fallout on Capitol Hill, where the calls for tougher actions against Beijing have risen since the end of the spy plane crisis. Senior members of Congress were briefed on the details of the arms deal last night.

China fears that the Aegis system could become the basis for a Taiwanese missile defence system against its coastal missile build-up. Any US move to provide such a missile shield to Taiwan, Korea or Japan would be seen by China as a major escalation of hostile military firepower.

Craig Thomas, who chairs the Senate foreign relations committee's East Asian and Pacific panel, said the Taiwan arms sale "will be a robust package ... But I don't think they're going to go all out to try to make the tension higher".

fields.headline: Tuesday's rumours
fields.standfirst: All today's rumours still feel more than a little queasy about the relationship between failed DJ Chris Evans and failed pop-star Billie Piper
fields.trailText: Arsenal have launched a £12m bid for Roma's Japan international Hidetoshi Nakata. The Mirror reports that Nakata, who is desperate to leave Rome after spending most of the season on the substitutes' bench, was informed of Arsenal's interest yesterday and "wants to talk".
fields.body:
Arsenal have launched a £12m bid for Roma's Japan international Hidetoshi Nakata. The Mirror reports that Nakata, who is desperate to leave Rome after spending most of the season on the substitutes' bench, was informed of Arsenal's interest yesterday and "wants to talk".

AC Milan are planning a £20m bid for Mark Viduka, according to the Mirror. The paper quote a Milan spokesman, who tells them: "Everyone at the club knows how much Viduka is wanted. There is no desire to sign Beckham or Owen. We want to beat Roma and Internazionale to sign Viduka." And the attraction seems to be mutual. According to the Mirror, Viduka "longs for a move to Italy" and would love to play for AC Milan - the club he supported as a boy.

Gustavo Poyet wants to leave Chelsea, reports the Star. "It makes me sad to say it, but I cannot see a bright future for me at Chelsea," he says. "I want to be given the chance to finish my career at a club where I have a real chance of winning the Championship." The root of the problem seems to be Poyet's frosty relationship with Claudio Ranieri, with the Uruguay international claiming: "After we changed manager at the start of the season we don't seem to know where we are going."

Meanwhile, Chelsea have denied any interest in Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke. "I can say we have no interest in either player," Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson told the Evening Standard.

Sunderland have agreed a £8m fee for Everton striker Francis Jeffers, claims the Star. According to the report, the move will go through when Jeffers finalises personal terms with the Black Cats. The paper also speculates that the signing of Jeffers could place a question mark over the future of Kevin Phillips at the club.

However, Sunderland have sealed the £2m signing of Argentinian midfielder Nicolas Medina from Argentinos Juniors, reports Teamtalk. The 19-year-old midfielder is expected to arrive on Sunderland in the next few days to put pen to paper on a contract agreed last week.

Manchester United could follow up the signing of Ruud van Nistelrooy by signing a second PSV Eindhoven player - £10m defender Kevin Hofland. The 21-year-old centre back, who has been dubbed "the new Jaap Stam", tells the Star: "I am not surprised by United's interest. I have been playing very well while they have been over here watching Ruud. My next move will probably be to England."

And Manchester United have been busy recently. According to the Daily Telegraph, they want Martin O'Neill to succeed Sir Alex Ferguson when he retires at the end of next season. The paper claims that Old Trafford officials will hold preliminary discussions with O'Neill next month.

Speaking of Celtic, Republic of Ireland midfielder Alan Mahon is set to join the club in a £1m deal, reports the Star. The Sporting Lisbon midfielder, who is currently on loan at Blackburn, spent yesterday having talks with Martin O'Neill in Glasgow.

webTitle: foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 64: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Day 64: Foot and mouth is back on the front page. It turns out that humans can catch it after all.
fields.body:
The Guardian

Foot and mouth is back on the front page. It turns out that we humans can catch it after all. But it's going to be 48 hours until we find out whether the slaughterman with the symptoms has it. A Guardian/ICM poll shows there is overwhelming public support for a vaccination, and that 40% of the public wants to call a halt to the mass culling of animals.

The Daily Telegraph

The slaughterman with symptoms gives new life to the coverage of foot and mouth - also back on the front page of the Telegraph. Page ten then goes on to talk about the anger ignited by the toxic fumes of the animal pyres. Total number of animals slaughtered so far: almost 1.9m.

The Independent
The Independent is the only broadsheet that splashes with foot-and-mouth and the health risks involved in burning cattle.

The Times

The Times suggests there's nothing to worry about, as 40 people have already caught it before, and the disease disappears after two months.

The Mirror and the Sun

Both papers support the napalming of animal carcasses. Apparently napalm will cut air pollution and dispose of carcasses in 60 minutes, compared to pyres that take three days. Ministers are considering the measure.

fields.headline: This one goes up to 11
fields.standfirst: The Seat Leon Cupra is a well-mannered, sensible family hatchback with a big boot. (Oh, it also handles like a getaway car and goes like the clappers)
fields.trailText: The Seat Leon Cupra is a well-mannered, sensible family hatchback with a big boot. (Oh, it also handles like a getaway car and goes like the clappers).
fields.body:
The Seat Leon comes pre-garlanded by the people at Top Gear, who recently handed the Cupra (which is the name given to the top of the range Leon with the hottest engine) their Best Value award for 2001. Not the most exciting category in which to storm out a winner, perhaps; it would be a bit like leaving the Oscars with one of those prizes for the technical quality of the soundtrack. But an honour, even so.

Had the Leon been able to make an acceptance speech, it probably would have declined the opportunity, smiled bashfully and driven away. It's not the kind of car to make an undue fuss about itself. The point is, though, that any sense of modesty about the Leon is a cunning illusion, brilliantly achieved. The car leads a crafty double life, as if modelled on that familiar comic trope, the shy man from accounts who turns into a full-tilt clubber at the weekends.

The Leon appears to be an understated, well-mannered, small family hatchback, with no greater plans for itself than a trip to PC World and maybe a holiday in Devon in the summer. People will open the boot, note its surprising capaciousness and say, "You know, I reckon, with the seat down, I can get the lawnmower in there."

And this is true. You can get the lawnmower in there and also, at the same time probably, a pine coffee table. And you would still have room left over for the biggest box that PC World can offer.

But then you will get behind the wheel and you will notice the figure-hugging sports seats and the rally driver's steering wheel. And you will be slightly mystified by these things, because they do not necessarily seem predicted by the car's quiet-man-of-Europe exterior.

And then you will turn the key and set off and, abruptly, the car will reveal the other, darker side of its character - as a police-baiting, high-speed attack vehicle, aimed centrally at the Jenson Button in all of us.

Its secret is a 20-valve, turbo-charged engine whose powers of acceleration had everyone I took in the car reaching nervously for the door handles. And me, too, for that matter. It just wasn't what any of us expected.

Obviously, you don't have to buy the model with the aggressive engine and the go-faster upholstery. There's an entry level Leon S; then there's an SE, which is an S with, among other things, fog lamps and sports suspension; and only then comes the Cupra. But the Cupra, clearly, is the one where the real value lies - the one which goes all the way up to 11.

The Cupra also comes (and this could be the clincher) with a CD-changer in the glove compartment. Once found almost exclusively in the boot, where only thieves with a particularly acute understanding of internal wiring could get hold of them, CD-changers are increasingly making their way forward into the world's glove compartments. This is a welcome development and not before time.

Having to stop, get out of the car and burrow around in the back between the spare wheel and the jack, simply in order to effect a change in your in-car listening, has always seemed a peculiarly pre-technological routine. And, at the same time, why have a compartment in a car devoted entirely to gloves? It was space begging to be reclaimed, and Seat have joined the front-runners of those who are boldly doing so.

In order to enjoy driving my Leon, I had first to get over some strong reactions against its colour. Though perfectly acceptable for bananas, yellow is surely no colour in which to paint a car. Especially not the throbbingly bright yellow chosen by Seat for the Leon, a yellow so intense that, even sitting inside the vehicle with your eyes closed, you could still see it.

Tragically, the yellow theme was continued in the interior, in the form of a decorative strip around the edge of the carpeting. It was like driving around in a fireman's helmet.

You can, of course, choose from a selection of other, quieter shades. But the car is so involving to drive that, with a little practice, even the yellow came not to matter. The steering is as taut and responsive as in a sports car and a reassuring feeling of togetherness characterises the car; there is no aspect of it that doesn't seem to have been thoroughly hammered in or screwed on.

The Leon is built on the base of the VW Golf - as so many cars seem to be these days. As a result of all this tool-sharing, a certain orthodoxy of design is creeping in. Here in the Seat fleet are the dials, the light switches and the air conditioning units now seen in Audis, Skodas and VWs themselves. But at least the Golf's is a good base to build on.

And at least these are good dials, light switches and air conditioning units. The Leon forms these familiar materials into that unlikely combination - something practical and pleasurable. Bravely ignoring the mass production aspects of contemporary car manufacture, Seat suggest the Leon is for "modern individualists". May modern individualists flock like sheep to buy one.

The lowdown: Seat Leon 1.8 20v T Cupra

Price: £14,995
Top speed: 142mph
Acceleration: 0-62 in 7.7 seconds
Consumption: 33.2 mpg (combined)
At the wheel: Matthew Pinsent

webTitle: Mountainless Norfolk erased from Disney film

fields.headline: Mountainless Norfolk erased from Disney film
fields.trailText: Disney's most expensive film ever has had to be hastily rewritten after two backstage mechanics exposed an embarrassing gaffe, reports The Times
fields.body:
Disney's most expensive film ever has had to be hastily rewritten after two backstage mechanics exposed an embarrassing gaffe, reports The Times. Reign of Fire, a fantasy adventure starring Matthew McConaughey and Christian Bale, was set to depict a plucky band of humans fleeing from dragons to a mountain-top castle in Norfolk. Only one problem: there are no mountains in flat-as-a-pancake Norfolk.

The glaring error was spotted by Shaun Hindle, who comes from the Norfolk town of Hingham, and who spent six weeks working on the movie. "It was only in my second week that I looked at the script," he tells The Times. "I couldn't believe what I was reading when I saw how the film featured a castle on top of a mountain in Norfolk. I tried to explain that they were making a terrible mistake, but they said it was a small detail."

The screenplay for the £100m feature, which has been shooting in Ireland - where, unlike Norfolk, there are hills above 300ft - has had all references to Norfolk removed. That's a source of regret and amusement to John Birchall, a spokesperson for Norfolk County Council, who said to the paper: "It would have been nice to have Norfolk in a Hollywood film - but we Wouldn't want people coming to Norfolk looking for mountains."

webTitle: It's a pill wind that blows no good

fields.headline: It's a pill wind that blows no good
fields.standfirst: The presenter of Channel 4's Football Italia gives us the dope on the drugs scandal engulfing Serie A
fields.trailText: Giving you the dope on the drugs scandal engulfing Serie A.
fields.body:
Zdenek Zeman was ahead of his time. Back in 1998, out of the blue, Roma's inscrutable Czech coach rocked the Serie A boat by accusing top stars of cheating with illegal substances.

"Look at del Piero and Vialli at Juventus," he asked. "How did they build up all those muscles so quickly?"

His remarks brought legal action from the pair, an official inquiry and - some say - damaged his career prospects permanently.

While Zeman's claims back then were never proved, now a wave of positive tests for the steroid Nandrolone has forced Italy to face the issue once more. And with eight players caught so far and more on the way, there's an obvious conclusion - this lot are worse than cyclists.

Last weekend brought the biggest name so far: Juventus and Holland star Edgar Davids. News filtered out on the eve of Juve's crucial match away to Parma that a urine sample Davids gave at a match back in March had shown levels of the steroid Nandrolone four times the legal limit.

Nandrolone is a banned substance - with diabetes reputedly among it's side-effects. It helps build endurance, defends muscle condition from the effects of heavy training, and speeds recovery from injury.

Davids must now await the painfully slow process of secondary testing - if that confirms the results, his prospects' look grim. Sixteen months of suspension is the penalty the Italian FA has so far been handing out to players involved, meaning Edgar would miss out on next years' World Cup with Holland (assuming they qualify). The same story goes for Lazio and Portugal defender Fernando Couto, who after getting his second results back is due for suspension this week.

For the Italian game, the outlook's equally dark. Apart from the eight positives, a further 30% of players tested this season have shown borderline results just creeping under the legal limits.

Why?

There are plenty of theories. The two Perugia players who were first to test positive back in November blamed the chicken they'd eaten the night before the game. The French banned Perugia meat exports the next day. Elsewhere, thinking follows more realistic lines.

The first is that the large levels of Norandosterone - which acts as a signal of Nandrolone - can be produced naturally by the body under certain conditions: extreme stress, intensive physical activity. It's an argument backed by team doctors from Italian clubs, who say the players singled out so far are guilty of nothing more than hard work. Fifa conducted their own tests two years ago, and the IOC (who regulate doping standards worldwide) say they're confident their legal levels allow enough room for this possibility. Still, in France, the Olympique Marseille forward Christophe Dugarry did overturn a ban after demonstrating that his body produced the incriminating chemical itself.

There's another theory though; that despite the denials, the players involved in Italy are all guilty. Consider: last season the FA's dope commission practised strict blood and urine tests on players right through the championship. However, this summer, the commission was suddenly disbanded and the blood tests discontinued. Did club doctors or players take this as a cue for more dope activity than Dr Dre? If not, how come eight (and rising) have fallen foul of the tests?

Cue the third view: the players are taking it, but without knowing - probably laced into "integrators" imported from America. It's an idea which is causing terror among Italy's footballers, who complain they've mostly no idea what they're being given. Perugia keeper Andrea Mazzantini has missed one fixture after refusing injections from his team medic, and the recent Lazio-Parma fixture saw several players hit by cramps - after cutting all their pre-match "supplements".

Says Alessandro Nesta of Lazio and Italy: "We need a solution, and soon." (Is he talking to us or his team doctor?) "Players should have clarity and certainty over what they're being fed on."

Who'd argue with that? After all, decades of "vitamin supplements" are now being blamed for a variety of ills among ex-footballers. Right now, though, it's the spectre of 16 months off games that's most on players' minds. As a result, the FA has undertaken to analyse all integrators available on the Italian market. They're also hearing an appeal from the Perugia pair, and are about to receive a mighty legal challenge from Lazio on Couto's behalf.

Finally, to handle the current crisis, they've also announced a brand new doping commission. Huzzah! Note that among the 20 officials elected at first was a Sardinian doctor previously caught offering to provide a urine sample for an athlete due for testing. That's taking the pee all right. Here's to some explanations, and some less positive performances in the future.

webTitle: Callers to census hotline cut short

fields.headline: Callers to census hotline cut short
fields.trailText: An official hotline to answer questions about the national census and allay the public's concerns was collapsing yesterday under pressure from tens of thousands of callers.
fields.body:
An official hotline to answer questions about the national census and allay the public's concerns was collapsing yesterday under pressure from tens of thousands of callers.

The helpline set up by the office for national statistics played a recorded message warning of "unexpectedly high demand".

Callers wanting to speak to an official were kept waiting for nearly two minutes through a series of further taped messages before being told that all the operators were busy. They were then automatically cut off.

Anyone ringing back to try again had to go through the same procedure, with the same waiting times and usually the same result. Calls to the 0845 3012001 helpline were charged at the local rate.

A spokesman for the ONS said the helpline received a record number of calls yesterday, reaching 150,000 by the afternoon. Demand was so high that some got the engaged tone and could not even listen to the recordings.

The Guardian became aware of the problems last week. The spokesman said census organisers were surprised at the volume of calls coming in well before the official date for completing the forms, April 29.

Last week the helpline was getting 70,000 calls a day, but it was not possible to estimate the number of callers who were cut off due to a shortage of operators.

The ONS promised to increase the number of operators from 50 to 190 by this week. Yesterday the spokesman said staffing would increase to 100 by today and 190 by the end of the week.

Last week he told the Guardian that the ONS would change its recorded message to warn callers at the outset if they were not going to be able to get through.

Yesterday, the recording said: "Please note that our operators are very busy so it may well take a while to connect your call." But there was no warning that the system was so overloaded that callers would be cut off automatically before an operator came on the line.

A menu of recorded messages offering callers information on commonly asked questions was 20 seconds shorter than last week, but this was largely due to speeding up the script, making it harder to follow.

"It is difficult and expensive to respond to a high volume of callers by putting them all through to operators. A lot of people don't need to speak to an operator. They require some basic information," the ONS said.

The helpline offered recordings explaining the census form, its confidentiality, origins and compulsory status. "Clearly demand is outstripping the facility to provide operators for everyone who wanted one," a spokesman added.

fields.headline: Turkish siege victims return home
fields.standfirst:
Chechen gunmen surrender to Istanbul police

Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: Chechen gunmen who stormed a luxury Istanbul hotel and held 120 staff and guests hostage overnight surrendered yesterday to Turkish police, after the building was surrounded by hundreds of heavily armed officers and armoured cars. No one was injured in the 12-hour stand-off.
fields.body:
Chechen gunmen who stormed a luxury Istanbul hotel and held 120 staff and guests hostage overnight surrendered yesterday to Turkish police, after the building was surrounded by hundreds of heavily armed officers and armoured cars. No one was injured in the 12-hour stand-off.

The attack, which was intended as a protest against Russia's military occupation of Chechnya, was led by militants who had taken part in the hijacking five years ago of a Russian ferry off Turkey's Black Sea coast. Thirteen suspects, including the leader of the ferry hijacking, Mohammed Emin Tokcan, were last night being questioned at Istanbul's police headquarters.

Among those detained at gunpoint on Sunday evening - when the siege began - were six Britons who had been staying at the fashionable Swissotel, which overlooks the Bosphorous. Armed with automatic rifles and shotguns, the Chechen gang fired warning shots as they burst into the lobby and began rounding up the hostages.

In the initial panic, guests ran screaming from the building. One hotel worker, Alisan, said he heard shots and saw four or five gunmen in the lobby as he fled. Some guests hid between tables in the reception while others escaped by forcing their way through fire exits.

Hotel guest Karen Early, 28, from Epsom, Surrey, said that she had been "shell-shocked" by the drama. "I was called in my bedroom at 1am by the reception and they said come down now to reception. I said 'why?' and they said 'you must come down for your own safety'. I thought it was a fire, but when I got to the elevator there was a guy waiting with a gun.

"He made us hold our hands up and walk into the lobby, where they were holding the other people. I was shell-shocked. I did not know what was going on. It was pretty scary."

She said the siege was "like something out of Rambo, with hostages ordered to lie on the floor in case they were caught in crossfire".

Ms Early and Helen Somerville, 21, from Surrey, who was also trapped in the hotel, returned to Heathrow airport last night.

A Turkish hostage, Erhan Erden, said that the gunmen had apologised for their actions. "They said they are sorry but they had to do this because of what is happening in Chechnya."

During the night the gang let many of the staff and guests leave in small groups, giving priority to Turks.

According to local television, the police were warned that, if they intervened, "this could turn into a mess". They urged officers to stay calm, insisting: "We don't have any intention to spill blood."

Before surrendering, the Chechens faxed an unsigned statement to a local television news channel saying their action was aimed at ending the "bloody and dirty Russian attack on our homeland, the Caucasus".

At midday yesterday they walked out of the screened-off hotel, surrendering their pump-action shotguns and automatic rifles.

"Chechens are our brothers. But we cannot allow and approve actions that are opposed to Turkey's interests," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said after the siege. "The necessary measures are going to be taken."

Last month, Chechens hijacked a Russian plane with more than 100 people aboard from Istanbul's airport to draw attention to the plight of their country. Saudi special forces stormed the plane in Medina, killing three, after the hijackers threatened to blow it up.

webTitle: NHS reform falters - ministers must let go of the reins

fields.headline: NHS reform falters - ministers must let go of the reins
fields.trailText: Leader: How did the euphoria evaporate? Just nine months ago the atmosphere of hope and expectation in the NHS was unprecedented. All sides - medics, managers and nurses - had signed up to a 10-year health plan that promised the biggest step forward since the NHS was set up.
fields.body:
How did the euphoria evaporate? Just nine months ago the atmosphere of hope and expectation in the NHS was unprecedented. All sides - medics, managers and nurses - had signed up to a 10-year health plan that promised the biggest step forward since the NHS was set up. It followed the biggest increase in NHS funding in history - a one third rise in real terms over five years. Nine months on there is bitterness, doubt and open disputes. GPs are threatening a mass resignation - in a ballot which will report just before the election - and even an unofficial disruption of services on May l. Hospital consultants are still resisting their new contract. This is not how Downing Street planned the run-up to the election. The PM will not be pleased.

How did things go so badly wrong? It is a complex picture. GPs are unhappy with the 2,000 increase to their ranks compared with 7,000 extra consultants. They are even more hurt by the huge pay hike conceded to consultants. The British Medical Association is under attack from three competing doctor journals, each trying to outbid the other in criticism of the BMA's leadership. One of the freebies is even sponsoring next month's day of protest. The teachers have shown that public service militancy can work. There is BMA anxiety about losing its exclusive negotiating rights in a new system of local deals.

But there are more fundamental developments reflecting the enormous pressure on public services. Ministers have rightly signalled a wish to modernise the health service, but have been reluctant to lift their foot from the accelerator to change direction for fear of missing their intimidating list of performance targets - some 150 or more. Local managers as well as medics complain about the treadmill they feel they are on as extra work piles up and the redesign of the NHS is delayed.

This is not the only sin of Alan Milburn. No one worked harder to put the 10-year plan together. The health secretary demonstrated phenomenal energy and admirable single-mindedness. But once signed, he took his eye off the ball. Winter was approaching. The key priority became ensuring that there was no scandal about patients on trolleys or turned away by accident and emergency departments. Yet the two separate industrial disputes (GPs and consultants) always had the potential to erode the goodwill generated by the plan. They should have been resolved earlier.

There are two inter-related structural problems, which have also led to the current malaise. First, the minister gets far too involved in the detail. The NHS is far too big for any minister, let alone one with limited management experience, to try and run it. Second, merging the roles of NHS chief executive and Health Department permanent secretary has been a mistake. The NHS has a mandarin running it, not a manager. NHS staff need someone to lead for them. There is an unhealthy vacuum at the top.

Mr Milburn is due to outline his vision of Labour's second term tomorrow at the launch of the modernisation agency. Here is a chance to make amends. Labour promised no return to command and control but has introduced the most centralised system since the NHS was launched. Mr Milburn is mistaken in believing power lies at the centre. His plan will only work with the support of the staff. They need to have a sense of ownership. Having set out Labour's vision, it is time to concede discretion to the field. This is the only way to generate the energy that the radical reform needs.

fields.headline: BBC regulation back on the agenda
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The contentious issue of BBC regulation may be reopened in the summer after the general election, writes Jason Deans
Special report: communications white paper
fields.body:
The contentious issue of BBC regulation may be reopened in the summer after the general election.

Sources say the draft communications bill has been virtually agreed in principle but there is still major "contention" about three areas - the role of the BBC board of governors, the structure of Ofcom and media ownership.

Some senior industry executives now believe the government could heed the widespread call from commercial broadcasters for the BBC governors to be made accountable to the new communications regulator, Ofcom, and revisit an issue that was initially dealt with in last year's communications white paper.

"I think there will be a subtle shift, with a bigger advisory role for Ofcom," said one public affairs executive.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, has already said he thinks BBC regulation should be left alone until parliament gets round to considering the renewal of the BBC Charter

The current charter runs to 2006 and the parliamentary review is likely to begin in 2003 or 2004.

The communications white paper published in December proposed maintaining the "legal responsibility and authority of the BBC governors for delivering the BBC's remit".

But in the media select committee hearings that followed, commercial broadcasters including ITV, Channel 4 and BSkyB called for this proposal to be revised so the BBC governors would be more directly accountable to Ofcom.

The committee's chairman, Gerald Kaufman, described the decision to exclude BBC governance from Ofcom's responsibilities as "utterly anomalous" when launching the subsequent report on the white paper.

Sources say there is still no consensus on the structure of Ofcom. However, the most talked about option is a body headed by a chairman - possibly the former BBC director general, Lord Birt - and a chief executive - possibly the ITC chief executive, Patricia Hodgson.

Beneath this would lie three individual divisions. One division would manage the spectrum, controlling telecoms, TV and radio licensing - a job currently done by the Radio Communications Authority at the DTI and Oftel.

A second division would be responsible for content and editorial, taking over the responsibilities of the ITC, BSC, and the Radio Authority.

The third division would handle all issues of "carriage and infrastructure". It is thought the issue of competition would cut across all three of these internal Ofcom divisions.

There is also a growing consensus among the five existing regulators that a "content panel" or "board" should be created to sit below the main Ofcom board.

Membership of this panel would reflect the UK's regional and ethnic diversity in order to head off possible criticism of Ofcom becoming too London-centric.

It is thought the proposed content board would take over responsibility for programme complaint processing and audience research from the Independent Television Commission and Broadcasting Standards Council.

A spokeswoman from the department of culture, media and sport confirmed that there "may be more consultation on some of the 'greener' bits of the communications white paper, including probably media ownership".

The spokeswoman did not rule out further consultation on the role of the BBC governors.

"The policy on the BBC was set out in the white paper and we are considering the responses at the moment," she said.

The joint department of culture, media and sport and department of trade and industry team working flat out to draft the communications bill is aiming to have all the non-contentious elements ready for publication immediately after the expected June 7 general election.

But there could be some further consultation on media ownership and BBC regulation in July.

The next couple of weeks is regarded as crucial, as it will be the last chance the civil servants drafting the bill have to run options past the relevant government ministers before the election is called.

Media lobbyists will be watching the Queen's Speech following the election to see if the communications bill is included in the legislation to be passed during the first session of the new Parliament.

webTitle: Tightrope walk in search of harmony

fields.headline: Tightrope walk in search of harmony
fields.trailText: The commission for racial equality hit back yesterday at criticism of its attempts to get every MP to sign up to a pledge to oppose racism in the upcoming general election campaign.
fields.body:
The commission for racial equality hit back yesterday at criticism of its attempts to get every MP to sign up to a pledge to oppose racism in the upcoming general election campaign. The CRE denied Tory claims that it had deliberately set a trap for the party, and alleged the party had damaged its own standing.

Robin Banerji, spokesman for the CRE, gave a detailed chronology of how the pledge came about and dealings between the statutory body and party leaders.

But senior Tory sources yesterday stuck by their position that they were not told that individual MPs would be asked to sign up until after the party leaders put their names to the compact at a public ceremony on March 14.

Party sources said they had "never expected this to turn into a naming and shaming exercise" and felt let down by the CRE.

William Hague and the CRE chairman, Gurbux Singh, met to discuss the race compact on February 13. Mr Banerji was at the meeting and says Mr Hague and his aides were told that MPs would be invited to add their signatures after the party leaders at a signing ceremony. That ceremony, on March 14, was in dining room A at the House of Commons and the CRE says 100 MPs did sign.

Mr Banerji said the CRE had written to all MPs on March 9 inviting them to attend. After the ceremony MPs were contacted to see if they would sign the compact.

By last week three Tory MPs had contacted the CRE to say they would not. Newspapers ran stories naming them and, said, Mr Banerji: "It was better to make the information public about who had or hadn't signed to stop speculation or hunting by the media. If asked, why would we keep that secret?"

Hindsight

The CRE is adamant it had no intention of embarrassing anyone, and yesterday the body, charged with policing the 1976 Race Relations Act, was left wondering how it had ended up in the eye of a storm.

The pledge on race had surfaced at the 1997 general election, when it was signed by Tony Blair, the then Tory chairman, Brian Mawhinney, and the then Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown.

The aim was to ensure that racism did not enter the heated political debate during the campaign. But the CRE decided that individual MPs should be asked to sign for this year's election. "That would send out the strongest possible signal to the public that all politicians of all persuasions stood shoulder to shoulder on this issue," Mr Banerji said. "It's not an agreement with the CRE, it's an agreement between the parties. All we did is walk from office to office saying are you happy with this."

Hugh Harris was deputy chairman of the CRE during the 1997 election. He said that with hindsight it was a mistake to ask individual MPs to sign the compact. "It probably has backfired, it's allowed the people who want to throw mud at the CRE to do so.

"I don't know what the logic was that led the CRE asking them this time. Because of all the flak coming out, it's unhelpful, but a lot of the flak is unjustified."

Some on the left believe that the CRE should be merged within a human rights commission covering race, gender and disability. Some ministers believe that under its current powers too often the only way for the CRE to tackle racism is through confrontation such as legal actions and formal inquiries.

The CRE has a tightrope to walk. Some Asian and black people accuse it of doing too little, while rightwing Tories believe it should be abolished. Within the organisation there has been a belief that its powers need to be beefed up for it to be more effective.

The former chairman Sir Herman Ouseley said running the CRE and navigating it through competing concerns was a nightmare. "You manage with a lot of difficulty, you feel like topping yourself most of the time, you get no thanks from anyone, you have to live with your conscience."

He believes the latest row will cause no lasting damage to the CRE.

But one expert believes the real loser could be the Conservative party and its efforts to improve its appeal to Asian and black voters. Shamit Saggar, a psephologist who studied the ethnic minority vote in the 1997 election, said the row would "harm the Conservative party's chances of making inroads into the ethnic minority vote".

If the last election is any guide, there are very few votes for the Tories to win this time from Asian and black voters. In 1997, the Conservatives won just one in 10 of the ethnic minority vote, with Labour getting 85%.

Dr Saggar, a reader in politics at Queen Mary and Westfield College, said: "The view at the top of the Tory party has been we'll engage in the rhetoric of racial equality but not the deed. The row is bad news for those in the party who believe in social inclusion and tolerance."

Despite increasing prosperity among Asian and black communities, Dr Saggar says the Tory party's stand on race puts ethnic minority voters off, especially middle class ones the party wishes to court. "The Tories have defaulted on winning the ethnic minority vote. The default is the long term ghost of [Enoch] Powell in the party. The grassroots is made up of little Powellites, despite what the leadership try to do."

Away from Westminster, the CRE compact was designed to ensure that racial tension in areas such as Tower Hamlets, in east London, does not increase because of politicians' rhetoric during the election campaign.

Control

Asians and black people in Tower Hamlets have suffered from racist attacks for years. Mohammed Shazad, 33, supports the CRE but thought the election pledge was worthless.

He said: "It's just a piece of paper. If deep down you're racist and you sign, it doesn't change you. The CRE shouldn't have bothered." But he felt it was "appalling" that MPs had not signed. "If you look at William Hague, he hasn't got control over his party - how is he going to control a government?"

Alan Grant, 49, unemployed, said: "MPs are the figureheads of the country and they should lead by example. They should have signed. It's better to have the CRE than not. They've opened up people's eyes and brought things to the forefront."

Others opposed the CRE pledge. Mrs Stoker, 60, from Wapping, east London, said: "I don't think the CRE should be a statutory body. I don't think MPs should have to commit themselves in this way.

"Anyone who is going to adopt a racist attitude would do so anyway. They're trying to make an election issue out of it."

He believes the latest row will cause no lasting damage to the CRE. But one expert believes the real loser could be the Conservative party and its efforts to improve its appeal to Asian and black voters. Shamit Saggar, a psephologist who studied the ethnic minority vote in the 1997 election, said the row would "harm the Conservative party's chances of making inroads into the ethnic minority vote". If the last election is any guide, there are very few votes for the Tories to win this time from Asian and black voters. In 1997, the Conservatives won just one in 10 of the ethnic minority vote, with Labour getting 85%. Dr Saggar, a reader in politics at Queen Mary and Westfield College, said: "The view at the top of the Tory party has been we'll engage in the rhetoric of racial equality but not the deed. The row is bad news for those in the party who believe in social inclusion and tolerance." Despite increasing prosperity among Asian and black communities, Dr Saggar says the Tory party's stand on race puts ethnic minority voters off, especially middle class ones the party wishes to court. "The Tories have defaulted on winning the ethnic minority vote. The default is the long term ghost of [Enoch] Powell in the party. The grassroots is made up of little Powellites, despite what the leadership try to do." Away from Westminster, the CRE compact was designed to ensure that racial tension in areas such as Tower Hamlets, in east London, does not increase because of politicians' rhetoric during the election campaign. Control Asians and black people in Tower Hamlets have suffered from racist attacks for years. Mohammed Shazad, 33, supports the CRE but thought the election pledge was worthless. He said: "It's just a piece of paper. If deep down you're racist and you sign, it doesn't change you. The CRE shouldn't have bothered." But he felt it was "appalling" that MPs had not signed. "If you look at William Hague, he hasn't got control over his party - how is he going to control a government?" Alan Grant, 49, unemployed, said: "MPs are the figureheads of the country and they should lead by example. They should have signed. It's better to have the CRE than not. They've opened up people's eyes and brought things to the forefront." Others opposed the CRE pledge. Mrs Stoker, 60, from Wapping, east London, said: "I don't think the CRE should be a statutory body. I don't think MPs should have to commit themselves in this way. "Anyone who is going to adopt a racist attitude would do so anyway. They're trying to make an election issue out of it."

fields.headline: Text messaging recovers in March
fields.trailText:
10am: The number of text messages sent between British mobile phones went up again in March, reports Amy Vickers.
27.03.2001: Text message numbers fall
22.02.2001: January text messaging breaks records
08.02.2001: Text messages to usurp Valentine's cards
fields.body:
The number of text messages sent between British mobile phones went up again in March.

This follows a fall of 120m in the number of messages sent between January and February.

However, the figures for March show that Britain is still on course to crash through the 1bn-a-month barrier this summer.

In all, 864m text messages were sent in March, up from 808m in February, according to the Mobile Data Association.

Year on year, the numbers are showing exponential growth. In March 2000, 372m messages were sent.

In January this year, a record-breaking 929m text messages were sent in Britain, a figure that prompted the MDA to revise its estimates for February.

It had expected the February figures to surpass the 1bn mark but this target is now thought to be a few months away.

webTitle: Women: New biography of Martha Gellhorn

fields.headline: Gunning for Martha
fields.standfirst:
Martha Gellhorn changed the face of war reporting. So why is a new biography more interested in what she wore and who she slept with? Audrey Gillan investigates

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Martha Gellhorn changed the face of war reporting. So why is a new biography more interested in what she wore and who she slept with? Audrey Gillan investigates.
fields.body:
In the last years of her life, the great American reporter Martha Gellhorn became aware of a writer trying to muckrake down among her most personal history. For someone so very public yet so very private, the idea was appalling. She told her friend, the journalist John Simpson: "There's some wretched little man who's gone around digging out material about me, and he's just waiting till I die to bring it out." That man was Carl Rollyson. Last week his finished product, Beautiful Exile, The Life of Martha Gellhorn, was published, three years after her death.

The woman who changed the face of war reporting, giving accounts of the suffering of real people, was right to be worried. Rollyson - who in 1990 published a previous edition of the book in the US but was forced to remove certain sections after a legal battle with Gellhorn - writes in his introduction: "She knew how important sex was for most men, and she used it not only to please men but to get good stories. She slept with generals; she had one-night stands with ordinary soldiers who might not survive the next day. She dressed elegantly, used make-up skilfully, flirted and coaxed men to do her bidding."

A picture emerges of a woman who "smoked, drank and travelled with abandon"; she is castigated for her beauty, her "wheat coloured hair", for wearing Saks Fifth Avenue slacks while reporting on the horrors of war. She is portrayed as a user of men and is said to have tired of her adopted son - a notion he has fiercely rejected.

In her final years in London, perched in a sixth-floor flat in Cadogan Square, Gellhorn had visits from a host of great war reporters and other journalists who had become friends. Most are disgusted by the book.

As the journalist John Pilger says: "The problem Martha Gellhorn still presents to the jealous, envious and scandalmongers is that she was brave, beautiful and clever, and had passionately held political principles. Worse, she was a woman who was decades ahead of her time in pushing the boundaries of her gender. Salacious demolition jobs on remarkable human beings after their death are not new; and they are as craven as ever."

Since she walked out on Ernest Hemingway in 1943, after five years of marriage, Gellhorn had refused to talk much about him. She was a writer in her own right, a woman who had covered the heaviest of wars, and she wished to be remembered for that. Yet all people recalled was the marriage.

Beautiful Exile makes it apparent why Gellhorn was so reticent to talk about the man who would eventually shoot himself. For the first time, her friends have learned that, jealously, he tried to destroy her reputation, dehumanising her as an "operative" during their years working together and trying to turn her into his property.

The book contains extracts from ferocious letters Hemingway wrote to Gellhorn after she walked off to war and out of their marriage. He called her a "career bulldozer", a "product of beauticians" and a "phoney and pretentious bitch".

Rosie Boycott was friends with Gellhorn from the early 70s when Boycott founded Spare Rib and Gellhorn told her the women's movement was "bunk". Boycott helped her find a lawyer to oppose publication of Rollyson's original biography and recalls "quite a nasty fight. I imagine he was monumentally pissed off." She says of the new book: "He comes up with all sorts of things - repeated gossip and rubbish. The stuff about how mean and vitriolic Hemingway was is astounding. I was taken aback by how he set out to destroy her. The only thing I came away with from that book was another level of understanding of why she was so insistent in not wanting to be portrayed as Mrs Ernest Hemingway."

But Gellhorn had seen the viciousness coming. In spite of her friends' pleadings, just before her death she burnt the letters from Hemingway. Following publication of the original biography, Gellhorn wrote 25 pages of notes on Rollyson's errors.

Bill Buford, the New Yorker editor who was a friend of Gellhorn's, explains: "Martha's objections to the prospect of the book were these: the author's previous works were distinguished by their relish for gossip and weak critical acumen and bad writing. She concluded that the man was interested only in salacious gossip. Martha asked many people to do what they could to stop the book."

The essence of Martha Gellhorn was that she was an ambiguity, a woman who was rankled by myth-like people but became a myth herself. In those later years she told stories to her "chaps" - those who came to read to her when she was near-blind following a botched cataract operation - which were hazily recollected through the mist of Famous Grouse. She knew that this way they would be half-remembered and they were rarely written down.

The journalist James Fox, who bonded with Gellhorn when they were writing about the miners' strike, is outraged by the notion that Gellhorn slept with people to get a good story and by the book's claims that she did not actually enjoy sex. He says: "Of course Martha had affairs. Hemingway was allowed to have affairs and that's fabulous and macho. She's portrayed as a scarlet woman. It's as if the author said: 'Hey, let's think of a new angle - Hemingway was a sweetie and Gellhorn was this voracious, vicious, heartless woman'."

Martha Gellhorn was born in St Louis, Missouri, to a mother who was a leading light in the suffrage movement. At 21, she talked her way into a free passage on a liner and sailed to Paris with just $75 in the hope that she could become a foreign correspondent. Four years later, in 1934, she returned to the US and wrote about the depression from the ground, living with the poorest families and railing to President Roosevelt. Her acclaimed book, The Trouble I've Seen, is an account of this time.

She met Hemingway in 1936 when she was on holiday with her family in Key West. It was when the two hooked up in Spain while covering the civil war that they began their affair. She was writing for Collier's magazine.

After the war they lived together in Cuba and travelled to China to cover its war with the Japanese. Back in Cuba, they settled down to domestic life but amid its passion it was a destructive relationship and a stifled Martha felt the pending war had to be written about. Eventually she went off to the front again and when he followed later, Hemingway stole the Collier's commission from under her. In spite of women being barred from reporting from the front line, she one-upped Hemingway by sneaking on to a hospital ship and getting on to the beach during the D-day landings. Hemingway was left to write from a ship. It seems he never forgave her this or the success of her war novel, The Wine of Astonishment.

Gellhorn wrote about the liberation of Italy, Israel, Russia, Poland, Vietnam, she was there when the gates of Dachau were opened after the Nazi surrender. Even in her 80s she was writing about Brazilian street children. She did not listen to "official drivel" and told the truth as she saw it.

Buford says: "Martha was passionate and political, glamorous and exciting. She loved to drink and gossip and smoke and flirt. She was hugely entertaining. She was motivated by a deep-hearted, deep-seated concern for justice; she was the friend of the dispossessed, the oppressed, the neglected. And she was a good writer." And she just happened to be beautiful into the bargain.

fields.headline: Vivendi signs up with Yahoo!
fields.trailText: 10am:The French media giant hopes to broaden its music licensing agreement with Yahoo! to take in TV shows and movies, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Vivendi Universal is to enter AOL Time Warner territory under plans being discussed to develop stronger distribution ties with Yahoo!.

The French media giant is hoping to broaden its three-week old music licensing agreement with Yahoo! to take in TV shows and movies, and develop a mutually beneficial partnership.

The link-up will stop short of a full-blown merger, but according to reports, will have all the benefits of one.

"We believe Yahoo! could be the privileged partner of Vivendi Universal and vice versa," said Jean-Marie Messier, the chairman of Vivendi, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal.

"We have other content. Let's discuss other content with Yahoo!."

Mr Messier also welcomed the appointment of Terry Semel as the chief executive of Yahoo!.

He called Mr Semel "a great manager with a great vision joining a team we are already pleased to be working with".

Separately, Vivendi this morning agreed a deal with Rupert Murdoch's News Corp to merge their loss-making Italian pay TV businesses, Telepiu and Stream.

Vivendi's pay TV unit, Canal Plus, is to hold two-thirds of the merged entity, to be called Telepiu, with the remainder held by News Corp.

Both Stream and Telepiu have incurred millions of pounds of debt after spending huge sums to secure exclusive deals to football rights.

The merger means there is no longer any competition for rights in Italy, therefore bringing down costs.

fields.headline: Fergie makes debut as ITV reporter
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV is to sign up the Duchess of York as a current affairs reporter working with Trevor McDonald, reports Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
ITV is set to sign up the Duchess of York as a current affairs reporter working with Sir Trevor McDonald.

She will make her debut on Sir Trevor's Tonight show this Thursday, fronting a 20-minute investigation into obesity.

And senior executives say they hope to persuade her to become an occasional reporter on the show.

"She comes across as warm and interested. And she has now got quite a lot of experience from her work on American television," said one source on the show.

Obesity is a subject familiar to the duchess, who for years was dubbed the "Duchess of Pork" because of her ballooning figure.

She has become an ambassador for Weightwatchers in the US, earning £1m a year, and claimed the company's diet regime helped her lose three stone.

However, the duchess has also been criticised after revealing she encouraged her daughters - Eugenie,12, and Beatrice, 10 - to calculate the calories and fat content of their food.

Insiders on Tonight are keen to sign her up - they know the duchess is "box office" but have yet to open negotiations with her.

"It will be a matter of establishing how much work she can fit into her schedule and what kind of issues we want her to report on," said a source.

It is understood the duchess has not been paid for her appearance on Thursday's Tonight.

A long-term deal will be a significant entree to mainstream British television, coming at a time when the royals' business interests are coming under intense scrutiny.

However, the duchess's activities will not come under the Lord Chamberlain's review of royals as she is now deemed an "ordinary person".

Her ITV debut comes two years after her Sky TV chatshow was axed after pulling in a meagre 12,000 viewers.

The much heralded Sarah - Surviving Life survived just one 10-show series on Sky and was a critical disaster.

One critic branded it "the most embarrassing 60 minutes in chatshow history".

Since then, however, she has gone on to front the biggest chatshow in the world, America's Larry King show. Americans claim to like her candour and ballsy style.

"I've had first-hand knowledge of what it's like to be overweight and have the media spotlight on me," the duchess says in her Tonight show.

"I think I understand the depression and despair people face when they are trying to lose weight. But what's frightening is that here in Britain we're following hard on the heels of America and fast becoming the fattest country in Europe.

"I've never been clinically obese but I can imagine I might well have been if I had not taken control of my eating when I did.

"Being overweight left me feeling very depressed and the more depressed I became, the more I wanted to eat.

"What I realise now is that in order to lose weight permanently you have to change your whole lifestyle and that's not easy," she said.

Among the obese people she meets in her report is Gary Hipperson, who had a 60-inch waist and weighed more than 25 stone when he was just 14.

webTitle: Straw hits out at 'weak' Hague as tit for tat goes on

fields.headline: Straw hits out at 'weak' Hague as tit for tat goes on
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday launched a strong attack on William Hague's handling of the race pledge as the political row rumbled on, descending into what one minister called a "tit for tat" war of words.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday launched a strong attack on William Hague's handling of the race pledge as the political row rumbled on, descending into what one minister called a "tit for tat" war of words.

The Conservative leader was unable to contain factions in his party who refused to sign the compact, Mr Straw told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"The problem with William Hague is not that I think for a second he is a racist but he is very, very weak and he is unable to contain this."

As the culture secretary, Chris Smith, admitted the issue had turned into a "tit for tat" argument, Tony Blair's spokesman acknowledged the Conservatives had every right to challenge the government over asylum.

Meanwhile the Lib Dems attacked a campaign leaflet published by David Shaw, Tory prospective parliamentary candidate in the Lib Dem-held marginal of Kingston and Surbiton. The leaflet, which prominently states that asylum seekers are costing each UK household £34 annually, includes a quiz to win the prize of a "bottle of English wine" featuring the question "What is the percentage of asylum applications that are unjustified?"

Kingston and Surbiton Lib Dem MP Ed Davey said: "Voters will see this scaremongering for what it is, both distasteful and irresponsible."

The former home secretary Michael Howard yesterday denied using inflammatory language in an advert revealed in yesterday's Guardian highlighting the Tories' record on asylum seekers.

The advert, in the local paper in the MP's Folkstone and Hythe constituency, asked: "What matters most to you? Bogus asylum seekers? Conservatives reduced the number before. We will do so again."

Mr Howard insisted: "I do not see what in this advertisement could possibly be regarded as objectionable."

Mr Blair's official spokesman said asylum issues had to be separated from arguments about racism - a response to Tory accusations that the government is running away from a debate on asylum.

"Our complaint about the opposition is not that they have raised the issue of asylum It is a perfectly fair, legitimate thing to do. Our complaint is that they have opposed the measures we have put in place to deal with that."

Mr Straw will today make a speech to the Foreign Press Association defending the government's asylum policy.

The government is now likely to stick to policy issues and steer clear of mudslinging over alleged racism within the Conservative party, since its accusations have led campaigners to question its own record on race matters.

A speech by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, praising Britain's multicultural identity and its love of chicken tikka masala was widely seen as patronising.

Our complaint is that they have opposed the measures we have put in place to deal with that." Mr Straw will today make a speech to the Foreign Press Association defending the government's asylum policy. The government is now likely to stick to policy issues and steer clear of mudslinging over alleged racism within the Conservative party, since its accusations have led campaigners to question its own record on race matters. A speech by Robin Cook, foreign secretary, praising Britain's multicultural identity and its love of chicken tikka masala was widely seen as patronising.

webTitle: Are humans at risk from foot and mouth?

fields.headline: Are humans at risk from foot and mouth?
fields.standfirst: A slaughterman may have become the first human to catch foot and mouth since the current outbreak began. We examine the current threats posed by the disease
fields.trailText: A slaughterman may have become the first human to catch foot and mouth since the current outbreak began. We examine the current threats posed by the disease.
fields.body:
Are people at risk from foot and mouth?
Not from the disease itself. If foot and mouth infects a human (an incredibly rare event) he or she experiences mild flu-like symptoms and blisters, which are not serious. But there is concern that high levels of carcinogenic dioxins may be emitted from animal pyres in the affected areas.

How does the disease infect humans?
People can be infected through skin wounds or by handling diseased stock. The possibly infected man is a member of the army who was heavily involved in the culling operation in Cumbria. He was accidentally sprayed with material from a slaughtered cow.

Can it be spread through food?
You can catch foot and mouth by drinking infected milk but not by eating infected meat. In 1834, a physician called Hertwig apparently managed to give himself the disease by drinking milk from infected cows.

How many people have suffered worldwide?
Since testing was developed, just over 40 humans have become infected with the disease, including several cases in Europe and others in Africa and South America. But even where foot and mouth is widespread it rarely crosses to humans. The last British case was recorded in 1967 when Bobby Brewis, a farm machinery salesman, developed a mild temperature, a sore throat, blisters on the palms of his hands and Ð in his own words Ð "felt a bit groggy".

What about the fires?
More seriously, officials from the Department of the Environment confirmed on Sunday that pyres lit during the first six weeks of the crisis had released 63g of cancer-causing dioxins into the atmosphere - equal to 18% of the UK's average annual emissions but concentrated in a handful of areas.

What are dioxins?
A by-product of heating and burning, dioxins are among the most toxic chemicals known to man. They are proven carcinogens and the World Health Organisation classes them as a serious risk to human health. Dioxins were also found in Agent Orange, the herbicide used by the US military for defoliating forest areas in Vietnam suspected of concealing the Viet Cong and their allies.

What is the governmentÕs response?
An official report on the subject is due later this week. But, despite protests, a pyre was lit at the weekend built to burn 7,000 carcasses at Arscott Farm near Holsworthy in Devon. Twelve more in Cumbria are burning or smouldering, though no more will be built until the report is out. The environment minister, Michael Meacher, has already conceded there is a health risk and is now ordering the monitoring of all pyres hourly for pollutants.

How else can the carcasses be destroyed?
The options are rendering in industrial rendering plants or burial in registered landfill sites. The government has rejected calls to allow further on-farm burials in Devon (where the greatest number of animals await disposal) in case the decomposing carcasses leak into the water table.

Is foot and mouth under control?
The average number of daily cases is now 16 compared with 43 just over two weeks ago. But the state of the disease is now a political issue Ð the government says it is under control while the opposition insists the measures put in place to end the disease are in chaos.
