fields.headline: McCarthyism goes anti-racist
fields.standfirst: Nobody ever did anything very foolish except from some strong principle, Melbourne said, and he could have added that nothing corrupts liberalism like good intentions, writes Geoffrey Wheatcroft
fields.trailText: Comment: Nobody ever did anything very foolish except from some strong principle, Melbourne said, and he could have added that nothing corrupts liberalism like good intentions, writes Geoffrey Wheatcroft.
fields.body:
Nobody ever did anything very foolish except from some strong principle, Melbourne said, and he could have added that nothing corrupts liberalism like good intentions. The row over the commission for racial equality's "compact", by which parliamentary candidates have been told to subscribe to "principles for good practice and conduct", illustrates this truth yet again.

We all know that there is racism in our society and we can all agree that anti-racism is a fine ideal. But the CRE's pledge is profoundly objectionable in authentic liberal terms. That is not less true because Ann Widdecombe and Nicholas Soames say so. The document is patronising, insulting and bullying at best; its implications almost totalitarian. Subscribers are invited "to reject all forms of racial violence, racial harassment and unlawful racial discrimination". And when did you stop beating your wife? The wording itself makes a presumption of guilt.

This is not the first time liberalism has been compromised in the name of anti-racism. The Race Relations Acts themselves were inspired by high ideals, and they were an attack on free speech which introduced a new form of censorship, as honest libertarians like John Mortimer and the late Nicholas Walter pointed out.

What happened in the struggle against white supremacy in South Africa was worse yet. Here was a good cause if ever there was one. And, all unnoticed, anti-apartheid campaigners adopted methods identical to those of McCarthyism: boycotts, blacklists and loyalty oaths. Sportsmen and entertainers who worked in South Africa were placed on blacklists designed to deprive them of work, but could purge their offence by making formal condemnations of apartheid. A generation earlier, American academics accused of fellow-travelling had been allowed to keep their jobs by signing anti-communist loyalty oaths.

Perhaps the most displeasing single feature of the anti-apartheid campaign was the boycott of South African universities and scholars. This was defended on the illogical as well as ignoble ground that although academic freedom was an absolute good, the fight against apartheid was even more important.

That was what anti-communists once said about their own cause. Once it is allowed that a South African academic could be ostracised for political reasons, how can we protest at, for example, the recent withdrawal, also for political reasons, of an invitation to Edward Said by a Freudian conference in Vienna?

Another case of good intentions leading to illiberal bullying was the Macpherson report. Leave aside the intellectually absurd definition of a racist incident as one which is perceived as such by any of those involved. The concept of "institutional racism" has totalitarian overtones: you are all guilty.

The idea of institutional racism smacks of the witch-hunt. A woman would be thrown in a pond. If she was innocent, she drowned. If she floated, she was guilty of witchcraft and could be burned to death. Accused of institutional racism, you can plead guilty (in the tones of a defendant in the Moscow trials), or not guilty - and are held to have demonstrated your greater guilt merely by having done so.

The row over the CRE compact has seen a good deal of humbug. Certainly there is racism on the fringes of the Tory party, and perhaps a guilty conscience among some Tories which made them walk into an obvious political trap. But a Pharisaical display of anti-racist scruples by the Labour party is as unappealing as anything on the Tory side. This is a government which has Jack Straw as home secretary, and is led by Tony Blair, who privately asked an adviser (we learned from a leaked document) to find ways he could be seen to take a tough stance against asylum seekers.

To say that liberals have betrayed their principles on this issue is not entirely true. Plenty of people on the left instinctively dislike the CRE pledge. That includes some Labour MPs, although in the cowed state of the parliamentary party their reservations are muffled. Straw said yesterday that Hague's weak leadership is shown by his inability to tell his MPs what to do. One might think the contrast with New Labour democratic centralism is one of the few things to be said for the Tories.

Outside the reach of party punishment squads, Mark Seddon, the editor of Tribune, has spoken up for left libertarianism by condemning the CRE and the government. Why stop at anti-racist pledges, he wondered. What about "compacts" of support for the free market, or oaths of undying loyalty to the party leadership?

It hasn't quite come to that, but those who have been gloating over this episode may live to see the glee wiped off their faces.

webTitle: Ministerial double-talk simply masks a racist law

fields.headline: Ministerial double-talk simply masks a racist law
fields.standfirst: The Race Relations (Amendment) Act offends against natural justice, writes Hugo Young
fields.trailText: Comment: The Race Relations (Amendment) Act offends against natural justice, writes Hugo Young.
fields.body:
Behind the rival hands of race cards that party politicians hold are the facts on the ground. This column is about one of them. As the main parties proclaim their concerns about race, facts are drowning under a Niagara of piety. Yet this particular fact is so startling that it deserves wide study. In an honest society, it would tell you that race, far from being excluded from the election, would be near the forefront of discussion. But since only the Liberal Democrats care about it, and have an honourable record in dealing with it, the conspiracy of self-congratulatory silence is likely to succeed.

The fact in question is the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000. Though William Hague is a slimy cardplayer, Jack Straw, I think, is worse. He, after all, is the minister. He saw the act through. Yesterday, purring sanctimoniously about Labour's superiority in all matters racial, he said this act "puts on the statute book some of the best anti-discrimination legislation anywhere in the world". But that is not why it should be famous. Its uniqueness is quite the opposite. It puts on the statute book the bluntest piece of state-sponsored ethnic discrimination in the 35 years since British parliaments started legislating in the field.

The act's ostensible purpose was benign. Responding to the Stephen Lawrence tragedy, it extended anti-discrimination law to public authorities, notably the police, previously outside its reach. There were hiccups along the legislative way. Ministers had to be goaded into outlawing indirect, as well as direct, discrimination. What they couldn't be shifted from, however, was a decision to exempt all immigration, nationality and asylum decision-makers from the new law. These are now explicitly permitted to override what were for many years accepted principles: first, that immigration officers must observe the law against racial bias, and second that ethnic groups must at all times be treated as individuals not as a collective.

How did this happen? Partly through the reptilian disingenuousness of the Home Office. Mr Straw depicted the specific change as itself benign. Without it, he said, "ministers would, for example, be unable to authorise special compassionate exercises when necessary for particular ethnic or national groups". The exemption would have only good purposes. Straw cited the mercy Britain had recently shown to Kosovo Albanians en masse. Discrimination for positive purposes had to be exempted from a new anti-discrimination law.

Seldom in the annals of ministerial double-talk was such apparent virtue so swiftly renounced. We know this from the first ministerial instruction to immigration officers that was issued under the act, under cover of near-darkness, which has been operative since early April. This legal document, seen by almost no one, makes clear how the act should be operated not to let needy cases in but to keep national groups, irrespective of individual circumstances, out. Here comes the heightening of authorised official prejudice against national groups. The instruction says these must be examined more rigorously, detained more freely, and refused entry more swiftly if "there is statistical evidence showing a pattern or trend of breach of the immigration laws by persons of that nationality".

Even supposing the statistics were reliable, this grotesquely offends against natural justice, not to mention the Human Rights Act and several international obligations. "Statistical evidence" in the immigration field is hard to verify, and in any case a baseless way of predicting the truth about an individual case.

What case is there for punishing a newly arrived Serb merely because previous Serbs have been refused? A society that had kept its legal head would be unhappy answering that question. Yet the sweeping exemption grants officials, through ministers, the power to deport, exclude, refuse leave to enter, withhold exceptional leave to remain, and grant or not grant asylum, not only by reference to the collective record of earlier Nigerians or Chinese or Russians, as nationalities, but on the still more offensive basis of ethnic or national origins.

During the act's passage last year, ministers showed themselves aware of the sensitivities this might arouse. When an issue arose about the meaning of "ethnic", Straw was quick to say it was unlawful for immigration staff to discriminate on grounds of race or colour. But this was as circular as it was duplicitous, as he surely knew. It was wordplay in the interest of squaring a supposedly progressive conscience with an indisputably aggressive attitude to asylum seekers. How can an immigration officer take ethnic origins into account, as the new law instructs, without this being simultaneously racial? Answer: any problem the officer may have can now be handled by the power the new act confers on ministers to determine when a racial/ethnic decision is "justified" or "necessary".

Searching for a reasoned justification, ministers fell back on racketeering. The main scenario they offered against which these blanket powers were necessary was where criminal gangs organised economic migration from China. People who looked Chinese might on these grounds have to be singled out for attention. Revealingly, Straw's deputy, Mike O'Brien, when challenged with a parallel hypothesis of white economic migrants from eastern Europe, perhaps orchestrated by Russian gangs, shrank from making a similar ethnic generalisation. "White people are not one homogeneous ethnic group, incapable of being distinguished one from another," he said, as if non-white people were somehow other.

The truth is that this part of the Race Relations (Amendment) Act is ethnically discriminatory, in a way which such ministerial language only confirms. It is not aimed at scams alone. It's meant to withhold justice from groups of people - unspecified in the law, but in categories open-ended to the whim of ministers - based on their ethnic or national origins, and without a fair chance to answer back. Anyone who doubts this has only to read the final clause in the ministerial directive. It says: "If the information [needed to pursue an application to enter] is not available in a language which the person understands, it is not necessary to provide the information in a language which he does understand."

So the net closes on the British reputation for the rule of decent law. Asylum and immigration pose complex problems in the modern age, but they do not need to be addressed by this kind of perversion of the system. Maybe only an optimist would expect it to feature in the election campaign. Even the Lib Dems may hesitate to talk up their record. But behind the smarmy talk about what politicians should say, there's the issue of what they do. What Jack Straw, famous for his anti-racism, has done is write into statute a law of national and ethnic and racial discrimination.

webTitle: Skipper reprimanded for fatal sub collision

fields.headline: Skipper reprimanded for fatal sub collision
fields.trailText: The commander of the US submarine Greeneville, which collided with a Japanese fisheries training ship, killing nine people, has been punished with a letter of reprimand, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The commander of the US submarine Greeneville, which collided with a Japanese fisheries training ship, killing nine people, has been punished with a letter of reprimand, it was confirmed yesterday.

The letter effectively ends the naval career of Commander Scott Waddle, 41, who said that he would retire before October.

"While I regret that my navy career has ended in this way, I know that I'm one of the lucky ones because I survived the accident," Cmdr Waddle said in a statement released by his lawyer, Charles Gittins.

The punishment was imposed by Admiral Thomas Fargo, the Pacific Fleet commander, at a navy court hearing, known as an "admiral's mast". It was attended by Cmdr Waddle, a military lawyer and several officers at the Pearl Harbour base.

Admiral Fargo concluded that there was dereliction of duty and negligence that put the vessel in danger, Mr Gittins said.

But he said that the admiral did not mention allegations of negligent homicide in the death of nine Japanese students and crew on the Ehime Maru when it was rammed on February 9 off Hawaii.

"I understand and accept the punishment that Admiral Fargo imposed. He treated me fairly, and with dignity and respect, and I thank him for that," Cmdr Waddle said.

Mr Gittins said the admiral indicated that he would accept Cmdr Waddle's forced retirement. If he had chosen not to retire, he would have had to show why he should be allowed to remain in the navy.

"My heart aches for the losses suffered by the families of those killed aboard the MV Ehime Maru and the grief that this accident unfairly has thrust upon them," Cmdr Waddle said, and urged Washington to settle the claims made by the families.

"I think about those lost at sea every day and I grieve for the families."

Cmdr Waddle has said that he plans to travel to Japan to meet the victims' families.

"I think about those lost at sea every day and I grieve for the families." Cmdr Waddle has said that he plans to travel to Japan to meet the victims' families.

webTitle: Two killed in Bolton hotel fire

fields.headline: Two killed in Bolton hotel fire
fields.trailText: Two people died today in a fire at a hotel in Bolton, Greater Manchester.
fields.body:
Two people died today in a fire at a hotel in Bolton, Greater Manchester.

The blaze, described as "severe" by the fire brigade, was reported in the seven-story Moathouse hotel in the early hours of this morning.

Hotel staff evacuated most of the 128 guests as fire took hold on the third floor and heavy smoke filled the floors immediately above and below.

Windows were smashed at the height of the blaze but as 50 fire fighters attempted to bring the flames under control it became clear "several people were unaccounted for", a spokesman said.

A team of 20 firefighters wearing breathing apparatus began a search of the hotel and found a man and a woman in a corridor on the third floor.

They were given first aid at the scene and rushed by ambulance to the Royal Bolton hospital where they were pronounced dead.

Two more people suffering from smoke inhalation were also taken to hospital, but later released.

The spokesman said a full investigation had been launched into the fire.

A spokeswoman for Greater Manchester police said emergency services were alerted to the blaze just before 1am.

"The fire was in a residential area. We do not know yet whether the people who died were guests or hotel employees," she said.

"The cause of the fire has not yet been established and is subject to a joint investigation between police, fire and forensic services."

Police cordoned off the area and early morning buses were diverted away from the scene.

People employed close to the hotel said they could see the effect of the fire as they came into work.

A woman, who declined to be named, said: "From here you can see that the windows have all been blown out."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart on foot and mouth

fields.headline: Napalm becomes burning issue for pyre authority
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Tam Dalyell wanted to know whether Michael Meacher, the minister in charge of the rural task force, had been in touch lately with the department of agriculture in Reno, Nevada.
fields.body:
Tam Dalyell wanted to know whether Michael Meacher, the minister in charge of the rural task force, had been in touch lately with the department of agriculture in Reno, Nevada.

You could see Mr Meacher mentally scratching his head. Reno? Where? Mr Meacher owns many houses, but he couldn't quite place one in Reno. Was it a village in Cornwall? Perhaps his wife had bought it last week and forgotten to tell him. It must happen all the time.

It turned out that Mr Dalyell wanted to recommend the use of napalm as a way of ending the present crisis. This did, at first sight, seem rather extreme. Would the South Downs Way have to be renamed the Ho Chi Minh Trail? Tourists strolling along an open footpath would hear the distant thunder of a B-52, and dash for refuge in the impenetrable jungle, sorry, into a nearby farm park featuring bouncy castle, a shop selling pincushions stuffed with dried herbs and a "pet the baby animals' sores" pen.

Mind you, it would attract American visitors, or at least a certain type of American visitor, and not the kind who like all those films in which men with floppy hair stammer at women as if they'd never met one before.

Tam wanted the napalm to be used on the corpses of slaughtered livestock. Work done in Nevada shows that with napalm a pyre (sounds like an American roadside restaurant chain: "Gourmet Stack O'Dead Animals") can be vaporised in 60 minutes, without any dioxins being released, whereas a pyre burns for three days and sends out enough poison to obliterate an entire Vietnamese village.

Mr Meacher was puzzled. All Mr Dalyell's ideas sound batty, but nobody can ever work out precisely why they are, in the Irish phrase, wired to the moon.

"We have, em, not consultated these authorities," he muttered. "Why not?" yelled some Tories, who probably think the only thing wrong with Vietnam was that the Americans didn't fight to win. "But we take the point he is making!" Mr Meacher finished, grateful to be off the hook, while Mr Dalyell, who never lets a good idea go, sat back, dreaming of a land shrouded in cows reduced to their constituent electrons.

Most of Mr Meacher's statement was a repeat of the promises he made last month, largely expressed in New Labour cliches (there are to be "capital repayment holidays" and a "skills boost package" plus, presumably, a capital repayment skills package holiday).

My mind drifted back 24 hours to the weekend I had just spent in the countryside. There is something oddly British about the way even the plastic "Keep out - foot and mouth" signs are now battered and torn as if they'd been there forever. The canal towpath was open, though with stern signs warning you to "disinfect all angling equipment", another typically British nit-picking detail, reminiscent of Mr Prescott's belief that 3p on petrol will stop the planet turning into a spinning ball of dust.

On Sunday the rain was ice cold and horizontal, so we had to scamper indoors and toss another infected lamb on the fire. That's why people aren't going to the country now; it's absolutely freezing.

Mr Meacher complained about the Tories who, he said, were making things sound worse than they were. He said of Archie Norman, "his general Jeremiah picture is fairly wide of the mark", and again I was back in the United States. "General 'Leathernuts' Jeremiah led Confederate troops to defeat at the Battle of Buffalo's Spleen. Though all his arms and legs had been shot off by Federal cannon he insisted on fighting to the last man..."

Rather like this government in its present disastrous state, I suppose.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: Anger mounts over pollution threat

fields.headline: Anger mounts over pollution threat after monitoring for dioxins stalls
fields.standfirst:
Devon town protests at 24-hour delay in air tests

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: In the north Devon town of Holsworthy, anger grew that it was nearly 24 hours before scientists started monitoring for pollution after the lighting of the Arscott farm pyre of 4,000 sheep and cattle.
fields.body:
A yellowish grey cloud of stinking smoke stretched over the empty fields like dirty cotton wool. The wind blew it away from the north Devon town of Holsworthy less than a mile away, but in the town anger had grown that it was nearly 24 hours before scientists started monitoring for pollution after the lighting of the Arscott farm pyre of 4,000 sheep and cattle.

Sampling for dioxins, the most toxic of the chemicals produced, had not begun by yesterday evening. The monitoring station, in a trailer next to the community hospital, was sampling for sulphur dioxide, oxides of nitrogen and particulates. Analysis for dioxins is more complex and could not be carried out with the equipment in the trailer, the contractors said yesterday.

Daryn Bray, president of Holsworthy chamber of commerce, said: "The first 24 hours are supposedly the worst, and I feel they have to monitor it from the start, not a day in to the burn ... it appears typical of the way the whole thing has been handled."

Fierce protest forced Maff to amend its plans to burn 13,000 sheep and 1,000 cattle at Arscott, and to aim for only 4,000 animals. But Mike Childs, campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, said: "It's disturbing that local people may have been exposed to the pollution before finding out if there were emissions causing ill health. One is suspicious that this monitoring exercise is only trying to prove the government is right to say all is safe."

A spokeswoman for the Department of the Environment denied accusations of incompetence. But in Holsworthy a giant board was chalked with the words "Air pollution 24 hours by Ministry Against Family Feelings". The mayor, John Allen, said: "We feel this site is just too near the town."

 Welsh assembly ministers yesterday decided against burning up to 180,000 sheep high in Brecon Beacons national park. Trecastle and Sennybridge residents claimed the burning and burials were abandoned because of water and smoke pollution, not because the disposal backlog had eased. Some have complained of sore throats from previous pyres' smoke, and say the rivers Usk and Towy will be contaminated.

Michael Bogdanov, the theatre director, who lives near a pyre at Epynt, said: "Only a madman would think of burying up to 180,000 sheep in unlined pits 1,500ft [up] and think that it won't affect the water table. They are treating people like idiots."

A spokeswoman for the Department of the Environment denied accusations of incompetence. But in Holsworthy a giant board was chalked with the words "Air pollution 24 hours by Ministry Against Family Feelings". The mayor, John Allen, said: "We feel this site is just too near the town."  Welsh assembly ministers yesterday decided against burning up to 180,000 sheep high in Brecon Beacons national park. Trecastle and Sennybridge residents claimed the burning and burials were abandoned because of water and smoke pollution, not because the disposal backlog had eased. Some have complained of sore throats from previous pyres' smoke, and say the rivers Usk and Towy will be contaminated. Michael Bogdanov, the theatre director, who lives near a pyre at Epynt, said: "Only a madman would think of burying up to 180,000 sheep in unlined pits 1,500ft [up] and think that it won't affect the water table. They are treating people like idiots." Email update Sign up for our free daily foot and mouth round-up What's going on? webTitle: Foot and mouth: Public unimpressed by strategy

fields.headline: Public unimpressed by handling of crisis
fields.standfirst:
40% want to halt culls on farms near infected sites

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: There is overwhelming public support for the introduction of a selective vaccination policy to deal with the foot and mouth crisis, according to the findings of this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
There is overwhelming public support for the introduction of a selective vaccination policy to deal with the foot and mouth crisis, according to the findings of this month's Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

It also finds that a substantial minority, some 40% of the public, want to call a halt to the policy of culling animals on farms next to sites where the disease has been detected and to use vaccination instead.

It reveals a gender split on the issue with men being more inclined to back a continuing cull while women generally prefer to see the introduction of mass vaccination.

A surprisingly large proportion of the public - 58% - also say they would be happy to buy meat that had come from a vaccinated animal, removing one of the major fears raised over the adoption of such a policy. Some 65% of men say they would be happy to eat vaccinated meat, compared with just 50% of women. The poll shows that 9% of the population say they do not eat meat - splitting 10% of women and 7% of men.

The government says it would be happy to introduce a selective vaccination policy but will not do it without the support of farmers.

The responses to the question of whether voters approve or disapprove of the government's handling of the foot and mouth crisis show that the electorate has not been impressed by Labour's performance, with a majority (56%) giving a negative verdict. But these figures have remained unchanged over the past three weeks, bearing out Labour's calculation that as the daily number of new cases falls so the political damage to the government will be contained.

Replies to the question about which party has the best policies for dealing with foot and mouth reveal the full extent to which the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats have failed to capitalise on the situation. Even after the television pictures of the pyres burning every night during the crisis not even a majority of Conservative voters believe they have the best policy to deal with the crisis.

 ICM interviewed a sample of 1,005 adults aged 18 and over by telephone from April 20 to 22, 2001. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The May Day anti-capitalist protests have an early success. The world patent protection summit was wittily scheduled for the same day in central London.
fields.body:
 The May Day anti-capitalist protests have an early success. The world patent protection summit, a conference at which biotech firms are paying over £2,000 per head to get staff briefed by legal experts from GM companies like Astrazeneca and Novartis on stopping the public benefiting from scientific breakthroughs, was wittily scheduled for the same day in central London.

The venue has been changed, however, as an email from Nisha Patel of organisers IQPC makes plain. "These demonstrations have tended to become violent. Due to the controversial nature of this conference and its relation to an area of great media attention, we have decided it would be best to stay out of central London." Very wise. "We have informed delegates about this change and they all appear to be quite excited!" Indeed. "I would be grateful if you could be discreet about the venue change."

Yes, secrecy is vital, as Nisha confirms in a follow up. "I am writing again to reiterate that the utmost discretion is required re this venue change. We have been tipped off that the activists will be targeting the pharmaceutical, research and science sectors... " It's not for us to blow the cover of these good-natured multinationals for the benefit of anarchists and we wish the conference all the best.

 Alright, you anarchists, just teasing. It's the Crowne Plaza at Heathrow.

 Is there a more lovable soul alive than ex-umpire Dickie Bird, whose wondrous store of cricketing tales are always such a tonic? Dickie's just the same humble Yorkshire lad now, even after writing history's best-selling sport's autobiography, and this emerges from a Sunday mag feature called It's Your Funeral. To follow burial in Barnsley, Dickie has modest plans for "a memorial service in Westminster Abbey" which would be "very, very nice". I'll say. But how deserved.

"I still umpire charity matches and I do what I can for charities for the elderly, cancer research... By and large, people don't realise what I do for charity" - how could they with him never talking about it? - "because I just get on and do it. And I've made a will leaving quite a lot of money to charity... "

 Interviewed in the Times after 10 years in the job, George Carey is full of Christian warmth towards his friend and sometime party host Jeffrey Archer. The timing's odd. How the jury in his lordship's forthcoming trial can be expected to ignore a character reference from the Archbishop of Canterbury, a spiritual leader to literally thousands, I cannot imagine. In its defence to the charge of contempt when the whole case crumbles, the Times might argue that no one has shown the remotest interest in anything Mr Carey has ever said before.

This may well be true, but if so why was the paper publishing the bleeding piece in the first place? Yet another item for the agenda, I feel, for the next time we speak to tank-top-wearing Times managing editor George Brock

 In today's extract from Teresa Gorman's Maverick: A Mind of My Own (publishers most welcome), we learn of her first visit to No 10 in the early 1980s, when campaigning against VAT inspections. "Out of the blue, John Redwood invited me to tea in Downing Street and praised my pamphlet Worried to Death." Naturally, Teresa took a photographer along to record this meeting of minds. "I paused on the doorstep to face the camera and the crowd of spectators watching from across the street," she goes on. "'Who's that?' shouted someone. 'Shirley Williams,' came the reply. This was the first time I'd been recognised in public by strangers even though they mistook me for someone else," records Teresa, "and I was flattered." Mm.

 Exciting news from the front of New Labour's tireless fight for open government. The official web site - www.open.gov.uk - is to close on July 1.

webTitle: Labour drive to clean up local neighbourhoods

fields.headline: Labour drive to clean up local neighbourhoods
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today unveil a "real people's issues" initiative designed to clean up neighbourhoods by declaring war on graffiti, abandoned cars, fouled pavements, and offenders who perpetrate these crimes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today unveil a "real people's issues" initiative designed to clean up neighbourhoods by declaring war on graffiti, abandoned cars, fouled pavements, and offenders who perpetrate these crimes.

The prime minister is expected to announce a series of measures including requiring young offenders to provide personal reparation for damaging bus shelters, spraying walls with graffiti and similar crimes. At the same time the DVLA in Swansea will acquire stronger powers to impound and remove abandoned vehi cles. Mr Blair's package, to be unveiled in Croydon, south London, to community organisations trying to improve the quality of local life would provide an extra £50m for existing neighbourhood warden schemes and propose a £30m fund to create "home zones". These would allow councils to designate areas where pedestrians or cyclists are given priority over cars.

The initiative reflects what voters tell Labour's focus groups: that their physical environment affects their morale significantly. The package will also give local authorities new rights to retain revenues from litter, dog fouling and parking fines.

fields.headline: Labour underspends Tories
fields.trailText: Labour spent less on building and repairing the fabric of Britain's public infrastructure in each of its four years in power than the Conservatives spent in their final 12 months in office, the government admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour spent less on building and repairing the fabric of Britain's public infrastructure in each of its four years in power than the Conservatives spent in their final 12 months in office, the government admitted yesterday.

Despite a last-minute surge in spending by Whitehall departments, investment by Gordon Brown in transport, schools and hospitals amounted to just £4.3bn in the latest financial year, compared to £4.7bn when Kenneth Clarke was chancellor in the run-up to the 1997 election.

The spending figures - a legacy of Labour's hard-line approach to the public finances in its first two years in power - coincide with the heftiest surplus in the state finances on record, and will be seized upon by the opposition parties in the general election campaign next month.

The Conservatives have been running a campaign aimed at linking tax increases with the state of public services, while the Liberal Democrats will make higher investment in health and education the centrepiece of their strategy.

Figures released jointly by the Treasury and the office for national statistics yesterday showed that public sector net investment stood at £1,366m in March, the highest monthly figure for the 2000-01 financial year. The total for the year was the highest of Labour's four years in power, but fell well short of the chancellor's target of £7bn.

Mr Brown believes that the anti-spending culture among officials in government departments rather than a lack of funds is to blame for the failure to invest, and he will argue during the election campaign that investment will rise strongly in a second Labour term.

According to the government's three-year spending plan, capital investment will rise to £17.3bn by 2003-04, the highest since the mid-1970s, when the International Monetary Fund forced cuts on the Callaghan government during the sterling crisis.

However, Labour's opponents claim that the failure of Labour to deliver on its spending promises calls into question its ability to invest the sums allocated for the next three years.

Capital spending, taking into account depreciation, stood at £11bn in Mrs Thatcher's last full year in power, but fell sharply from the mid-1990s onwards. Under Labour, spending was £3.8bn in 1997-8, £4.1bn in 1998-9 and £3.5bn in 1999-2000.

During the past four years, spending on infrastructure has averaged less than 0.5% of gross domestic product each year, compared to more than 1% a year during the 1980s.

Yesterday's figures showed that high tax receipts and low spending resulted in a record budget surplus for the government of £16.5bn last year, up on the 1999-2000 surplus of £15.5bn, and £1.5bn higher than Mr Brown estimated in his Budget forecast as recently as early March.

During the past 12 months the Treasury has also secured £22.5bn from the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences, the proceeds of which will be used to pay off the national debt.

City analysts believe that slower growth and the belated increases in spending, which are now coming through, will dent the size of the surplus in the current financial year, but that it may still reach £10bn-£12bn.

fields.headline: English learn the Scottish way
fields.standfirst:
Higher public spending is persuading families to seek superior schooling and health care north of the border

Special report: Scottish parliament
fields.trailText: Higher public spending is persuading families to seek superior schooling and health care north of the border.
fields.body:
Every school day Morag Wood, her brother Craig and a clutch of other teenagers cross the old sandstone bridge over the Tweed for lessons in another country. For rural children, the trek from the family's Northumberland cottage to a school bus in the frontier town of Coldstream might seem unremarkable. But in educational terms, the gap is much wider than the deceptively narrow Anglo-Scottish boundary astride a salmon river.

Parents, like Richard and Carol Wood, are voting with their children's feet for a better education in a nation which boasts much higher public spending in almost every area, from schools to hospitals, roads to housing and - significantly, in the foot and mouth crisis - agriculture.

Strictly speaking, 14-year-old Morag and Craig, aged 17, from Moneylees, near Cornhill, live within the catchment area of Berwick upon Tweed community high school, ten miles to the east in England. "But if we had to send them there I would move back to Scotland," says Richard Wood, a farm stockman who was born north of the border. "They're at a fantastic place. The schooling is much better in Scotland - they put a much higher value on education there."

Berwickshire High, in the small town of Duns 12 miles north, might have a similar name to its English rival - but that's where the comparison ends. With more staff - now benefiting from a salary hike the envy of teachers in England - classes are much smaller, the exam curriculum is generally broader and, unlike its hard-pressed English equivalent, the Scottish school does not seem strapped for cash.

"The two systems are certainly different," says Ian Ross, depute rector of Berwickshire High, which has 750 pupils (including almost 20 from England) and 50 full-time staff. "We have certain advantages. Class sizes are regulated in subjects like science to a maximum of 20 and we are under 30 for non-practical subjects. Our rule of thumb is to keep classes to 25 if we can. I do not believe this exists south of the border." His average pupil-teacher ratio is 13.5.

At Berwick community high, which has 800 pupils and 47 full-time staff, head teacher Steve Quinlan looks despairingly northwards as he grapples with a school deficit of £140,000. "Our funding levels are appalling," he says and ponders an "official" ratio of over 22 pupils per teacher. "In reality it is more than 30."

While unhappy with the perception that schooling is better in Scotland, Mr Quinlan admits: "The most important thing is that parents think they are getting a higher quality education across the border whereas we have the capacity and everything pupils need and have a good record of getting them to university."

Conscience

A native of Kent, Mr Quinlan admires Scotland's political system since the creation of an Edinburgh parliament two years ago. "They have still got a social conscience and, to their credit, they have retained an ethos that social investment is as important as private investment...".

His worry, however, is that with big pay rises for Scottish teachers - a 24%, three-year package - his staff (six are Scots) will increasingly look over the border for work. Already he is finding it difficult to fill three vacancies in information technology, maths and learning support.

Fifty miles west at Lochinvar high school, in the Cumbrian border village of Longtown, it is a similar story. Scott Wylie, who teaches geography, RE and information technology, lives in Scotland but travels to England each day for work. He believes it will be difficult for English schools to hang on to staff, let alone recruit new teachers. "Every day as I travel to work I see Scotland doing things much better - from decent roads to handling the foot and mouth crisis more efficiently."

Politically, the nations of a union created almost 300 years ago are drawing apart. First the Scottish parliament parted company with Westminster by abolishing tuition fees for higher education. Then it decided to give old people free central heating installation while offering the prospect of free residential care. A big hike in teachers' pay followed, with Scotland's Department of Rural Affairs showing it was far more attuned to the foot and mouth crisis than its English equivalent. Increasingly, Anglo-Scottish divisions are widening, priorities diverging. And the people in England's border country are restless.

Like countless others in Northumber land and Cumbria, Mr Wood, who lives three miles inside England, looks north of the border for better public services.

Buoyed by new Treasury figures showing that public spending per head in Scotland is still almost a quarter above the English average, Mr Wood sees no reason to apologise for sending his two children to Berwickshire High. "Living right on the border, we seem to be a forgotten lot - roads are appalling, the health service is not that good, and everything seems to much better a mile or so north."

When he needed an operation last year, he opted for the ultra-modern Borders general hospital, at Melrose, rather than an inferior hospital in Northumberland. In any case, says Janet Wakenshaw, Scots-born editor of the Berwick Advertiser, the hospital in Berwick closes for X-rays after 5pm and at weekends. "If I broke my arm at night, or at the weekend, I would have to go elsewhere."

"Berwick is out on a limb," she adds. "We feel we won't get a fair deal from Westminster. Cross the border and you instantly see the difference."

The town certainly has an identity crisis; once a pawn in the power game between England and Scotland, it changed hands 13 times between 1147 and 1482. Now, while quite definitely English, it is trying to get a little more independence by becoming the first town outside London to hold a referendum on having an elected mayor. A poll, likely on June 7 will evoke memories of a 16th century mayor who presided over what Edward IV and Mary Queen of Scots declared to be a "free state" between the two countries.

Invidious

Some argue that the £25,000 cost of the exercise is a waste of money. But almost everyone believes the area gets a raw deal from the government.

Bill Ferguson, the Liberal Democrat who leads Berwick-upon-Tweed district council, estimates that the Scottish Borders Council, which serves the south east of Scotland two miles northwards, spends about £800 a year more on each of its people than Northumberland councils.

According to Alan Beith, MP for Berwick and deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, it is all down to an invidious Whitehall public spending formula which penalises Northumberland and - despite numerous protests - gives Scotland 23% more per head than the English average, according to latest Treasury figures.

Based on this, estimates by the Campaign for the English Regions (CFER), an increasingly vocal pressure group, show that the north-east of England alone would need an extra £1.1bn annually to catch up with Scotland.

For the moment the Wood family, and a handful of other English taxpayers locked into Scottish education, are happy. But when Craig, aged 17, goes to Aberdeen University later this year, they will face the reality of devolution. Unlike Scots students, he will have to fork out £1,000 in tuition fees as a resident of England. That explains why some Northumbrians, and Cumbrians, are at the point of rebellion - and why some Berwickers want to go it alone.
fields.bodyText: Every school day Morag Wood, her brother Craig and a clutch of other teenagers cross the old sandstone bridge over the Tweed for lessons in another country. For rural children, the trek from the family's Northumberland cottage to a school bus in the frontier town of Coldstream might seem unremarkable. But in educational terms, the gap is much wider than the deceptively narrow Anglo-Scottish boundary astride a salmon river. Parents, like Richard and Carol Wood, are voting with their children's feet for a better education in a nation which boasts much higher public spending in almost every area, from schools to hospitals, roads to housing and - significantly, in the foot and mouth crisis - agriculture. Strictly speaking, 14-year-old Morag and Craig, aged 17, from Moneylees, near Cornhill, live within the catchment area of Berwick upon Tweed community high school, ten miles to the east in England. "But if we had to send them there I would move back to Scotland," says Richard Wood, a farm stockman who was born north of the border. "They're at a fantastic place. The schooling is much better in Scotland - they put a much higher value on education there." Berwickshire High, in the small town of Duns 12 miles north, might have a similar name to its English rival - but that's where the comparison ends. With more staff - now benefiting from a salary hike the envy of teachers in England - classes are much smaller, the exam curriculum is generally broader and, unlike its hard-pressed English equivalent, the Scottish school does not seem strapped for cash. "The two systems are certainly different," says Ian Ross, depute rector of Berwickshire High, which has 750 pupils (including almost 20 from England) and 50 full-time staff. "We have certain advantages. Class sizes are regulated in subjects like science to a maximum of 20 and we are under 30 for non-practical subjects. Our rule of thumb is to keep classes to 25 if we can. I do not believe this exists south of the border." His average pupil-teacher ratio is 13.5. At Berwick community high, which has 800 pupils and 47 full-time staff, head teacher Steve Quinlan looks despairingly northwards as he grapples with a school deficit of £140,000. "Our funding levels are appalling," he says and ponders an "official" ratio of over 22 pupils per teacher. "In reality it is more than 30." While unhappy with the perception that schooling is better in Scotland, Mr Quinlan admits: "The most important thing is that parents think they are getting a higher quality education across the border whereas we have the capacity and everything pupils need and have a good record of getting them to university." Conscience A native of Kent, Mr Quinlan admires Scotland's political system since the creation of an Edinburgh parliament two years ago. "They have still got a social conscience and, to their credit, they have retained an ethos that social investment is as important as private investment...". His worry, however, is that with big pay rises for Scottish teachers - a 24%, three-year package - his staff (six are Scots) will increasingly look over the border for work. Already he is finding it difficult to fill three vacancies in information technology, maths and learning support. Fifty miles west at Lochinvar high school, in the Cumbrian border village of Longtown, it is a similar story. Politically, the nations of a union created almost 300 years ago are drawing apart. First the Scottish parliament parted company with Westminster by abolishing tuition fees for higher education. Then it decided to give old people free central heating installation while offering the prospect of free residential care. Increasingly, Anglo-Scottish divisions are widening, priorities diverging. And the people in England's border country are restless. Like countless others in Northumber land and Cumbria, Mr Wood, who lives three miles inside England, looks north of the border for better public services. Buoyed by new Treasury figures showing that public spending per head in Scotland is still almost a quarter above the English average, Mr Wood sees no reason to apologise for sending his two children to Berwickshire High. webTitle: Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe

fields.headline: Scots and Welsh face subsidy axe
fields.standfirst:
Funding said to be unfair to English regions

Special report: Scottish parliament
Special report: Welsh assembly
fields.trailText: Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are poised to lose their privileged status as the big spenders of the UK. Ministers are preparing for a post-election battle with the three devolved administrations by unstitching the complex Whitehall formula which guarantees them much higher levels of public spending than the English regions.
fields.body:
Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are poised to lose their privileged status as the big spenders of the UK. Ministers are preparing for a post-election battle with the three devolved administrations by unstitching the complex Whitehall formula which guarantees them much higher levels of public spending than the English regions.

The move comes amid mounting criticism from regional lobby groups, backbench MPs and senior English ministers that the current method of distributing resources discriminates against the poorest parts of England, where unemployment is high and manufacturing is steadily declining.

New Treasury figures show that attempts to narrow the public-spending gap between England and the remainder of the UK under New Labour have failed: Public spending in Scotland remains 23% above the English average, while Northern Ireland and Wales are 39% and 18% above, respectively.

Senior ministers are alarmed because, for the first time, the figures make direct and unflattering comparisons with the English regions.

Yorkshire and Humber, which roughly reflects Scotland's 5m population, would need an additional £5.2bn annually to match the spending levels north of the border. The north-east would need more than £1bn and the south-east more than £12bn due to its larger population.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has signalled that a review of local government finance, promised soon after the election, will include a detailed examination of funding throughout the UK.

Warning of "blood on the carpet" because the exercise will produce losers as well as gainers, he says the government should "bite the bullet" before the summer and finally address an issue which has been dodged for years amid fears of a tartan backlash.

"This will have to be done quickly because it's not the sort of row you want in the [next] election period," he told The Guardian. "We need to get a timetable for it to be settled as quickly as we can."

While careful to stress that direct comparisons between the nations and regions of the UK can be invidious, Mr Prescott insisted that the complex funding formula is certainly not "written in stone".

He said New Labour only in tended for the so-called Barnett formula to apply for the current parliament.

"No government can guarantee beyond that," he said.

The formula was devised by Lord (Joel) Barnett while Treasury chief secretary during the mid-70s. At the time, Scotland was poorer than many parts of Britain, although its level of wealth is now considerably higher than many English regions.

Lord Barnett now says it has outlived its usefulness and discriminates against England.

Mr Prescott predicted "one hell of a debate" as the government moved to examine spending throughout the town halls, regions and nations of the UK.

With a string of ministers pressing Downing Street to answer the English question by moving to create elected re gional assemblies where there is demand, the deputy prime minister said it was time to consider new financial structures.

He wants the prime minister, Tony Blair, to include plans for regional referendums to test the mood for elected assemblies in the first Queen's Speech of the next parliament.

Stressing that English regionalism should form the centrepiece of constitutional reform in Labour's second term, he said: "I don't think it will be at all credible not to have referendums in the next parliament."

He said that the government had no plans to abolish county councils to make way for regional assemblies. They would be purely strategic bodies overseeing planning, transport and housing, while supervising eight regional development agencies, business-led quangoes.

"The argument before has been that Whitehall always delivers best and knows best, but regions are now looking to London and saying 'maybe we can do things a bit better'," he said. "I think the regions would make for better government and make decisions more likely to work instead of blaming central government for getting it wrong all the time... they could challenge central government where necessary."

webTitle: Leader: NHS reform falters Ministers must let go of the reins

fields.headline: NHS reform falters Ministers must let go of the reins
fields.trailText: How did the euphoria evaporate? Just nine months ago the atmosphere of hope and expectation in the NHS was unprecedented. All sides - medics, managers and nurses - had signed up to a 10-year health plan that promised the biggest step forward since the NHS was set up.
fields.body:
How did the euphoria evaporate? Just nine months ago the atmosphere of hope and expectation in the NHS was unprecedented. All sides - medics, managers and nurses - had signed up to a 10-year health plan that promised the biggest step forward since the NHS was set up. It followed the biggest increase in NHS funding in history - a one third rise in real terms over five years. Nine months on there is bitterness, doubt and open disputes. GPs are threatening a mass resignation - in a ballot which will report just before the election - and even an unofficial disruption of services on May l. Hospital consultants are still resisting their new contract. This is not how Downing Street planned the run-up to the election. The PM will not be pleased.

How did things go so badly wrong? It is a complex picture. GPs are unhappy with the 2,000 increase to their ranks compared with 7,000 extra consultants. They are even more hurt by the huge pay hike conceded to consultants. The British Medical Association is under attack from three competing doctor journals, each trying to outbid the other in criticism of the BMA's leadership. One of the freebies is even sponsoring next month's day of protest. The teachers have shown that public service militancy can work. There is BMA anxiety about losing its exclusive negotiating rights in a new system of local deals.

But there are more fundamental developments reflecting the enormous pressure on public services. Ministers have rightly signalled a wish to modernise the health service, but have been reluctant to lift their foot from the accelerator to change direction for fear of missing their intimidating list of performance targets - some 150 or more. Local managers as well as medics complain about the treadmill they feel they are on as extra work piles up and the redesign of the NHS is delayed.

This is not the only sin of Alan Milburn. No one worked harder to put the 10-year plan together. The health secretary demonstrated phenomenal energy and admirable single-mindedness. But once signed, he took his eye off the ball. Winter was approaching. The key priority became ensuring that there was no scandal about patients on trolleys or turned away by accident and emergency departments. Yet the two separate industrial disputes (GPs and consultants) always had the potential to erode the goodwill generated by the plan. They should have been resolved earlier.

There are two inter-related structural problems, which have also led to the current malaise. First, the minister gets far too involved in the detail. The NHS is far too big for any minister, let alone one with limited management experience, to try and run it. Second, merging the roles of NHS chief executive and Health Department permanent secretary has been a mistake. The NHS has a mandarin running it, not a manager. NHS staff need someone to lead for them. There is an unhealthy vacuum at the top.

Mr Milburn is due to outline his vision of Labour's second term tomorrow at the launch of the modernisation agency. Here is a chance to make amends. Labour promised no return to command and control but has introduced the most centralised system since the NHS was launched. Mr Milburn is mistaken in believing power lies at the centre. His plan will only work with the support of the staff. They need to have a sense of ownership. Having set out Labour's vision, it is time to concede discretion to the field. This is the only way to generate the energy that the radical reform needs.

fields.headline: Brown warns US of markets 'instability'
fields.trailText: The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today warn Europe and the US not to "retreat into protectionism" in the face of growing economic uncertainty around the world as the US economy rapidly slows down.
fields.body:
The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will today warn Europe and the US not to "retreat into protectionism" in the face of growing economic uncertainty around the world as the US economy rapidly slows down.

Adopting a more cautious tone than has been evident in his optimistic predictions of recent months, Mr Brown's coded warning that what he called "the current instability in the financial and commodity markets" could turn into a hard landing for the American economy - taking the rest of the world with it - reflects the message which he delivered to the EU finance ministers meeting in Malmo, Sweden last weekend.

"We know that in today's world of instantaneous global markets, risk and instability anywhere have repercussions everywhere," the chancellor will admit at the annual meeting of the European bank for reconstruction and development in the City of London.

"At a time of slowing world economic growth, the answer to the current instability is not to retreat into protectionism, not to surrender the benefits of greater openness, increased trade and economic reform. Rather the way forward is greater and enhanced cooperation, with each and every country working together to maximize the benefits of global markets." However, Mr Brown is still insisting that the British economy will weather any US downturn, as well as the domestic foot and mouth crisis.

In an interview in today's Times the chancellor said it would be "entirely the wrong time and the wrong reason to move from the long-term reforms we are making in Britain and our public spending commitments". Because the government had been cautious in its spending plans, it was also "well placed to cope with issues such as foot and mouth", he said.

But even before its delivery today Mr Brown's City speech prompted Conservative claims of a "deeply humiliating climbdown". Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, declared that Mr Brown could no longer afford the £60bn worth of extra spending he has promised because it lifted spending above the underlying rate of growth in the economy.

Mr Portillo said: "The chancellor thought he had abolished the economic cycle and has set out plans for the future on that basis. Now it appears that his complacency is finally being shaken.

"This is a deeply humiliating climbdown for Gordon Brown. The UK is very much part of an uncertain global economy which means for government spending to be sustainable it should be affordable in good times and bad."

Labour seizes on EU trade ties
Nicholas Watt

The government will today intensify its assault on the Tory stance on Europe by seizing on new figures showing that Britain's exports to Europe are overwhelmingly outstripping sales to North America.

Peter Hain, the Europe business minister, will say the figures highlight the "folly" of Tory demands to weaken links with the EU by signing up to the North America free trade area.

The figures will show that more than 60% of British exports are destined for the EU, compared to less than 20% to North America. In traditional manufacturing areas the gap is even greater, with exports to Europe at 10 times the rate of exports to the US.

fields.headline: US slowdown hurts British exports
fields.trailText: The first signs of the American slowdown affecting the British economy emerged yesterday as government figures showed a drop of more than 15% in exports to the US.
fields.body:
The first signs of the American slowdown affecting the British economy emerged yesterday as government figures showed a drop of more than 15% in exports to the US.

Sales of UK products to the US fell from £2.903bn in February to £2.368bn in March, leading to a rise in Britain's trade deficit with countries outside the European Union.

Although officials believe that some of the deterioration may be due to one-off factors, economists said the data for exports marked a significant development, which would add to the problems caused by the foot and mouth crisis. "This is the first concrete confirmation that the US slowdown is hitting UK trade performance", said Daniel Kaye of Capital Economics.

He added that exports to non-EU nations had fallen by their largest amount since the start of the 1998 financial crisis, and that all of the decline was accounted for by the US. The office for national statistics said that exports to non-EU countries fell from £7.4bn to £6.8bn in March, with imports remaining unchanged at £9.4bn. The deficit of £2.6bn was the highest since last December's £2.8bn, and provided early evidence of the impact of the foot and mouth epidemic. Officials said exports of £20m in live animals, meat and dairy products were lost and imports rose a similar amount.

Measured by volume, which strips out the impact of changes in prices and currency movements, exports of goods excluding oil and those products with irregular trading patterns such as aircraft and precious stones fell 10% in March.

The news on exports to the US offset an improvement in the overall trade deficit for February. The deficit in goods narrowed from £2.6bn to £2.3bn, with an estimated £800m surplus in services leaving an overall deficit of £1.5bn.

fields.headline: Cherie's got room up top
fields.trailText: Ever fancied sleeping on top of Cherie Booth? - well, now Guardian Unlimited can present you with a once in a lifetime opportunity.
fields.body:
Ever fancied sleeping on top of Cherie Booth? - well, now Guardian Unlimited can present you with a once in a lifetime opportunity.

Two flats on the floor above Ms Booth QC's chambers, the oh-so-trendy human rights outfit Matrix, have just gone on the market. The two-bed flat on the floor above the first lady's chambers, on the corner of Gray's Inn Road and Theobold's Road in Clerkenwell, is going for £450 a week. Unfurnished.

Or for the Bridget Jones' out there, a one bed flat, unfurnished, for a more modest £327 per week.

It is the first time the owners, the honourable society of Gray's Inn, have deigned to let property on the open market. Matrix's offices are, in fact, themselves housed in a converted former police station.

A car parking space is also available for £2,500 a year.

And possible tenants can sleep soundly at night - estate agents Farebrother admit: "Security is very high because there's a er barristers' chambers below."

Matrix's offices are, in fact, themselves housed in a converted former police station. A car parking space is also available for £2,500 a year. And possible tenants can sleep soundly at night - estate agents Farebrother admit: "Security is very high because there's a er barristers' chambers below." fields.headline: Labour underspends Tories
fields.trailText: Labour spent less on building and repairing the fabric of Britain's public infrastructure in each of its four years in power than the Conservatives spent in their final 12 months in office, the government admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour spent less on building and repairing the fabric of Britain's public infrastructure in each of its four years in power than the Conservatives spent in their final 12 months in office, the government admitted yesterday.

Despite a last-minute surge in spending by Whitehall departments, investment by Gordon Brown in transport, schools and hospitals amounted to just £4.3bn in the latest financial year, compared to £4.7bn when Kenneth Clarke was chancellor in the run-up to the 1997 election.

The spending figures - a legacy of Labour's hard-line approach to the public finances in its first two years in power - coincide with the heftiest surplus in the state finances on record, and will be seized upon by the opposition parties in the general election campaign next month.

The Conservatives have been running a campaign aimed at linking tax increases with the state of public services, while the Liberal Democrats will make higher investment in health and education the centrepiece of their strategy.

Figures released jointly by the Treasury and the office for national statistics yesterday showed that public sector net investment stood at £1,366m in March, the highest monthly figure for the 2000-01 financial year. The total for the year was the highest of Labour's four years in power, but fell well short of the chancellor's target of £7bn.

Mr Brown believes that the anti-spending culture among officials in government departments rather than a lack of funds is to blame for the failure to invest, and he will argue during the election campaign that investment will rise strongly in a second Labour term.

According to the government's three-year spending plan, capital investment will rise to £17.3bn by 2003-04, the highest since the mid-1970s, when the International Monetary Fund forced cuts on the Callaghan government during the sterling crisis.

However, Labour's opponents claim that the failure of Labour to deliver on its spending promises calls into question its ability to invest the sums allocated for the next three years.

Capital spending, taking into account depreciation, stood at £11bn in Mrs Thatcher's last full year in power, but fell sharply from the mid-1990s onwards. Under Labour, spending was £3.8bn in 1997-8, £4.1bn in 1998-9 and £3.5bn in 1999-2000.

During the past four years, spending on infrastructure has averaged less than 0.5% of gross domestic product each year, compared to more than 1% a year during the 1980s.

Yesterday's figures showed that high tax receipts and low spending resulted in a record budget surplus for the government of £16.5bn last year, up on the 1999-2000 surplus of £15.5bn, and £1.5bn higher than Mr Brown estimated in his Budget forecast as recently as early March.

During the past 12 months the Treasury has also secured £22.5bn from the auction of third-generation mobile phone licences, the proceeds of which will be used to pay off the national debt.

City analysts believe that slower growth and the belated increases in spending, which are now coming through, will dent the size of the surplus in the current financial year, but that it may still reach £10bn-£12bn.

fields.headline: Bright Station looks at break-up
fields.trailText: Outspoken entrepreneur Dan Wagner is understood to be exploring the possibility of breaking up his Bright Station technology business. by John Cassy.
fields.body:
Outspoken entrepreneur Dan Wagner is understood to be exploring the possibility of breaking up his Bright Station technology business in a move that would lead to him taking a step back from the public company arena.

Mr Wagner, Bright Station's chief executive and a 10% shareholder, is thought to be working on a plan that would see non-core businesses sold or closed and its knowledge management software division, Smartlogik, emerge as the focus of the new business.

Smartlogik would run by its chief executive, Steve Hill - one of the founders of highly regarded US software firm Inktomi - and former National Grid chairman David Jefferies.

Mr Wagner, who has endured a difficult relationship with the City, is then expected to quit as a director of the public company after many years of arguing that it is undervalued. Shares in Bright Station are trading close to a record low of 17p after having touched 220p a year ago.

Mr Wagner might also use his resignation as an opportunity to make an offer to take private the non-core Bright Station businesses that he believes have long been undervalued by investors.

Those include Sparza, an infrastructure business built around technology bought from collapsed e-tailer Boo.com and the remains of Bright Station's previous incarnation, Dialog.

Smartlogik is seen as the firm's brightest prospect and had been lined up for a stock market flotation of its own in the early part of this year. However, market conditions turned against Bright Station, leaving the company with a dilemma on how best to extract value and visibility from it.

Selling off Bright Station's other assets, leaving Smartlogik as a pure-play technology firm, would make it easier for analysts to value. Mr Wagner believes it could one day be as big as Autonomy, Britain's largest listed knowledge management firm.

At the end of the year to December, Bright Station had about £16m in the bank which the company says is enough to take it through to profitability. However, that cash would have to be spread across several different divisions and technologies, preventing star performers like Smartlogik from securing the investment that some insiders believe they need to allow them to fulfil their potential.

Mr Wagner has struggled to win the City over ever since Dialog saddled itself with massive debts after buying the database arm of US newspaper group Knight Ridder. The firm was nicknamed "Dial-a-dog" and Mr Wagner was slated in the press.

A spokesman for Bright Station last night refused to comment.

webTitle: Blair urges businesses to take prime role in regeneration

fields.headline: Blair urges businesses to take prime role in regeneration
fields.trailText: The prime minister, Tony Blair, is today expected to swing the government behind a radical US-style regeneration scheme that will give the private sector a greater role in improving run-down towns and cities.
fields.body:
The prime minister, Tony Blair, is today expected to swing the government behind a radical US-style regeneration scheme that will give the private sector a greater role in improving run-down towns and cities.

The business improvement district scheme (Bids) is a new attempt by ministers to harness private sector money and expertise to work aimed at turning around run-down areas.

Whitehall insiders say that private sector firms will be asked to vote on a package of specific improvements to their local area, such as new CCTV cameras or extra police officers. The council would then levy a charge on businesses to pay for the improvements.

The policy was mooted in last year's local government finance green paper, in which ministers suggested creating Bids along three models. These included funding the improvement district through a supplementary business rate levied on some parts of an authority area, rather than all.

Bids already exist on a voluntary basis, but the prime minister is set to promise legislation to give the arrangements a statutory basis as part of a major regeneration speech today.

Local Government Association (LGA) policy officer Tony Rich said: "We'd be in favour of more long-term funding for town improvement and town centre management. If this offers a way of doing that, it's a good thing."

The proposals appear to be a partial repackaging of the government's plan to hand councils wider powers to levy a supplementary business rate, worth up to an extra 5%.

Ministers appear to have dropped those plans in favour of Bids under strong pressue from the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), which believes the supplementary rate would have cost business some £750m.

CBI chief Digby Jones said earlier this year that he backed moves to improve relationships between business and local government, but added: "The government needs to recognise that bureaucracy and compulsion are not typical characteristics of successful partnerships."

The CBI was unavailable for comment on whether it felt Bids would be more acceptable.

Bids have been extremely successful in the United States, where they have helped to revitalise areas such as New York's Grand Central Station and Times Square.

In US cities, however, the scheme is essentially corporate-led, with businesses generating their own proposals, which often involve cosmetic improvements, such as cleaning up graffiti, or security improvements.

It is not yet clear to what extent business will lead UK schemes.

There are 130 Bids in New York alone, and more than 1,000 across the US.
