fields.headline: English learn the Scottish way
fields.trailText: Higher public spending is persuading families to seek superior schooling and health care north of the border, writes Peter Hetherington
fields.body:
Every school day Morag Wood, her brother Craig and a clutch of other teenagers cross the old sandstone bridge over the Tweed for lessons in another country. For rural children, the trek from the family's Northumberland cottage to a school bus in the frontier town of Coldstream might seem unremarkable. But in educational terms, the gap is much wider than the deceptively narrow Anglo-Scottish boundary astride a salmon river.

Parents, like Richard and Carol Wood, are voting with their children's feet for a better education in a nation which boasts much higher public spending in almost every area, from schools to hospitals, roads to housing and - significantly, in the foot and mouth crisis - agriculture.

Strictly speaking, 14-year-old Morag and Craig, aged 17, from Moneylees, near Cornhill, live within the catchment area of Berwick upon Tweed community high school, ten miles to the east in England. "But if we had to send them there I would move back to Scotland," says Richard Wood, a farm stockman who was born north of the border. "They're at a fantastic place. The schooling is much better in Scotland - they put a much higher value on education there."

Berwickshire High, in the small town of Duns 12 miles north, might have a similar name to its English rival - but that's where the comparison ends. With more staff - now benefiting from a salary hike the envy of teachers in England - classes are much smaller, the exam curriculum is generally broader and, unlike its hard-pressed English equivalent, the Scottish school does not seem strapped for cash.

"The two systems are certainly different," says Ian Ross, depute rector of Berwickshire High, which has 750 pupils (including almost 20 from England) and 50 full-time staff. "We have certain advantages. Class sizes are regulated in subjects like science to a maximum of 20 and we are under 30 for non-practical subjects. Our rule of thumb is to keep classes to 25 if we can. I do not believe this exists south of the border." His average pupil-teacher ratio is 13.5.

At Berwick community high, which has 800 pupils and 47 full-time staff, head teacher Steve Quinlan looks despairingly northwards as he grapples with a school deficit of £140,000. "Our funding levels are appalling," he says and ponders an "official" ratio of over 22 pupils per teacher. "In reality it is more than 30."

While unhappy with the perception that schooling is better in Scotland, Mr Quinlan admits: "The most important thing is that parents think they are getting a higher quality education across the border whereas we have the capacity and everything pupils need and have a good record of getting them to university."

Conscience

A native of Kent, Mr Quinlan admires Scotland's political system since the creation of an Edinburgh parliament two years ago. "They have still got a social conscience and, to their credit, they have retained an ethos that social investment is as important as private investment...".

His worry, however, is that with big pay rises for Scottish teachers - a 24%, three-year package - his staff (six are Scots) will increasingly look over the border for work. Already he is finding it difficult to fill three vacancies in information technology, maths and learning support.

Fifty miles west at Lochinvar high school, in the Cumbrian border village of Longtown, it is a similar story. Scott Wylie, who teaches geography, RE and information technology, lives in Scotland but travels to England each day for work. He believes it will be difficult for English schools to hang on to staff, let alone recruit new teachers. "Every day as I travel to work I see Scotland doing things much better - from decent roads to handling the foot and mouth crisis more efficiently."

Politically, the nations of a union created almost 300 years ago are drawing apart. First the Scottish parliament parted company with Westminster by abolishing tuition fees for higher education. Then it decided to give old people free central heating installation while offering the prospect of free residential care. A big hike in teachers' pay followed, with Scotland's Department of Rural Affairs showing it was far more attuned to the foot and mouth crisis than its English equivalent. Increasingly, Anglo-Scottish divisions are widening, priorities diverging. And the people in England's border country are restless.

Like countless others in Northumber land and Cumbria, Mr Wood, who lives three miles inside England, looks north of the border for better public services.

Buoyed by new Treasury figures showing that public spending per head in Scotland is still almost a quarter above the English average, Mr Wood sees no reason to apologise for sending his two children to Berwickshire High. "Living right on the border, we seem to be a forgotten lot - roads are appalling, the health service is not that good, and everything seems to much better a mile or so north."

When he needed an operation last year, he opted for the ultra-modern Borders general hospital, at Melrose, rather than an inferior hospital in Northumberland. In any case, says Janet Wakenshaw, Scots-born editor of the Berwick Advertiser, the hospital in Berwick closes for X-rays after 5pm and at weekends. "If I broke my arm at night, or at the weekend, I would have to go elsewhere."

"Berwick is out on a limb," she adds. "We feel we won't get a fair deal from Westminster. Cross the border and you instantly see the difference."

The town certainly has an identity crisis; once a pawn in the power game between England and Scotland, it changed hands 13 times between 1147 and 1482. Now, while quite definitely English, it is trying to get a little more independence by becoming the first town outside London to hold a referendum on having an elected mayor. A poll, likely on June 7 will evoke memories of a 16th century mayor who presided over what Edward IV and Mary Queen of Scots declared to be a "free state" between the two countries.

Invidious

Some argue that the £25,000 cost of the exercise is a waste of money. But almost everyone believes the area gets a raw deal from the government.

Bill Ferguson, the Liberal Democrat who leads Berwick-upon-Tweed district council, estimates that the Scottish Borders Council, which serves the south east of Scotland two miles northwards, spends about £800 a year more on each of its people than Northumberland councils.

According to Alan Beith, MP for Berwick and deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, it is all down to an invidious Whitehall public spending formula which penalises Northumberland and - despite numerous protests - gives Scotland 23% more per head than the English average, according to latest Treasury figures.

Based on this, estimates by the Campaign for the English Regions (CFER), an increasingly vocal pressure group, show that the north-east of England alone would need an extra £1.1bn annually to catch up with Scotland.

For the moment the Wood family, and a handful of other English taxpayers locked into Scottish education, are happy. But when Craig, aged 17, goes to Aberdeen University later this year, they will face the reality of devolution. Unlike Scots students, he will have to fork out £1,000 in tuition fees as a resident of England. That explains why some Northumbrians, and Cumbrians, are at the point of rebellion - and why some Berwickers want to go it alone.

webTitle: O'Reilly and Soros join Eircom race

fields.headline: O'Reilly and Soros join Eircom race
fields.standfirst:
Three of Ireland's top tycoons in telecoms takeover battle

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Tony O'Reilly yesterday confirmed his interest in bidding for Eircom, heralding a struggle for control of Ireland's telecoms company by three of the nation's richest businessmen. by David Teather.
fields.body:
Tony O'Reilly, the newspaper magnate, yesterday confirmed his interest in bidding for Eircom, heralding a struggle for control of Ireland's former state-run telecoms company by three of the nation's richest businessmen.

Mr O'Reilly, chairman of the Independent News & Media group, is leading a consortium which includes the financier, George Soros.

In early April, Eircom confirmed that it had attracted two potential offers, from Denis O'Brien's eIsland vehicle and a consortium led by Dermot Desmond.

The bids could mark the beginning of a wave of takeovers in the telecoms sector as share prices continue to slide, providing potential bargains for buyers.

The consortium led by Mr O'Reilly, as non-executive chairman, is made up of Providence Equity partners, Soros Private Equity, Goldman Sachs and Warburg Pincus. Mr O'Reilly will also make a personal investment in the bid while Goldman Sachs is also acting as an adviser.

Mr O'Reilly said: "This consortium brings the right blend of telecommunications expertise, Irish management experience and financial muscle to deliver an attractive offer to Eircom shareholders. We believe that a strong, developed and efficient telecoms infra structure is critical to ireland's competitive position and attraction as a business location."

The consortium is believed to be considering an offer of about €2.7bn (£1.7bn), compared with the €2.4bn offer eIsland is reported to have made. Eircom declined to comment although it is reported to look more sympathetically onMr O'Reilly's bid.

His consortium said discussions with Eircom management were at an early stage.

All three offers are conditional on the sale of Eircom's mobile phone division, Eircell, to Vodafone for about £2.1bn. Shareholders meet to approve the sale next month.

Mr O'Reilly, 64 and holder of an honorary British knight hood, is reportedly worth £1.2bn. He ranked as Ireland's second-richest man in this year's Sunday Times rich list. Mr Desmond, 50, was fourth with £466m and Mr O'Brien, 42, ninth with £261m.

Telia and KPN, the Swedish and Dutch telecoms firms, which together own 35% of Eircom through holding company Comsource, have said they are keen to sell.

A buyer would need to convince Eircom's employees who hold 15% of the shares. Another 30% is held by institutional shareholders and 20% by retail investors who bought shares when the business was floated in 1999.

Eircom shares climbed almost 4% yesterday to €2.69.

The consortium led by Mr O'Reilly, as non-executive chairman, is made up of Providence Equity partners, Soros Private Equity, Goldman Sachs and Warburg Pincus. Mr O'Reilly will also make a personal investment in the bid while Goldman Sachs is also acting as an adviser. Mr O'Reilly said: "This consortium brings the right blend of telecommunications expertise, Irish management experience and financial muscle to deliver an attractive offer to Eircom shareholders. We believe that a strong, developed and efficient telecoms infra structure is critical to ireland's competitive position and attraction as a business location." The consortium is believed to be considering an offer of about €2.7bn (£1.7bn), compared with the €2.4bn offer eIsland is reported to have made. Eircom declined to comment although it is reported to look more sympathetically onMr O'Reilly's bid. His consortium said discussions with Eircom management were at an early stage. All three offers are conditional on the sale of Eircom's mobile phone division, Eircell, to Vodafone for about £2.1bn. Shareholders meet to approve the sale next month. Mr O'Reilly, 64 and holder of an honorary British knight hood, is reportedly worth £1.2bn. He ranked as Ireland's second-richest man in this year's Sunday Times rich list. Mr Desmond, 50, was fourth with £466m and Mr O'Brien, 42, ninth with £261m. Telia and KPN, the Swedish and Dutch telecoms firms, which together own 35% of Eircom through holding company Comsource, have said they are keen to sell. A buyer would need to convince Eircom's employees who hold 15% of the shares. Another 30% is held by institutional shareholders and 20% by retail investors who bought shares when the business was floated in 1999. Eircom shares climbed almost 4% yesterday to €2.69.

fields.headline: Survival of the shrillest
fields.standfirst: Graham Lancaster founded one of the leading PR consultancies, Biss Lancaster, and next year will become chairman of the Public Relations Consultants Association. Today he joins MediaGuardian.co.uk with a monthly column on the PR industry
fields.trailText: April 24: In the run-up to an election is becomes increasingly hard to grab the media's attention, writes Graham Lancaster.
fields.body:
Charles Darwin would not have made a good public relations consultant. Just look at his advice for the survival and evolution of most species. Cryptic colouration. Survival by blending in with your surroundings. Keeping your head down. Being grey so the predators don't notice you.

This may still be good advice for your career. Unthreatening corporate toadies and compliant nodding dogs often do well in cultures of fear when reporting to bullies. But it certainly doesn't work in PR.

As we hurtle towards a general election, the silly season will come early and Darwinian theory will be rewritten as what I call "survival of the shrillest". Or, at its worst, "origin of the specious".

To be noticed by the media, let alone to be quoted, requires something truly new, fresh and interesting - or something very shrill.

This latter point is especially true of political debate.

The row over the Commission for Racial Equality's pledge rumbles on, pushing aside foot and mouth, China and the Middle East.

The story isn't feeding off the many balanced and sensible responses but off the few shrill, accusatory and indignant voices on both sides of the argument.

Any politician making a thoughtful weekend speech on this, or any issue of national or local importance, will find it difficult to be reported without eliciting some spicy prose.

A shrill soundbite may come back to haunt them and maybe their party and it would almost certainly hijack any thought and hard work the politician put into the rest of the speech.

In the run-up to an election it also becomes harder for a commercial business to get noticed. Certainly any profit warnings or redundancy announcements will be turned into political capital. There's never a problem attracting coverage for bad news but how do you win space for positive stories and points of view?

If you have some real, innovative news, the media will pick up on it if it is presented professionally.

For example, we have just helped launch a genuinely ground-breaking product, Airogym, invented by a former BA pilot to combat the risk of developing deep vein thrombosis on long-haul flights.

The media attended in high numbers and we achieved very positive coverage in most national newspapers, the regional media, worldwide TV and radio. This generated a flood of sales and business leads.

What we call data-driven PR is also very effective. We have also just helped launch What Car? magazine's Target Price, a consumer guide to the achievable discounts people can expect to make on new cars.

Again, this achieved widespread media coverage on a busy news day.

Steve Fowler, the editor of What Car? said: "We've been inundated with requests for further details of our Target Price and we expect to see a boost in magazine circulation - all for a fraction of the cost of a major advertising campaign."

What then about being shrill and the "origin of the specious"?

Can or should the business community follow politicians down that slippery route?

My answer is the PR industry is a broad church but we should never be ecumenical with the truth.

Graham Lancaster is the founder of PR consultancy Biss Lancaster.

fields.headline: Today stages Milosevic 'trial'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The BBC's Today programme is staging a mock trial for former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Today programme is staging a mock trial for the former president of the Yugoslav republic, Slobodan Milosevic, to establish whether or not it would be possible to prosecute him for war crimes.

The case will ask whether Mr Milosevic would have a case to answer in a prosecution by the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

In an unprecedented reconstruction based on prime facie evidence, the Today production team are to set up a mock trial that will be held at the Inns of Court School of Law.

The trial will begin at 6.40am on Wednesday morning, and a "verdict" is expected to by 8.40am.

The trial will feature Geoffrey Robinson QC for the prosecution, and Anthony Scrivener QC for the defence, and the "judges" will be three legal experts; Inns of Court School of Law lecturer Robert McPeake, Professor Colin Warbrick from Durham University and Professor Geoff Gilbert from the University of Essex.

Lawyers will call two "witnesses" from either side; for the prosecution will be a Kosovar Albanian who witnessed the shooting of his brother and the Guardian journalist, Maggie O'Kane.

The defence will call Marko Gasic, a representative for the Serbian Information Centre, and Branislav Ifkovic, the vice-president of the Socialist Party of Serbia and a close friend of Mr Milosevic.

Mr Milosevic is under arrest in Belgrade, awaiting trial for corruption and possible additional charges of ordering political assassinations.

He is also wanted by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia for alleged atrocities in Kosovo.

fields.headline: Channel 4 drops Right to Reply
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Channel 4's commitment to public service broadcasting was questioned yesterday when it axed the influential viewers' forum Right to Reply after almost 20 years.
fields.body:
Channel 4's commitment to public service broadcasting was questioned yesterday when it axed the influential viewers' forum Right to Reply after almost 20 years.

Roger Bolton, who has presented the programme for the past six years, said viewers had been deprived of an important forum. "There is now an accountability gap at Channel 4 and on British television," he said.

Channel 4 - which, along with the other main commercial broadcasters, published its first "statement of commitment to viewers" yesterday - said there was now more opportunity for interaction through its website.

But Mr Bolton rejected the view. In a measured but critical article for MediaGuardian.co.uk, he suggested that commercial pressures had forced Channel 4's hand. "In the increasingly multichannel world, the competition for ratings is such that only a handful of half-hour slots given to the viewer is too much even for a channel which claims a special relationship with its public."

He rejected the channel's argument that viewers could make their feelings known online. The medium enabled broadcasters to answer questions "away from the glare of the lights and with advisers clustered around the word processor".

Jocelyn Hay, chairman of Voice of the Listener and Viewer, deplored the decision. "I think that Right to Reply was incredibly important. It pioneered the feeling of accountability and provided one of the very few opportunities for ordinary viewers to challenge programme makers. It broke new ground, breaking down the arrogance of the 'producer knows best' attitude that existed before."

Norman Baker, broadcasting spokesman for the Liberal Democrats, rejected the argument that viewers could express their opinions online: "That tends to exclude those who don't have access to that medium."

With Right to Reply, the only programme made by Channel 4 rather than commissioned from outside, viewers could put their views direct to programme makers for the first time. It pioneered the "video box" for viewers who were outside London. It also gave viewers the opportunity to complain about programmes on any channel - the BBC's Points of View covers only the corporation's output.

Two years ago it was moved from Saturday evenings to a prime time slot at 7.30pm on Fridays, when Channel 4 News was shortened to make way for it. Channel 4 said yesterday the slot would still be used for factual programmes.

A spokesman said: "The general feeling is that we are a multimedia company which viewers can contact in many different ways. Public access has been a tradition at Channel 4 but it has never been a statutory requirement ... when there is a programme that is controversial or should be debated, there will be the flexibility to do that."

fields.headline: Doreen Stephens
fields.standfirst: Woman television pioneer who rose to the top at the BBC and LWT
fields.trailText: Woman television pioneer who rose to the top at the BBC and LWT.
fields.body:
An article in the London Evening Standard in 1953 launched the career of the television pioneer Doreen Stephens, who has died aged 88. Headlined "They seek her here, they seek her there", it described the fruitless search by the BBC to find an editor for its women's programmes department.

"There you are," said Doreen's husband, Dr Jack Gorsky, "there's your career." At first, she did not take him seriously, but, on the basis of her involvement with women's issues in the 1940s and 50s, she was persuaded to apply. She started the job on her 41st birthday.

Ten years later, Doreen was head of BBC Television's family programmes, and one of the first women to hold an executive position in the corporation. She spearheaded programmes which introduced cookery guru Fanny Cradock and keep- fit expert Eileen Fowler to viewers, as well as bringing in Playschool and Dougall in The Magic Roundabout for children. For two years, she was also president of the Women's Press Club.

Early in the spring of 1967, she was invited by David Frost to join the new ITV company, London Weekend Television, at twice her BBC salary. At LWT, she had command of religious programmes, as well as those for children and women. She recalled that when Frost told her she would be responsible for religion, she clapped her hand to her head and said, "Oh, God!" "Yes," Frost replied, "you'll have to come to terms with Him."

Doreen always said that her time at LWT was the best of her life, but it was cut short after only two years when she became involved in a dispute between the LWT board and its managing director Michael Peacock over the station's direction. Doreen was among the senior staff, including Frank Muir, who stood behind Peacock and resigned in protest at his departure.

Doreen Stephens was born into a middle-class family in Hammersmith, west London. Family holidays were spent in France, where her father enjoyed the casinos. She was educated at a private boarding school in Folkestone, before attending finishing schools in Brussels and Wimbledon.

In 1933, at the age of 19, she married a stockbroker, Richard Holden, with whom she had two children, though after five years she and Holden divorced. During the second world war, she worked as a medical assistant in the Red Cross, and, while helping in an underground air-raid shelter in London, met her second husband, Jacob "Jack" Gorsky. Enthralled by her personality and her fine collection of cigars - she loved to smoke them because of the smell - he proposed, and they married in 1942.

With Gorsky's encouragement, Doreen took a diploma in social studies at London University, winning the Goldchrist Medal for her thesis on the national health service. She joined the Liberal party in 1944, and stood as a candidate in North Hackney in the general election the following year. Although not elected, she was one of the few Liberals who did not lose their deposit.

The same year she became involved in two organisations working for women's equality: the Married Women's Association, which argued for women's opportunities outside the domestic sphere, and the Equal-Pay-For-Equal Work Organisation, run by Thelma Cazalet. For the next seven years, Doreen campaigned for women's equality, writing magazine and newspaper articles, and giving talks around the world. In 1950, she became president of the Women's Liberal Federation.

Following her departure from LWT, she ran television training courses for religious personalities, and, in 1976, organised the first world conference on religious television, in Jerusalem. In the mid-1970s, she became vice-chair of the board of governors at Raynes Park high school for boys.

Doreen Stephens was a woman ahead of her time. Everyone who knew her talked of her zest for life and sense of fun, an attitude shared by her husband. Once, when shown a photograph of himself with "Miss Stephens" - Doreen always used her maiden name at work - he replied: "Oh yes, I sleep with her occasionally."

Doreen's final years were clouded by dementia, but she fought it more than most and continued to frequent her favourite restaurants in a wheelchair. Her husband died in 1961; she is survived by her son and daughter.

webTitle: Foot and mouth: vaccination strategy abandoned

fields.headline: Ministers abandon vaccination strategy
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The government last night effectively abandoned its plans for a limited vaccination policy in Cumbria saying the case for it had receded amid signs that foot and mouth was being brought under control.
fields.body:
The government last night effectively abandoned its plans for a limited vaccination policy in Cumbria saying the case for it had receded amid signs that foot and mouth was being brought under control.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, denied this represented a veto for the farmers unions, saying instead the consumer was king. He revealed for the first time that government focus groups showed 40% of the public would want separate labelling for milk or meat from vaccinated cattle.

"The case for vaccination recedes as the number of daily cases declines," he said.

Mr Brown was speaking as the Ministry of Agriculture was investigating the suspicion that a slaughterman had contracted a human form of foot and mouth disease. Maff said the likelihood of the case being confirmed was limited.

The environment minister, Michael Meacher, said in the Commons he was willing to look at proposals for napalming carcasses. Later he became aware that the idea, first canvassed in Science magazine, had already been considered and ruled out by Mr Brown. The powerful incendiary device, used during the Vietnam war, can burn animals in 60 minutes - what a conventional fire would take three days to do .

Mr Meacher conceded that animal pyres can poison humans with dioxins, and added that his ministry's preference was for rendering or burial.

The number of new foot and mouth cases confirmed in the 24 hours to 7pm on Sunday fell to nine, and only 10 extra cases were confirmed yesterday.

In the previous week the average daily number of new cases had fallen to 16, compared with 43 just over two weeks ago. During the Easter break, ministers had reflected in public the differences within Whitehall over vaccination, but Mr Brown said the trend was now downward.

Despite the protests about the environmental dangers of pyres in Devon, Mr Brown assured MPs that the backlog of slaughtered animals was being brought under control.

He admitted that the difficulties of finding suitable disposal sites in Devon meant that 100,000 carcasses were still awaiting burial. Mr Brown said no disposal option was entirely risk free. "Doing nothing is not a solution either," he told MPs, adding that the chief medical officer was revising his advice on the subject. He insisted he could not allow animal waste to enter the water supply, one possible outcome given the high water table in Devon.

He said he was also sending out advice to farmers who were about to turn out cattle into fields, warning them that they must be kept separate from sheep that might be harbouring the disease.

The compelling case for vaccination, he said, would have been to protect 95,000 cattle in northern Cumbria that might otherwise have had to be slaughtered. He added that an animal welfare scheme, introduced yesterday, would make it easier for farmers to take stranded or distressed animals to slaughter. He said 52,000 licence applications had been received and they would be processed in consultation with the RSPCA.

Mr Brown admitted the National Farmers Union, the Scottish Farmers Union and the Ulster Farmers Union were opposed to vaccination.

webTitle: Poll shows Tory voters' faith in Hague is slipping

fields.headline: Poll shows Tory voters' faith in Hague is slipping
fields.standfirst: Special report: Conservative party
fields.trailText: William Hague's personal popularity has fallen sharply among Conservative supporters in the past three weeks despite his attempts to make capital out of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
William Hague's personal popularity has fallen sharply among Conservative supporters in the past three weeks despite his attempts to make capital out of the foot and mouth crisis.

The April Guardian/ICM poll published today shows that the Tory leader's personal support among Conservative voters has fallen 11 points since the end of March - a devastating blow, particularly on the eve of a general election campaign.

The combination of a race row in which the Tories have been seen as a party out of control and continuing speculation over its future leadership have badly damaged Mr Hague's standing.

Three weeks ago, 60% of Tory voters named Mr Hague as the best prime minister for Britain in the last Guardian/ICM poll. But that has fallen to 49%. Most Conservatives now say that if they vote for the party, it will be despite William Hague's leadership.

The scale of the problem facing the Conservative leader is underlined by the ICM poll finding that Labour has emerged politically unscathed by the foot and mouth outbreak. The 14 point lead, which Tony Blair enjoyed before the farm crisis, has remained intact.

Today's ICM survey puts Labour on 47% (down 2), the Conservatives on 33 (down 1) and the Liberal Democrats on 14 (up 1).

Using the ICM "variometer" which takes account of regional swings in voting patterns, these figures would give Labour an overall majority of 165 if there were a general election tomorrow with Labour on 412 seats, the Tories picking up seats from the Liberal Democrats with an estimated 192 MPs and Charles Kennedy's party down from 47 MPs to only 25.

This continuing evidence of such a solid and substantial Labour lead begs the question of why should Tony Blair delay calling the general election much longer. The principal virtue of June 7 is that it will be on the same day as the delayed local government elections.

Mr Blair's commanding position among Labour voters with 82% naming him as the best prime minister for Britain contrasts sharply with William Hague's stark lack of support among his party's voters. Charles Kennedy's position among Liberal Democrat voters is even weaker with 27% naming Tony Blair as their preferred prime minister - the same proportion who think Mr Kennedy would do the best job.

Even among Conservative voters, 16% are say they think Mr Blair makes the best prime minister.

The resilience of the Labour vote is also shown by the polling data on specific questions about the foot and mouth crisis. Although 56% of voters are unimpressed by the government's performance in the crisis, the Tories and Liberal Democrats failed to make any greater impression on the voters.

Conservative voters show a distinct lack of faith in the Tories' performance on foot and mouth, with only 49% of Tory voters saying it is the best party to deal with the problem. Only 19% of Liberal Democrat voters named their party as the best to deal with the issue.

Although Mr Kennedy's party, with its targeted seats strategy, is expected to outperform its opinon poll ratings, these figures show the foot and mouth crisis may have been very damaging as so many of its 47 seats are in the affected areas in the south west, mid-Wales and the Scottish borders.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,005 adults aged 18 and over by telephone between April 20 - 22. Interviews were conducted across the country and have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Straw admits fall in police numbers

fields.headline: Straw admits fall in police numbers
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The largest boost in police recruitment for many years was yesterday welcomed by the home secretary but he conceded that overall police numbers were still below the level when Labour came to power in 1997.
fields.body:
The largest boost in police recruitment for many years was yesterday welcomed by the home secretary but he conceded that overall police numbers were still below the level when Labour came to power in 1997.

Home Office figures released yesterday showed that 7,009 recruits entered residential police training colleges in the last 12 months, compared with 3,963 recruits during 1999/2000 - a rise of 77%.

The rise is largely the result of a £450m boost in resources for recruitment after rows over police numbers. Jack Straw had promised to increase recruitment by 9,000 extra officers over the next three years over and above the plans of chief constables.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, claimed the government was comparing the new figures with "an all-time low" in recruitment. "Having let the number of regulars fall and the number of specials fall throughout their term of office they now suddenly turn round one month before an election and say 'oh look we've got record numbers', " she said.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, said: "More police officers are, of course, welcome. But better figures in the last month before the general election can't make up for four years of inadequate funding, belated interest and broken promises by this Labour government." Mr Straw said the recruits would very quickly boost overall police numbers, which "went down from 1993 under the four years of the Conservative government and then they went down under the first three years of this government".

fields.headline: New fuel price demonstrations next month, pledge protesters
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol crisis
fields.trailText: A new wave of fuel demonstrations and blockades is expected next month after the main protest group threatened action in response to the latest increases in petrol prices.
fields.body:
A new wave of fuel demonstrations and blockades is expected next month after the main protest group threatened action in response to the latest increases in petrol prices.

The People's Fuel Lobby said that recent forecourt price rises had all but wiped out the benefits of duty cuts made in the March Budget.

Anger within the lobby was stoked last night by Exxon Mobil, which trades in Britain as Esso, after its global operations made £28,000 profit a minute in the first three months of this year.

There was also a warning from the Petrol Retailers Association, representing small independent filling stations, that its members could join the protests this time. This could be a serious embarrassment to the government just before a general election.

Trevor Savage, a spokesman for the People's Fuel Lobby, said a meeting on Sunday involving 40 to 50 truckers and farmers had unanimously decided to take more action next month but had not finalised what form the protests would take.

"We are looking at several different options. We are very aware of the problems caused by foot and mouth, so if we are going back to refineries we need to be selective," said Mr Savage, a haulier and farmer from south-west England.

His views were supported by Mark Francis, one of the leaders of last September's protests. "There is no doubt we are still getting ripped off. Petrol prices have gone up 1.7p in the last couple of weeks which makes it phenomenally difficult for people like me who have trucks which burn 12,000 litres [of fuel] a month."

Ray Holloway, director of the Petrol Retailers Association, said that for some groups the conditions were worse than before last September's demonstrations.

His members were particularly angry about a situation in which they were being squeezed between government and major oil company policies.

Tony Blair had hit the very people he was trying to placate by forcing the oil majors to reduce their forecourt prices, he claimed. Hauliers and independent petrol retailers allegedly have to bulk-buy fuel at high prices from the oil majors who simultaneously kept their own pump prices much lower.

Such allegations have repeatedly been denied by the oil majors.

The fuel protesters admit openly they can succeed only if they carry public opinion with them. They are aware that foot and mouth is preoccupying farmers who played a vital role in the last demonstrations.

BP and Texaco are the latest to announce a rise in petrol prices of up to a penny a litre at some forecourts, following recent similar increases by Royal Dutch/Shell and Esso on unleaded petrol.

When the last demonstrations were in progress, Brent crude oil prices went close to $35 a barrel and petrol was near 90p per litre. Last night crude was selling at $26.49 a barrel and unleaded petrol at anything from 75p to 83p.

webTitle: Slaughterman tested for foot and mouth

fields.headline: Slaughterman tested for foot and mouth
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A slaughterman may have contracted foot and mouth from culling infected animals, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A slaughterman may have contracted foot and mouth from culling infected animals, it emerged last night.

The Department of Health confirmed that tests were being carried out on the man from West Cumbria, who has not been named. A diagnosis would not be made for 48 hours, until the results of blood tests are returned. But if confirmed, it would be the second ever case of the human form of the disease - the first occured during the 1967 epidemic.

The suspected victim has been heavily involved in the cull of infected animals.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: "There are documented cases of transmission to humans, but they are very rare. It is a flu-like illness which causes blisters on the hands and mouth. It clears up of its own accord. If we had one case in 1967, it is fair to expect we would have one or two cases this time around."

Professor Tony Hart, of Liverpool University, said the slaughterman had all the symptoms of the illness. The previous victim of the human strain of the disease suffered no long-term health effects.

The Public Health Laboratory Service said it had been alerted to several suspected cases of human foot and mouth since the beginning of the crisis - but tests had proved negative. A spokesman said that human foot and mouth was not a big public health issue.

The symptoms are mild and clear up without special treatment. There has been no recorded case of transmission between humans.

People can be infected through skin wounds, by handling diseased stock or by drinking infected milk but not by eating meat from infected animals. Foot and mouth disease should not be confused with hand foot and mouth disease, which is unrelated. The usually mild viral infection mostly affects children.

The average incubation period for foot and mouth is between three and eight days.

Angus Nichol, director of the Public Health Laboratory Service, said: "I must stress that the case is only a possible case. Of the previous people who thought they had the disease, all of them came up negative. So if I was a betting man, I would think this one would be negative as well. Basically this is an animal virus - it doesn't like human beings."

The report adds to fears over human health in relation to the crisis - particularly over the release of carcinogenic dioxins from animal pyres. The environment minister Michael Meacher conceded that the pyres could be a health risk.

The National Farmers Union said last night: "It has always been accepted that there's a small risk that humans could contract a mild form of foot and mouth if they are in prolonged personal contact with animals infected. We are very concerned to hear about this case. We will continue to work with government vets and scientists to eradicate this disease."

fields.headline: Suffer the little children
fields.standfirst: Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Brothers and sisters, it's time to confess - for a number of years now I have been an ordained minister. The privileged access this could grant me to vestments and fresh widowers has long been a cruel temptation to my soul, but I have resisted and lived the life of an ordinary sinner.
fields.body:
Brothers and sisters, it's time to confess - for a number of years now I have been an ordained minister. The privileged access this could grant me to vestments and fresh widowers has long been a cruel temptation to my soul, but I have resisted, set aside my hard-won ($35, plus postage) ecclesiastical status and lived the life of an ordinary sinner.

This had nothing to do with fears my credentials might not be valid in the UK and it is purely coincidental that, once in the US for a prolonged period, I have weakened and fallen. Never mind the potential tax breaks, never mind preying upon the weaker (or even the more upstanding) members of a congregation - like Aaron on Mount Nebo, I have seen my Promised Land. I've had the call, friends, to begin a ministry.

Now, like unto the disease-free goats of Gilgal, the ministries available are multitude: healing, shaking, quaking, laughing, guitar-playing, snake-handling. But none of these appealed - especially not the guitar-playing. Then, as with Moses, a Bush showed me the way. One minute George W was happy to save poor meat producers the trial of having school supplies checked for salmonella and then, he changed his mind - although an absence of controls might only have killed a handful of children annually. Because even a market-led cretin can love children. It was a sign.

So let me testify, brethren, about children - those innocent dears on whose behalf British adults are willing to riot, loot and attack blameless paediatricians everywhere in frenzies of typographical confusion. Our spotless seed - how may we best defend it from the snares and pitfalls of sin?

Well, hallelujah, we're doing our best. For example, by ensuring the Blessed Chasm between the Righteously Comfortable and the Suspiciously Impecunious grows ever wider, we help save the souls of children in poverty. Original Sin apart, the infant carries no burden of wrongdoing to keep it from the Lord. But the offspring of drug addicts, drunks and the undernourished - their defences against evil are already weakened.

As they grow, they look forward to addiction, the sin of despair and a myriad of pathways towards wrong-doing and the blistering hands of the Evil One. By offering them and their benighted parents less and less support, we radically reduce their life expectancy and send them to the angels with some chance of gaining admission to the plainer areas of Paradise.

Increasingly, the children of the poor are untroubled by the state education system, but a few of them attend schools, along with other youngsters who are, Lord save them, destined to be of no use to anyone. These are the straying (unincinerated) lambs who will vandalise, shoplift, have extra-marital sex and never amount to anything upon which the Almighty might smile.

By ensuring a lack of staff, discipline, morale, textbooks and sane examination systems, we leave individual young souls cunningly exposed to every possible temptation. Those who emerge with any skills or dignity will merit our praise and social inclusion, those who are shown to be only puppets fashioned from devilish clay can be easily disposed of into prisons, poverty and hardships which will bring them quickly to death's merciful release. The suicides, obviously, will be consigned to Hell: this proving the existence of Eternal Mercy, since Hell will be the one place where they'll feel at home.

The infrastructure of our schools, like that of our children's wards and hospitals, has also been subjected to the perfect level of neglect. The crumbling roofs, rotting window frames, inadequate water supplies, hopelessly underfunded cleaning: they all assist in sorting the wheat from the chaff. Every person of good conscience can look forward to the first full-blown building collapse or TB outbreak and its blessedly wholesale liberation of relatively stain-free spirits.

The role of the computer and St William of the Pearly Gates in this sanctified work is key. By forcing all devices not of his making from our schools and replacing them with his own, he has yet further depleted the minimal funds allotted to education, left staff to battle with bewilderment and rage and abandoned pupils to fret while the one in every class of 30 or so with computer access tries to get Windows 98 not to crash.

Those who wrestle with these angels and triumph will be proof against all Satan's works, those who fail will be clearly identified by mental illness, RSI and a tendency to blaspheme. The mark of the beast will be upon them. Just as it will be upon those senior school pupils provided with laptops - a guaranteed source of muscular and skeletal problems. What an age we live in, that martyrdom (or the kind of crippling infirmities that prevent malcontents committing serious crime) can be available to ones so young and tender.

So onward, friends, in our mission and, whatever you do, don't read the bible. It's full of "For the needy shall not always be forgotten: the expectation of the poor shall not perish forever," and other nonsense like that. Entirely unsuitable for children.

Increasingly, the children of the poor are untroubled by the state education system, but a few of them attend schools, along with other youngsters who are, Lord save them, destined to be of no use to anyone. These are the straying (unincinerated) lambs who will vandalise, shoplift, have extra-marital sex and never amount to anything upon which the Almighty might smile. By ensuring a lack of staff, discipline, morale, textbooks and sane examination systems, we leave individual young souls cunningly exposed to every possible temptation. Those who emerge with any skills or dignity will merit our praise and social inclusion, those who are shown to be only puppets fashioned from devilish clay can be easily disposed of into prisons, poverty and hardships which will bring them quickly to death's merciful release. The suicides, obviously, will be consigned to Hell: this proving the existence of Eternal Mercy, since Hell will be the one place where they'll feel at home. The infrastructure of our schools, like that of our children's wards and hospitals, has also been subjected to the perfect level of neglect. The crumbling roofs, rotting window frames, inadequate water supplies, hopelessly underfunded cleaning: they all assist in sorting the wheat from the chaff. Every person of good conscience can look forward to the first full-blown building collapse or TB outbreak and its blessedly wholesale liberation of relatively stain-free spirits. The role of the computer and St William of the Pearly Gates in this sanctified work is key. By forcing all devices not of his making from our schools and replacing them with his own, he has yet further depleted the minimal funds allotted to education, left staff to battle with bewilderment and rage and abandoned pupils to fret while the one in every class of 30 or so with computer access tries to get Windows 98 not to crash. Those who wrestle with these angels and triumph will be proof against all Satan's works, those who fail will be clearly identified by mental illness, RSI and a tendency to blaspheme. The mark of the beast will be upon them. Just as it will be upon those senior school pupils provided with laptops - a guaranteed source of muscular and skeletal problems. What an age we live in, that martyrdom (or the kind of crippling infirmities that prevent malcontents committing serious crime) can be available to ones so young and tender. So onward, friends, in our mission and, whatever you do, don't read the bible. It's full of "For the needy shall not always be forgotten: the expectation of the poor shall not perish forever," and other nonsense like that. Entirely unsuitable for children. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Uniscape breaks down barriers to trade

fields.headline: Uniscape breaks down barriers to trade
fields.standfirst: More internet news
fields.trailText: If you don't want your customers to eat tadpoles or stuff mares with wax then Silicon Valley software firm Uniscape is looking for you.
fields.body:
If you don't want your customers to eat tadpoles or stuff mares with wax then Silicon Valley software firm Uniscape is looking for you.

It is targeting European companies seeking international online business without the restriction of linguistic and cultural barriers. The company, which employs 120 people and hopes to become profitable next year, claims its software can helpclients to avoid marketing mistakes.

For instance, Coca-Cola in Chinese means "Bite the Wax Tadpole" or "Female Horse Stuffed with Wax", depending on the dialect. Coca-Cola had to find a phonetic equivalent, "Kokou-Kole", which translates into "happiness in the mouth", Uniscape says.

"Our software empowers companies to globalise more efficiently by automating the business processes involved in keeping customer, partner and employee information updated on a worldwide basis," said Steve Adams, Uniscape's chief executive.

According to the company the market for non-English content is likely to grow dramatically. At present more than two-thirds of websites are in English but more than 50% of internet users are not English speakers. International Data Corporation predicts that by 2003, nearly seven out of 10 web users will live outside the US and will account for 55% of global e-commerce revenues.

Uniscape expects European contracts to make up between 30% and 40% of its business in the next two to three years.

fields.headline: 'Patchy' refugee checks a health risk, warns BMA
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The patchy screening of asylum seekers for infectious diseases such as TB and HIV is risking their health and that of the wider public, the British Medical Association warned yesterday.
fields.body:
The patchy screening of asylum seekers for infectious diseases such as TB and HIV is risking their health and that of the wider public, the British Medical Association warned yesterday.

The doctors' organisation also warned that the hardening of attitudes towards asylum seekers and the introduction of the dispersal system and voucher scheme have exacerbated their health problems in Britain.

A BMA handbook, the Medical Profession and Human Rights, published yesterday says the rise in the number of asylum seekers coming to Britain means that doctors are having to treat torture victims for the first time. More than 5,000 torture victims entered the country last year.

Although initial problems of GPs refusing to put asylum seekers on to their lists by turning away people with very poor English or only taking them as temporary patients have diminished, asylum seekers have been cut off from support and advice from existing refugee community groups. Doctors have struggled to cope with the needs of "vulnerable people arriving without warning, planning or language support services", says the BMA report.

The doctors are concerned, with the increase of highly infectious diseases such as drug resistant tuberculosis, about the risk to public health if those coming into the country do not receive adequate health screening when they arrive.

"Unfortunately, due to a lack of funding and insufficient staff in UK port medical units, this examination may only be cursory, thereby undermining its effectiveness," the report says.

It urges that every refugee and asylum seeker should undergo a thorough medical examination on arrival.

"The individual's consent should be sought and the examinee should also be aware that the purpose of the medical assessment is primarily for the protection of the public," says the report.

Vivienne Nathanson, the BMA's head of health policy and research, said screening was "very patchy" and there was a separate ethical issue of asylum seekers being given HIV tests without their consent.

The report highlights difficulties faced by torture victims who are dispersed outside London getting the specialist treatment they need.

It says that the voucher system leads asylum seekers to bulk buy and rely on tinned, processed foods, which has damaged their health. Some even fail to get enough food as the vouchers provided are worth only 70% of income support levels.

The doctors also raised concerns about the health of the increasing number of asylum seekers detained in prisons.

webTitle: London Underground gets a new fragrance

fields.headline: Underground scent promises transports of delight
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: LU yesterday launched its latest assault in the battle to make tube travel more pleasant - a fragrance called Madeleine designed to mask the more familiar odours.
fields.body:
To Marcel Proust, the flavour of madeleines was enough to transport him back to his childhood. But when commuters on the London Underground get a whiff of Madeleine, it is more likely to evoke memories of crowded, stressful journeys.

LU yesterday launched its latest assault in the battle to make tube travel more pleasant - a fragrance called Madeleine designed to mask the more familiar odours.

The fragrance, to be applied to station floors and released by passengers' footsteps, is described as "a fresh, watery floral bouquet of rose and jasmine, combined with citrus top notes, tiny touches of fruit and herbs, giving way to woody accents and a hint of sweetness in the base".

But yesterday, commuters at St James' Park station, where the scent is on trial, were not convinced. Comments ranged from "medicinal" to "slightly naff suburban". Simon Jacobs, a management consultant, said: "It's a cheap fragrance that smells slightly like industrial cleaner. It's a good idea as long as you use a fragrance that doesn't make the station smell like a toilet."

The month-long trial is at St James' Park, Euston and Piccadilly Circus. Whether the project continues depends on the customers, said Andy Byford, service delivery manager for LU. "With 3m customers using the system every day, it does get a little smelly," he said. "Our top priority is a safe, reliable train service and this is by no means a distraction, but if we can make the system smell a lot nicer as people are going from A to B, then I think that's worth looking at."

The scent is modelled on one used on the Paris metro since 1998, also called Madeleine, which was recently applied on the Hong Kong underground.

Pierre Nuyens, the perfumier, said he had modified his scent to suit London. "There are a lot of elements to the underground. There's a mechanical scent, and railway sleepers impregnated with chemicals. Other smells I detect from people - perfume, food or sweat." The London scent lacks the "heavy woodiness" of the original, he said.

LU concedes the scheme will need fine tuning. Yesterday, some commuters were sneezing, while others said they smelt nothing at all. Some rather liked the "tube au naturel", with hints of engine oil and an upper register of mouse droppings. Dave Witcomb, a passenger, said: "I don't think they should have tried to mask it. It's part of its charm."

fields.headline: Montenegro split over breakaway
fields.standfirst:
High vote for pro-Yugoslavia coalition spoils plan for referendum on independence

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Plans to separate Montenegro from Yugoslavia were set back yesterday by general election results showing the pro and anti-independence groups neck and neck.
fields.body:
Plans to separate Montenegro from Yugoslavia were set back yesterday by general election results showing the pro and anti-independence groups neck and neck.

President Milo Djukanovic's coalition emerged from the polls on Sunday with a three-seat majority in parliament but too small a share of the popular vote for a convincing win in the referendum on the country's future status it proposed during the election campaign.

The result brought an immediate resumption of pressure from the international community for Montenegro to stay in the federal republic.

The officials results showed that the "Victory belongs to Montenegro" coalition had won just over 42% of the vote. Its opponents, who fought under the banner "Together for Yugoslavia", confounded the opinion polls by coming just 2% behind. Some polls had suggested that it would get just over a quarter of vote.

Supporters of both groups claimed victory and were celebrating on the streets of the capital, Podgorica, into the early hours ofyesterday, waving flags and firing guns in the air.

The election was fought entirely on the issue of independence. Montenegro and Serbia are the last remaining states in the present-day Yugoslav federation.

The result has forced Mr Djukanovic's partners to reconsider their plans to hold a referendum on independence as soon as possible.

"We need some more time. Some of our calculations have proved wrong, there is a victory for the independence, but it is not very convincing," said Dragisa Burzan, the former deputy prime minister.

Nevertheless the referendum, initially planned for July, may go ahead, because the partner Mr Djukanovic's party needs to form a government, the Liberal Alliance, is committed to breaking away from Yugoslavia as soon as possible. Without its support the coalition will not have a working majority in parliament.

Foreign diplomats used the results to warn the govern ment against holding a referendum so soon, and urged it to resume a dialogue with Serbia about their relationship in the Yugoslav federation.

Gerard Stoudman, representing the Organisation of Security and Cooperation in Europe, said: "What is sure, what we find is ... there is no clear mandate for or against [independence]."

"There is a very clear split. This should be understood as a clear message to both those that who want to rush to independence as well as Belgrade. There is a need for a serious discussion in good faith to resolve the outstanding issues." .

That message is likely to be reinforced by the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who is visiting Podgorica tomorrow.

Western diplomats fear that Montenegro's pursuit of inde pendence will give added impetus to other separatists in the region, most notably in Kosovo.

Mr Stoudman warned that it would also increase tension in Montenegro itself.

"The risk is that there will be a very heated campaign, and that people will be frustrated whatever the results."

He suggested that by focusing on independence Mr Djukanovic had neglected the voters' real concerns.

"They did not implement much of what they had promised when they were last elected. People are fed up with corruption. This was a vote of no confidence in the present coalition."

Sweden, as president of the EU, also urged the resumption of talks with Belgrade.

fields.headline: Separation must wait
fields.standfirst:
Montenegro's voters are split

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Montenegro's President Milo Djukanovic should reconsider his plan for a summer referendum on independence in the light of Sunday's parliamentary election results.
fields.body:
Montenegro's President Milo Djukanovic should reconsider his plan for a summer referendum on independence in the light of Sunday's parliamentary election results. Far from gaining the hearty endorsement he had predicted, Mr Djukanovic's allies won only 42% of the vote, placing them less than 2% ahead of the federalist bloc that wants the republic to remain a part of Yugoslavia. Even with support from minor, pro-independence parties, the president will find himself well short of the two-thirds majority required in parliament for fundamental constitutional changes of the type envisaged. Before the polls, Mr Djukanovic disputed the legal necessity of a two-thirds ratification, claiming that a simple majority would suffice. After the polls, and apparently undaunted, he declared that the "necessary arrangements" for putting independence to the vote would be set in train immediately.

Mr Djukanovic needs to stop and think about the consequences of this precipitate course. The six-nation "contact group" for former Yugoslavia, including the US and Russia, has already threatened to withdraw financial aid should Montenegro halt talks and force a unilateral break with Belgrade. The EU is publicly warning of a "new crisis in the western Balkans" while Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, urges that relations with Serbia be renewed "in accordance with the existing constitutional order". Britain's Robin Cook will also stress the priorities of peace and regional stability when he visits Mr Djukanovic tomorrow in Podgorica.

All this advice is not entirely disinterested, of course. Western countries fret about separatist "contagions" spreading through Bosnia, Macedonia, and most of all, Kosovo. They worry, with reason, that Montenegro, with its population of 650,000, will become yet another Balkan mini-state economically and militarily dependent on them. The west worries, too, about how a narrow pro-independence victory could provoke the Serbs of northern Montenegro and undermine Serbia proper's fragile rehabilitation. But if Mr Djukanovic wants support for Montenegro's integration into modern-day Europe, as he says, he must pay heed to these concerns. Even more so, he must listen to all of Montenegro's voters, who are split down the middle. There is no secessionist mandate to be found here. A push for independence now will dangerously exacerbate divisions.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Cambridge spy ring member Guy Burgess (Rage over money from home for spies Burgess and Maclean, page 6, April 20) died in 1963, not 1984 as stated.
fields.body:
 In the profile of James Ellroy (Out of the dark, G2, page 4, April 20) Warren Harding was said to have been president of the United States between 1916 and 1924. He was in the White House from 1921 to 1923, when he died in office and was succeded by his vice president, Calvin Coolidge.

 Cambridge spy ring member Guy Burgess (Rage over money from home for spies Burgess and Maclean, page 6, April 20) died in 1963, not 1984 as stated.

 Brian Wilson was mistakenly shuffled into position as secretary of state for Scotland (The break-up of Britain, page 17, April 23). He has never occupied that post but was a minister of state at the Scotland Office until he moved to the Foreign and Commonwealth Office in January this year. Helen Liddell is secretary of state for Scotland.

 Nasa's prototype "scramjet", the X-43A (Things to come, page 16, April 20), was said to scoop oxgyen from the air for fuel. The oxygen is used for combustion with its on-board fuel, hydrogen.

 A caption in the piece on the Basque separatist organisation, ETA (Bloody bequest, Weekend Guardian, page 33, April 21), referred to Jose Maria Aznar as the Spanish president. The Spanish head of state is King Juan Carlos. Snr Aznar is Presidente del Consejo de Gobierno (chairman of the cabinet), but a more accurate translation is "prime minister".

 Sullum Voe, locus of some sleuthing by Ian Rankin's Inspector John Rebus (The detective of darkness, Saturday Review, page 11, April 21), was misplaced in the Hebrides. Some elementary investigation reveals that the largest oil terminal in these islands is a further 200 miles to the north east, in Shetland.

 It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Our attention is drawn to an intriguing entry on the latest list of Britain's 50 "least loved" public companies, drawn up by accountants RSM Robson Rhodes.
fields.body:
 Our attention is drawn to an intriguing entry on the latest list of Britain's 50 "least loved" public companies, drawn up by accountants RSM Robson Rhodes. Topping the table of stockmarket ugly ducklings - firms that have failed to attract investor interest despite posting astonishing earnings growth - is marketing group Incepta, owner of financial PR firm Citigate. Concerned for the future of our good friends the City spin doctors, we call and inquire why investors have been spurning Incepta. If a company's share price remains sluggish while revenues rocket, we ask (mentioning no names, so as not to cause upset), surely it would be childish and unfair to point the finger of blame at those responsible for the firm's PR? Alas, we are wrong. "If that was the case," insists Citigate's Patrick Donovan (who, by happy coincidence, used to write on these pages), "questions would have to be asked: Are there things that are not being explained to the analysts? Or not getting through to the financial media?" Questions which may yet come back to haunt him.

 By way of a postscript to the unseemly parading of Croesus-like wealth through the pages of the Sunday Times' rich list supplement at the weekend, we note a largely overlooked press release from Gold Group International. While others privileged to receive a ranking continue to maintain the charade that they would rather die than actively draw attention their beloved bank balances, Gold Group chairman David Gold offers a refreshingly candid approach. "Champagne will be popping on publication of this year's list," promises the release. "David started his working life selling buttons on a stall outside his East End home ... Last year he was placed 78th on the list - where will he be this year?" (Joint 82nd, it transpires). Gold is "easily worth over £370m with brother Ralph," we are told, and now resides in one of Surrey's "premier mansions, set in 50 acres of park land". Nor, it appears, does Gold care to mask the nature of his business interests - in 1981 his tired mail order "adult entertainment" business was revitalised after his daughter Jacqueline persuaded him to back her Ann Summers chain. webTitle: Brussels seeks to pacify US over Airbus loans

fields.headline: Brussels seeks to pacify US over Airbus loans
fields.trailText: The European Union sought to head off another transatlantic trade dispute yesterday by saying that billions of pounds of state aid for Airbus's new A380 superjumbo complied with global trade rules.
fields.body:
The European Union sought to head off another transatlantic trade dispute yesterday by saying that billions of pounds of state aid for Airbus's new A380 superjumbo complied with global trade rules.

Countering US claims that government loans towards the estimated £7.3bn development cost of the airliner amount to illegal state subsidies, Brussels provided Washington with details of costs.

"There should be no cause for concern on the American side," European commission spokesman Anthony Gooch said. "On our side we've kept to what we agreed to."

Washington, which fiercely defends US aerospace group Boeing, is worried that European governments have agreed to shoulder just under a third of the aircraft's development costs in the form of long-term loans.

The A380 will be the world's largest airliner and is expected to create up to 20,000 jobs in Britain, where the wings will be built, and safeguard an other 62,000. Britain is providing £530m towards its launch cost.

Brussels says global trade rules set a maximum 33% for this kind of funding and that it will retaliate if Washington takes legal action.

Airbus's new A340-600 long-haul jetliner made its first test flight yesterday. It made a five hour 22 minute journey from Toulouse, near Airbus's headquarters. Commercial flights are due to start in 2002.

fields.headline: Hilton makes quantum leap in £612m Scandic hotel buy
fields.trailText: Hilton International has laid out £612m to buy the 154-strong Scandic hotel chain, nearly doubling the size of the UK hotel group's operations.
fields.body:
Hilton International has laid out £612m to buy the 154-strong Scandic hotel chain, nearly doubling the size of the UK hotel group's operations.

The Hilton International organisation, previously known as Ladbroke, owns the Hilton name outside the US, and the Scandic deal will take its portfolio to 390 city centre, resort and airport hotels.

Scandic is the biggest hotel operator in the Nordic region and most of its three and four star hotels, like the rest of Hilton International, is focused on business travellers.

The agreed cash and shares deal will strengthen the group in Scandinavia, where 133 of the Scandic hotels are located. Twenty will be rebranded as Hiltons, along with 17 of the non-Nordic hotels, in northern Europe and the UK, which are also included in the deal. Altogether the acquisition will boost Hilton by 26,459 rooms.

"We have declared over the past year that we intended to get Hilton more into Europe, so this is the first step in doing just that," said chief executive David Michels. "We're likely to do more deals in Europe in the future... We plan to cover as much of Europe as possible."

He has identified "synergy benefits" totalling at least £17m from the takeover, made up of £8m in cost savings and £9m from "revenue enhancement initiatives", including the HHonors frequent stay scheme.

Analysts said Hilton, which pulled out of the bidding for the Meridien hotel group earlier this year, had done a good deal at a cheap price. Hilton also provided a trading update for the first three months of this year, showing strong growth in both its hotels and betting divisions.

Hotel profits were up 27%, but Mr Michels said they would be hit by the foot and mouth outbreak.

Ladbrokes' profits were ahead 30% on last year despite serious disruption to UK and Irish racing caused by foot and mouth and the wet weather, which has caused many meetings to be abandoned.

Mr Michels said those problems had been more than offset by extra gambling on greyhounds and overseas racing and a string of favourable race results, as muddy courses have reduced the number of favourites winning. The Grand National, for instance, was won by a 40-1 outsider after almost the entire field fell.

Manchester United's exit from the Champions League, boxer Naseem Hamed's defeat by Marko Antonio Barrera and the weekend defeat of 16-1 on favourite Lennox Lewis will all benefit Ladbroke in the second quarter.

webTitle: CGNU meeting is target for asbestos protest

fields.headline: CGNU meeting is target for asbestos protest
fields.trailText: Shareholders and directors arriving for insurance group CGNU's annual meeting today will be confronted with images of South Africans suffering from asbestos-related illnesses in the latest example of activists targeting a high-profile institutional investor.
fields.body:
Shareholders and directors arriving for insurance group CGNU's annual meeting today will be confronted with images of South Africans suffering from asbestos-related illnesses in the latest example of activists targeting a high-profile institutional investor.

CGNU's Norwich Union arm is being targeted because it is a big shareholder in Cape plc, a UK-based company which mined asbestos in South Africa during the apartheid era and is involved in a long-running legal battle over compensation claims from miners and residents.

Campaign group Action for Southern Africa (Actsa) is calling on Norwich Union to exercise its shareholder muscle by publicly calling on Cape to end the legal wrangle and swiftly settle the claims.

Members of the London-based campaign group will be joined by representatives from the South African National Union of Mineworkers, and plan to hold a demonstration at the Barbican in London today during which they will "line the route" with protesters holding up giant-size photographs of South African asbestos victims and the "devastation" they claim was caused by Cape's operations.

To mark an international memorial day for asbestos workers, shareholders will also be handed flowers in remembrance of the South Africans who have died, said a spokeswoman for the group.

As shareholders, Actsa and the South African NUM representatives plan to question the Norwich board at the annual meeting.

Norwich Union holds about 2% of Uxbridge-based Cape's shares. The company ceased asbestos mining in South Africa in 1979 and has been involved in a legal battle which was taken up by more than 3,000 South African miners and residents claiming asbestos poisoning.

Last summer the former employees of Cape won the right to sue for damages in the British courts when the House of Lords overturned a court of appeal decision against them.

Actsa said that as a "socially responsible investor" it expected Norwich Union "to take a bolder position than other institutional shareholders and join the campaign to see justice delivered".

The group is likely to highlight a pledge made by CGNU earlier this year that it would bring ethical criteria to the fore across the entire £200bn that it manages.

webTitle: Jobs fear as Enodis sells Magnet

fields.headline: Jobs fear as Enodis sells Magnet
fields.trailText: The kitchens group Magnet was bought by Stockholm-based Nobia in a £134m deal yesterday.
fields.body:
The kitchens group Magnet was bought by Stockholm-based Nobia in a £134m deal yesterday.

Nobia, which is backed by venture capitalists, is understood to be most interested in Magnet's 227 retail outlets. This leaves a question mark over the future of 1,150 Magnet manufacturing workers in Darlington, Keighley, Flint and Penrith.

A sale of Magnet along with various other building and consumer product businesses had been widely expected. Magnet's parent company, Enodis, has been struggling with £500m debt and has issued two profit warnings this year.

Magnet has had a turbulent history after being bought by its management for £600m ten years ago. It was sold on for a knock-down price to Enodis - then trading as Berisford - but was hit by a series of strikes between 1996 and 1998.

Enodis will make a £25m profit on the sale of Magnet and will reduce its debt mountain by £100m.

Peter Brooks, chairman of Enodis, said he was delighted by the deal with Nobia, whose brands include Poggenpohl and A La Carte.

"It will enable us to focus exclusively on our core food-equipment business where we have powerful market-leading positions and excellent long-term growth opportunities," he said.

He believed that Magnet's workers would benefit from being part of a leading European manufacturer of domestic kitchen furniture.

Enodis has been suffering from its own woes, with a slowdown in its important US market, where it supplies stoves to fast-food restaurants such as the McDonald's chain. The British company recently announced 900 redundancies and has seen the resignation of its chief executive, David Williams.

The City welcomed the latest development and Enodis shares rose by 10%. They ended the day at 117.5p, up 13.5p, the rise showing the relief that Magnet was off its hands, and buoyed by speculation that Enodis had become a potential takeover target.

The deal will be transacted with £114m in cash plus £20m through a vendor loan. Privately owned Nobia, which had a turnover of £275m last year, expects to float on the stock market within two years.

webTitle: Intel slashes price of fastest Pentium 4

fields.headline: Intel slashes price of fastest Pentium 4
fields.trailText: Intel introduced its fastest Pentium 4 processor at bargain-basement prices yesterday, putting pressure on rival Advanced Micro Devices to match the speed and the price tag.
fields.body:
Intel introduced its fastest Pentium 4 processor at bargain-basement prices yesterday, putting pressure on rival Advanced Micro Devices to match the speed and the price tag.

The chip maker said the low price of the 1.7 GHz Pentium 4, pictured, is a reflection of savings that are being passed on to customers. Many analysts believe it is an attempt to boost Intel's market share.

The new processor will sell for $352 (£245) when purchased in bulk. When Intel unveiled its 1.1 GHz Pentium III last July, it carried a price tag of $990. The company also will cut prices on its slower Pentium 4 processors next week.

In the fourth quarter of last year Intel processors powered 81.5% of PCs, while Advanced Micro Devices had 17.1%. In the first quarter of this year Intel's share fell to 77.3% and AMD's grew to 21.1%, according to preliminary figures from Mercury Research in Arizona.
