webTitle: Market forces: Decision time for Baltimore

fields.headline: Decision time for Baltimore
fields.trailText: Decision time is fast approaching for the 69 individuals who own 2.2% of internet security firm Baltimore Technologies.
fields.body:
Decision time is fast approaching for the 69 individuals who own 2.2% of internet security firm Baltimore Technologies.

On Wednesday, they are released from a lock-in period and are free to sell their 11.1m shares - the equivalent of two days' average trading in Baltimore - in the market. Given the company's recent lamentable performance, dealers expect a number to cash in.

In the past month Baltimore's stock price has been in free fall, tumbling from 150p to 64p as it issued not one but two revenue warnings. Baltimore is one of those tech companies that has been affected by the US economic slowdown.

The 69 individuals entered into the lock-in agreement when Baltimore acquired Content Technologies, the email security firm they were employed by in October. All of them are now thought to be Baltimore employees.

As such, it is by no means certain any will sell. With Baltimore trading at its lowest level since February 1999, they might reason that the shares can only go up from here. However, if recent market rumours are correct and Baltimore runs out of cash before it becomes profitable, they might want to sell. Baltimore shares ended 1.75p higher at 73.75p.

Pausing for breath after the fireworks of last week, leading shares ended little changed as institutions pondered the sustainability of the market's recent rally.

The FTSE 100 ended down 8.5 points at 5,871.3, with the tech sector doing most of the damage. Market turnover was a respectable 2bn shares.

Semiconductor stocks were the worst offenders after bearish comments from investment bank Merrill Lynch. Lowering its ratings on a number of US chipmakers, Merrill warned investors that the stocks had not yet fallen far enough to merit buying. Merrill thinks the bottom for the sector is at least a quarter away.

Heeding the advice, investors in London sold ARM Holdings, off 33p to 329p, ARC International, down 11.5p to 93.5p, and IQE, 19p weaker at 236.5p.

The telecom sector was another weak spot. News of a profits warning from US telecoms company SBC Communications undermined Cable & Wireless, off 25.5p to 479.5p, and Colt Telecom, 39p weaker at 784p. The FTSE Techmark 100 closed 41.06 points lower at 1,962.70.

Old-economy stocks were having a better day as investors seeking safe places to park their cash bought the likes of Rolls-Royce, up 8.25p to 216.75p, Imperial Tobacco, 23.5p stronger at 689.5p, and Diageo, 19.5p higher at 714.5p.

Meanwhile, the rumour mill cranked back into life. Media display group Photobition was chased 4.25p higher to 50.25p as the 65p-a-share management buyout story did the rounds again, and advertising group WPP fell 12.5p to 816p on renewed talk of a pessimistic statement with Thursday's first-quarter figures.

Among the mid caps, Regus, the serviced office specialist, fell 39.5p to 272.5p as Merrill Lynch set about trying to place the 5.1% stake of founding shareholders AP Regus Investors, Serviced Investments and Deutsche Bank Capital Partners after the expiry of their lock-in agreement.

Fallen software star NSB Retail Systems was making up some lost ground, as a trip for major shareholders and analysts to its Canadian business, STS Systems, got under way.

In early March, NSB saw its market value halve after a dismal set of full-year figures. But yesterday the shares recovered 6p to 76p as positive feedback from the visit filtered into the market. The trip continues today.

On Aim, Chelsea Village, the owner of Chelsea football club, provided the day's main talking point. In early trade the stock raced to 47p on reports that its vice-president, Peter Harrison, was preparing a hostile bid. However, the shares finished at 40p, up 3.5p, after Mr Harrison said there was absolutely no truth in the speculation.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: About 500 British jobs are expected to be among 5,000 to be cut by 3M, whose products range from Post-It notes to fibre-optic connectors. The company said it was planning to reduce its workforce by 7% and boost productivity as it faced unpredictable markets and currency trends.
fields.body:
3M to cut 500 British jobs

About 500 British jobs are expected to be among 5,000 to be cut by 3M, whose products range from Post-It notes to fibre-optic connectors. The company said it was planning to reduce its workforce by 7% and boost productivity as it faced unpredictable markets and currency trends. 3M has 18 British sites, including Swansea, Loughborough and Bracknell.

Kalms steps down at Dixons

Consumer electronics retailer Dixons Group yesterday confirmed its chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is to retire in September 2002.

Dixons said in a statement that Sir Stanley would become the company's president.

EC warns on price-fixing

The European commission said yesterday it has sent five plasterboard companies formal warnings on possible price-fixing. BPB of Britain, part of the European gypsum industry, said it had received the warning and expected no final decision until the end of the year. In its statement yesterday the EC did not identify the five firms to which it had sent statements of objection.

Loan rate helps house sales

The housing market showed no sign of slowing in March as borrowers took advantage of competitive loan rates, according to new figures yesterday. The Council of Mortgage Lenders said the amount being lent by banks and building societies was up by almost a quarter on the previous month as the sector proved resistant to general economic worries. Competition between lenders pushed the average rate for new mortgages down to 5.82% during March, with an average new variable rate of 5.72%, and an average new fixed rate of 6.02%.

Elan leaps by 89%

Irish pharmaceuticals group Elan Corp posted an 89% leap in first-quarter net income on Monday, and said it remained confident of meeting revenue targets for its main products. Elan said net income after tax and before other charges rose to £100.1m, with revenues up 27% compared with the £297.7m reported for the same period last year, reflecting product revenue growth of 39%. Elan shares, which are mainly traded in New York, slipped nearly 1% to €54.0 in Dublin.

Repairs lifeline for Cammell

Work to refurbish naval ships could help rescue the troubled shipbuilders Cammell Laird, the GMB union said yesterday. Cammell called in the receivers earlier this month, but Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, has given it permission to bid for contracts to refit Royal Fleet Auxiliary vessels, said a union spokesman, adding: "This could be the contract Cammell has been waiting for."

Kalms steps down at Dixons Consumer electronics retailer Dixons Group yesterday confirmed its chairman, Sir Stanley Kalms, is to retire in September 2002. Dixons said in a statement that Sir Stanley would become the company's president. BPB of Britain, part of the European gypsum industry, said it had received the warning and expected no final decision until the end of the year. fields.headline: Confidence in CMG
fields.trailText: Analysts may not be recommending the stock to clients after last week's profits warning, but senior management at CMG obviously think the shares are a bargain.
fields.body:
Analysts may not be recommending the stock to clients after last week's profits warning, but senior management at CMG obviously think the shares are a bargain.

Yesterday, the IT firm revealed that executive chairman Cor Stutterheim bought 20,432 shares on Friday. He was followed by chief executive Tom Rusting, who acquired 16,000 shares, finance director David Robbie, who picked up 8,150, and marketing manager Hugo Schaap, who splashed out £62,000 for 17,002 shares.

"A number of group board members wish to demonstrate their confidence in the long-term prospects of the business," a spokesman said. Last Thursday, CMG shares fell 19% after the company revealed its key wireless software division would incur an operating loss because of the slowdown in spending by telecoms companies.

CMG closed down 16p at 344p yesterday.

webTitle: John Fordham meets jazz legend Sonny Rollins

fields.headline: 'Life is a struggle'
fields.standfirst: Jazz legend Sonny Rollins tells  John Fordham about drugs, racism and reincarnation
fields.trailText: Jazz legend Sonny Rollins tells John Fordham about drugs, racism and reincarnation.
fields.body:
It must be hard being a "legendary improviser". How do you reconcile a life devoted to the avoidance of repetition with a 50-year career and back catalogue? "I've always treated what I do as a work in progress," says Sonny Rollins, the 70-year-old saxophonist who makes a rare appearance in Britain on Saturday.

Yet a legend Rollins undoubtedly is, and for good reasons. Just one of the true stories to have become Rollins folklore concerns his tendency to improvise unaccompanied on the tenor sax for an hour or more without preparation, written music, repetition or pauses for breath any longer than the minimum necessary to sustain life.

As an aside to his music, yet also an intimate part of it, Rollins has at times been given to all manner of sartorial and theatrical detours, including playing nightclub gigs in dangling-cork outback hats, raincoats and Mohican haircuts, stepping out of cabs and into venues while already playing, or continuing to blow into the small hours to long-departed audiences. Summoned to Britain in the 1960s to compose the score for the movie Alfie, Rollins arrived with a single stave of written music. When Ronnie Scott asked how the musicians should treat the work, Rollins replied, "Lightly."

Try as you might, it's hard to find anyone with a bad word to say about Rollins, and his modesty is as renowned as his achievements. One British publicist who accompanied him on an earlier trip here was astonished to discover that he refused meals in upmarket restaurants, talked mainly about his steady home life (he lives on a farm in Germantown, outside New York, with his wife, Lucille) and displayed an unexpectedly intimate familiarity with the plotline of EastEnders.

Some more of the stuff of legend: Rollins grew up with Thelonious Monk for a childhood friend, Miles Davis for one of his first bandleaders, and John Coltrane for a tenor-sax sparring partner. And though he no longer plays nightclubs or experiments as impulsively with his wardrobe, Rollins still produces a glow of awe with his worldwide performances. Now in his 70s, he will still play furious two-hour sets, whirling impulsively in and out of old songs he hasn't played for years. He has a perfect memory for music he has heard, however far back, and can haul it - intact or in bits - into the most headlong improvisations on the fly.

He was raised Theodore Walter Rollins in Harlem and its environs in the 1930s, with the most successful black musicians of the day - including Duke Ellington and Coleman Hawkins - living around the corner. Monk gave him lessons in harmony and unorthodox melody (by osmosis rather than formal instruction), and Davis was a regular partner between 1949 and 1954. From the late 1950s onwards, Rollins has almost always run his own show.

"I was the youngest of my siblings," he recalls of his Harlem childhood, in his deep, creaking drawl, "and I would often stay with my uncle and his girlfriend. She was from Georgia, so she liked all those country blues guys like Arthur Crudup and Lonnie Johnson - mostly guitar and vocals. But she also liked Louis Jordan. My older brother was a classical violinist and my sister played piano in church. But I liked jazz."

Jordan, a popular 1940s alto saxophonist influenced by jazz and rhythm and blues, is widely credited as a vital element in the chemistry that led to rock'n' roll. "I consider myself fortunate to have been born in Harlem then," Rollins says, "because it was always jumping with music. I remember Jordan performing in a venue on my way to elementary school. I implored my mother to get me a saxophone - I guess I was about nine. Then we moved to a more affluent area, Sugar Hill. It was where a lot of the successful black musicians and showbusiness people lived - Hawkins and Ellington, Jimmy Rushing, Red Allen. You saw them in the street, very glamorous people. They made a big impact on us."

In high school, Rollins led a group that included the fiery alto player Jackie McLean, pianist Kenny Drew and drummer Art Taylor. It was the kind of talented circle of enthusiastic young musicians that was bound to go places and, by the late 1940s, all of them were working with celebrities they had idolised from a distance such a short while before. Rollins rehearsed with his pianist neighbours Monk and Bud Powell during 1948, toying with new harmonic and structural ideas, and the following year began to work in clubs with Davis. He was starting to develop a characteristic sound: a mixture of the stately weightiness of Hawkins, the intensity and speed of Parker and the lyrical whimsicality of Lester Young.

But Rollins was also picking up some darker habits from the New York jazz scene - and, like Davis at much the same time, a blossoming career was suspended by the need to find the time, space and mental energy to combat the bebop scene's familiar temptation: hard drugs. "When I wanted to play jazz music as a little kid in Harlem, I didn't know anything about drugs," Rollins says. "I just had this spark to play from really early on, and I'm fortunate that I've never lost it. Writers like to associate drugs with the jazz scene, but that's nothing to do with it really. Drugs are part of the things we all have to deal with, the booby traps of living. If you take drugs or you drink whisky in the hope of elevating yourself, it may seem to be relevant to who you really are, but it isn't."

Rollins has wrestled with physical temptations a good deal in his life, and, from the 1960s tried to take exercise, control his eating and avoid the hellraising after-hours agenda of the stereo typical touring musician. He has also subjected himself to several long layoffs from music - to take on personal demons, study ways of becoming a better improviser, sidestep music-industry pressures and, for a while in the late 1960s, study Buddhism in the far east.

Rollins says these layoffs were, more often than not, "brought about by things in my life that weren't to do with music, about trying to survive as a human being. Underneath, they were all tied to the creative musical thing, of course. But when I studied in the east for two years around 1969, which was part of trying to deal with what seemed to me a hostile environment, I found it illuminated the real meaning of my musical life. I found I could see that part of myself much more clearly."

What does he mean by "hostile environment"? "Tribalism, competition. And of course, though I hate to always bring in race - and it can be overdone to the point where it doesn't mean anything - it's very hard growing up in a minority, an untouchable caste. You go through life wrapped in the skin of an untouchable, and you have to find some way to come to terms with it. I don't want to overstate this ..." (Rollins becomes briefly uncomfortable, as if he has overstepped some boundary related to his relaxed, freewheeling, onstage creative status.)

"I've been lucky enough to travel all over the world in my work and discover how much we all have in common. And the racial thing has perhaps prepared me to fight other demons. Being able to get away from my habits - drinking, smoking, overeating - prepared me in a sense for the colossal struggle of life. Music is my way of living - but I'm still striving for complete enlightenment, and getting to be a better person. That seems to me what life is about. We're not put here to eat ice cream, compete with each other, and then die. Life is a struggle. And when people ask if my social and class status as I was growing up were a handicap, I say they helped me. I believe in reincarnation. I've lived through other times and maybe it's helped me know certain things about right and wrong I didn't know in earlier lives."

Of all the famous jazz musicians who have preceded him, Rollins counts the troubled, ethereally gifted saxophonist Lester Young as perhaps the most affecting and significant of his idols. It becomes clear that Young's inner struggles, as well as his method of improvising, based on lighting endless new melodies on the fag-ends of preceding ones, are among the reasons for this empathy.

"To use one of his own expressions," Rollins says, "Lester Young was 'bruised by life'. Others were more like ordinary guys. Hawkins was very self-assured, but it didn't make him any less an artist. And some people show more bravado, although that isn't necessarily how they feel. People made a lot of Miles's habit of turning his back on the audience and all that, called it arrogant - but it came from shyness."

Who does he feel more akin to? "Lester Young," comes the answer after a pause. "There's a fine line between sensitivity and vulnerability, and a lot of people tread it, but for artists that's where their work comes from. But I don't want to make too much of this. If you have a conscience, and a consciousness, what you do is like a task, governed by that golden rule - do unto others as you would have them do unto you.

"I hope it's reflected in my music. I've never thought of music as a straight line: it's something ... else. It's an ideal out there, beyond you. Gee, Sonny's playing a long time, people sometimes say. But to me it just means there's something out there, and I know I have to find it. But it's just what I do. We're all footsoldiers, but it's never a drudgery to me. It's my joy."

fields.headline: Fischer perjury inquiry is dropped
fields.trailText: The controversy surrounding the radical past of the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, appeared to have run its course yesterday. Prosecutors announced that they were dropping the investigation into whether Mr Fischer lied in court.
fields.body:
The controversy surrounding the radical past of the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, appeared to have run its course yesterday. Prosecutors announced that they were dropping the investigation into whether Mr Fischer lied in court about his contacts with the urban guerrilla movement in the 1970s.

The deputy head of the prosecutors' office in Frankfurt, Petra Bertelsmeier, said there was no evidence to suggest that he had lied at the trial of a friend who turned to terrorism. She said many witnesses had supported that finding.

Mr Fischer's past came back to haunt him in January, shortly before the murder trial of his friend Hans-Joachim Klein began. Photographs were published showing Mr Fischer joining Klein in beating a policeman during a 1973 demonstration.

Mr Fischer said he had never tried to hide his past as a street-fighter. But, he argued, there was a difference between fighting the police with stones and terrorist violence.

His contention that he had rejected the "armed struggle" that those such as Klein had taken up was at the nub of the controversy that rumbled on for months. At the trial, the foreign minister denied providing accommodation to a woman who went on to join the terrorist Red Army Faction.

But he later said that it was possible that the woman, Margrit Schiller, had stayed in another part of the house in Frankfurt where he then lived.

The prosecutors' inquiry was criticised by the trial judge who said, both during and after the hearing, that the question concerning Ms Schiller had no bearing on the case.

Klein was charged with taking part in the 1975 raid on an Opec oil ministers' meeting in Vienna, in which three people died. He was convicted and sentenced to nine years in jail. Mr Fischer did not testify on oath, but under German law it is an offence to make false statements in unsworn testimony.

fields.headline: No-go for doctors in Paris suburbs
fields.trailText: Ever-mounting levels of suburban violence are turning France's big-city housing estates into no-go areas for ambulances, doctors and even dispensing chemists.
fields.body:
Ever-mounting levels of suburban violence are turning France's big-city housing estates into no-go areas for ambulances, doctors and even dispensing chemists, according to figures released yesterday.

Sparking fears that the trend will soon deprive those that most need it of even the most basic medical attention, the figures showed that 40% of chemists in the Paris suburbs suffered break-ins or hold-ups last year, and more than 15% of doctors were physically attacked - half of them in their consulting rooms.

"Youths have begun turning their attention from police, firemen and other uniformed representatives of the state to medical professionals," said a police official in Seine Saint-Denis north of Paris, where 50 armed attacks on pharmacies have been reported since January.

"It's a worrying development, not only for the medical professionals concerned but for the elderly and the unwell in these areas."

Last week ambulance crews took the exceptional step of boycotting the high-rise Pierre-Collinet estate outside the northern town of Meaux after their colleagues were subjected to a string of violent attacks - including one with teargas - in the past fortnight.

In Trappes, also just outside Paris, doctors now make their rounds accompanied by an armed policemen. One doctor in the run-down suburb of Val-Fourré has hired bodyguards from among the local unemployed, and the 120 doctors and specialists practising in Colombes have joined forces to equip their premises with steel shutters, closed-circuit TV and delayed-action locks between waiting room and surgery.

Patrick Zeitoun, head of the Paris region pharmacists' association, said not only had the number of attacks increased, the level of violence had too. "Drug addicts used to insult us because we wouldn't give them methadone without a prescription. Now they come armed with a shotgun."

fields.headline: EU ready to take hard line on Israel
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel is facing punitive measures from the EU because of hardening and widening opposition to its policies towards the Palestinians, diplomats said last night.
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Israel is facing punitive measures from the EU because of hardening and widening opposition to its policies towards the Palestinians, diplomats said last night.

Violence continued yesterday with a Palestinian boy killed at a funeral in Gaza and four injured in a car bomb explosion in Israel.

EU member states, including Britain, are now actively debating changing their approach to the Jewish state, with decisions expected at two key foreign ministers' meetings next month.

France is leading a campaign to suspend Israel's prized association agreement with the EU, which gives it preferential trade terms worth millions of dollars.

A more likely result will be a crackdown on Israel's flouting of EU "rules of origin" under which goods produced in occupied territories have been illegally benefiting from duty free access.

The EU is also likely to cold -shoulder Israeli attempts to secure enhanced cooperation in science and technology.

In the latest in a series of signals that it cannot be business as usual with the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, Brussels last week issued an angry condemnation of Israeli attacks on both Syria and Palestinians in Gaza.

Israel has insisted that the statement was one-sided, and warned that the EU is in danger of losing what little influence it has.

Romano Prodi, the president of the European commission, and Chris Patten, external relations commissioner, are being targeted by Israel to persuade them to adopt a softer line.

In the past Israel has been defended in the EU by traditional friends such as the Netherlands, Sweden and Britain, but it now has few defenders left, even in Germany, where public opinion wants to see action.

The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, yesterday met the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, in the West Bank town, Ramallah. Mr Michel, whose government is next in line for the European presidency, angered the Israeli government two months ago by threatening EU sanctions.

In a significant development, Mr Arafat said afterwards: "I want to be very clear. We are against any operation targeting civilians, whether they are Israelis or Palestinians."

Israeli army radio said it had been the first condemnation by the Palestinian leader since the uprising began in September.

The Israeli government also took a tentative step towards renewing the peace process, but there was little optimism on either side.

Mr Sharon's government yesterday said it was still considering a Jordanian-Egyptian peace plan under which Israel would lift its economic embargo of the West Bank and Gaza in return for the Palestinians ending their attacks on Israel and Jewish settlements.

Violence continued yesterday with a Palestinian boy killed at a funeral in Gaza and four injured in a car bomb explosion in Israel. EU member states, including Britain, are now actively debating changing their approach to the Jewish state, with decisions expected at two key foreign ministers' meetings next month. France is leading a campaign to suspend Israel's prized association agreement with the EU, which gives it preferential trade terms worth millions of dollars. A more likely result will be a crackdown on Israel's flouting of EU "rules of origin" under which goods produced in occupied territories have been illegally benefiting from duty free access. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: US blocks Aegis sale to Taiwan
fields.body:
US blocks Aegis sale to Taiwan

The US defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, has advised Washington against selling Aegis-equipped destroyers to Taiwan, and recommended the less technically advanced Kidd-class. President Bush is expected to accept the advice, officials said. AP, Washington

Gunmen end Turk hotel siege

After holding 120 hostages overnight in an Istanbul hotel, 13 men surrendered to the police yesterday. No one was hurt in the 12-hour standoff.

The men agreed to surrender after the Turkish interior minister, Saadetti Tantan, held talks with them. The men were apparently led by Muhammed Tokcan, who hijacked a Turkish Black Sea ferry in 1996 to try to force Russia to stop its assaults on Chechens. AP, Istanbul

Secret agent jailed in Russia

A Moscow court has jailed a former Russian intelligence officer for 7 years for passing secrets to Britain and Estonia.

Valery Oyamaye was recruited in the Estonian capital, Tallinn, by a British diplomat. Agencies, Moscow

Kansas tornado ravages town

A tornado caused havoc in a small Kansas town on Saturday night, ripping the roof off a hospital, lifting cars into trees and leaving hundreds of people in Hoisington homeless.

One person died and at least 26 others were hurt, three seriously, when the tornado ripped through the town of 3,000 people at 9.15pm. AP, Hoisington

S African Aids boy, 12, robbed

Three robbers broke into the bedroom of a 12-year-old Aids sufferer, Nkosi Johnson, held his nurse at gunpoint and ransacked their home in Melville, Johannesburg, yesterday.

Nkosi became famous in South Africa after criticising President Thabo Mbeki's policies at an international Aids conference last year. The boy is semi-comatose, said his foster mother, Gail Johnson. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

German nuclear protesters held

The German police detained 13 activists who chained themselves to railway lines in Mannheim yesterday in an attempt to halt atomic waste containers destined for Sellafield in Britain.

About 500 protesters gathered near the Neckarwestheim nuclear power station in Baden-Württemberg state on Sunday. Germany had suspended dealings with Sellafield after a scandal over operations at the plant last year. AP, Mannheim

webTitle: Mbeki in thrall to fear and suspicion

fields.headline: Mbeki in thrall to fear and suspicion
fields.standfirst: Conspiracy theories and allegations about private life add to South African leader's resistance to criticism
fields.trailText: The South African security minister's claim that the police are investigating plots in the African National Congress to "physically harm" president Thabo Mbeki and remove him from power has been almost universally dismissed as nonsense.
fields.body:
The South African security minister's claim that the police are investigating plots in the African National Congress to "physically harm" president Thabo Mbeki and remove him from power has been almost universally dismissed as nonsense.

But unlikely though Steve Tshwete's assertion to a Johannesburg Sunday newspaper may be, it revealed a deeper and more disturbing truth about the South African presidency; it is consumed by suspicion of even well-founded criticism and fear of a challenge to Mr Mbeki's leadership.

The allegation even prompted a bizarre and unexpected denial by the deputy president, Jacob Zuma, that he is trying to oust Mr Mbeki. But disenchantment in the ANC has led to a secret pamphlet from one branch of the party calling for Mr Mbeki to be a "one-term president".

Mr Tshwete told the Johannesburg Sunday Times that police intelligence units were investigating alleged "plots" against the president from high inside the party. The impression left is that there is a threat to Mr Mbeki's safety.

Mr Tshwete told the paper: "As the state department charged with protecting the safety and security of this country, we have to ensure that these plots do not culminate into something ugly. As far back as last year, we picked up clandestine activities involving certain individuals and we are monitoring this on a day-to-day basis to ensure that the president is safe."

But few in the ANC believe that there is a serious threat to Mr Mbeki's safety. Rather, Mr Tshwete's comments are read as a warning to anyone who may think of challenging the president's leadership at the party congress next year that they are under surveillance.

Mr Mbeki came to power nearly two years ago, heralded as an able technocrat with grand plans for Africa's renaissance. But his presidency has been marked by perpetual crises and growing questions about his judgment as reflected in the calibre of those he has chosen to surround himself with and bizarre allegations, such as his claim that there was a CIA plot to destabilise him because he was a threat to the international economic order.

Mr Mbeki's sensitivity to criticism has grown as the ANC allies, such as the trade unions, have become increasingly prepared to chastise the government publicly for its handling of issues such as Aids and Zimbabwe.

It has been increased by the public airing of allegations about his personal life.Stories of his alleged womanising have been circulating inside the ANC for months. They are now discussed in newspapers and on the radio.

Three weeks ago the ANC's national executive committee met to discuss the alleged plots against Mr Mbeki. Among the matters of concern was the circulation inside the party of the pamphlet calling for "one president, one term".

The document is believed to have originated in the ANC branch in North West province. The regional premier, Popo Molefe, has denied any knowledge of the pamphlet, but he is known to be among the party leaders most disenchanted with Mr Mbeki.

Then, a few days after the national executive meeting, Mr Zuma issued his unexpected denial that he was after his boss's job.

"We have been aware of some elements in various guises who have been trying to isolate the president by creating the impression that some of his trusted comrades are plotting against him," he said.

"It is clear that as we move towards the national conference of the ANC, less than two years from now, these faceless forces that have a presence in various places and levels of our society are working harder to create confusion among our members and mislead the country in general."

Mr Zuma's statement was probably prompted by a party leak last year accusing him of being at the forefront of another "plot" against the president. Shortly afterwards an ANC official delivered a file of unsubstantiated allegations against Mr Zuma to a Johannesburg daily newspaper.

Months earlier, similar accusations of conspiring against Mr Mbeki were levelled against Cyril Ramaphosa, the former union leader who was in the running to succeed Nelson Mandela.

The alleged plots are not confined to the ANC, or even South Africa.

Last month the party's secretary general, Thenjiwe Mthintso, claimed that the European Union and governments in the developed world had mounted their own campaign to discredit Mr Mbeki.

She said that criticism of his policies on Zimbabwe and Aids were used as "entry points to discredit the president - they wish to prove that the ANC is incapable of leading ... [that] Africans are not capable".

Sceptics wonder whether South Africa is that high up the agenda in Washington, Whitehall or Brussels. More to the point, Mr Mbeki's economic policies could not be more pleasing to the west.

But nothing has fed suspicion as much as the public airing of allegations about the president's personal life.

Stories about Mr Mbeki's alleged philandering have been circulating in the establishment for years. But a renowned South African journalist, Max du Preez, gave them wider currency on a radio discussion programme.

Mr Du Preez was a vigorous and brave opponent of apartheid who, as editor of a weekly Afrikaans magazine, exposed the white regime's death squads. The point he made on the radio was that there has been so much discussion about Mr Mbeki's personal life in the ruling party that it had become of political significance, because it affected how the country was governed.

Winnie's letter

"This issue has been discussed, it is the hot topic of gossip in black high society, the political elite, journalists know about it, his whole security establishment know and talk about it and is concerned about it," he said.

"Should we again be a little group of elite who knows this side of our president like happened in the past? We all knew about the previous [apartheid-era] cabinet and didn't talk about it."

The allegations about Mr Mbeki's personal life first surfaced publicly in a letter from Winnie Madikizela-Mandela to the South African deputy president, repeating a number of specific charges.

"The facts, as I discovered upon investigation, were that these rumours had been making the rounds in Luthuli House [ANC headquarters] for some time," she wrote.

But while the ANC made no comment on Mrs Madikizela-Mandela's letter, it denounced Mr Du Preez as a racist, a "commissar for apartheid", and declared "war" on him.

"The ANC has learned that among some sections in our society respect and dignity is accorded only to those with a certain type of pigmentation and being black and powerful qualifies one to be the recipient of a barrage of insults and abuse," Mr Mbeki's spokesman, Smuts Ngonyama, said.

The party even suggested introducing a new, and almost certainly unconstitutional, law against defaming the president. What it did not do was to deny the that allegations were true.

"It does indicate a certain mentality that I thought only existed in Zimbabwe," said Mr Du Preez.

"Clearly, in the ANC's reaction, they are again confusing the interests of the party with the interests of the state."

fields.headline: Ukrainian MPs prepare to sack prime minister
fields.trailText: Ukraine's worst political crisis since independence seems certain to lead to the collapse of Viktor Yushchenko's government this week.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow, and agencies
fields.body:
Ukraine's worst political crisis since independence seems certain to lead to the collapse of Viktor Yushchenko's government this week.

After a week of backroom plotting, MPs said yesterday that they would call for a vote of no-confidence in the government today.

Since a resolution condemning the government's policies was was carried by 283 votes to 65 last week, there is little doubt that the MPs will vote to bring down Mr Yushchenko, despite his public popularity.

But President Leonid Kuchma told reporters during a visit to Lithuania yesterday that he would do what he could to help work out a compromise between the government and parliament.

For the past six months Ukraine has been rocked by street protests, violence, and political sackings as President Kuchma confronted allegations that he ordered the murder of an opposition journalist, Georgiy Gongadze, and rigged elections.

As the crisis has deepened, Mr Yushchenko, who was appointed by Mr Kuchma and was once his ally, has emerged as a potential rival for the presidency should Mr Kuchma ultimately bow to the pressure and resign.

Mr Yushchenko and the former deputy prime minister Yuliya Tymoshenko are becoming the most formidable alternatives to the hardline Mr Kuchma.

Ms Tymoshenko was sacked in January and investigated for embezzlement, and has spent weeks alternating between hospital and prison, turning her into an anti-Kuchma martyr.

Mr Yushchenko, a former central banker, is the sole remaining figure of substance in Kiev to enjoy the support of the west, and his departure will be taken as a strong signal that Ukraine, after years of seeking to edge out of the post-Soviet orbit and into Nato's central European embrace, is sidling back into a Moscow alliance.

In recent months Mr Kuchma and President Vladimir Putin of Russia have intensified contacts and increased cooperation.

The EU's foreign policy supremos, Chris Patten and Javier Solana, have been alarmed by the situation in Ukraine during recent visits to Kiev, and frustrated in their attempts to bring pressure to bear on Mr Kuchma.

Later this week the Council of Europe, whose human rights committee has denounced political repression and persistent human rights abuses in Ukraine, will debate the committee's call for its expulsion. If carried, it will be the first expulsion in the council's 51-year history, and a blow to Ukrainian pride.

Mr Kuchma has hitherto distanced himself from the battle to decide Mr Yushchenko's fate, leaving it to the communists who dominate parliament and oppose Mr Yushchenko's reforms to call the no-confidence vote.

Mr Yushchenko's dismissal has the support of several smaller parties run by influential industrialists who, like their Russian counterparts, have become immensely rich and fear that Mr Yushchenko's economic reforms will jeopardise their control of key industries.

The vote could bring further street clashes between the security forces and the tens of thousands calling for the president's resignation or impeachment for Gongadze's murder.

Clandestine recordings of conversations in the presidential office, tapes which Mr Kuchma says have been doctored, show the president requesting action against Gongadze and ordering close aides to deliver the vote in the poll for his second term.

About 3,000 protesters rallied outside parliament last week in support of Mr Yushchenko, and bigger protests are expected this week.

The prime minister appears to be calculating that his political prospects will be enhanced by cutting his ties with the Kuchma regime and spearheading the opposition.

fields.headline: Winds of change
fields.standfirst: Cheshire
fields.trailText: Cheshire.
fields.body:
"In these busy weeks a country diary is apt to become some sort of catalogue", and while there have been many changes in the Cheshire landscape since A W Boyd wrote this introduction to his diary notes of 10 April 1936, the arrival of spring is still a time of hectic activity and full notebooks.

Even the lingering threat of foot and mouth disease cannot halt the return of our migrant birds from south of the Sahara, nor the sudden awakening of the spring butterflies from their long hibernation, or the daily appearance of another colony of bright flowers to transform the countryside. The frustration of not being able to witness the arrival of a new spring in those favourite corners of the valley has been somewhat relieved by the decision of the National Trust to open some carefully selected sites in time for the Easter weekend, which included the riverside path from the mill through the southern woods.

The effect of a two-month closure has been immediately obvious: gone are the ugly scars of the continually over-trodden paths; the spring vegetation has been free to spread at will on to previously barren soil, softening the whole appearance of the wood. The real herald of spring has to be the chiff chaff - usually the first of our returning summer visitors - who, having flown all the way from southern Europe, has now added its cheerful, repetitive song to the ever-growing woodland dawn chorus. I heard my first new arrival on the 30th March in a small roadside copse about a mile outside the village. The persistent northerly weather has slowed down much of the spring migration, but a warm southerly wind will open the floodgates.

fields.headline: No 1,865
fields.standfirst: Michael Howard
fields.trailText: Michael Howard.
fields.body:
I thought he was dead. Just resting. He still comes out after sunset when the mood takes him.

Something of the night about him? Look, that was a misunderstanding. What Ann Widdecombe meant was that her former Home Office chief deserved a knighthood.

webTitle: Rory Carroll on mafiosi Bernardo Provenzano

fields.headline: Gangster No 1
fields.standfirst: For 37 years, mafiosi Bernardo Provenzano has been on the run, masterminding the ruthless activities of the Cosa Nostra from safehouses in the Sicilian mountains. But finally the net is beginning to tighten around the man they call the Accountant.  Rory Carroll  reports
fields.trailText: For 37 years, mafiosi Bernardo Provenzano has been on the run, masterminding the ruthless activities of the Cosa Nostra from safehouses in the Sicilian mountains. But finally the net is beginning to tighten around the man they call the Accountant. Rory Carroll reports.
fields.body:
For a supposedly stupid man, Bernardo Provenzano chose a fine day to go on the run. He vanished into hills baked brown and hard, perfect for hiking, with a breeze to cool the sun. There was the occasional shepherd to break the loneliness among citrus trees and olive groves. It was September 18 1963.

Dozens of people were being shot, bludgeoned, strangled, sliced and drowned in the mafia war ravaging Sicily. In Corleone the graveyard was smack in the centre of town, and Provenzano did his bit to fill it. Wherever he passed, people were cut down - so they called him the Tractor.

"He shoots like an angel but has the brains of a chicken," said his boss, and Provenzano seemed to fit the bill: a peasant's son who had left school aged 10, he was chunky, taciturn and slow. Some said he killed too many, others that he killed not enough. Either way, there were enough enemies made and left alive to threaten Provenzano, so he fled.

To survive on the run required cunning, as betrayal came with a smile. Many Corleone fugitives never returned from the hills. Their bones would turn up, if at all, years later under a plough. It seemed only a matter of time before Provenzano's corpse became a footnote in the history of Cosa Nostra. But now, 37 years later, the police are still looking for him.

In the meantime, Bernardo Provenzano has come far. While eluding an army of pursuers, Italy's most wanted man has climbed to the top of the Cosa Nostra. He is still in the hills, which now bristle with electronic listening equipment, roadblocks and spies. Helicopters, dawn raids of farmhouses, reward money: the state has tried them all, and failed.

Beneath the concrete arches at the entrance to Palermo's justice ministry lounge Carabinieri police officers. Submachine guns dangle from shoulders, eyes swivel at newcomers passing through electronic scanners. From this fortress, magistrates have battled the mafia for decades. In theory, they are safe here from assassins' bombs and bullets.

By 9pm corridors are deserted, but behind oak doors some magistrates remain, hunched over documents and computers, murmuring into phones and filling ashtrays. They feel close to success. They think the near-mythical godfather, the strategist who rescued the mafia from catastrophe and rebuilt it in his image, is near capture.

One by one, Provenzano's lieutenants have been snared in recent months and Pier Luigi Vigna, Italy's national anti-mafia prosecutor, is bullish: "We are close to the capture of Provenzano."

The country hopes so. Under Provenzano, now 68, the mafia has become leaner, fitter and slyer, returning to its roots while innovating new crimes. Belatedly, the penny has dropped: the Tractor is highly intelligent, shrewd and calculating. He has a new nickname - il Ragioniere - the Accountant.

The last-known photo was taken in 1959: a serious youth with brilliantined hair wearing a suit for a saint's festival. Today, say informers, he is frail and bald, save for white tufts above his ears. They say his skin is the colour of milk from consecutive months in boltholes.

"Provenzano is extremely powerful and extremely dangerous. He is in contact with all the clans and calls the shots," says Giuseppe Cipriani, the mayor of Corleone. Police believe he spends most of his time in western and central Sicily, flitting to safe houses in an endless game of cat and mouse.

From some snow-capped peaks, ferries can be seen trailing foam from the capital, Palermo. Provenzano - known as Binnu to friends - shuns telephones and faxes as too risky. His empire is run through cryptic, handwritten notes transported by key aides. There are occasional visits and very occasional summits with clan leaders, but otherwise the godfather is a hermit. Or a ghost. So low did he lie that for years investigators thought he was dead.

The one fixed reference point is his family. After several years abroad, thought to be Germany or Switzerland, his wife, Saveria, and sons Angelo, 25, and Paolo, 20, moved back to Corleone in April 1992.

Four letters to the godfather were intercepted by police in January, yielding gossip about business, health, relationships and advice to wash socks in cold water. "My beloved sweetheart," Saveria called him. She also promised to send a fleece jacket and snow trousers. Cue a police stampede to the frozen slopes of Mount Cammarata. No Binnu.

Ever since it gave its name to Mario Puzo's fictional godfather, fact and fiction have collided in the cobbled alleys of Corleone. Perched high, 60km south of Palermo, it is from here that the Cosa Nostra spread mayhem and bloodlust across Sicily.

It is not difficult to find Saveria, now in her late 50s. She lives in a four-storey block above a car dealer's shop. Below the bell, in small black letters: Provenzano. Beside the bell: an entryphone. There is a long pause before the adult female voice answers. "You want a chat?" I ask. Laughter. "No, no, nothing to say. Bye bye." Another three rings elicit only silence.

Less than a mile away, in Piazza Santa Maria, is the family's latest enterprise: a launderette named Splend-Or. The last two letters are in gold, a pun since or is Italian for gold. Fiddling the switches of a giant red washer-drier is a tubby, handsome man wearing rimless glasses, jeans, jumper and check shirt: Angelo. He looks astonished to be asked for an interview, but recovers swiftly. "Thanks but no thanks, I'm not interested." Pressed, he repeats the formula three times.

In one of the intercepted letters, he complained of the laundry business being slack. According to a group of teenage girls, that was because he charged twice that of his only rival, Pinguini. "A pity, he's very cute," said one.

Provenzano's rise is encrusted with myth, but some things are known. Born to peasants, he and his friend Toto Riina became assassins for a rising boss, Luciano Liggio. Pumping 112 bullets into the black Fiat containing, Michele Navarra, a rival in Corleone, established them as the trinity of terror by 1958. They then moved down the valley to take on the Palermo clans, unleashing a war of extermination in which Provenzano was convicted in absentia of multiple murders.

By the 80s, Riina was the undisputed boss of bosses, with Provenzano as his deputy. It was a path to dictatorship paved with 800 corpses, and very much a double-act, says Roberto Scarpinato, a leading anti-mafia magistrate. "Riina was the military boss, Provenzano the businessman."

A skilled mediator, Provenzano persuaded clans to restructure, ditching a pyramidal hierarchy for a cell-type system where no one was to know more than two other mobsters. When someone was arrested, or turned informer, the damage could be contained. "Binnu was the tugboat who towed us to safety," one informer reportedly said.

Strategy was changed. Cosa Nostra melted back into the shadows, resolving internal disputes peacefully, where possible, and no longer challenging the state. It concentrated on infiltrating public-work contracts, racketeering and smuggling. The result was quiet, lucrative days for the mafia, said the former mayor of Palermo, Leoluca Orlando.

The Accountant has approved forays into electronic and internet fraud. Profits are recycled into legitimate ventures, especially construction, waste-disposal and retailing. But according to Lucio Violante, speaker of the senate, the biggest scam is yet to come. "In the next six years there will be L16,600bn (£5.3bn) invested in the Sicilian region. Do we want a Sicily in which the economic power ends up in the hands of Cosa Nostra?"

Hundreds of police, sometimes thousands, comb an area no bigger than 200sq miles. They cannot pass through the smallest hamlet without being noted by a Provenzano spy. Sting after sting has failed, for their prey is said to have the instincts of a wild animal. "He can smell danger," said one detective.

The godfather sends lieutenants to appointments and drops in on colleagues when not expected. His self-discipline is said to be awesome. "He can stay in a room for six months without poking his nose out," said the detective.

Botched operations have been blamed on squabbling between law-enforcement agencies. Some suspect Provenzano has an informer of his own. Generations of police officers have come and gone, predicting his imminent capture. But his time may be running out. Jailed bosses, desperate to improve harsh conditions, are negotiating with prosecutors. Handing over Binnu could be an ace.

Provenzano has become dispensable, a liability even. Under his command, a new generation of university-educated, sophisticated bosses have emerged. Power is devolved. "Provenzano is no dictator; he is a mediator. He builds consensus, but he doesn't control everything," says Scarpinato.

Thanks to Provenzano's reforms, Cosa Nostra is flexible and versatile. Though he is still the boss, the organisation's future is no longer entwined with his. Were he to be caught tonight, it would sail on, say magistrates.

Italy's fascination with the Accountant, and the government's decision to stake credibility on catching him, risks pushing the mafia back into the limelight. His arrest would suit everyone. The odds are turning against him, and now we will find out just how smart is Bernardo Provenzano.

webTitle: Tim Parks on his beloved Hella Verona

fields.headline: The Pastor and the Pope
fields.standfirst: Hellas fans loathe their president. But, says our man in the stands, his connections in high places could deliver the miracle that saves the club from relegation
fields.trailText: Hellas Verona fans loathe their president. But, says our man in the stands Tim Parks, his connections in high places could deliver the miracle that saves the club from relegation.
fields.body:
"No, I've no idea why they hate me so much." Behind his desk in the club's luxurious new offices, Giambattista Pastorello is taking a painkiller for his sciatica. "Though the best cure," he admits with a bitter smile, "would be a win or two."

Tall and stiff, white beard too neatly trimmed, thick hair too stylishly coiffed, Pastorello is the presidente of Hellas Verona. The most common chorus at the end of last year's games, sung to the tune of an old grandfather clock chiming the hour, went very simply like this: "PAS-TOR-EL-LO, VAF-FAN-CU-LO."

"When I bought the team we were in Serie B," Pastorello says shaking his head. "The following year we won the division. Last season we finish 10th in Serie A. Why should they hate me?"

I field a few ideas: because he tends to get players on loan for a year rather than buy them. The fans feel they have no loyalty to the club. Because when he does own a good player he sells him the moment some other team shows interest.

Pastorello sighs. "These are the realities of provincial football. The big seven clubs run a deficit ranging from 50 to 130bn lire a year. I can't afford to do that. I can't put success on the pitch before a healthy balance sheet. The fans can't hate me for that."

But they do hate him.

"I loath Pastorello," someone calling himself Lo Scaligero writes to the Hellas website, "almost as much as I hate the Neapolitans." These are strong words. The Scaligeri were the family who ruled an independent and prosperous Verona in the late 13th and early 14th centuries. To call yourself Lo Scaligero is nostalgia on a grand scale. It was a time when Neapolitans weren't even known to be loathed.

Pastorello's disastrous relationship with the Verona fans came to a head at the end of last season. With huge banners telling him to fuck off, he decided to do just that. The club had finished the season with the right to play for a place in Europe. Il presidente renounced that right, sold half the team and put the club up for sale. "I'd had enough," he tells me, "I couldn't bear it."

Again the move didn't win him any friends. The greatest of the Scaligeri family was the so-called Can de la Scala - Dog of the Ladder. Though he died in 1329, in early September of 2000 his namesake was alive and well and writing to Hellas Verona: "Hellas isn't your (shitty) company, Pastorello. It's us who suffer every time the Bentegodi's gates swing open. Hellas is a feeling, it's a faith. Not a cheque to stick in your filthy wallet."

The nicknames and the rhetoric suggest the truth of the matter. For the fans, football is a re-enactment of medieval rival ries, city against city, Scaligeri versus Visconti, Medici versus Sforza. It's a scenario that puts the presidente in a role unimaginable in British football. For what the fans demand of Agnelli in Turin, Berlusconi in Milan, and even of Pastorello in Verona, is that they play the part of Can de la Scala, or Lorenzo the Magnificent. And these great men didn't sell out their dynasties from one day to the next.

But nor did Pastorello sell Hellas Verona. For it soon turned out that nobody wanted to buy it. Like a husband with his bags packed who realises he can't afford the divorce, il presidente was stuck with us and we with him.

"The strange thing is," he suddenly leans toward me across his big desk, "that after months of being attacked and slandered, you know, the moment I announced I was selling up, it all stopped. The vaffanculos stopped. All of a sudden people are telling me, 'Giambattista, you have to stay, only you can save the club.'" He sits back, perplexed. "Go figure."

Actually it's not hard to figure at all. Alongside the hate messages, the constant accusations that he's come to Verona to take our money rather than bring us glory, another kind of rumour constantly revolves around Pastorello.

"Did you see the Pope's sports jubilee game," my barman says to a customer last November. "El Pastor was there! He kissed Wojtyla's hand!"

Ironically, they call Pastorello, El Pastor - the shepherd. "Let's hope the Madonna gives us a penalty or two," is the client's wry reply.

"Good morning, kids," someone called Martino opens the website chat on March 29 at 7am. "Listen, yesterday evening, during Italy-Lithuania, sitting beside Petrucci, did I really catch a glimpse of ... El Pastor????"

Petrucci is head of the Federcalcio, the football league. A very important person. Shortly afterward confirmation arrives from il Bandito: "Yep, you saw right, our mythical shepherd is weaving his wicked webs and scheming his clever schemes to save us from relegation and get us right back into Uefa next year."

Rightly or wrongly, the fans are convinced that football is not fair in Italy and that political clout is essential if a small provincial team isn't to disappear from the face of the map. Like a tiny dukedom in the middle ages, the only way to survive is through a network of unspoken, perhaps unspeakable alliances. So the boys loathe Pastorello because, to them, he represents the last word in modern mercenary football. On the other hand, they deeply respect Pastorello because he has friends in high places. "Refereeing decisions have much improved since Pastorello came," Verona's deputy mayor tells me over a beer.

Can it be true? I stand on the terraces of the Bentegodi to watch the annual hate match with Juventus, political power incarnate. "You're slaves of Agnelli," the Curva Sud is taunting the Juve fans. Italian fans are always aware of the money and influence of the opposing team's owner. "Juve ladro," they shriek. Thief!

The game is scrappy. Juventus are all grim energy and zero inspiration. If anything we look slightly better. The referee, a certain Signor Rodomonti is a ref Juventus have never lost with. Nine points adrift of Roma, the Turin team must win today to keep the championship alive. And they do, courtesy of a penalty, very late in first-half injury time, and the decision to disallow a Verona goal in the second half, because the ball might have gone a whisker over the touchline. The video is not convincing. The linesman's flag wasn't raised until after the goal was scored.

But it's not these incidents that convince you that a provincial team really does need a presidente with political contacts. It's the whole drift of the refereeing. Anyone looking for an explanation as to why the big Italian teams did so poorly in Europe would have done well to see this game where the Turin celebrities were treated with extraordinary leniency while the also-rans took all the yellow cards, until of course our central defender was sent off. The most eloquent match report I've seen appeared in chalk on a cement wall only minutes after the game: "Verona 0 Rodomonti 1." Time for Pastorello to get on the plane to Rome.

 This column appears fortnightly. Tim Parks is writing a book about following Hellas Verona. A Season with Verona will be published by Secker & Warburg in March 2002.

The greatest of the Scaligeri family was the so-called Can de la Scala - Dog of the Ladder. Though he died in 1329, in early September of 2000 his namesake was alive and well and writing to Hellas Verona: "Hellas isn't your (shitty) company, Pastorello. It's us who suffer every time the Bentegodi's gates swing open. Hellas is a feeling, it's a faith. Not a cheque to stick in your filthy wallet." The nicknames and the rhetoric suggest the truth of the matter. For the fans, football is a re-enactment of medieval rival ries, city against city, Scaligeri versus Visconti, Medici versus Sforza. It's a scenario that puts the presidente in a role unimaginable in British football. For what the fans demand of Agnelli in Turin, Berlusconi in Milan, and even of Pastorello in Verona, is that they play the part of Can de la Scala, or Lorenzo the Magnificent. And these great men didn't sell out their dynasties from one day to the next. But nor did Pastorello sell Hellas Verona. For it soon turned out that nobody wanted to buy it. Like a husband with his bags packed who realises he can't afford the divorce, il presidente was stuck with us and we with him. "The strange thing is," he suddenly leans toward me across his big desk, "that after months of being attacked and slandered, you know, the moment I announced I was selling up, it all stopped. The vaffanculos stopped. All of a sudden people are telling me, 'Giambattista, you have to stay, only you can save the club.'" He sits back, perplexed. "Go figure." Actually it's not hard to figure at all. Alongside the hate messages, the constant accusations that he's come to Verona to take our money rather than bring us glory, another kind of rumour constantly revolves around Pastorello. "Did you see the Pope's sports jubilee game," my barman says to a customer last November. "El Pastor was there! He kissed Wojtyla's hand!" Ironically, they call Pastorello, El Pastor - the shepherd. "Let's hope the Madonna gives us a penalty or two," is the client's wry reply. "Good morning, kids," someone called Martino opens the website chat on March 29 at 7am. "Listen, yesterday evening, during Italy-Lithuania, sitting beside Petrucci, did I really catch a glimpse of ... El Pastor????" Petrucci is head of the Federcalcio, the football league. A very important person. Shortly afterward confirmation arrives from il Bandito: "Yep, you saw right, our mythical shepherd is weaving his wicked webs and scheming his clever schemes to save us from relegation and get us right back into Uefa next year." Rightly or wrongly, the fans are convinced that football is not fair in Italy and that political clout is essential if a small provincial team isn't to disappear from the face of the map. Like a tiny dukedom in the middle ages, the only way to survive is through a network of unspoken, perhaps unspeakable alliances. So the boys loathe Pastorello because, to them, he represents the last word in modern mercenary football. On the other hand, they deeply respect Pastorello because he has friends in high places. "Refereeing decisions have much improved since Pastorello came," Verona's deputy mayor tells me over a beer. Can it be true? I stand on the terraces of the Bentegodi to watch the annual hate match with Juventus, political power incarnate. "You're slaves of Agnelli," the Curva Sud is taunting the Juve fans. Italian fans are always aware of the money and influence of the opposing team's owner. "Juve ladro," they shriek. Thief! The game is scrappy. Juventus are all grim energy and zero inspiration. If anything we look slightly better. The referee, a certain Signor Rodomonti is a ref Juventus have never lost with. Nine points adrift of Roma, the Turin team must win today to keep the championship alive. And they do, courtesy of a penalty, very late in first-half injury time, and the decision to disallow a Verona goal in the second half, because the ball might have gone a whisker over the touchline. The video is not convincing. The linesman's flag wasn't raised until after the goal was scored. But it's not these incidents that convince you that a provincial team really does need a presidente with political contacts. It's the whole drift of the refereeing. Anyone looking for an explanation as to why the big Italian teams did so poorly in Europe would have done well to see this game where the Turin celebrities were treated with extraordinary leniency while the also-rans took all the yellow cards, until of course our central defender was sent off. The most eloquent match report I've seen appeared in chalk on a cement wall only minutes after the game: "Verona 0 Rodomonti 1." Time for Pastorello to get on the plane to Rome.  This column appears fortnightly. Tim Parks is writing a book about following Hellas Verona. A Season with Verona will be published by Secker & Warburg in March 2002. Useful link Tim Parks' website

fields.headline: Take five
fields.standfirst: The daily news quiz
fields.trailText: The daily news quiz.
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. All you have to do is come up with each day's answers, then send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders.

(c) Yelpie

(d) Fang

(a) Snoop Doggy Dogg

(b) Nate Dogg

(c) Lil' Bow Wow

(d) Golden Retriever

(a) Goldie

(b) Bonnie

(c) Petra

(d) Percy Thrower

B4 Lassie rescued blonde children from

(a) The Ooze

(b) Jellyfish

fields.headline: As good as it gets
fields.trailText: Perfect | The Strange Case of Peking Man | Bob Martin | Hollywood Greats
fields.body:
Princess Anne was marrying Timothy Laurence at Crathie Church. It was all a bit on the quiet side. Not, however, quiet enough. One of those woman who watch weddings observed loudly: "I think she's crazy tae get rid of one and tak on another. I wouldna."

Such Scottish prudence would not suit Julie in Perfect (ITV) who, by half time, had married two sailors and three interchangeably nice blokes without the formality of divorce. Sequentially, of course. Not all at once.

Unusually, this was not played for comedy or tragedy but as a rather tender fantasy. I was not astounded to hear that the writer, Susan Oudot, was the fiction editor of Woman's Own but she has a nice, light, skimming touch, imitated by the hand-held camera. Sheer speed kept it fresh and airborne. Michelle Collins is always decoratively deft as a bedraggled bird taking flight and she has strong support, notably from Cathy Tyson. It didn't feel like an hour and a half. A second helping next week.

In The Strange Case of Peking Man (Channel 4) Dr Wang Tao of London University and Davidson Black IV, a nice Canadian lad known as Dave to his friends (and not, as you might expect, Dave, Dave, Dave, Dave) embarked on one of those endearingly doomed attempts to find the 500,000 year old bones of Peking Man, which vanished mysteriously during the second world war. He was widely believed to be the missing link, having protruding brows on which you could rest a pencil, very handy if you're a builder. The Chinese, who respect their ancestors whatever they look like, were tremendously proud of him.

When the Japanese were about to occupy Peking, arrangements were made to smuggle the bones to America. The only suggestion that they reached there lay in a lively encounter between Christopher Janus, a rich amateur anthropologist, and a mysterious widow on top of the Empire State Building. Janus, now 90, recounted it with gusto. She had read of his search for the bones in The New York Times and rang to say she had them. On the Empire State she took a picture of some bones from her handbag, dickered over the price, saying her husband believed they were worth a million dollars, and fled when she thought Japanese tourists were taking pictures of her. Which, of course, they were. This was a fishy little mystery in itself.

It was a desperate search for disappearing evidence. Beijing is being rebuilt ("That is the world's largest shopping mall") and witnesses were in their nineties. Professor Jia Lanpo described the Japanese invaders in touching translation: "If they found food they ate them. If they found drink they drank them." If they found two boxes of carefully wrapped bones - who knows? Emperor Hirohito was always a strong suspect in Chinese eyes. Dave and the doctor approached the Imperial Palace and got an imperious brush-off. The air shimmered with Chinese-Japanese hostility.

If I had been entrusted with a box of bones during a blitzkreig, I think I would have buried them in a cemetery with a gravestone to indicate, gravely, that here lay a very old man. But then, I have read Edgar Allan Poe.

Bobby Davro has inherited Des O'Connor's title as Chief Tease. The Big Brother household, you remember, were given a Bobby Davro video as a punishment. Bobby himself, a rare sighting like the lesser tit, was a guest star on Bob Martin (ITV), the downbeat quiz show hosted by Michael Barrymore. Stephen Fry was supposedly researching it for a revival of The Entertainer. Oozing charm from every pore, he oiled his way across the floor and begged the pleasure of watching Davro at work. Davro drew himself up to his full height, such as it was, and said suspiciously: "Obviously I've spend years perfecting my stuff. I don't want to see it turn up on anything." Fry raised horrified hands like a bishop caught watering the wine. I laughed a lot at that. You don't think Davro's becoming an icon, do you?

Judy Garland rang Tony Bennett: "I'm in the St Regis and I'm being beaten up right now." Tony told Frank Sinatra. Judy rang Tony: "I have 500 policemen outside my hotel and five Jewish lawyers in my suite. I asked for help but this is ridiculous." Frank rang Tony: "Is that all right, kid?" (Hollywood Greats BBC 1) Now, that's an icon.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Between Ourselves | Lost Orders? | Case Notes
fields.body:
If there is one thing worse for undercover investigators than fear of discovery, it is the struggle to retain their own personality. Talking to two of them in Between Ourselves (9.0am, Radio 4) Olivia O'Leary finds that both have had nervous breakdowns. Peter Blecksley spent 10 years infiltrating criminal gangs for Scotland Yard until he learned there was a contract out on his life. Jackie Davis was trained by the SAS and was so committed to her undercover persona that she did not even react to news of her own mother's death.

It's getting on for 200 years since Edmund Rice, a wealthy Irish merchant, established the first Christian Brothers' school in Waterford. As Peter Stanford notes in Lost Orders? (8.0pm, Radio 4), the movement spread across the world. While some of its alumni went on to run anything from the Irish government to the BBC, the Brothers also acquired a reputation for mercilessly beating knowledge into more recalcitrant pupils. Now sexual scandals involving the order have brought a dramatic retrenchment.

Dr Graham Easton attempts a brief role reversal in Case Notes (9.0pm, Radio 4), trying to see things from the patients' point of view. It's a feat that few general practitioners seem to manage. Not that Easton absolves patients preliminary responsibilities. If they want an accurate diagnosis he advises them to carry out their own research before going in for their 10 minutes with the GP.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Tom Jones | Cinema Paradiso | Weightlifting
fields.body:
Films

Tom Jones
(Tony Richardson, 1963)
3.20pm, The Studio

Henry Fielding's bawdy, big-hearted 18th-century novel enthusiastically recreated for the swinging 60s. A youthful Albert Finney is Tom, the foundling who undergoes a variety of picaresque and amorous adventures before finally wedding the squire's daughter Sophie (Susannah York). David Warner plays the sleazy troublemaker, Blifil. It won four Oscars, for best picture, best director, best music and for screenwriter John Osborne's masterly distillation of the massive book.

Cinema Paradiso
(Giuseppe Tornatore, 1988)
8pm, FilmFour

In a wartime Sicilian village, 10-year-old Salvatore (Salvatore Cascio), fascinated by the movies, wins the affection of Phillipe Noiret's grizzled old projectionist, Alfredo. The cinema is a hub of the small community, running into comic confrontation with the church when the priest bans kissing scenes; but the crowds keep coming and when Alfredo is blinded in a fire, the boy steps in. A moving, magnificent celebration of cinema.

The Godfather
(Francis Coppola, 1971)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Marlon Brando in magisterial form won an Oscar for his Don Vito Corleone in the first part of Coppola's classic mafia trilogy. It's a riveting tale of Family life, densely textured, with an almost operatic gravitas, and gorgeously shot - from sun-dazzled wedding to murder in a darkened bar. Al Pacino and James Caan are terrific as Vito's sons, Don-to-be Michael and Sonny; Robert Duvall is trusty adviser Hagen, and Diane Keaton emotes gamely amid the bloodletting.

Internal Affairs
(Mike Figgis, 1990)
11pm, 3am, Bravo

British director Figgis does a thorough American job in this powerful tale of police corruption. The self-regarding Richard Gere is unusually dark and dangerous as a cop with too much money, under investigation by LAPD's internal affairs section: basically a mano-a-mano contest with investigator Andy Garcia which opens raw wounds, physical and emotional, as Garcia's wife (Nancy Travis) is brought into the fray.

Best Laid Plans
(Mike Barker, 1999)
11.35pm, Sky MovieMax

Brit director Barker comes on like Mike Figgis with this enjoyable neo-noir tale about a young man (Alessandro Nivola, building on his impressive appearance as Nicolas Cage's brother in Face/Off) who owes big money to the nastiest man in Tropico, USA. Reese Witherspoon as his girlfriend and Josh Brolin as a pal leading him into a dodgy heist are canny performers in an uneven but at times ingenious little drama.

Sports

Weightlifting
12pm, British Eurosport

If you ever get bored of the staple British sporting diet, you can always trust Eurosport to keep you on your toes. Weightlifting is this week's big thing - the 80th European Weightlifting Championships at Trencin, Slovakia. It's the first big tournament since last year's Olympics, so everyone is excited. Today: the women's 48kg and men's 56kg class.

fields.headline: R Chetwynd-Hayes
fields.standfirst: Mixing ghost tales and monster yarns made him a master of the horror story
fields.trailText: Mixing ghost tales and monster yarns made him a master of the horror story.
fields.body:
Although he was by no means an innovator, the author R Chetwynd-Hayes, who has died aged 81, enjoyed steady popularity with his horror-story collections, which mixed traditional ghost tales with sometimes humorous monster yarns. They made him an award-winning horror writer, and one of Britain's consistently high earners of public lending rights.

Taking one of his books from the library shelves was a guarantee of humour, pathos and chilling situations, all of which Chetwynd-Hayes considered the ingredients of a good ghost story. Over the years, the formula was put to good use in more than 200 short stories and a dozen novels.

Chetwynd-Hayes was born in Isleworth, Middlesex, and educated locally at Hanworth school. His father, Henry, was a movie theatre manager, and Ronald became an enthusiastic film fan, appearing as an extra in several prewar films, including A Yank At Oxford (1938) and Goodbye, Mr Chips (1939).

With the outbreak of the second world war, he joined the Middlesex Regiment, and was evacuated from Dunkirk, later returning to France on D-Day in the Normandy landings. Demobbed in 1946, he became a salesman, firstly at Harrods, and then at the Army & Navy Stores and Bourne & Hollingsworth, before joining Peerless Build-In Furniture as a showroom and exhibition manager.

He spent his evenings writing, selling a story to the Lady magazine in 1953. His first novel, The Man From The Bomb (1959), was sold to John Spencer for £25, all rights. His next novel, The Dark Man (1964), was the first in a series about Clavering Grange, an ancient dwelling reputedly the most haunted house in England. Chetwynd-Hayes based protagonist Anthony Wentworth, a bachelor showroom manager living in a bedsit in Middlesex, on himself.

The saga of the house down the ages eventually became the focus of three collections, Tales Of Darkness (1981), Tales From The Other Side (1983) and Tales From The Hidden World (1988), as well as two novels, The King's Ghost (1985) and The Haunted Grange (1988), and various other stories in other collections.

In the late 1960s, Chetwynd- Hayes began regularly selling collections of stories, some of which have become classics. Looking For Something To Suck (1969), about an elemental force that feeds off human life energy, and The Gatecrasher (from his fine collection, The Unbidden, 1971), in which Jack the Ripper is summoned by a group performing a séance, show their author at his best. The latter bought him to the attention of Kevin Connor, who directed four of the best for the anthology horror movie From Beyond the Grave (1974).

In 1973, a takeover at Peerless Furniture led Chetwynd-Hayes to turn freelance, and a move to Fontana as his publishers led to even greater prolificacy. He introduced the psychic detective Francis St Clare and his assistant Frederica Masters in the collection The Elemental (1974), and the characters reappeared a number of times, notably in the novel The Psychic Detective (1993), which is under option by Hammer Films. His best-known work is the collection of linked stories set in The Monster Club (1976), which was the basis for the 1980 film starring Vincent Price, John Carradine (as Chetwynd-Hayes), Anthony Steel and others.

Chetwynd-Hayes was also a notable anthologist, producing 12 volumes of The Fontana Book Of Great Ghost Stories (1973-84) and six of The Armada Monster Book (1975-81) for children, as well as stand-alone volumes such as Cornish Tales Of Terror (1971), Scottish Tales Of Terror (as Angus Campbell; 1972) and Welsh Tales Of Terror (1973).

His work continued to appear throughout the 1980s and 1990s, especially in the year's best horror anthologies, edited by Karl Edward Wagner, and has recently been championed by Stephen Jones, who edited The Vampire Stories of R Chetwynd-Hayes (1997) and Phantoms And Fiends (2000). In 1989, he was given a life achievement award by the Horror Writers of America, and won the British Fantasy Society's special award for his con- tributions to the genre.

Towards the end of his life, Chetwynd-Hayes moved into a care home in Teddington, Middlesex, where he died of bronchial pneumonia.

 Ronald Henry Glynn Chetwynd-Hayes, author and anthologist, born May 30 1919; died March 20 2001
