He introduced the psychic detective Francis St Clare and his assistant Frederica Masters in the collection The Elemental (1974), and the characters reappeared a number of times, notably in the novel The Psychic Detective (1993), which is under option by Hammer Films. His best-known work is the collection of linked stories set in The Monster Club (1976), which was the basis for the 1980 film starring Vincent Price, John Carradine (as Chetwynd-Hayes), Anthony Steel and others. Chetwynd-Hayes was also a notable anthologist, producing 12 volumes of The Fontana Book Of Great Ghost Stories (1973-84) and six of The Armada Monster Book (1975-81) for children, as well as stand-alone volumes such as Cornish Tales Of Terror (1971), Scottish Tales Of Terror (as Angus Campbell; 1972) and Welsh Tales Of Terror (1973). His work continued to appear throughout the 1980s and 1990s, especially in the year's best horror anthologies, edited by Karl Edward Wagner, and has recently been championed by Stephen Jones, who edited The Vampire Stories of R Chetwynd-Hayes (1997) and Phantoms And Fiends (2000). In 1989, he was given a life achievement award by the Horror Writers of America, and won the British Fantasy Society's special award for his con- tributions to the genre. Towards the end of his life, Chetwynd-Hayes moved into a care home in Teddington, Middlesex, where he died of bronchial pneumonia.  Ronald Henry Glynn Chetwynd-Hayes, author and anthologist, born May 30 1919; died March 20 2001

fields.headline: Bert Sutcliffe
fields.standfirst: Inspiring figure in New Zealand's cricket revival
fields.trailText: Inspiring figure in New Zealand's cricket revival.
fields.body:
In New Zealand, few sportsmen have been mourned as will be Bert Sutcliffe, who has died of emphysema, aged 77. With his neat built and golden, wavy hair - and invariably capless - he was the embodiment of class, and, for a decade or more after the war, gave his country's cricket a star player, just when it was suffering a crisis of credibility.

The first name of Bert, chosen by parents who had emigrated from Lancashire, was a touch too artisan for his world-class talents. Like many left-handers, his strokes seemed to glitter, but he was also among the most reliable of opening batsmen, a virtue based not only on technique but also on a temperament often described as "sunny". There was great artistry, and an absence of artistic temperament. He was unaffected by success, good-humoured and reliable. His countrymen were enchanted.

Another formidable New Zealand left-hander, Martin Donnelly (Obituary, October 26 1999), once said: "If I had to pick a team from all the players I saw, my openers would be Hutton and Bert Sutcliffe. He was the one player we had who could truly be compared to Bradman."

In fact, it was the great English batsman Wally Hammond, who made 227 and 336 in just two Test innings in New Zealand in 1933, that kindled the ambition of the 10-year-old Sutcliffe. Fourteen years later, a 1946 Test at Christchurch marked the last Test for one, and the first for the other. Hammond made 79, Sutcliffe 58 - the debutant contributing to a 133-run opening stand that ensured a more than honorable draw.

That was a relief for New Zealanders, following a thrashing the year before, when Australia dismissed them for 42 and 54. Thus, Sutcliffe became a central figure in his country's rehabilitation. When New Zealand toured England in 1949, the visitors contributed strongly to a batsmen-dominant series, Sutcliffe finishing with a remarkable tour tally of 2,627 and an average of nigh-on 60.

A PE instructor by profession, he was blessed with a fitness that seems to have come easily to those who played their cricket in another age. Perhaps it came from a more balanced life. That was demonstrated in his biggest innings, in 1952. Not out 215 on the Saturday, he enjoyed - as always - an evening at the piano, leading the singing. On the Sunday, a rest day, he played two and half rounds of golf - 45 holes. Back to cricket on Monday, he went on to reach 380. Even now, it is the 10th biggest score ever made.

Sutcliffe scored 44 centuries in all, averaging 47 in first-class cricket and 40 in Test matches. More memorable still was his central role in one of Test cricket's most dramatic episodes. On Boxing Day 1953, at Johannesburg's Ellis Park, hostile bowling on a grassy wicket caused all of New Zealand's batsmen to be hit - none more badly than Sutcliffe, who, yet to score, ducked into a bouncer. He collapsed on the pitch, and again after reaching hospital.

Against all expectation, he returned, with the score at 81 for six. Head swathed in bandages, his face described as being "like parchment", he immediately went on the attack, and rapidly scored 80 (out of 112), including seven sixes and four fours. Drama was piled on drama when the last man, the fast bowler Bob Blair, made an unexpected appearance; overnight, his fiancée had died in New Zealand's biggest rail disaster.

He too hit a six, adding to three from Sutcliffe in a single over from Hugh Tayfield which cost 25. The crowd was in joyful turmoil until Blair fell, stumped, and the two departed the field arm-in-arm.

It was said that Sutcliffe never again played fast bowling with quite the same confidence. But there was no diminution of his authority against spin. In India in 1955-56, he made an undefeated 230 - his highest Test score - and, in that series, he scored 611 runs at an average of 87.

Ten years later, he was picked for another tour to India; his experience, it was felt, was needed in a young and inexperienced party. He had not played Test cricket for six years, but, at Calcutta, he batted for a day and a half to make 151. To younger players, the conditions were decidedly foreign, with temperatures around 100 degrees - and a very noisy crowd. But Bert was imperturbable, at 41. And affable. But for that, his young teammates would have held him in even greater awe.

He leaves his wife Norma, a son and two daughters.

 Bert Sutcliffe, cricketer, born November 17 1923; died April 20 2001

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: It is a truth universally acknowledged that one of the marvellous things about a long-term relationship is the mutual history a couple constructs, those cherished intimacies that can never be erased.
fields.body:
It is a truth universally acknowledged that one of the marvellous things about a long-term relationship is the mutual history a couple constructs, those cherished intimacies that can never be erased. But it must be with a degree of equivocation that Robin Cook recalls his shared culinary excursions with first wife Margaret, last weekend offering the Mail on Sunday a savoury take on the foreign secretary's recent pronouncements on the British identity.

"Robin's international credentials have certainly been hard-won," she mused. "When I knew him as a student, his idea of a gastronomic treat was a trip to Willie's Cafe in Edinburgh. I worked hard to introduce him even to a corn cob." She goes on to detail his love affair with French cooking: "Eventually he became so confident that he selected from a menu without bothering to translate ... until he discovered he'd swallowed a dish of toad." Poor Robin. It's the spousal equivalent of a mother with a photo album stuffed with naked-toddler-in-the-bath shots.

At least the latter detail offers his ethical foreign policy a degree of verisimilitude, however. We all know he would never wittingly have eaten toad, knowing as he does that toads have been involved in terrorising East Timor with British-made planes, maintaining destructive sanctions on Iraq and allowing elderly dictators to slope off home. All qualities, the evidence suggests, that leave Cook more likely to shake a toad's hand than eat it.

As millions flock to see Bridget Jones's Diary, the debate rages as to which debate is the essence of the film. Is it Hugh Grant v Colin Firth? Is it big pants v thongs? Is it fat v thin? Guess again. The most pressing issue raised by the film - and ignored everywhere else - is taking it up the wrong 'un, which Bridget does cheerfully and which women generally hold firmer views on than the strength of their tummy control panels.

The silence that surrounds this scene (Bridget: "Do you realise what you just did to me is illegal in many countries?"; Daniel: "That's why I'm so glad to be living in Britain today. I don't understand why the prime minister doesn't mention it more often in his speeches") suggests that anal sex between consenting heterosexual adults remains the final taboo. (Unlike female masturbation, which was the final taboo last week.) So Sidelines will stop talking about it now, because she's shy.

webTitle: Philip Larkin's two unpublished naughty novellas

fields.headline: Larkin's lesbians
fields.standfirst: Rachel Cooke on what the poet's never-before-seen naughty novellas say about men's fantasies of gay women
fields.trailText: Rachel Cooke on what the poet's never-before-seen naughty novellas say about men's fantasies of gay women.
fields.body:
Philip Larkin has always had his fans but he has never, to my knowledge, been what one might call a bestselling author. Next spring, however, that is set to change when Faber publishes two naughty novellas written by the poet when he was an undergraduate at Oxford. The stories, Trouble at Willow Gables and Michaelmas Term at St Bride's, are written in the breathless style of Angela Brazil under the deliciously camp nom de plume Brunette Coleman (for some reason, this makes me think of the poor, plain, bespectacled poet sitting at his typewriter in a large bouffant wig).

They reveal that Larkin was rather keen on the lesbian activities of boarding school girls and that, after a hard day at the Bodleian library, he liked nothing better than to jot down a couple of scenes featuring frisky young ladies in hockey skirts and black stockings, hairbrushes in hand as they prowl their dorms.

Larkin's literary executors can insist till they are blue in the face that this juvenilia is worth publishing for literary reasons, but we all know why they are really doing it. These slim volumes will sell as fast as sweets in the Willow Gables school tuck shop. "Thwack!" goes the cane on Pam's pert little bottom. "Ker-ching!" goes the till at your local Waterstone's.

You see, there is money in hot girl-on-girl action, as anyone who has ever perused the pages of magazines such as Maxim and FHM will know. The current Versace campaign, shot by Steven Meisel, features an ad in which a couple of female models - and one male - are sprawled on a bed in various states of undress. These girls look turned on, but as much by one another as by the chichi suspender belts they are wearing - and I expect rather a lot of young men have been inspired to dash into Versace to buy a sexy little number for their girlfriend as a result.

Similarly, the latest woman to appear in an ad for Virgin Atlantic's Upper Class service is Anna Friel, an actress who - hold the front page - first made her name when she kissed another girl in the Channel 4 soap Brookside. As far as the airline's rich, male customers are concerned, this confusion no doubt adds an extra frisson of excitement to her whispered exhortation to "come to bed". Never before, I fear, can a mere reclining seat have seemed so extraordinarily exciting.

The sad truth is that for many men, the idea of watching two women engaged in sexual activity with one another is the ultimate fantasy. (When I told a male friend I was writing on this subject, his only response was to emit a long, wistful sigh.) It would, of course, be nice to be invited to join in - but, failing that, to watch is enough. When it comes to sex, men, or so the scientists tell us, respond to "visual stimuli".

A lesbian friend of mine says she has lost count of the number of times men have asked her to "perform" for them with her girlfriend; she has even been offered money to do so. It is, she says, a numbers thing. Men are an acquisitive bunch. Some like to line up their trendy trainers in rows; others like to fill the street with their Ferraris. And some like to count girls: one, two, three, the more the merrier.

As for when these girls get all hormonal and violent with one another, well, as Larkin's repressed manuscripts show, we are entering the (black leatherette) gates of fantasy heaven. For a start, this sort of scenario backs up what most men secretly believe: that, were they to leave women to their own devices, the result would be anarchy. Then there is the fact that you get two fantasies for the price of one: spanking and girls. Crikey.

In 1943, Larkin told his friend Kingsley Amis that he had finished Trouble at Willow Gables, but that he was unable to send it to him. "I cannot let it out of my sight as it's too incriminating," he wrote. Poor Philip. He must be blushing crimson in his grave. Still, as he peers down at us from his bunk bed in the great dorm in the sky, he should comfort himself with the knowledge that his youthful scribblings will no doubt bring a lot of happiness to many thousands of male readers. The rest of us, meanwhile, had better start hiding our hairbrushes.

 Rachel Cooke is deputy editor of Nova magazine.

fields.headline: Price war offers cheer as the champagne bubble bursts
fields.trailText: An Easter price war has brought the cost of a bottle of champagne tumbling.
fields.body:
It used to be the drink of the rich and famous. Dom Perignon, the monk who invented it in 1688, tried to get the bubbles out and failed. Winston Churchill famously said in 1918: "Remember, gentlemen, it's not just France we are fighting for, it's champagne."

Now we can all celebrate because an Easter price war has brought the cost of a bottle of champagne tumbling.

Sainsbury's was selling a bottle of Duval-Leroy at £6.99 last weekend, half its usual price, and Tesco responded by slashing its vintage Heidsieck from £16.49 to £6.49 for the holiday.

These stocks are now sold out. But champagne prices remain the cheapest for seven or eight years, according to Majestic Wine's buyer Justin Apthorp.

"The growers have been upping production over the last couple of years and they need to sell off stock," he said. "People were wildly optimistic about how much they could sell for the millennium."

French producers are offering big retailers the best prices for years and supermarkets have begun selling champagne as a loss leader.

Tesco's cheapest champagne this week is Pol Aimé at £10.96. From May 9 all its French wines will be heavily discounted, probably by about 20%, for two weeks. Sainsbury's, which ordered much more than it sold for the millennium, has been offering discounts and special offers since last year.

Safeway's Mumm Cordon Rouge is down from £19.99 to £14.99 until April 28. Asda has a series of special offers planned, with Mumm Cordon Rouge now down to £12.49 until June 24 and its own brand champagne will be cut to £20 for two bottles from June 18 to July 15.

Champagne is cheaper than ever at the independent retailers, too. Offers on single purchases are not so spectacular but many shops are offering discounts when more than one bottle is bought. Majestic Wine's Brossault is £12.49 but only £9.99 if you buy six bottles, and from May 8 the cheaper price will apply when you buy two bottles.

The advice is, celebrate the cuts while you can. "If I had a September wedding planned, I'd buy now," Mr Apthorp said.

webTitle: Ex-aide to duchess 'stabbed lover to death'

fields.headline: Ex-aide to duchess 'stabbed lover to death'
fields.standfirst: Old Bailey told businessman victim meant everything to accused woman, who felt spurned
fields.trailText: A former aide to the Duchess of York murdered her boyfriend after he refused to marry her, a jury was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A former aide to the Duchess of York murdered her boyfriend after he refused to marry her, a jury was told yesterday.

Jane Andrews hit Thomas Cressman, a businessman, on the head with a cricket bat and stabbed him through the chest with a kitchen knife in the bedroom of their west London flat, the Old Bailey heard.

Andrews, 34, was alleged to be angry after discovering that Mr Cressman, 39, had been exchanging suggestive emails with a woman in Las Vegas. In one, Mr Cressman compared his girlfriend to a pair of comfortable slippers.

Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting, also told the jury that Andrews had been upset at losing her job with the Duchess in 1997. But at the time of the alleged attack she was depressed because she felt the relationship with Mr Cressman was ending.

Mr Houlder said: "She realised that their relationship was simply not going to last and her hopes of marriage to him were evaporating.

"As the hope went out of the relationship, so the anger and jealousy rose up in her and led her to take a terrible revenge on the man she loved.

"Here we have a normally friendly and decent woman who was so transformed and burnt up inside by her anger that she killed."

Mr Houlder said Mr Cressman probably died in the early hours of September 17. He was ready for bed when his girl friend hit him with the cricket bat, incapacitating him, and then stabbed him.

Although the prosecution did not suggest the murder was planned in advance, Mr Houlder said there was time while Andrews fetched the knife from downstairs for her to "put a brake on her emotions".

Mr Houlder said she spent some time washing blood from various items before fleeing. She was found by police four days later in a layby in the west country after Mr Cressman's body had been discovered by an employee.

She had taken a "large number" of painkillers and was rushed to hospital. When interviewed by police, Mr Houlder said, Andrews pretended she knew nothing about her boyfriend's death. Later she said she had acted in self-defence and when she left the house had no idea that he was badly hurt."

The court was told that the couple lived together at Mr Cressman's flat in Fulham for about 16 months. They were described as "intelligent young people with a go-ahead approach to life."

After leaving the Duchess' employment, Andrews, who had been married previously, worked for the society jeweller Theo Fennell. Mr Cressman ran several companies including one which sold covers for expensive cars. The court was told that he enjoyed being a single man. He loved cars and gadgets.

Andrews, the court was told, was possessive about Mr Cressman and insecure about their relationship. Counsel said Andrews had been abused as a child and was desperate for a long-term relationship.

One friend of the couple had described Mr Cressman as "Jane Andrews' life". Another said that she had threatened to kill herself because of the failing relationship. She claimed to another friend that Mr Cressman had had affairs.

While Mr Cressman was away on a stag weekend, the court was told, Andrews found an email of a "strongly sexual nature" which he had sent to a woman in Las Vegas. He had told her that his girlfriend was "like a pair of old slippers that he couldn't get rid of". On or around the day of the murder, she had sent copies of emails which Mr Cressman had exchanged with the woman to his parents.

The jury heard that shortly before the attack, they had been on holiday in the south of France where Mr Cressman's mother lives. They had visited a festival in Italy on Mr Cressman's boat but were clearly unhappy.

They were due to fly home from Nice airport. On the way there Andrews made a series of calls to friends telling them that the relationship was over even though Mr Cressman's mother and nephew were in the car. She told one that she had wasted two years of her life.

Back in London on the morning of Saturday September 16 Mr Cressman dialled 999 and told police that he needed the police to come and break up a fight between them. He told the police operator: "I would like somebody here to stop us hurting each other."

On the same day Andrews made appointments with two therapists to discuss the relationship.

Andrews pleads not guilty to murdering Mr Cressman between September 15 and September 19 last year.

The trial continues.
fields.bodyText: A former aide to the Duchess of York murdered her boyfriend after he refused to marry her, a jury was told yesterday. Jane Andrews hit Thomas Cressman, a businessman, on the head with a cricket bat and stabbed him through the chest with a kitchen knife in the bedroom of their west London flat, the Old Bailey heard. Andrews, 34, was alleged to be angry after discovering that Mr Cressman, 39, had been exchanging suggestive emails with a woman in Las Vegas. In one, Mr Cressman compared his girlfriend to a pair of comfortable slippers. Bruce Houlder QC, prosecuting, also told the jury that Andrews had been upset at losing her job with the Duchess in 1997. But at the time of the alleged attack she was depressed because she felt the relationship with Mr Cressman was ending. Mr Houlder said: "She realised that their relationship was simply not going to last and her hopes of marriage to him were evaporating. "As the hope went out of the relationship, so the anger and jealousy rose up in her and led her to take a terrible revenge on the man she loved. "Here we have a normally friendly and decent woman who was so transformed and burnt up inside by her anger that she killed." Mr Houlder said Mr Cressman probably died in the early hours of September 17. He was ready for bed when his girl friend hit him with the cricket bat, incapacitating him, and then stabbed him. Although the prosecution did not suggest the murder was planned in advance, Mr Houlder said there was time while Andrews fetched the knife from downstairs for her to "put a brake on her emotions". Mr Houlder said she spent some time washing blood from various items before fleeing. She was found by police four days later in a layby in the west country after Mr Cressman's body had been discovered by an employee. She had taken a "large number" of painkillers and was rushed to hospital. When interviewed by police, Mr Houlder said, Andrews pretended she knew nothing about her boyfriend's death. Later she said she had acted in self-defence and when she left the house had no idea that he was badly hurt." The court was told that the couple lived together at Mr Cressman's flat in Fulham for about 16 months. They were described as "intelligent young people with a go-ahead approach to life." After leaving the Duchess' employment, Andrews, who had been married previously, worked for the society jeweller Theo Fennell. Mr Cressman ran several companies including one which sold covers for expensive cars. The court was told that he enjoyed being a single man. He loved cars and gadgets. Andrews, the court was told, was possessive about Mr Cressman and insecure about their relationship. Counsel said Andrews had been abused as a child and was desperate for a long-term relationship. One friend of the couple had described Mr Cressman as "Jane Andrews' life". Another said that she had threatened to kill herself because of the failing relationship. She claimed to another friend that Mr Cressman had had affairs. While Mr Cressman was away on a stag weekend, the court was told, Andrews found an email of a "strongly sexual nature" which he had sent to a woman in Las Vegas. He had told her that his girlfriend was "like a pair of old slippers that he couldn't get rid of". On or around the day of the murder, she had sent copies of emails which Mr Cressman had exchanged with the woman to his parents. The jury heard that shortly before the attack, they had been on holiday in the south of France where Mr Cressman's mother lives. They had visited a festival in Italy on Mr Cressman's boat but were clearly unhappy. They were due to fly home from Nice airport. On the way there Andrews made a series of calls to friends telling them that the relationship was over even though Mr Cressman's mother and nephew were in the car. She told one that she had wasted two years of her life. Back in London on the morning of Saturday September 16 Mr Cressman dialled 999 and told police that he needed the police to come and break up a fight between them. He told the police operator: "I would like somebody here to stop us hurting each other." On the same day Andrews made appointments with two therapists to discuss the relationship. Andrews pleads not guilty to murdering Mr Cressman between September 15 and September 19 last year. The trial continues.

webTitle: Brigadier's widow calls for terror gang to face justice

fields.headline: Brigadier's widow calls for terror gang to face justice
fields.trailText: The widow of a British military attache vowed yesterday not to give up hope of seeing his terrorist killers brought to justice, nearly a year after his "cold-blooded" murder.
fields.body:
The widow of a British military attache vowed yesterday not to give up hope of seeing his terrorist killers brought to justice, nearly a year after his "cold-blooded" murder.

Stephen Saunders was shot in an ambush as he drove to the British embassy in Athens, an inquest in Salisbury heard.

The 52-year-old brigadier was hit through the passenger window of his official white Rover 800 as he drove through the Greek capital on June 8 last year. Two men on a motorcycle from the terrorist group November 17 pulled up beside his car after it stopped in traffic. The pillion passenger fired a semi-automatic rifle, disguised by plastic covering, but it jammed after the first shot. The rider drew a .45 Colt pistol, and shot the decorated army officer four times.

Brig Saunders managed to get out of his car and "cried for help in English", but collapsed in the street, according to statements from Greek witnesses who gave evidence anonymously for fear of reprisals. He was taken to a Red Cross hospital with wounds to his stomach and chest, but surgeons could not save him.

His widow, Heather, 44, renewed her call for his killers to face justice after the Wiltshire coroner, David Masters, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing. She said: "I have to believe they will be brought to justice. I don't want this to happen again. My life has been completely ruined, my life has been blown from under me. And my children have been left without a father."

She called for a change in embassy procedure for dealing with relatives of victims of serious incidents, saying that the "world knew" 15 minutes before she did that her husband had died.

November 17, named after the date on which students in Greece rose in protest against their military government in 1973, is a renowned anti-western terror group. Opposed to Greece's membership of Nato and the EU, it has carried out 103 terrorist attacks, resulting in 23 deaths, often targeting European diplomats. But the Greek authorities have not caught anyone in connection with these crimes. The assistance of anti-terrorist squad officers from New Scotland Yard and a $2.5m (£1.7m) bounty for Brigadier Saunders' killers has not helped the Greek police bring the assassins to justice.

The inquest heard that forensic tests had shown that the pistol which killed the attache had been used in other terrorist shootings.

Mrs Saunders rubbished claims by November 17 that her husband was instrumental in the bombing campaign against Kosovo in 1999. Brigadier Saunders, who the group said was an air chief marshal when it claimed responsibility for the attack, was learning Greek in Bournemouth at the time of the campaign.

The coroner said his death was a "deliberate, cold-blooded and pre-planned murder" and the hunt for the killers was still going on.

Brig Saunders set off on the 10-mile journey at 7.40am every day in his Rover, which displayed number plates identifying it as an embassy vehicle.

Mrs Saunders realised something was wrong only when a friend called after seeing the news about an incident involving a white Rover. Mrs Saunders saw her husband in hospital at 10am where she thought he was being treated for his wounds. She was not told he had been certified dead at 8.45am.

Mrs Saunders, from Dorchester, said the couple had never had any fears for their safety in Athens. "This was his final posting before retirement and we thought it would be a nice safe posting to be in."

Her husband, from Dorset, had previously served in Australia, Iraq and Northern Ireland before being posted to Athens in May 1999.

Mrs Saunders said she still had faith in the Greek police and hoped that anti-terrorist legislation introduced after her husband's death would help.

She confirmed that embassy security had been tightened since her husband's murder.

She will return to Athens on June 8, the anniversary of his death, for a memorial service at the city's cathedral.

Press Association

webTitle: Youth barred for 10 years from ex-home town

fields.headline: Youth barred for 10 years from ex-home town
fields.trailText: A 15-year-old boy who threatened to terrorise a district of south Manchester has been barred from there for 10 years.
fields.body:
A 15-year-old boy who threatened to terrorise a district of south Manchester has been barred from there for 10 years. Billy Kelly is believed to be the subject of the longest anti-social behaviour order ever made.

He is not allowed back in Fallowfield until April 20 2011.

Manchester magistrates court imposed the 10-year order after hearing evidence that he threatened members of the city council's housing department when his family were evicted from their council home in Fallowfield in November last year. He told a police officer: "I'm going to come back and terrorise Fallowfield. You think you've won but I'm going to terrorise this place."

The court also heard that Kelly, who is 16 next month, had been given a six-month detention order for threatening to firebomb a witness the day after he was evicted from home. He is expected to be released from custody next month.

He was involved in incidents from October 1998 to December last year including shoplifting, threatening behaviour, stealing a charity box and making a death threat to a neighbour. He also took cars, one of which was involved in a police pursuit.

His application to enter the exclusion zone to visit his father was turned down by the court.

Kelly is an associate of Marvin and Michael Berkeley, who were the subjects of anti-social behaviour orders at Fallowfield.

The previous longest specific anti-social behaviour order was a five-year ban imposed on a 12-year-old boy from Smethwick in the West Midlands who had troubled an estate and pelted a vicar with stones. Magistrates in Manchester have also imposed an indefinite ban on a 12-year-old from the city.

Basil Curley, Manchester city council's executive member for housing, said: "This once again underlines our determination to crack down on people who terrorise their neighbours in this way. Billy Kelly was a menace to the neighbours and the court found his behaviour so serious that a long ban was the only answer.

"The trouble started three years ago and he has been misbehaving ever since. When he was evicted from his home on November 17 last year he threatened housing staff in the presence of the police force.

"We asked for a 10-year ban and we think it is fitting because there is no reason why this man should enter Fallowfield. It is also an indication to others who are contemplating creating havoc - please don't do it because the council will take action against bad behaviour."

He said there was no other way the situation could have been handled. There had already been feedback from residents indicating they were delighted that Kelly had been removed. "If people see him in the area he will be reported to the police and apprehended."

Anti-social behaviour orders were introduced in 1998 as part of the Crime and Disorder Act.

Kelly is also barred from a large part of Rusholme. He is not allowed to approach, threaten or communicate with witnesses or use abusive or intimidating language in public.

He will live in Sale when he is released from custody.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 12 years' jail for ex-policeman
fields.body:
12 years' jail for ex-policeman

Laurence Shaw, 49, a former officer with the West Midlands serious crime squad, was jailed for 12 years yesterday at Warwick crown court after he admitted two armed robberies on a post office in Solihull, West Midlands, in 1999 and last year.

Man dies after marathon

A man died after collapsing at the finishing line of the Flora London Marathon on Sunday, it emerged yesterday. The man, who has not been named, suffered a heart attack.

Jodie to leave hospital soon

The conjoined twin Jodie could be discharged within two weeks, said a spokeswoman at St Mary's hospital, Manchester, where she was born in August. Her life was saved in November by a 20-hour operation to separate her from her sister Mary, who died after the surgery.

Boat victims named

Two people who drowned after being swept overboard on the river Ouse at Offord Cluny, Cambridgeshire, were named yesterday as Eileen McKay, 20, of Glasgow, and Thomas Walker, 21, of Ramsey, Cambridgeshire. The accident happened on Sunday.

Bomb alerts hit rail services

Bomb alerts caused the closure of three train lines in Northern Ireland yesterday, including the main cross-border Belfast to Dublin service. Police blamed dissident republicans for the alerts.

Hello! I'm on the gnome!

Garden gnomes are to be given a makeover with their old-style fishing rods being ditched for mobile phones and laptop computers. Declining sales have prompted the supermarket giant Tesco to ask manufacturers to update the figures.

Two remanded in murder case

Mark Christopher Woolley, 35, of no fixed abode, and Jackie Moorhouse, 23, of north London, appeared at Highbury Corner magistrates court in north London yesterday charged with the murder of Liz Sherlock, 42, who died when she was run over outside Euston station last week. They were remanded in custody to appear at the Old Bailey next Monday.

Queen's oldest corgi dies

Kelpie, the Queen's oldest corgi and her companion for 17 years, has had to be put down at Windsor Castle, it emerged yesterday.

At £70,000, a Freudian snip

A Persian carpet which belonged to Sigmund Freud is expected to fetch up to £70,000 when it is auctioned at Christie's in London on May 3.

Stalling for time

A survey of office habits has shown that 49% of workers always use the same toilet cubicle, even if it means waiting for it to become vacant.

fields.headline: REM guitarist says sorry
fields.trailText: Peter Buck, lead guitarist with the rock group REM, yesterday apologised outside court after he was charged with a string of offences for an alleged air-rage incident.
fields.body:
Peter Buck, lead guitarist with the rock group REM, yesterday apologised outside court after he was charged with a string of offences for an alleged air-rage incident.

Buck, a 44-year-old father of two, was at Uxbridge magistrates court, west London, to face charges which included two counts of assault against British Airways crew members.

The alleged incident happened on Saturday during a flight from Seattle to London Heathrow.

The case was adjourned until June 18 and Buck was granted bail set at £30,000.

Outside court Bertis Downs, REM's lawyer, read out a statement written by Buck. It said: "I am grateful for the court allowing me to undertake our promotional tour."

The band are due to play the South Africa Freedom Day concert in Trafalgar Square in London on Sunday, before departing on world tour to promote their new album, Reveal.

The statement added: "The matter will now be delayed until mid-June and of course I will be here.

"I am sorry for the incident and of course I am embarrassed about the whole thing. However, I have been advised not to talk about it further."

Buck was charged with disobeying the commander of the aircraft, being drunk on board, damaging crockery belonging to British Airways, and of using threatening behaviour.

He was also charged with assaulting crew members Mario Agius and Holly Ward.

REM's agent, Robert Gold, said: "Hopefully the concert next week will go ahead.

"Peter will be going back to the hotel now to speak to his family."

webTitle: Letters: Living in fear of the pyres

fields.headline: Living in fear of the pyres
fields.trailText: Have the government and the anti-vaccination farmers thought things through (Cancer fear from animal pyre chemicals, April 23)?
fields.body:
Have the government and the anti-vaccination farmers thought things through (Cancer fear from animal pyre chemicals, April 23)? Have they considered the hundreds of farmers, farmworkers and their families imprisoned on farms, unable to escape the carcinogenic fumes from burning carcasses on their land? Have they considered the consequences of even a minor flood on thousands of buried carcasses, and the inevitable leaching of putrid fluids into watercourses?

Long-term environmental damage and the cost to human life is apparently less important than a few unaffected animals gaining a clean export licence and their owners lining their pockets. Vaccination would have meant a couple of years' relative hardship and a few burials or burnings of infected animals only.
A Franklin-Ryan
Bexhill on Sea, East Sussex

It's not just dioxins that should be considered when Maff investigate the burning of infected carcasses, but also the possibility of spreading the virus. As a science teacher, I am sure the residual ash is quite sterile, but what about the convected gases and dust caught in the updraught? Is a temperature reached that will destroy the virus?

TV pictures of cattle being dumped on hot pyres show the corpses steaming immediately, at relatively low temperatures. Cattle, like us, steam at body temperature, after all, and the virus can be borne on the wind. In a warm updraught, might it not be carried still further?
Jim Wilson
Halifax mailto:jw@idsolutions.eu.com

It is alarming to learn that burning cattle pyres are emitting more carcinogenic dioxin than all the country's factories combined. In happier times, of course, the cattle would be consumed by meat-eaters, rather than by flames. Where does the dioxin go then?
James Tickell
London

From my home I can smell carcasses lying in fields. In Devon, more than 170,000 animals lie dead, waiting to be transported and buried. Over the last week smoke rising from pyres has plumed across the land. Evidence mounts of dangerous contamination resulting from pyres.

The magnitude of the crisis has escalated because of delay in getting to grips with the initial cases. The few incidents in European countries have been dealt with efficiently; why not here?
Dr Ann Allen
Alverdiscott, Devon

To reassure the public that the burning and burial of slaughtered animals is not harmful to humans, and show that politicians completely believe the advice of Maff "experts", Mr Blair and family should move to Chequers, where they would bury and burn large quantities of cattle and sheep carcasses before the assembled media.
Sara Davidson
John Ballyn
Didcot, Oxon

Who says that nothing good can come of the foot in mouth crisis (US tourists may not return for years, April 23). Sounds like good news to me.
Pete Reffell
Leeds

I believe there is a solution. The Queen must abdicate. The razzmatazz of a coronation (with perhaps a Charles-Camilla wedding the year after) should prove irresistible to Americans. This is a time for the Guardian's campaign to modernise the monarchy to go on the back burner (in the national interest, of course)
Jeremy MT Sutcliffe
Oldham, Lancs mailto:Jmtsutcliffe@aol.com

fields.headline: We need journalists
fields.trailText: I have a profound sympathy with the questions raised by BBC correspondent David Shukman (Does the media circus make disasters worse? April 23). However, on balance I believe he is incorrect.
fields.body:
I have a profound sympathy with the questions raised by BBC correspondent David Shukman (Does the media circus make disasters worse? April 23). However, on balance I believe he is incorrect.

As emergencies journalist at Christian Aid, I covered the floods in Mozambique as well as the recent Indian earthquake and several other natural disasters. It is my job to harness media attention to highlight the issues behind these so-called natural disasters in the developing world. Aid agencies and the people we struggle to help need the media. Without the public attention journalists bring, we are unable to raise money and our governments are able to turn their backs on the victims without being held to account.

I would say that the media are too keen on the one-hit wonder and that the circus leaves town too early. Coverage lacks context. We need to know how debt, climate change, unfair trade rules, Aids and poverty combine to make disasters more likely and how they exponentially exacerbate the consequences when they do strike.

If the media has a crisis of conscience and decides to hold back in future, we will have no chance of getting any of these essential issues aired.
Dominic Nutt
Christian Aid mailto:Domnutt@aol.com

It is my job to harness media attention to highlight the issues behind these so-called natural disasters in the developing world. Aid agencies and the people we struggle to help need the media. Without the public attention journalists bring, we are unable to raise money and our governments are able to turn their backs on the victims without being held to account. I would say that the media are too keen on the one-hit wonder and that the circus leaves town too early. Coverage lacks context. We need to know how debt, climate change, unfair trade rules, Aids and poverty combine to make disasters more likely and how they exponentially exacerbate the consequences when they do strike. If the media has a crisis of conscience and decides to hold back in future, we will have no chance of getting any of these essential issues aired. Dominic Nutt Christian Aid mailto:Domnutt@aol.com

fields.headline: My motives
fields.trailText: Muriel Gray claims (G2, April 19) that my attempts to help the Afghan refugees in Pakistan are motivated by a desire to help my husband achieve his ambition to "become the almighty leader of Pakistan".
fields.body:
Muriel Gray claims (G2, April 19) that my attempts to help the Afghan refugees in Pakistan are motivated by a desire to help my husband achieve his ambition to "become the almighty leader of Pakistan". For a start, it is Pakistani votes that my husband will be seeking at the next election, not Afghan votes and, as anyone who is aware of the political situation in Pakistan will testify, there is little sympathy for Afghan refugees and helping them is no vote winner.

She bizarrely claims that I am attempting to present the Taliban in a favourable light due to my "new heightened political awareness". In fact, I never mentioned the Taliban in my article, except to say that I had felt ashamed that, before witnessing the terrible conditions in the camp, I had been passionately decrying the senseless destruction of Afghanistan's historical statues yet had "given little thought to the same nation's forgotten refugees", most of whom, as ethnic minorities from northern Afghanistan, are as much under threat from the Taliban as the Buddhist statues.
Jemima Khan
Islamabad

fields.headline: Livingstone: you presumed
fields.trailText: Your leader (April 23) implies that I have not succeeded in communicating the issues of principle in the debate about the future of the tube to Londoners. I disagree.
fields.body:
Your leader (April 23) implies that I have not succeeded in communicating the issues of principle in the debate about the future of the tube to Londoners. I disagree. My polls indicate that these issues - that a fragmented system would be less safe, less efficient and more expensive - have been communicated successfully, with two out of three Londoners opposing the government's plan to break up the system. After Hatfield and other tragedies on the national railways, the public regards the differences between Bob Kiley and the government over unified management of the system as anything but "arcane".

Your claim that last year I "as good as condoned violence" on the May Day protests is also totally false. I spent the three weeks before May Day urging people not to go on the anarchist protests for the same reasons as I am urging people not to go this year. I am urging everyone who has the slightest sympathy with any of the stated objectives of the May Day Monopoly protesters not to attend the action on May 1.

You assume that I harbour ambitions for national office. Far from harbouring other ambitions, I am standing down from parliament at the election. I am more than happy occupying an office with the largest electorate in Europe, other than the presidents of France and Portugal!
Ken Livingstone
Mayor of London

webTitle: Letters: A marathon session on our new sport section

fields.headline: A marathon session on our new sport section
fields.trailText: Frank Keating may well have had his tongue near his cheek when mocking the London Marathon runners as "knobbly kneed obsessives [who] presume to be applauded for their self-absorption" (Guardian Sport, April 23).
fields.body:
Frank Keating may well have had his tongue near his cheek when mocking the London Marathon runners as "knobbly kneed obsessives [who] presume to be applauded for their self-absorption" (Guardian Sport, April 23), but his derision insults all those who raised money for good causes, overcame their own handicaps, or just made the effort to do something extra special. Yes they mainly looked daft and many looked about as athletic as Lennox Lewis midway through the fifth, but I think it is a real pleasure to watch a sporting event which is for the main part about giving not receiving and taking part, not winning.

Pages of your paper are devoted to sports which, as much as we love them, are governed by money, infighting and television rights so to criticise a once a year event of good-humour and charitable action, which most participants actually have to pay to enter, seems a little churlish. Also - why no specific letters page? And why is the web address on the front page only for football? Otherwise a great job.
Alan Bingle
London

I was delighted to see your bumper new sports tabloid as I was sure it would report Saturday's UK national youth final for sportshall athletics, in which my daughter participated. I was shocked to find not only no mention of it but only one image of a female sportsperson in the entire paper. And that was not Derartu Tulu (the article about her success was illustrated with a photograph of El Mouaziz) but Stephen Redgrave's wife. A single column on women's football and 10 lines on Julia Mann's badminton success were the only signs that women do sport. How am I supposed to motivate my 13-year-old daughter if there is so little recognition of sportswomen?
Catherine Hyde
Worcester

Racism in football has long been a problem, but your report on the Arsenal-Everton match last weekend did nothing to improve matters (Smith miffed as Nyarko retires hurt, April 23). Alex Nyarko was assaulted and his decision to leave the pitch gets my full support. It is indefensible to accuse him of being "shirty", of being "a player with such a suspect head and heart" and it is wholly inappropriate to link this event to Mr Nyarko's footballing talent.
Dr Jeffrey Forshaw
Manchester
mailto:Jeffrey.Forshaw@cern.ch

So Jim White (Teddy on the spot but Ruud on the verge, April 23) thinks that Manchester City's substitute Andrei Kanchelskis was "substituted no more than 20 minutes after himself coming on" in the Manchester derby on Saturday. For the record, Kanchelskis came on at half-time and was taken off in the 86th minute. Can I assume that Jim purchased his watch from the same jeweller who supplies United manager Sir Alex Ferguson with his time-keeping equipment?
Mike Barnett
Editor, Manchester City magazine

fields.trailText: I am pleased that the anonymous enumerator (Letters, April 23) is willing to provide help in completing census forms. In fact, enumerators are trained to provide help where it is requested. However, for obvious reasons, they are not encouraged to enter people's homes.
fields.body:
I am pleased that the anonymous enumerator (Letters, April 23) is willing to provide help in completing census forms. In fact, enumerators are trained to provide help where it is requested. However, for obvious reasons, they are not encouraged to enter people's homes.

Another letter that day claimed the census ignores voluntary work. That is not so. Question 12 seeks information on the level of voluntary help or support given to family members, friends, neighbours or others because of long-term physical or mental ill-health or disability, or problems related to old age.
Graham C Jones
Director Census Office for National Statistics

fields.headline: Marcel Berlins
fields.standfirst: It's a clever scheme to unclog our overloaded courts - so why is Widdecombe so critical?
fields.trailText: It's a clever scheme to unclog our overloaded courts - so why is Widdecombe so critical?
fields.body:
 I'm surprised at the vehemence of the opposition - by the likes of Ann Widdecombe as well as many lawyers - to what seems to be a perfectly sensible proposal: take very minor crimes out of the criminal justice system, thereby unclogging the courts, and let them be dealt with administratively by some sort of fines system. The director of public prosecutions is keen on the idea, and it's likely to be recommended by Lord Justice Auld's report on reforming criminal justice. Offences such as not having a car tax, MoT or TV licence would be included. The DPP even suggested that non-violent, unabusive drunks could be downgraded in this way.

So what's the objection to ridding the criminal justice system of these offences? The main one: if there's no possibility of prison as a last-resort punishment, why should offenders bother to pay the fines? Many transgressors only pay up, belatedly and reluctantly, because they know there is that final sanction. Without that ultimate threat, why bother? It's not an unworthy question, but one that can easily be answered by providing some non-custodial penalties for deliberate non-payment. Anyway, does it really matter that much if some people at the trivial end of the criminal hierarchy don't get their just deserts? Or are we for ever to remain slaves to our elaborate and expensive system of criminal justice just so we can put a few miserable recalcitrants in jail?

 Next Thursday, you may not know, is World Intellectual Property Day. It won't make much of a stir, but it deserves a mention because its cause is a good one. Intellectual property is the fruit of a person's talent, effort and originality. The laws of copyright, patents and trademarks are supposed to protect it, whether it's a book, a piece of music, a painting, the tick on Nike footwear, the word Coke, the format of Big Brother or computer software. Anything worth copying is worth protecting, the legal saying goes.

The problem is that the technology of copying, of faking, of - let's be blunt - stealing is outstripping the law's capacity to keep up. Music and video piracy has been with us for years, but is getting more difficult to contain, let alone control. Now the internet has opened up hitherto unimagined ways of stealing other people's ideas with impunity. The Geneva-based World Intellectual Property Organisation does its best, but it and individual countries have neither the resources nor, often, the legal frameworks to make real dents into illegality. On Thursday, I shall be pessimistic.

 Lawyers may earn fortunes, but they do not accumulate them. I suppose if you pocket half a million or a million a year, there's no great incentive to turn it into a stash of £50m. Those thoughts flitted around as I looked through the list of Britain's richest 1,000 people and failed to spot any lawyers, although perhaps some of those mentioned may have a law qualification buried in their past before they turned to making real money (the Bee Gees? The Queen?). There was one entrant whose wealth was the direct result of the law. At number 562 on the Sunday Times list is Patricia Kluge, made rich by a divorce settlement. It's a bit humiliating that the only way lawyers can get on a rich list - even unnamed and vicariously - is as a result of a broken marriage.

 This isn't hindsight; I wrote about it in this very column when the whole shabby nonsense started. Dressing-down Fridays for lawyers, I said, were doomed, because no client can possibly take seriously any advice given by a chap wearing chinos and a peach-coloured cashmere sweater. Nor was any lawyer thus attired capable of saying anything that made any legal sense, because his mind was so fully occupied with feeling embarrassed by his attire. I've seen photographs of dressed-down lawyers, and it is impossible to distinguish them from mugshots of newly arrested criminals - those staring eyes, that desperate "it ain't me" look.

Anyway, I've been proved right. A survey carried out by consultants Charles Fellowes showed that 85% of 400 midlands solicitors felt uncomfortable doing their work in casual gear. OK, it's not height-of-fashion London, and some City firms are still pathetically keeping up the pretence that "casual captures clients" but, it turns out, what they regard as radically dressing down is wearing dark blue. Sometimes it's the same suit as the Monday to Thursday job, but without a tie. I once met a casuals enthusiast who rather spoiled it by adding: "Of course, I wouldn't dream of seeing a client on a Friday."

webTitle: Clare Dyer on the Diane Blood case

fields.headline: 'How can you penalise my son for what I did?'
fields.standfirst: In 1997, Diane Blood finally won a two-year battle for the right to conceive a child with her dead husband's frozen sperm. Now she is fighting for her son's right to have his father's name on his birth certificate. Clare Dyer reports
fields.trailText: In 1997, Diane Blood finally won a two-year battle for the right to conceive a child with her dead husband's frozen sperm. Now she is fighting for her son's right to have his father's name on his birth certificate. Clare Dyer reports.
fields.body:
Two-year-old Liam Stephen Blood nestles into his mother's shoulder. "Sit on mummy's knee," he murmurs. It's tea time and he's tired out after an afternoon of serious play with his doting grandma. Liam loves to be read bedtime stories before he dozes off in his bright blue nursery. But he's still too young to be told the dramatic tale of his mother's extraordinary fight for the right to bear him and the obstacles she had to overcome to bring him into the world.

In February 1995, Diane Blood's husband, Stephen, contracted bacterial meningitis. He quickly fell into a coma and was put on a life support machine. The couple, who had been sweethearts since their teens and married for four years, had started trying for a baby and Diane thought - mistakenly, as it happened - that she might be pregnant already. But, taking no chances, she asked doctors if sperm could be taken from her 30-year-old husband before the life support machine was switched off, and they agreed. Just months before, she said, the couple had come across a magazine article about a widow impregnated with her dead husband's sperm, and he had told her that he wanted her to have his baby if she was ever in the same situation.

Four days after he was stricken with meningitis he was dead. But for his shocked and grieving young widow there was a new blow: the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), which regulates artificial insemination services in Britain, refused to allow her to try to conceive a child with Stephen's sperm. He hadn't given written consent and hadn't had the opportunity to be counselled, as required by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act.

In 1996, Diane remortgaged the modest, comfortable bungalow in Worksop that she had shared with Stephen to finance a high court battle against the HFEA. After the Guardian broke her story, opinion polls revealed that nine out of 10 people supported her case, and many sent cheques to her fighting fund. But the legal ground was uncharted and if she lost the bill would be huge. She was to spend the next two years on an emotional rollercoaster of successes and setbacks before finally winning through against daunting odds.

Naturally private and reticent, she found it hard to lay bare the intimate details of her relationship with Stephen, and gratefully stepped out of the limelight after the appeal court ruled that, under European law, she could take his sperm to Belgium for IVF treatment. For more than two years after her son's birth no journalist was allowed to cross her threshold. Only now, with a new crusade to fight, has she has moved reluctantly back into the public arena.

On Liam's birth certificate a line is drawn through the space for his father's name, as if his paternity was unknown. Because the toddler was conceived after his father's death, the law will not allow Stephen to be named on his birth certificate. Tomorrow a private member's bill to change the law will reach its committee stage in the Commons. It will still have to have to pass its third reading and report stages there and go through the Lords before parliament prorogues for the election. Diane has no reason to think that the bill, which has government support, will meet opposition, but she is anxious about the limited time remaining for it to reach the statute book.

Critics accused her of trying to re-create her dead husband, but Liam is himself and resembles neither parent. ("Except he's got Stephen's eyes, or at least his eyelashes," notes his mother. "Stephen had lovely, lovely long eyelashes.") Clearly a secure and confident child with both sets of grandparents actively involved in his life, he seems in little danger of the maternal suffocation that some predicted for him.

With plenty of family help, Diane carries on her small advertising and PR business, mainly working from home. At 34, she has not ruled out remarriage, but says she still "feels the warmth" of her relationship with Stephen. Enough sperm was taken to make it "medically possible" to give Liam a brother or sister. Will she have another go? "My thoughts on that, one way or the other, are private. But I'm not pregnant," she quickly adds.

The last time round, she was fighting implacable opposition from the HFEA. She initially lost her case in the high court, which ruled that she could not lawfully be inseminated in Britain. Her hopes were raised when the authority agreed to reconsider exercising its discretion to let her take the sperm to another country. But a letter from the British Medical Association's ethics committee chairman urged it to stand firm, and her hopes were dashed again.

She ultimately won in the court of appeal, though the ruling established that the storage of sperm taken without the man's written consent is illegal. Diane just squeezed through the door, but others are barred from the route she took.

"The one thing that's different this time is no one's opposing me," she says. "The opposition to this bill is apathy. That's why I'm speaking now - no other reason." The government accepted last year that the law should be changed to allow a father's name to appear on the birth certificate of a child conceived after his death. Tony Clarke, the Labour MP for Northampton South, was encouraged to take forward a private member's bill. Unusually for UK legislation, the change will be retrospective, benefiting around 30 children conceived in Britain after their fathers' deaths. The other fathers had agreed in writing that their sperm could be frozen for future use by their partners.

Diane and Liam, along with another mother and child, were at the Commons last month when the bill received its second reading with only six minutes to spare, and she knows the timetable is tight. "The government made us the promise that we would have the law this term. If for some reason it wasn't fulfilled I would be totally devastated, not least because of the emotional highs and lows I have gone through just to get this far. All of that would have been for nothing." Clarke gives the bill a 60% chance of getting through this time.

Diane's aim is to ensure that the law is passed before Liam is old enough to ask why his birth certificate shows his father as unknown. He points to photographs of Stephen and says, "That's Daddy," but at the moment he seems to have only a vague idea what a father is. "He knows what other people's daddies are. He has looked at our wedding album with most interest and he knows that's Mummy and Daddy. But who knows what's in the mind of a two-year-old?" says Diane.

"I applied for a passport for him and you had to fill in the father's details. Because you have to send it accompanied by the birth certificate, I had to put that his father was unknown, so I was asked to lie.

"I was told that at one school in Worksop the mothers were asked to bring the birth certificates to school on the first day because there have been problems when mothers have tried to put their children into school early. Imagine how I'd feel if I was told I had to send Liam on his first day of school with his birth certificate.

"This situation he's in is something I took on board before he was born, but he didn't. It's now why I feel it ought to be fought for, because it's for him and I realised it might be important for him. Is it the government putting some kind of rubber stamp on what I did? My answer to that is that it doesn't matter what you think of what I did. How can you penalise my son because you happen to think that what I did was wrong?"

When Stephen died, the chances that Diane would ever hold his son or daughter in her arms looked small, but luck and her own determination were on her side. "The odds were certainly very remote, particularly when you divided all the probabilities: were they going to be able to get the sperm successfully, would the sperm be OK, were we going to win the court case, and then was I going to be medically successful, because the chances were only 20%."

When Liam was born prematurely, there was more trauma to endure. He was unable to breathe on his own and had to go into intensive care. A few months later, Diane wrote: "I am painfully aware that few people can be as lucky as me to hold the title 'mother'."

What made her so determined? "I had to know that I'd done everything I possibly could. In what I took on there was no way I could lose, because even if I'd lost the legal case I'd have still done everything I could possibly do. To me the only way to lose is to give up. The alternative was going through the rest of my life thinking that if I'd gone this route or if I'd done that, would we have won?"

Just months before, she said, the couple had come across a magazine article about a widow impregnated with her dead husband's sperm, and he had told her that he wanted her to have his baby if she was ever in the same situation. Four days after he was stricken with meningitis he was dead. But for his shocked and grieving young widow there was a new blow: the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority (HFEA), which regulates artificial insemination services in Britain, refused to allow her to try to conceive a child with Stephen's sperm. He hadn't given written consent and hadn't had the opportunity to be counselled, as required by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act. In 1996, Diane remortgaged the modest, comfortable bungalow in Worksop that she had shared with Stephen to finance a high court battle against the HFEA. After the Guardian broke her story, opinion polls revealed that nine out of 10 people supported her case, and many sent cheques to her fighting fund. But the legal ground was uncharted and if she lost the bill would be huge. She was to spend the next two years on an emotional rollercoaster of successes and setbacks before finally winning through against daunting odds. Naturally private and reticent, she found it hard to lay bare the intimate details of her relationship with Stephen, and gratefully stepped out of the limelight after the appeal court ruled that, under European law, she could take his sperm to Belgium for IVF treatment. For more than two years after her son's birth no journalist was allowed to cross her threshold. Only now, with a new crusade to fight, has she has moved reluctantly back into the public arena. On Liam's birth certificate a line is drawn through the space for his father's name, as if his paternity was unknown. Because the toddler was conceived after his father's death, the law will not allow Stephen to be named on his birth certificate. Tomorrow a private member's bill to change the law will reach its committee stage in the Commons. It will still have to have to pass its third reading and report stages there and go through the Lords before parliament prorogues for the election. Diane has no reason to think that the bill, which has government support, will meet opposition, but she is anxious about the limited time remaining for it to reach the statute book. Critics accused her of trying to re-create her dead husband, but Liam is himself and resembles neither parent. ("Except he's got Stephen's eyes, or at least his eyelashes," notes his mother. "Stephen had lovely, lovely long eyelashes.") Clearly a secure and confident child with both sets of grandparents actively involved in his life, he seems in little danger of the maternal suffocation that some predicted for him. With plenty of family help, Diane carries on her small advertising and PR business, mainly working from home. At 34, she has not ruled out remarriage, but says she still "feels the warmth" of her relationship with Stephen. Enough sperm was taken to make it "medically possible" to give Liam a brother or sister. Will she have another go? "My thoughts on that, one way or the other, are private. But I'm not pregnant," she quickly adds. The last time round, she was fighting implacable opposition from the HFEA. She initially lost her case in the high court, which ruled that she could not lawfully be inseminated in Britain. Her hopes were raised when the authority agreed to reconsider exercising its discretion to let her take the sperm to another country. But a letter from the British Medical Association's ethics committee chairman urged it to stand firm, and her hopes were dashed again. She ultimately won in the court of appeal, though the ruling established that the storage of sperm taken without the man's written consent is illegal. Diane just squeezed through the door, but others are barred from the route she took. "The one thing that's different this time is no one's opposing me," she says. "The opposition to this bill is apathy. That's why I'm speaking now - no other reason." The government accepted last year that the law should be changed to allow a father's name to appear on the birth certificate of a child conceived after his death. Tony Clarke, the Labour MP for Northampton South, was encouraged to take forward a private member's bill. Unusually for UK legislation, the change will be retrospective, benefiting around 30 children conceived in Britain after their fathers' deaths. The other fathers had agreed in writing that their sperm could be frozen for future use by their partners. Diane and Liam, along with another mother and child, were at the Commons last month when the bill received its second reading with only six minutes to spare, and she knows the timetable is tight. "The government made us the promise that we would have the law this term. If for some reason it wasn't fulfilled I would be totally devastated, not least because of the emotional highs and lows I have gone through just to get this far. All of that would have been for nothing." Clarke gives the bill a 60% chance of getting through this time. Diane's aim is to ensure that the law is passed before Liam is old enough to ask why his birth certificate shows his father as unknown. He points to photographs of Stephen and says, "That's Daddy," but at the moment he seems to have only a vague idea what a father is. "He knows what other people's daddies are. He has looked at our wedding album with most interest and he knows that's Mummy and Daddy. But who knows what's in the mind of a two-year-old?" says Diane. "I applied for a passport for him and you had to fill in the father's details. Because you have to send it accompanied by the birth certificate, I had to put that his father was unknown, so I was asked to lie. "I was told that at one school in Worksop the mothers were asked to bring the birth certificates to school on the first day because there have been problems when mothers have tried to put their children into school early. Imagine how I'd feel if I was told I had to send Liam on his first day of school with his birth certificate. "This situation he's in is something I took on board before he was born, but he didn't. It's now why I feel it ought to be fought for, because it's for him and I realised it might be important for him. Is it the government putting some kind of rubber stamp on what I did? My answer to that is that it doesn't matter what you think of what I did. How can you penalise my son because you happen to think that what I did was wrong?" When Stephen died, the chances that Diane would ever hold his son or daughter in her arms looked small, but luck and her own determination were on her side. "The odds were certainly very remote, particularly when you divided all the probabilities: were they going to be able to get the sperm successfully, would the sperm be OK, were we going to win the court case, and then was I going to be medically successful, because the chances were only 20%." When Liam was born prematurely, there was more trauma to endure. He was unable to breathe on his own and had to go into intensive care. A few months later, Diane wrote: "I am painfully aware that few people can be as lucky as me to hold the title 'mother'." What made her so determined? "I had to know that I'd done everything I possibly could. In what I took on there was no way I could lose, because even if I'd lost the legal case I'd have still done everything I could possibly do. To me the only way to lose is to give up. The alternative was going through the rest of my life thinking that if I'd gone this route or if I'd done that, would we have won?"

webTitle: Technology sector hit by massive job losses

fields.headline: Technology sector hit by massive job losses
fields.standfirst:
The technology sector has been devastated by a wave of redundancies in recent months

Talk about it
fields.trailText:
3M

Last night US manufacturer 3M said 500 jobs would be cut in the UK over the next year as part of a global cutback.
fields.body:
3M

Last night US manufacturer 3M said 500 jobs would be cut in the UK over the next year as part of a global cutback.

Ericsson

Last week Ericsson, which has about 2,000 staff in the UK, announced plans to axe 12,000 jobs worldwide. The Swedish company blamed the job losses on a need to cut costs by £1.4 billion a year after being hit by the slowdown in the telecoms market. Ericsson is closing its plants at Carlton, Notts, and Scunthorpe.

The cuts were an attempt for better "economies of scale, higher capital efficiency and better volume flexibility," a company spokesman said.

Marconi

1,500 British jobs at telecoms group Marconi are to go in the next year as the company shakes up its global management and reorganises the business.

The job losses represent around 6% of Marconi's total workforce of 55,000 - around 20,000 of which are employed in the UK, where it has large sites in cities including Coventry and Liverpool.

Compaq

Computer giant Compaq, one of the main overseas companies operating in Scotland's Silicon Glen computer belt, said that 700 jobs were to go at its plant in Erskine, Renfrewshire.

The US-based company plans to outsource the manufacture of consumer and desktop personal computer products currently made at Erskine but will continue to manufacture made-to-order personal computers and servers there.

Other big losses

In an effort to head off a sharp shortfall in revenues in the hi-tech sector triggered by lower demand in the US, Asia and parts of Europe, three of the world's biggest companies also announced job cuts this month. The move by network equipment firm Cisco Systems, Dutch electronics group Philips and photography giant Eastman Kodak, has left thousands of British-based workers fearing they will lose their livelihoods.

Full details of job cuts have not been released but 8,500 jobs from Cisco Systems's 40,000-strong global staff base are to go. The group, which hopes to save £697 million a year through the cuts, employs about 2,000 people at Uxbridge, Manchester and Strathclyde.

Philips, which has a worldwide workforce of 200,000, said the 7,000 job cuts would be made over the next couple of months in its consumer electronics and component businesses.

It employs 6,300 people at manufacturing sites in Durham, Washington, Stockport, Blackburn, Burnley, Southport and at Hamilton in Scotland.

Eastman Kodak, hit by a sharp slowdown in film sales, is cutting 3,000 to 3,500 jobs to cut costs and improve the effectiveness of its operations.

fields.headline: Last orders on modernisation consultation
fields.standfirst: The government wants to modernise councils and the public must get involved. But how aware is the public on the changes and does it even care? Mori's Colin Wilby investigates.
fields.trailText: There are only a few weeks left for councils to complete one of the biggest public consultation exercises they have ever undertaken. One of the key planks of the government's modernisation plan for councils is to revolutionise how they are managed politically with new city mayors and Westminster-style cabinets.
fields.body:
There are only a few weeks left for councils to complete one of the biggest public consultation exercises they have ever undertaken. One of the key planks of the government's modernisation plan for councils is to revolutionise how they are managed politically with new city mayors and Westminster-style cabinets.

The government wants people to engage with their councils, to be involved, to care about them. So it has set all 386 councils in England the task of consulting on the first major changes in how they are managed for over a century. But how many people know about this, or care for that matter? Precious few, according to Mori's research.

The Local Government Act 2000 requires all councils to consult on new political structures by this June - not on whether to change how they are managed, but how to change. All except the smallest councils have been told to consult "inclusively" and objectively about which of three new management structures should replace the old committees.

These are: a powerful, directly elected mayor working with a small cabinet of councillors; a council leader working with a cabinet, or a mayor working not with councillors at all but with a full-time council manager.

The idea is that greater public consultation and participation in decision making will build councils that are inclusive and democratic. The end result should be that communities receive the leadership they want and need. The starting point for this participative style of local government is to involve local people in the decision about which of the new political structures to adopt.

Most councils have embraced the need to inform and consult widely on these changes. Up and down the country leaflets have been delivered, council newspapers have covered the story, posters have been put up and great efforts have been made to engage residents and stakeholders. Many have engaged researchers such as Mori to help meet the requirement to find out what ordinary people think. But with what success?

The challenge should not be underestimated. It's hard work changing perceptions that have evolved over decades. Mori has worked in around 50 councils on these changes and our research shows that typically only half of the population have even heard of the proposals for new political management, and a further third know nothing about them or not very much.

This lack of knowledge is not surprising. Residents are far more interested in council outputs in terms of services rather than internal structures or processes. They know little about how councils make decisions - typically, four in five claim to know nothing at all or not very much.

But it is clear this lack of understanding does have a significant impact on people's attitudes to the new models of political management.

Opinion is often fairly evenly divided between the three options. In one county council survey almost exactly a quarter of residents favoured each option and a further quarter had no preference.

But there is no uniform picture nationally. Mori has often found a relationship between how satisfied residents are with their council and their demand for change.

The less content they are with the way their area is governed, the more likely they will want a mayor to replace the old committees. Younger people are also more likely to prefer a mayor, as are those who are less engaged in the affairs of the council.

Mayors tend to be preferred in urban areas or those with a single urban focus. The signs are that we might see a call for mayors in the big cities. But there is generally much less enthusiasm in rural areas or where councils represent diffuse communities. Here, people's predominant sense of identity is with a more local area than is covered by the council. There is a long way to go before the government's aspiration of the community being genuinely engaged in the affairs of their councils is achieved. But the fact that this major consultation exercise has not, so far, engaged residents should not discourage councils.

Mori has consistently found that most people are quite content to let councils get on with their job provided they are told what they are doing. It is those who are dissatisfied with councils who want more of a voice.

The challenge for local government is to turn this around so it is not just the malcontents who want to get involved - particularly given the government's latest expectations that local authorities will have to consult on all their "key" decisions.

The way to achieve this is for councils to show people they are serious not just about listening to residents but in informing them - interestingly and imaginatively - on what they have done as a result.

 Colin Wilby is an associate director at Mori.
 The above pie chart is based on 429 respondents of a London borough, February 2001.
