fields.headline: Barcelona sack coach Ferrer
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe's Spanish round-up
fields.trailText: Barcelona, beaten in the Uefa Cup semi-final by Liverpool last week and struggling in the Spanish league, sacked their coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer last night after a reign of 11 months and one day.
fields.body:
Barcelona, beaten in the Uefa Cup semi-final by Liverpool last week and struggling in the Spanish league, sacked their coach Llorenc Serra Ferrer last night after a reign of 11 months and one day.

Following protracted discussions in the Nou Camp boardroom, the club announced that Serra Ferrer had been replaced by Carles 'Charly' Rexach, former assistant of Johan Cruyff and a member of the current Barca coaching staff. Rexach has been appointed coach in a caretaker role until the end of the season.

A club legend in his 12 years as a player at the Nou Camp, he retired in 1981 to take over the Barca youth team and had been in talks with the club president Joan Gaspart for much of the day. He has coached Yokohoma Flugels in the J-League and been part of the back-up team at Barca for Cruyff, Louis van Gaal and Serra Ferrer.

A millionaire internet tycoon yesterday denied reports that he was planning to take over Chelsea following speculation that the current chairman Ken Bates was about to lose control of the club.

Peter Harrison, a vice-president at Chelsea, reacted to press reports that he planned a hostile takeover by saying: "There is absolutely no truth in the speculation that I am about to launch a hostile bid for Chelsea Football Club. It's complete nonsense and I made this absolutely clear to the journalist before the story was published. I will continue to support Chelsea Football Club on the pitch and in my capacity as one of the club's vice-presidents."

Harrison, who is worth an estimated £270m, is the financial backer of Britain's bid for the America's Cup. It emerged yesterday that he had been asked to buy some shares in Chelsea Village, the holding company of the club, at the request of Bates.

Speculation over a takeover sent the share price of Chelsea Village soaring 23% to 45p per share, making the company worth £75m. Bates said: "I have seen the nonsense and I can tell you it has caused me some mild amusement. It's a load of rubbish."

The Lazio striker Marcelo Salas has written to Chelsea via his agent Gustavo Mascardi to say he is not interested in a move to the Premiership club. He said if he did decide to move, he would stay in Italy.

The France international midfielder Christian Karembeu looks set to leave Middlesbrough at the end of the season, even if they avoid relegation from the Premiership.

"I would find the prospect of signing for Paris St Germain at the end of the season very exciting," he said.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

Bates said: "I have seen the nonsense and I can tell you it has caused me some mild amusement. It's a load of rubbish." The Lazio striker Marcelo Salas has written to Chelsea via his agent Gustavo Mascardi to say he is not interested in a move to the Premiership club. He said if he did decide to move, he would stay in Italy. The France international midfielder Christian Karembeu looks set to leave Middlesbrough at the end of the season, even if they avoid relegation from the Premiership. fields.headline: Shirty Nyarko goes missing
fields.trailText: The Everton midfielder Alex Nyarko could face a fine and suspension without pay after he failed to turn up for training and disappeared.
fields.body:
The Everton midfielder Alex Nyarko, who chose the second half of Saturday's 4-1 defeat at Arsenal to retire from football, performed another disappearing act yesterday when he failed to turn up for training.

Despite his decision to quit the game, Nyarko still has four years to run on his contract and yesterday's absence was a breach of that contract. Everton failed in various attempts to make contact with the Ghanaian international, and if he has not been in touch by today he will face suspension without pay and a heavy fine.

The £4.5m summer signing demanded to be substituted during Saturday's defeat after a fan ran on the Highbury pitch and angrily questioned his commitment to the club.

Although the former Lens player travelled back to Liverpool with the team, he has not been seen since. It is believed he has left the country either to Switzerland, where he still has a home, or back to Ghana.

Nyarko's act of insubordination has left Everton in a tricky position. They do not want to get too heavy-handed with the player because, although they will never select him again, they need him to renounce his retirement so they can sell him at the end of the season and recoup some of their outlay.

"It has been decided to give him another 24 hours," said a club spokesman. "However, he is already in breach of contract for not attending training. He could face having his wages stopped and a club fine.

"We are currently trying to make contact with Alex to arrange a meeting with him. If this cannot be achieved the club would have to consider some form of disciplinary action."

The Everton manager Walter Smith added: "We have to wait for him to come back or have some contact with him before we can find out the road we will travel down."

As for the fan who came on the pitch to offer a shirt swap with Nyarko, the club will consider what action to take after he has been tried on a charge of entering the field of play.

"Whilst conceding that football is a game which will always inflame emotions and divide opinion, Everton will never tolerate the misbehaviour of any of its supporters," added the spokesman. "Because of the onset of legal proceedings involving one of our supporters in the aftermath of Saturday's game at Arsenal, we cannot comment further."

Meanwhile, with relegation still a possibility, Smith wants to concentrate the players' minds on their next game and forget about Nyarko. "It is a situation we don't need," he said. "I think for everyone at the club the focus has to be towards the Bradford game."
